fields.headline: Table dancing in practice
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Soho
Pleasance Cabaret Bar ***
fields.body:
Soho
Pleasance Cabaret Bar ***

"Imagine they are a birthday party and you are the cake," advises club manager Marco to new girl Veronica, who has just taken up a position as a table dancer in a Soho club. The next news is that there is no basic wage. "We found this system works better for you."

Rebecca Lenkiewicz hasn't so much written a play as come up with the treatment for an entire TV series. But if this is no great shakes as drama, it is still an enormously enjoyable 90 minutes that is enlivened by delicate characterisation, great one-liners and some exceptionally good performances.

Lenkiewicz packs too much incident and history - drug-taking, pregnancy, self-loathing and lesbianism - into a single month in the life of Club Venus, and it is hard to imagine how the impossibly naive Veronica ever found her way into Soho, let alone a table dancing club in the first place. Yet the great thing about the piece is that it never judges or preaches. It's a job, after all, and it pays better than waitressing.

The balance between sweet and sour is just right and if I didn't quite believe in the level of camaraderie between the girls, I would like to. The achievement is to have written a play that captures the seediness of the subject but isn't seedy itself.

Ends tonight. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

fields.headline: The deposed prime minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Lumumba
Filmhouse/Cameo 3 ****
fields.body:
Lumumba
Filmhouse/Cameo 3 ****

There is something of the Shakespearean epic about Lumumba, director Raoul Peck's second investigation of the deposed prime minister of the Congo. While 1991's much-feted Lumumba - Death of a Prophet was a straight-forward documentary, this account of the rise and fall of the Democratic Republic of Congo's enigmatic first prime minister takes the bare facts and weaves a mesmerising, grand, timeless drama.

Lumumba's story is told as the flashback of a man waiting for his execution, with interventions from an anniversary celebration of Congo's independence and his actual murder bookending the main narrative. From his days selling beer to the budding of his political career, a captivating central performance from Eriq Ebouaney makes Lumumba's story irresistible. Ebouaney inhabits this most compassionate and fierce of characters with pathos and passion.

As the land he fought to free slips beyond his control and the political machinations of post-colonial government start to churn against him, Peck's story of Lumumba's martyrdom never once stoops to sentimentality. With a dazzling array of stunning set pieces - the army raids on the marketplace, the burning of Lumumba's body and an exquisite moment on a deserted runway - this is a film which brands itself onto the conscience and leaves Lumumba's hopeful words about "the history of a new Africa" ringing in the ears.

At the Filmhouse tonight and Cameo 3 on Thursday. Box office: 0131-623 8030.

webTitle: In legal eyes, 3i and iii may be the same

fields.headline: In legal eyes, 3i and iii may be the same
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ever confused venture capital firm 3i with online personal finance company "iii" otherwise known as Interactive Investor International? 3i believes someone could.
fields.body:
Ever confused venture capital firm 3i with online personal finance company "iii" otherwise known as Interactive Investor International?

3i believes someone could. It considers the risk of mistaken identity is enough to warrant court action and is fighting a legal battle with iii for it to drop the use of its initials.

The venture capitalists - originally known as Investors In Industry - claim that the use of the iii logo has infringed on 3i's trademarks and consequently claims to have suffered "loss and damage".

There are some obvious similarities; 3i's listing code, for example, on the London stock exchange is III.

However, iii has dug its heels in and is confident it can prove that no such confusion exists among the public.

An iii spokesman yesterday said iii established and patented its trading identity five years ago. "This is an action which we will robustly defend," the spokesman said.

3i was not available for comment yesterday but the venture capital group is also understood to want iii to stop using the internet address www.iii.co.uk and has demanded a copy of the internet company's client list. Interactive Investor had more than 1m registered accounts at the end of June.

The ultimate arbiter of who owns the web address www.iii.co.uk is the World Intellectual Property Organisation in Switzerland. The battle between the two companies is expected to take place in the high court next year.

The action is unfortunate timing for iii, which confirmed last week that a drop in transaction-related revenues had curbed revenue growth in the third quarter.

The transaction revenues - which include fees from online share placings and the sale of Isas - fell 37% compared with the previous quarter.

Tomas Carruthers, chief executive of iii, blamed the decline on seasonal factors and the fall in investor activity after the internet investment hype in the first few months of the year.

However, overall revenues were flat at £1.8m with iii having benefited from solid growth in advertising turnover. Pre-tax losses for iii widened to £3.8m compared with £2m for the corresponding period last year.

The company listed in February and its shares peaked at 415p in the midst of the internet frenzy but were trading at 48.5p on Friday.

Internet stocks have lost their lustre since the beginning of the year as investors have focused more closely on revenue projections.

fields.headline: A scary portrait
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
The Second Amendment
C Underbelly ***
fields.body:
The Second Amendment
C Underbelly ***

Promising young Oxford writer Peter Morris had a hit a couple of years ago here with The Square Root of Minus One and confirms his talent with a scary portrait of a young American teenager about to go on a Colombine High School-style rampage. Admittedly, the piece goes exactly where you expect as Martin, alone in his bedroom, fantasises about the violent death of his hated stepmother and gradually reveals through his website a mind twisted by race hate and a festering rage at the world. But the writing and the psychology are spot-on.

The really scary thing is that you start to warm to Martin, see the brilliance of a mind crippled by emotional damage and laugh at his savage jokes. What you see in front of you, in both the restless teenage energy of the script and Ben Duhl's terrifying, compelling performance, is the slow disintegration of a personality, the tortured road to complete mental breakdown.

The horror is not at Martin's murderous impulses, but that nobody around him has noticed what is happening to him; that in the midst of such suburban affluence he should be so alone.

Till August 27. Box office: 0131-225 5105.

fields.headline: Punch drunk
fields.standfirst: Businessmen should stay of fight clubs, says Judi James. They are confused enough about the boundaries between real life and work
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Businessmen should stay of fight clubs, says Judi James. They are confused enough about the boundaries between real life and work
fields.body:
So are we turning into a nation of bruisers? I need to know, you see. It could be the only thing we excel at.

With boxer Lennox Lewis being the only British sportsman in living memory to have won anything comprehensively on the world stage, and Vinnie Jones cleaning up in Hollywood with his real-life hard man act, snarling and fisticuffs are now part of a growing trend amongst business communities, too.

Spurred on by the recent football hooliganism and films like The Fight Club and Gladiators, office workers actually glove up to give one another a pugilistic pasting in organised boxing bouts in the middle of the City of London.

Reassured by the fact that - like jargon and dress-downs - this is the latest US business trend to hit the UK the blokes in worsted were lining up to bash one another about.

So where's the problem? What if the pinstripe types like getting their rocks off in the ring? What's a bit of a bloody nose between friends?

Virtual punchbags

Well there are two problems here. First, it is further proof - as if we needed it - that City types are terminally confused about the boundaries between work and real life.

This is exactly why stress levels in business are so high. We think we are doing something important every day. We're not. There is very little about an office job that matters in the great scheme of life, the universe, etc. And yet those of diminishing brain cells consider themselves to be genuine battlers. The mind is already locked into combat, so why not get the body out there doing it as well? We forget that most of business is just a giant, contrived role-play, and they confuse virtual battles and brawls - like take-overs - for the real thing. Hence all that working out in the gym for no apparent reason. Girding your physical loins for nothing more strenuous than sprinting to catch a tube or weigh-lifting a laptop.

Repeat after me: Russell Crowe is an actor. And so is Brad Pitt. The adrenalin buzz you all claimed you got climbing into that ring the other day would have quickly turned into a bout of diarrhoea had you thought you were risking life and limb for real. Those of you who said you now knew how Lennox feels are patently stupid. He could get killed. Or at least an ear bitten off. You were just larking around.

Working women as warriors

Secondly, where do working women fit into this new cult of acted-out, new-age aggression? We are faced with three clear-cut options:


 Sit it out and wait for it to go away. And it will eventually. For one thing there is the cost of dental bridgework to consider.

 Join in. Tempting, I know. But only if we could field a team that could give the blokes a pasting. The point of the whole exercise at present is its butchness.

 Cheer on. Remember the woman's role at the real events? Clad in satin knicks, carrying a card with the next round number on it high above your head while the blokes all whistle? We need very badly not to go there, not even for an ironic lark.

Passive- aggressive

The biggest threat to the status quo is the left-over pent-up, pumped-up aggression that will surely come back into the workplace itself. We've learnt over the years to settle things in assertive style. Aggression was bad. We did the course.

Fight clones It's okay for the pair that have been getting it off their chests in the ring, but what about the audience? We've all seen what happens at real fights or football matches. The goons turn copy-cat and start laying into one another. With all that unchecked testosterone are we in for a return to old-style business behaviours of conflict and bullying?

Steps to achieve fight back


 Encourage the choreographed punch-ups. Only insist that they don't become a preserve of white-collar and management. Sponsor Barry, the big bloke from packing. That should soon shut the rest of them up.

 Learn the rules. Know more about the sport than the blokes do. That always puts them off.

 Ask bosses whether the company can be sued if one of their employees either damages or gets damaged by another during one of the bouts.

 Tell them you're arranging illegal bare-knuckle fights every Friday, for the real men to join in and prove themselves.

That should see an end to it for good.

fields.headline: Flea copulation
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Cardoso Flea Circus
Princes Street Gardens ***
fields.body:
Cardoso Flea Circus
Princes Street Gardens ***

Did you know that flea copulation is one of the wonders of the world? Or that it takes a male flea up to six hours to get an erection? Or even that once his two phalluses - there are compensations for such a short lifespan - are in working order it takes another eight hours to have sex? You've got to be patient if you're a female flea.

The study of fleas turns up many funny facts, which is a lucky thing for Colombian Professor Maria Fernanda Cordoso. She runs the last true flea circus on earth and she has reinvented it as a kitsch, clever 50s throwback. Unfortunately she takes the starring role as a kooky compere in a Day-Glo yellow house coat.

The fleas themselves - yes, they are real fleas - are fantastic, from the amazing escapologist Harry Fleadini ("one lucky member of the audience will take a flea home tonight") to the fearless Alfredo who is shot from a canon. Fleas, as anyone who has ever got them will tell you, are hardy little buggers. Which is where Cardoso's problem comes in. She's likeable enough but it's not hard to guess what a true performer - who could riff off the fleas' multifold mishaps - could do.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2151.

webTitle: Edinburgh:  Theatre:  Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind

fields.headline: An audience-interactive hour
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind
Bongo Club ***
fields.body:
Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind
Bongo Club ***

Chicago's Neo-Futurists have written over 3,600 plays; none lasts longer than two minutes. Performances take the form of a beat-the-clock, audience-interactive hour in which they attempt to perform 30 of them.

Can a play that lasts less time than it takes to brush your teeth have much impact? Of course, Samuel Beckett proved brief can be beautiful. But on the evidence of the first 30 plays, the Neo-Futurists seldom rise above the level of sketch.

It is good fun, but the tone is self-consciously jokey, and although the company specialises in writing on the hop, there is little that is topical or sharply observed. Whatever they may claim, the hour is as far removed from daily life as most other theatre in Edinburgh.

A selection of the published plays suggests that the company's material has more emotional depth than it appeared on the first night, and the idea is sufficiently intriguing to make a return visit - the plays are changed every day - seem like a good idea. But on the basis of what I saw, this is fun but not essential.

Till August 26. Box office: 0131-226 5204.

fields.headline: A middle-class ponce
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Chris Addison
Pleasance Upstairs ****
fields.body:
Chris Addison
Pleasance Upstairs ****

Chris Addison is a middle-class ponce. Not that he makes any apologies for this: "I went to a fee-paying school. You deal with it! I have." In fact, he makes it a selling point, and he's right. Addison has benefited from his education, and now he wants to make sure we do, with this hilarious debunking of the English class system.

Addison has so much natural charm he could probably win people over in places where eating with a spoon is considered posh. And he excels in comedic intelligence, as he methodically ridicules upmarket English society. Subjects covered at breakneck pace include athletic incompetence in public schools and why the Queen Mother never says anything (Queen: "Just grin and wave." Mum: "Hic. Sod off Liz, you're not too old to be spanked!"). It's sometimes difficult to keep up with jokes that start, "TherearenobailsoncricketpostsinEnglandunlessaforeignpersonisinfrontofthem", but at least the speed means three hours of comedy are packed into just one.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

fields.headline: Setting the screen test
fields.standfirst:
Recruitment agencies are introducing online applications, interviews and - no kidding - psychometric assessment. But, Ian Boughton asks, does it work?

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Recruitment agencies are introducing online applications, interviews and - no kidding - psychometric assessment. But, Ian Boughton asks, does it work?
fields.body:
Hell for the human resources department lies in the emailed CV - where applicants would once have crafted together a story to fit the vacancy, it's now too easy to send the epic electronic version everywhere with one click, accompanied by an attached note saying: "Hope you find something useful in here." A hundred of these, says one recruitment agency with a notable lack of sympathy, is a fine way to ruin any personnel manager's morning.

So how does the employer handle initial selection and avoid a mailbox full of indigestible and inappropriate personal data? Easy - let software weed out the likely candidates.

Recruiters disagree, however, about just how well that software can perform. Relying entirely on automated online assessment can be dangerous, says recruitment consultancy Robert Half International.

"Neither we nor our candidates are freaked out by technology," insists managing director Steve Carter. "But we know candidates are frustrated by spending hours filling in these online applications and getting nowhere, when they could ring us and get, in five minutes, a far better idea of their prospects for the job.

"There's no way an online system can give a cultural match between candidate and employer. Recruitment is 5% science, and 95% about getting on with each other - how can anyone possibly find out how people will work together by looking at data on a PC?"

By using psychometric testing, answers Psychometric Services Limited (PSL), whose new JobSift has just been taken on by the pan-European career portal StepStone. This online test claims to do more than simply assess competence - it will "define better than any traditional system how a candidate will fit the employer's culture and values".

The client helps to create a set of questions around the image of the candidate they are looking for, and advertisements for the vacancy direct applicants to a web page where they sit the test online. "Psychometric analysis measures personal attributes," explains PSL's managing director, Richard Alberg. "Any test of ability will confirm you can count, but it's our test of disposition which says you'll make a lousy accountant, because you get easily bored."

The advantage, according to PSL, is that any advertisement may produce hundreds of applicants, and the software will take equal interest in each of them without getting bored or tired. "For interviews, you might prepare one or two decent questions, but you will probably end up asking different things of each candidate," says Alberg. "You get a richer conversational experience, but no means of measuring or comparing. Psychometric tests can create patterns of answers which let us compare how different applicants will like a varied job, or get on with other people."

It's geared to spot time-wasters, too - well-judged "killer" questions early in the test will allow the system to identify and discard speculative applications from those candidates who apply for any vacancy, whether qualified for it or not.

But it remains a one-way street, say the critics - the applicant cannot fire questions back. "It's better," retorts Alberg. "In a tight market, an employer has to sell himself as much as the candidate, but no recruitment agency will actively 'sell' the client to each of a hundred applicants, so the application web page is the employer's best opportunity to create the right image of his company."

According to Tempz.com, the internet offers a different sort of recruitment opportunity. The online temping agency has logged 5,800 candidates and 200 employers in the past three months in London alone, prior to a national roll-out. Director Paul Barrett was amazed to discover that some banks book up to a thousand temps a day without knowing who might turn up, and maintains that the theory of the high street agency presenting a well-matched applicant to the client would be fine - if it really happened.

"Employers abdicate selection to the agency, and it doesn't work," says Barrett. "The reality of matching the two is: 'You want a temp, I've got one.' And the worst thing for the client is for a temp to arrive and be useless, because the agency sent the wrong person."

Instead, the Tempz.com system offers the employer three or four appropriate candidates for inspection through their website. "This is the sensible road, in which the employer gets a general idea of the candidate," Barrett explains. "If they want to ask questions or negotiate, they do it by secure email through our site - we don't give away the email address of the candidate."

But the technology itself doesn't create problems, says Steve Carter. It is the practical understanding that falls short. "Candidates are fine with online applications, but it's down to the agency, [which has an] understanding of an employer, to tell the candidate what a job is really like," he says. "I can't see, 'Can you put up with the bad language in this office?' or, 'can you take practical jokes?' cropping up in any psychometric tests."

A hundred of these, says one recruitment agency with a notable lack of sympathy, is a fine way to ruin any personnel manager's morning. So how does the employer handle initial selection and avoid a mailbox full of indigestible and inappropriate personal data? Easy - let software weed out the likely candidates. Recruiters disagree, however, about just how well that software can perform. Relying entirely on automated online assessment can be dangerous, says recruitment consultancy Robert Half International. "Neither we nor our candidates are freaked out by technology," insists managing director Steve Carter. "But we know candidates are frustrated by spending hours filling in these online applications and getting nowhere, when they could ring us and get, in five minutes, a far better idea of their prospects for the job. "There's no way an online system can give a cultural match between candidate and employer. Recruitment is 5% science, and 95% about getting on with each other - how can anyone possibly find out how people will work together by looking at data on a PC?" By using psychometric testing, answers Psychometric Services Limited (PSL), whose new JobSift has just been taken on by the pan-European career portal StepStone. This online test claims to do more than simply assess competence - it will "define better than any traditional system how a candidate will fit the employer's culture and values". The client helps to create a set of questions around the image of the candidate they are looking for, and advertisements for the vacancy direct applicants to a web page where they sit the test online. "Psychometric analysis measures personal attributes," explains PSL's managing director, Richard Alberg. "Any test of ability will confirm you can count, but it's our test of disposition which says you'll make a lousy accountant, because you get easily bored." The advantage, according to PSL, is that any advertisement may produce hundreds of applicants, and the software will take equal interest in each of them without getting bored or tired. "For interviews, you might prepare one or two decent questions, but you will probably end up asking different things of each candidate," says Alberg. fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: "It's not often that you get to work for a company right from the beginning," says 23 year old Sam How, "and that's one of the best aspects of working for a dot.com. I've been at As Seen on Screen since it started and it's really exciting to see a company grow and an idea take off."
fields.body:
"It's not often that you get to work for a company right from the beginning," says 23 year old Sam How, "and that's one of the best aspects of working for a dot.com. I've been at As Seen on Screen since it started and it's really exciting to see a company grow and an idea take off."

How's job is a combination of PA to the retail director, Lorri Penn, and general researcher for the site. "I think dot.coms tend to be fairly unconventional," she says. "Everybody tends to do their own correspondence and phone calls so there's a lot less hierarchy - and I work quite autonomously from Lorri."

One of the most time-consuming aspects of How's job is dealing with the flood of emails that come into the site each day. "As Seen on Screen is basically a shop - we sell products, clothes, jewellery that are seen in films, on TV, in pop videos - and we have an email address where people can request products they would like to buy. I'm responsible for queries about pop stars, pop videos and new film releases, so if someone writes in and says they would like to buy Craig David's hat, or Tom Cruise's sunglasses in MI-2, then I have to find out where we can get them from."

How is responsible for logging every email she deals with and her response. "We often get a lot of requests for the same thing, so it's essential to have information about what has been asked for and what response we sent out."

Even in a dot.com there is administration to be done, but How believes there is less than in a conventional business. "I do churn out quite a few standard letters - introductions to new companies, press packs and information - and I also have to write up reports when Lorri has had meetings with new clients," she says. "But it's only a small part of the job."

When it comes to research, How believes a good telephone manner is essential. "I tend to make the first contact with companies and then pass them over to Lorri," she says. "I find out who is the best person to contact and then call them, explain who we are and what we're looking for. I get the name and number and as many details as possible and then Lorri will set up a meeting with them to discuss supplying the product to us."

How also does a lot of independent research, looking through newspapers and magazines for news on upcoming films or videos, and trying to find products that people will want to buy. "It's great to feel that you have a voice, some creative input," she says. "I used to be an administrator for Marks & Spencer, but here I get to come up with ideas. We have a morning meeting each day to discuss what requests have come in and what new products are of interest, and everyone gets to have a say."

Working for a dot.com demands a flexible approach, she insists. "In a new company, things change and develop constantly and you have to keep up. There's none of the conventional boss-secretary relationship: everyone is young and we all pull together as a team. There can be quite a lot of pressure but somehow that makes it more exciting - after somewhere as traditional as Marks & Sparks, I feel like working for As Seen on Screen is really cutting edge."

fields.headline: Red, red and more red ...
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Ross Noble
Gilded Balloon Main Theatre *
fields.body:
Ross Noble
Gilded Balloon Main Theatre *

Red hair, red clothes - there's even a pair of red eyes in the stage set. This makes Ross Noble look like somebody from the Wonder Stuff but gives him at least another 10 minutes of jokes (for example, one about attempting to join the Red Devils). It also provides additional fuel for the hecklers.

Where would last year's Perrier nominee be without them? Hecklers trigger off at least a quarter of Noble's set. Tonight he's blessed with a cursing anaesthetist, a psychologist and someone who describes his occupation as "being from Texas" (Noble: "Good job!"). You can't help wondering what would happen if everybody shut up. Would Noble actually have any material?

His clowning cannot disguise the cavernous gaps in this show. The red menace stretches out a tenuous tale about a Japanese fighting monks film for almost 20 minutes; the rest of the time he's running on hot air.

Robbie Williams does juvenile one-liners in interviews and doesn't earn money from them. In fact, you could hear most of Noble's jokes in any Geordie pub on any night, you wouldn't have to pay and you could even get plastered in the process. By the end of Noble's execrable hour that feels like two days, I'm thinking I could even do this rubbish myself.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2151.

fields.headline: Trombone lyricism
fields.trailText:
BBC Symphony Orchestra/Saraste
Royal Albert Hall, London ****
fields.body:
BBC Symphony Orchestra/Saraste
Royal Albert Hall, London ****

Christian Lindberg's determination to establish the trombone as a credible solo instrument has already produced more than 70 specially commissioned concertos from different composers. On Friday he appeared with the BBC Symphony Orchestra at the Proms for the British premiere of a work written for him by Luciano Berio last year. SOLO - the capital letters seem de rigueur - was the central panel in a programme conducted by Jukka-Pekka Saraste that also included Sibelius's En Saga and Tchaikovsky's Pathétique Symphony.

An important part of Lindberg's mission is to bring gravitas to the image of his instrument. The common perception of the trombone has been that of a poor relation to its orchestral colleagues, getting comically out of its depth when asked to do anything lyrical or expressive. Berio made use of that tendency towards absurdity early in his career, in his solo-trombone Sequenza V; that 1965 work required the soloist to act as well as play and its bittersweet humour was conceived as a tribute to the Italian clown Grock.

But in SOLO there is no clowning around. The nearest this 20-minute movement comes to theatricality is at the climax of spectacular bravura passage for the soloist, which is saluted by a derisory cheer from the members of the orchestra. Otherwise, it's the ability of the trombone to sing that Berio concentrates upon. He relies on Lindberg's astonishing technique, and his ability to sustain huge arching phrases without ever seeming to take a breath, to project that line while the orchestra spins a web of glinting, intricate textures around it.

All the familiar fingerprints of Berio's concertante works are here. Kindred instruments in the orchestra - three trombones and a tuba - mediate between the soloist and the orchestra, while horns and trumpets reinforce the brassy brilliance of the scoring. Sometimes the solo trombone duets with the principal trombone behind him, elsewhere he is shadowed by a bass clarinet, or eclipsed by interjections from the rest of the woodwind. The strings are generally used to fill in the harmonic background.

This is not the conventional concerto confrontation between a soloist and the orchestra. Berio creates a much more symbiotic relationship between the two. Everything grows organically from the endlessly sustained note, a D, that begins the work and to which it returns at the end - pitches expand around it, chords are filled in and just occasionally references to past masterpieces flit past. The whole process has that effort less certainty and musicality that are Berio's very special gift. SOLO is not one of his greatest works, but still a fine example of his originality and craftsmanship.

It's also a superb demonstration of what Lindberg can do, and what he is achieving as the world's only full-time solo trombonist. His playing was astounding, not only in its sheer technical completeness but also in its musicality. The work is a celebration of lyricism, and he is a master of that, just as much as Berio.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: •IN TRAINING
fields.body:
IN TRAINING

Inside Job makes its debut on Channel 4 tonight at 7.50, the first of three mini-programmes being screened this week aimed at driving home some important points about training and development. This evening's edition will look at time management, and the subsequent programmes will cover presentation and negotiation skills. The idea was developed by Richard John, a top trainer and consultant, who felt there was a lack of television programmes dealing with the vital issue of workplace training.

ACCESS ALL AREAS

If you're involved in recruitment at your firm, you need to know about the impact the Disability Discrimination Act has on your legal duties. If you're not au fait, check out an excellent new book, Disability Discrimination - A Practical Guide to the New Law (Kogan Page, £19.95), which aims to demystify the requirements of the act for employers and gives clear advice on setting up workable policies. Order direct on 01903 828800 or try your local bookshop.

TALKING HEADS

No matter how much effort you put into preparing your CV, it is still only a piece of paper, and doesn't fully reflect the "real" you. A new online recruitment tool, Talking CV, gives potential employers the chance to see and hear you before you meet them. Candidates are filmed and recorded giving responses to tailored interview questions, and this is then loaded securely on to the internet alongside your conventional CV for employers to access. For a demonstration visit www.talkingcv.com

INSIDER DEALING

"Advertising internal job vacancies is just going through the motions, because managers already know who they want to appoint." According to a new report from the Institute for Employment Studies, this is a common gripe among staff when it comes to their firm's attempts to recruit internally. The suspicion that the outcome is already decided means many workers don't bother to apply for jobs advertised around the building.

PAPER VIEW

Afraid to let go of paper and suspicious of electronic systems, UK businesses are in a halfway house, unable to embrace all the advantages of the technological revolution. A study by Toplevel Computing found most firms are running paper and electronic administration systems side by side, and are unable to move forward. A staggering 70% of companies still work on entirely paper-based systems. The results amazed the researchers, as one-third of the 130 companies questioned for the report were in the IT arena.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine.

fields.headline: Letters to the Editor
fields.trailText: Should we be getting in a funk about jazz?
fields.body:
The big issue : Should we be getting in a funk about jazz?

While agreeing wholeheartedly with Cleo Laine's assertion that UK jazz is as good as any in the world (Review, last week) - one only has to hear Howard Riley, Mike and Kate Westbrook, or Andy Sheppard to be convinced of this - I feel she is wrong to lay some of the blame for its neglect at the feet of jazz journalists.

As someone who has worked for three national newspapers as a jazz writer, I can assure her that it is arts editors, to a man and woman, entirely uninterested in jazz, who prevent their writers covering UK players, on the grounds that jazz is 'self-evidently' a US art form, and that readers will not be interested in the home-grown article.

Incidentally, while working for the Daily Telegraph , I requested an interview with John Dankworth prior to a Generation Band Ronnie Scott's week, so that I could make many of the points Ms Laine makes. I was turned down, presumably because Mr Dankworth was too busy ensuring his band turned in a world-class performance.

Chris Parker
London N8

Cleo Laine hit the nail on the head. It is regrettable that, when the Arts Council of England ratified their Jazz Policy in 1996, they failed to allocate explicit resources. Although much good has been achieved, far more would have been, and can still be, made possible with an increased and 'earmarked' budget.

Despite the good intentions of the Jazz Policy, jazz - with the same size of audience as opera - received a subsidy of 0.15 pence per head in 1995/96 rising to 0.29 pence per head in 1996/97, falling to 0.25 pence per head in 1999/2000.

While not wanting to rob Pavarotti to pay Courtney Pine, this discrepancy, where a subsidy per attender of opera of £12.07 per head in 1995/96 is rising to £12.75 per head in 1999/2000, cannot be justified and still requires urgent adjustment. Despite this underfunding, jazz continues its success story in the United Kingdom. In 1997/98 research commissioned by the Arts Council showed that the percentage of adults in the UK who attended jazz concerts was 5.7 per cent. In 1999/2000 research shows this has risen to 6 per cent. It does not take much nous to work out what even a modest increase in funding for jazz could achieve.

Chris Hodgkins
Jazz Services
London WC2

Cleo Laine's lament for British jazz artists hits several false notes. Compared with, say, 40 years ago there are far more UK jazz festivals - Edinburgh, Coventry and Cleethorpes highlight 95 per cent home-grown talent. Several independent record companies (Linn is a good example) promote British jazz.

And this is not forgetting the array of venues, pubs and clubs (even the Wigmore Hall). Lack of TV coverage lets jazz down badly, but sporadic newspaper/magazine coverage? Well hardly!

N.R. Gansell
London N13

Our proud air safety record

Your claim that 'secrecy seems to be the watchword when it comes to discussing safety in the air' (Review, last week) could hardly be further from the truth. Airprox incidents, which reflect a loss of separation between aircraft, are announced by the Civil Aviation Authority, and after assessment by the independent UK Airprox Board the findings are published twice a year. We also have a successful system known as the Mandatory Occurrence Reporting Scheme, which requires pilots, air traffic controllers and engineers to report safety-related incidents.

It is inaccurate to say that British Airways pilots arrive at their aircraft only shortly before take-off, leaving no time to check equipment. Crews must undertake regular spot check inspections of UK airlines, and cabin safety is one of the main items assessed.

What you fail to mention is that UK civil aviation is regulated by a specialist, independent regulator not subject to outside influence - the Civil Aviation Authority. To us safety is paramount and we shall continue to ensure that UK civil aviation has one of the best safety records in the world.

Sir Malcolm Field
Civil Aviation Authority
London WC2

The NATS' key safety indicator (the number of airproxes) is at a record low of just five this year, two less than last year's record low of seven. Flight delays over Britain were down 23 per cent last year, despite increased traffic and in contrast to Europe as a whole where they rose 24 per cent.

NATS' satisfaction rating among airlines and pilots - who have a great interest in safety - improved for the fourth year running to another high of 90 per cent.

The airlines continue to vote NATS as best for safety, a reputation that has prompted 100 countries to use us to train their controllers and share the safety ethic that lies at the heart of everything NATS does.

William Semple
National Air Traffic Services
London WC2

Savage prejudice

I was shocked by the headline: 'Stone Age rebels risk wrath of Indonesia'. Are people whose nose rings are slightly larger than those I see on our streets Stone Age? Disgraceful. Shall this country never overcome its imperialist, social Darwinist, eugenicist past?

Marika Sherwood
Institute of Commonwealth Studies
London WC1

Hysteria that is a threat to children

The shriller the pitch of hysteria in the matter of sex offenders, the greater the danger to children; and not only because offenders will seek to make themselves invisible (News, last week).

Suppose you come across a child in distress; you offer a comforting word and a helping hand; a voice screams out: 'He's snatching my child!' Would the gathering mob believe your protestations? Even if they did, would you put yourself at risk a second time? When the mobs are looking for witches to burn, nobody's safe.

Tom Paterson
Whitley Bay
Tyne & Wear

Living to learn

Amelia Hill is right to point out the importance of school holidays (News, last week). Education is more than being taught the curriculum, it includes the human development we get through travel, work or leisure activities. As an admissions tutor for chemical engineering, which is not a school subject, in the next couple of weeks I shall be very interested in factors other than A-level grades for near-miss or clearing applicants. The ability to deal with the world outside school and generally live a life is really the start of higher education.

Martin Pitt
University of Sheffield

Choice is a right

Death is inevitable, and the only question is when. Once I am old and lonely, incapacitated and possibly in physical pain, tell me what is the point of carrying on? I am going to die anyway, so suicide is not necessarily an act of despair but a perfectly reasonable choice (News, last week). How dare another person take it upon themselves to make it more difficult to achieve.

David Buckingham
Exeter

Massow's folly

After reading Ivan Massow's article (News, last week) with its concerns for personal freedom, economic liberalism, et al, I was puzzled why he defected to a party with such centralising inclinations and containing the likes of Jack Straw, rather than following Emma Nicholson into the Liberal Democrats, which argued for gay rights and independence for the Bank of England long before Labour woke up to them.

Ken Milward
Weymouth
Dorset

Who Thatcher?

Mary Riddell penned an interesting column on the political consequences of marriage. But one concern: 'The chancellor now has the one thing that every potential PM must have - a wife.' You haven't really managed to forget Margaret Thatcher have you?

Sarah Beck
Birmingham

Ageist concern

As someone who has turned 65, has started a writing career after early retirement and has just had a first novel published, Nicholas Woolaston's excellent article on publisher's current obsession with youth (Review, last week) struck an immediate chord. Certainly no agents were interested in my book and around 40 publishers turned it down before I found one willing to take a chance.

Nick Blackstock
Bradford
W Yorks

Mountain facts

Robert MacFarlane's sour remarks (Books, last week) on our biography of George Mallory, The Wildest Dream , really need correcting. It is nonsense to say that we do not address why Mallory left his wife Ruth three times to attempt Everest. We in fact assert in our prologue that this is the key conundrum which our book seeks to resolve. Mr MacFarlane also chides us for not describing the 'deeper historical provenance' of Mallory's urge to climb Everest. In fact, Everest and the rest of the Himalayas had very little mountaineering provenance before Mallory and his pioneering colleagues arrived; in that sense Mallory and his colleagues are Everest's provenance, which has inspired mountaineers since.

Peter and Leni Gillman
London EC1
fields.bodyText: The big issue : Should we be getting in a funk about jazz? While agreeing wholeheartedly with Cleo Laine's assertion that UK jazz is as good as any in the world (Review, last week) - one only has to hear Howard Riley, Mike and Kate Westbrook, or Andy Sheppard to be convinced of this - I feel she is wrong to lay some of the blame for its neglect at the feet of jazz journalists. As someone who has worked for three national newspapers as a jazz writer, I can assure her that it is arts editors, to a man and woman, entirely uninterested in jazz, who prevent their writers covering UK players, on the grounds that jazz is 'self-evidently' a US art form, and that readers will not be interested in the home-grown article. Incidentally, while working for the Daily Telegraph , I requested an interview with John Dankworth prior to a Generation Band Ronnie Scott's week, so that I could make many of the points Ms Laine makes. I was turned down, presumably because Mr Dankworth was too busy ensuring his band turned in a world-class performance. Chris Parker London N8 Cleo Laine hit the nail on the head. It is regrettable that, when the Arts Council of England ratified their Jazz Policy in 1996, they failed to allocate explicit resources. Although much good has been achieved, far more would have been, and can still be, made possible with an increased and 'earmarked' budget. Despite the good intentions of the Jazz Policy, jazz - with the same size of audience as opera - received a subsidy of 0.15 pence per head in 1995/96 rising to 0.29 pence per head in 1996/97, falling to 0.25 pence per head in 1999/2000. While not wanting to rob Pavarotti to pay Courtney Pine, this discrepancy, where a subsidy per attender of opera of £12.07 per head in 1995/96 is rising to £12.75 per head in 1999/2000, cannot be justified and still requires urgent adjustment. Despite this underfunding, jazz continues its success story in the United Kingdom. In 1997/98 research commissioned by the Arts Council showed that the percentage of adults in the UK who attended jazz concerts was 5.7 per cent. In 1999/2000 research shows this has risen to 6 per cent. It does not take much nous to work out what even a modest increase in funding for jazz could achieve. Chris Hodgkins Jazz Services London WC2 Cleo Laine's lament for British jazz artists hits several false notes. Compared with, say, 40 years ago there are far more UK jazz festivals - Edinburgh, Coventry and Cleethorpes highlight 95 per cent home-grown talent. Several independent record companies (Linn is a good example) promote British jazz. And this is not forgetting the array of venues, pubs and clubs (even the Wigmore Hall). Lack of TV coverage lets jazz down badly, but sporadic newspaper/magazine coverage? Well hardly! N.R. Gansell London N13 Our proud air safety record Your claim that 'secrecy seems to be the watchword when it comes to discussing safety in the air' (Review, last week) could hardly be further from the truth. Airprox incidents, which reflect a loss of separation between aircraft, are announced by the Civil Aviation Authority, and after assessment by the independent UK Airprox Board the findings are published twice a year. We also have a successful system known as the Mandatory Occurrence Reporting Scheme, which requires pilots, air traffic controllers and engineers to report safety-related incidents. It is inaccurate to say that British Airways pilots arrive at their aircraft only shortly before take-off, leaving no time to check equipment. Crews must undertake regular spot check inspections of UK airlines, and cabin safety is one of the main items assessed. What you fail to mention is that UK civil aviation is regulated by a specialist, independent regulator not subject to outside influence - the Civil Aviation Authority. To us safety is paramount and we shall continue to ensure that UK civil aviation has one of the best safety records in the world. Sir Malcolm Field Civil Aviation Authority London WC2 The NATS' key safety indicator (the number of airproxes) is at a record low of just five this year, two less than last year's record low of seven. Flight delays over Britain were down 23 per cent last year, despite increased traffic and in contrast to Europe as a whole where they rose 24 per cent. NATS' satisfaction rating among airlines and pilots - who have a great interest in safety - improved for the fourth year running to another high of 90 per cent. The airlines continue to vote NATS as best for safety, a reputation that has prompted 100 countries to use us to train their controllers and share the safety ethic that lies at the heart of everything NATS does. Are people whose nose rings are slightly larger than those I see on our streets Stone Age? Disgraceful. Shall this country never overcome its imperialist, social Darwinist, eugenicist past? Suppose you come across a child in distress; you offer a comforting word and a helping hand; a voice screams out: 'He's snatching my child!' Would the gathering mob believe your protestations? Even if they did, would you put yourself at risk a second time? When the mobs are looking for witches to burn, nobody's safe. Education is more than being taught the curriculum, it includes the human development we get through travel, work or leisure activities. As an admissions tutor for chemical engineering, which is not a school subject, in the next couple of weeks I shall be very interested in factors other than A-level grades for near-miss or clearing applicants. The ability to deal with the world outside school and generally live a life is really the start of higher education. Once I am old and lonely, incapacitated and possibly in physical pain, tell me what is the point of carrying on? I am going to die anyway, so suicide is not necessarily an act of despair but a perfectly reasonable choice (News, last week). How dare another person take it upon themselves to make it more difficult to achieve. fields.headline: Scots lose Old Firm
fields.trailText: Celtic and Rangers are set to quit Scottish football and start competing in a new European league against teams from Holland, Portugal, Belgium and Scandinavia.
fields.body:
Celtic and Rangers are set to quit Scottish football and start competing in a new European league against teams from Holland, Portugal, Belgium and Scandinavia.

The Old Firm's long-predicted abandonment of the Scottish game could now happen as soon as 2003. That is the likely starting-date for the new league, which would see Glasgow's big two playing Ajax and Benfica rather than Motherwell and Dunfermline.

The so-called Atlantic League would involve 16 teams from seven countries - four each from Holland and Portugal, three from Scotland, two from Belgium and one each from Sweden, Denmark and Norway - playing each other on Saturdays. Scottish clubs' sole surviving connection with their home country may be competing in the Scottish Cup.

The Old Firm's departure drew closer yesterday when the Rangers chairman, David Murray, said the Ibrox club had agreed in principle to join the venture. Significantly, Murray - who until now has wanted Rangers to retain their domestic ties - now believes they must go if both they, and their would-be domestic rivals outside Glasgow, are to prosper.

Celtic have made no secret of their desire to broaden their horizons competitively - and simultaneously realise their full commercial potential.

'I'm changing my opinion. We are now hindering Scottish football,' Rangers' majority shareholder said. 'Perhaps it will be better for the other clubs not to strain themselves financially in trying to keep up with Rangers and Celtic.

'There is a merit in the idea of Rangers and Celtic joining a new league if it can be worked out with Uefa.' The Scottish Premier League, which has been drawing up detailed plans for a new league on behalf of the interested clubs across Europe, believes Uefa will sanction it.

If other leagues and Uefa sanction it, it would thus not be a 'breakaway' league as envisaged last year by European super clubs such as AC Milan and Barcelona. Rather, it would be self-governing, but under Uefa's jurisdiction. Without Uefa approval, clubs in the new league would not realise their ambition of also playing in the Champions League or Uefa Cup.

Various recent plans for a pan-European competition among the second-string nations of European football have differed on the number of teams involved, how many countries should provide members and whether member clubs should also maintain some sort of presence in their own domestic leagues. That last issue, at least, has now been settled.

Suggestions that the clubs behind the Atlantic League are merely trying to gain concessions from Uefa, such as the Uefa Cup switching to a league format, seem misplaced.

Graham Kelly, ex-chief executive of England's Football Association, predicted that the Atlantic League could prove popular with both fans and television companies.

fields.headline: Classicwatch: 13 Aug
fields.trailText: Published in 1925, the same year as Fitzgerald's Great Gatsby, Manhattan Transfer has suffered neglect at the hands of postwar readers.
fields.body:
Manhattan Transfer
John Dos Passos
(Penguin £8.99, pp360)
Buy it at BOL

Published in 1925, the same year as Fitzgerald's Great Gatsby, Manhattan Transfer has suffered neglect at the hands of postwar readers. Despite being received by some critics as a masterpiece, Dos Passos's debut is rarely mentioned in the same breath as the modernist classics by Joyce and Eliot that it deserves to stand alongside.

Dos Passos's novel is a sprawling, kaleidoscopic work that is concerned above all with the modern metropolis. The overarching idea behind Manhattan Transfer is that the inhabitants of New York are 'carried along' by the social and economic machinations of the city. There is no single narrative; rather, Dos Passos creates a collage in prose by wandering in and out of the lives of a number of New Yorkers. He captures something of the fractured, difficult nature of living in the city without ever being morose or unreadable. And, crucially, he is able to place his characters in the context of what he sees as irrepressible forces without damaging their essential humanity or dignity.

An insightful essay by New York writer Jay McInerney prefaces this edition of a great modernist meditation.

fields.headline: Paperbacks: 13 Aug
fields.standfirst: Grand Central Winter | The Blackwater Lightship | The Sword Cabinet | The Faithful Tribe | A Star Called Henry
fields.trailText: A collection of biographical pieces which trace the fall and rise of the author from graphic designer to New York hobo to editor, plus The Blackwater Lightship, The Sword Cabinet, The Faithful Tribe and A Star Called Henry
fields.body:
Grand Central Winter
Lee Stringer
Review £6.99, pp250
Buy it at BOL

Grand Central Winter is a collection of biographical pieces which trace the author's descent, as a result of crack addiction, from graphic designer to New York hobo, and his subsequent rehabilitation through the exhilaration of writing (he became an editor on New York's equivalent of the Big Issue).

The book is impelled by outrage at a society which regards its derelicts as invisible; Stringer writes with satiric wit on strategies for survival in the urban wilderness and the economy of homelessness, and with pathos on its solitude. The best pieces have the suggestiveness and compression of short stories, although the collection feels padded out with instances of his journalism. His prose is tough and spare to the point of being mannered at times, but is capable of great lucidity and precision - particularly when he describes crack highs.

The Blackwater Lightship
Colm Toíbín
Picador £5.99, pp273
Buy it at BOL

A serious and sombre study of relationships and social mores, Colm Toíbín's latest novel focuses on an estranged family in Ireland brought together by illness. The early chapters are seen from the viewpoint of Helen, a headmistress, as she joins her mother and grandmother to nurse her brother, who is dying of Aids. The hesitant and difficult reconciliation is matched by the novel's progressive expansion beyond the confines of Helen's consciousness. In restrained and subdued prose, Toíbín conveys the claustrophobia and oppression of life in a small, conservative community: the rancour of unresolved, unspoken conflicts and the way families act both to sustain and damage the individual. It is an intense work, yet uncomfortable to read, partly because of the unlikeability of the principal characters.

The Sword Cabinet
Robert Edric
Anchor £6.99, pp252
Buy it at BOL

The Sword Cabinet interweaves the tale of Mitchell - an illusionist and manager of a failed club in a seaside resort - with that of his father, an escapologist accused of murder in the 1950s: both are stories of deception and escape. We follow Mitchell's attempts to reconstruct the past, then cut to the police interrogation of his father.

We are left to assemble the story from a variety of partial sources; past events are filtered through hearsay and, further obscured by swaths of metaphor, remain mysterious. It is a study in seedy lives and disappointed hopes. Its distinctiveness lies in its evocation of the 'shabby-exotic' world of their ancestors: acrobats and magicians, fairground entertainers. The art of the illusionist is a recurring image and there is something of the magician's sleight of hand in the ostentatious skill with which Edric juggles the various strands.

The Faithful Tribe
Ruth Dudley Edwards
HarperCollins £7.99, pp602
Buy it at BOL

Ancient rancour also furnishes the theme of The Faithful Tribe. A desire to rehabilitate the reputation of the Orangemen is its unfashionable starting point. Dudley Edwards's contention is that they have been misrepresented as violent bigots by a media biased in favour of PR-conscious Republicans and that Orangemen are decent if dogged people whose gatherings serve mainly as an innocent form of male bonding.

She portrays Orangemen as beleaguered moderates - pious and obdurate upholders of civil liberties who are so convinced of the justice of their case that they don't feel the need to explain it. The book contains a history of the Orange Order (including details of rhubarb pies consumed in more convivial times) and explores the paradox of a loyalty that has at times expressed itself in defiance of the power to which the Order proclaims allegiance.

 Helen Hayward

A Star Called Henry
Roddy Doyle
Vintage £6.99, pp342
Buy it at BOL

Doyle has set himself a difficult task this time - an epic trilogy covering the 1916 Easter Rising and the forging of the Republican movement. But in this first volume he tackles his subject with the energy and humour familiar from The Commitments and Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha, and his story is vivid and engaging.

Henry Smart, his handsome, swaggering young hero, is born in a Dublin slum and learns his quick wit and fighting skills on the streets; by 14 he's joined the Irish Citizen Army, plays a major part in the events of Easter Monday and goes on to become one of Michael Collins's protegés, a fearless leader with fierce loyalties to family and country. Doyle blends historical characters and detail with the history of his imagination; the result is a rich, gripping and often moving novel.

 Jane Perry

webTitle: Was the Great Gatsby a black man?

fields.headline: Was the Great Gatsby a black man?
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Was Jay Gatsby, one of the most celebrated figures in twentieth-century literature, a black man in code?
fields.body:
Was Jay Gatsby, one of the most celebrated figures in twentieth-century literature, a black man in code?

The theory that the social climber, playboy and wheeler-dealer, played in a screen version of F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic novel by Robert Redford, was essentially black has been made in a paper by a US academic, Dr Carlyle V. Thompson.

He sees in The Great Gatsby Fitzgerald's deep-seated apprehensions about miscegenation between blacks and whites. He also suggests that the rebellious author was playing a trick on his conservative publishers, Charles Scribner's Sons, who five years earlier published The Rising Tide of Colour: Against White World-Supremacy by the eugenicist Lothrop Stoddard. In the novel, Tom Buchanan is reading this book, though it is incorrectly entitled, The Rise of the Coloured Empires.

'The overwhelming characterisations of Gatsby are black,' claims Thompson, an assistant professor in the department of literature, languages and philosophy at Brooklyn's Medgar Evers College. Gatsby is unfathomably wealthy. He gives swell parties, but no one comes to his funeral. 'He's a bootlegger,' says one guest.

'Bootleg means counterfeit - and Gatsby is racially counterfeit,' says Thompson. 'And racial passing was at a peak when the book was published.' Thompson insists the text is brimming with evidence that Gatsby is black.

'How do you explain all of these things - his brown body, his tanned skin, his close-cropped hair? These are signifiers of racial passing.'

Then there's Gatsby's house: 'He's got 40 acres and a mansion. That speaks towards the legacy of slavery in America. All slaves were supposed to get 40 acres and a mule.'

Thompson sees Gatsby's link to Montenegro, where he was awarded a medal for heroism, as a symbol. 'It means black mountain. Is Fitzgerald calling Gatsby a black mountain?'

Professor Matthew Bruccoli, one of America's leading Fitzgerald scholars, says the theory is nonsense. 'Saying that Gatsby is black is utterly implausible. It turns the teaching of literature into a silly game.'

fields.headline: A tale of two women
fields.standfirst: Sara Paretsky talks to Stephanie Merritt about glass ceilings, Dickens and putting V. I. Warshawski behind bars
fields.trailText: Sara Paretsky talks to Stephanie Merritt about glass ceilings, Dickens and putting V. I. Warshawski behind bars
fields.body:
The delicate, fine-boned woman in the silk Chanel blouse sitting quietly for her photographs in the elegant tea room of a London hotel is not at all what I expected. Naively, I had been picturing Sara Paretsky as her steely, fast-talking heroine, private investigator V. I. Warshawski; brash and tough, with fighting skills honed on the mean streets of Chicago's South Side.

This soft-spoken, finely groomed woman with the neat, feathery hair doesn't look as if she often drops down empty lift shafts and flings herself on to the roof of moving trains, and of course there's no reason why she should, except that the detailed authenticity of her Warshawski books convince you that she must have lived at least some of it. But she shares with her character a determination and resilience that flashes sometimes in her quick eyes; like Warshawski - indeed, because of Warshawski - Paretsky knows what it's like to be a woman fighting her way through a man's world.

Now that female detectives are almost de rigueur, and Paretsky's own books have over six million copies in print, it's difficult to imagine that only 20 years ago it was virtually unheard of for women to be writing hardboiled crime in the Raymond Chandler vein, and those who did were actively dissuaded from creating female protagonists.

'If I hadn't been a crime fiction reader, I might never have tried to write for publication,' Paretsky says. 'Women didn't do that. But I got this bug that I wanted to have a woman detective, because I was so put off by the way women in crime fiction acted. Either they weren't there at all, or they would be total victims, or they'd be sexually active, so then you knew they were rotten to the core.'

Paretsky has been working to fracture stereotypes of women since childhood. She grew up with her four brothers in rural Kansas, where her father was the first Jewish teacher to be hired by the university. 'We were like a family of giraffes,' she smiles. 'All the fundamentalist Christians wanted to come round and see if it was really true that we had little horns.'

I ask if she felt isolated at school and she offers a little shrug. 'Sometimes, but not because of being Jewish - more because my parents were very contemptuous of ordinary social conventions.' Her parents were bookish and fond of music and Paretsky describes her mother as 'a phenomenal storyteller, much more inventive than I am,' which might have seemed an ideal environment to encourage an intelligent young woman. But after school, Paretsky encountered another glass ceiling to be broken through.

'Although my parents were very progressive in their social and racial politics, they were very conservative in their sexual politics,' she says, slightly sadly but without bitterness. 'It really concerns me the way government is for sale these days, and the massive amounts of money companies can spend to buy the legislation they want. 'I felt angry, and I felt really powerless,' she says, with fierce eyes. 'The average age of a woman in an American prison is 20, 65 per cent are illiterate, 80 per cent are black or Hispanic. 'I hope I never have to go to prison,' she says earnestly. 'I don't think I'd be strong enough, physically or mentally.'

fields.headline: Audio: 13 Aug
fields.trailText: Anthony Trollope's vision of life in the 19th century keeps the listener involved for more than 32 hours in Timothy West's version, plus An Old Man's Love
fields.body:
An Old Man's Love
Anthony Trollope
Read by Tony Britton
Running time 8hrs 35mins
Chivers £15.95

The Way We Live Now
Anthony Trollope
Read by Timothy West
Running time 32hrs 30mins
Cover to Cover £79.99
Buy it at BOL

The young man Mary Lawrie truly loves returns from the South African diamond mines on the very day she has promised to marry her kindly father substitute, William Whittlestaff. Does the older man still have the right to marry her?

Whittlestaff's anguish was Trollope's own; he finished An Old Man's Love seven months before he died in 1882 aged 67, thus ending his 10-year unconsummated relationship with Kate Field, a vivacious American in her twenties. Tony Britton's mature, reflective tones are right for Trollope's narrative voice, and as kindly Whittlestaff, but Mary, who has strength of purpose, is made to sound irritatingly frail.

The 425,000 words of the monumental The Way We Live Now distils Trollope's musings on the modern ways of the 'new dispensation' which represented to him the betrayal of all that was decent.

The fact that the listener can be totally involved for more than 32 hours in the families of this society so fatally seduced by money is due as much to West's skills as it is to Trollope's. He can produce the oily tongue of the wholly crooked financier, Melmotte, as convincingly as the 'impedimentary gurgles' in poor Hetta Carbury's voice as she speaks of the lover who has proved untrue. A wonderful indulgence for the listener.

fields.headline: No shrinking Violet
fields.standfirst: The last instalment of Violet Bonham Carter's diaries, Daring to Hope, reveals a woman of wit and passion
fields.trailText: The last instalment of Violet Bonham Carter's diaries, Daring to Hope, reveals a woman of wit and passion
fields.body:
Daring to Hope: the Diaries and Letters of Violet Bonham Carter
edited by Mark Pottle
Weidenfeld & Nicholson £25, pp442
Buy it at BOL

Is it possible to be smitten by a woman who died 31 years ago aged 81 simply through the diaries she wrote in the last two decades of her life? In the case of Violet Bonham Carter, the answer is yes. You feel yourself in the presence of a great woman, a woman of wit and cultivated discourse, passionately devoted to the Liberal principles she inherited from her father, H.H. Asquith, Prime Minister from 1908 until 1916, and utterly loyal to her family and friends.

Her liberalism was principled, certainly, but it was perhaps more truly dynastic. Fidelity to her beloved father's memory and reputation was the mainspring of her life. Indeed, he had only one rival - Winston Churchill, whose declining years are one of the central themes of the diaries, the last of three volumes. Her husband Maurice Bonham Carter ('Bongy') gave her domestic happiness but Churchill was in other senses the love of her life. An entry for 1967 records the answer she gave to Kenneth Harris when he asked her before a television interview 'if she had been in love with Winston'.

'I had not been in love - though I could not have loved him more - & - our relationship was an intimacy of minds - & words & an emotional one.'

It is perfectly truthful as far as it goes, but these diaries were written with an eye to posterity and are not fully confessional (the editor, Mark Pottle, has removed passages which would be hurtful to those still living). As Churchill's daughter, Mary Soames, discloses in a perceptive and elegant introduction, Violet found some difficulty in accepting his marriage in 1908 to Clementine Hozier and was rather rude about her in letters and conversation. Eventually, they were reconciled and with good sense Clementine made no attempt to stand in the way of her friendship with her husband.

The account of Churchill's twilight years is vivid and touching, but her affection makes her tolerant of his faults. He could be jealous of rivals and was unable to reciprocate Attlee's respect and liking, though his reluctance to hand over to Anthony Eden was fully justified by the botch his successor made of Suez. And this passionate opponent of racism and apartheid forgives her hero's racism as a minor blemish in a 'great tree' towering over all the rest in the political forest.

The diaries are largely an account of an energetic public life in which her Liberal principles, uncontaminated by the exercise of power, burned with a kind of purity. With Churchill, she had opposed appeasement before the war; now with him she embraced the European movement and as the opportunities of boarding the European bus slipped by she lamented the loss of cohesion and pace. With him, she detested de Gaulle and the high tone of the diaries falters when she almost exults in his ill-health and imminent death.

For all her devotion, she refused Churchill's repeated offers of an electoral pact, preferring a long electoral winter to the end of principle. For the Tories, Churchill apart, she entertained a genuine contempt. Instead, she poured her energies into helping her son-in-law, Jo Grimond, lead the party's hesitant revival that began with her son Mark's victory in the Torrington by-election of 1958.

But the most important man in her life, until her death, remained her father. She was fiercely proud of his achievement, particularly in building the foundations of the welfare state, and scornfully dismissive of Lloyd George who supplanted him. And the diaries assume their only note of real personal distress, moments of personal bereavement apart, when she contemplates the proposed publication of 500 letters written by her infatuated father over three years from 1912 to her own close friend, Venetia Stanley (later Montagu). He abandoned the relationship after Venetia's marriage.

Pottle deserves a special word - he is the Jeeves of editors, ever ready with a concise but helpful footnote, the master of the informative appendix. He edited the first two volumes with Mark Bonham Carter, who died in 1994, but was the sole midwife of the third. The result is once again a highly readable book, with narrative pace.

For all her egalitarian and humanitarian principles, Violet Bonham Carter was a member of the old ruling caste, a toff. In 1961, after a lifetime of being driven about London, she returns from a performance of Beyond the Fringe. 'I got back by Tube from Holborn which I was rather proud of finding my way to.'

Violet was not only clever, articulate, principled and brave; she was sweet, too.

webTitle: Observer review: A Change is Gonna Come by Craig Werner

fields.headline: The message of the blues
fields.standfirst: Craig Werner has produced an impressive study of race and rock'n'roll, A Change is Gonna Come
fields.trailText: Craig Werner has produced an impressive study of race and rock'n'roll, A Change is Gonna Come
fields.body:
A Change is Gonna Come: Music, Race and the Soul of America
Craig Werner
Payback Press £12.99, pp430

In 1958, African-American poet Langston Hughes wrote the definitive rationale of the blues: 'Sad as the blues may be, there's almost always something humorous about them - even if it's the kind of humour that laughs to keep from crying.' Almost 30 years later, blues guitarist B.B. King, speaking to Rolling Stone magazine, snapped: 'Singing the blues is like being black.'

In this authoritative and engaging study of race and class in popular music, Craig Werner makes the point from the very outset that rock'n'roll has its origins in the deep South, forged out of black misery and repression.

Decade by decade, Werner translates the black experience, from Vietnam-era rage to the Clintonite race for commerciality. A Change Is Gonna Come, published to outstanding reviews in the United States last year, is almost as definitive as the examples he uses to illustrate his theory.

The war in Vietnam perfectly highlights Werner's case. Edwin Starr's 'War' was the dominant soul response to the conflict. 'War? What is it good for? Absolutely nothing,' wrote Starr, incensed that black casualties on the front line accounted for 23 per cent of total losses, while African-Americans comprised only 12 per cent of the armed forces.

Starr's response didn't entirely represent the African-American experience. In 1972, ageing jazzmen Eddie Harris and Les McCann launched a blistering attack on Starr's peacenik anthem. 'Compared to What' pounds out a jazz-funk groove that barely suppresses Harris's screaming condemnation of US politicians who could barely muster even the semblance of justification. 'Nobody gives us rhyme or reason/ Half a doubt and they call it treason.'

Both records ignited a far-reaching debate within the African-American community. Yet an equally virulent rivalry was being played out elsewhere between Canadian songwriter Neil Young and southern rockers Lynyrd Skynyrd. Young set the feud in motion when he wrote 'Southern Man' and 'Alabama', denunciations of the racist South. Skynyrd replied with 'Sweet Home Alabama'. Both sets of performers have now been slugging it with thinly veiled insults for the past 30 years, but as Werner notes: 'Not many black folks care who won.'

A Change Is Gonna Come, annotated with meticulous detail, maps the racial evolution of the American record industry, a strand of music theory where Werner comfortably holds his own against already established critics like Greil Marcus, Nelson George, David Toop and Peter Guralnick. The symbiotic relationship between big finance and rock'n'roll, however, is only hinted at and perhaps better explained elsewhere - Fred Goodman's The Mansion on the Hill: Dylan, Young, Geffen, Springsteen and the Head-On Collision of Rock and Commerce, a seminal 1997 study of rock'n'roll commerce, stands unchallenged.

Werner's chapters on Springsteen, one of the rare occasions in the book when the author dissects a white icon, make for inspired reading. 'The Boss thing hung heavily over Springsteen's "Born In The USA" tour, and a lot of black folks who never heard the music saw the flag behind the stage, and in the hands of the white crowd in the film clips, and thought it must be the soundtrack for the next war.'

Werner extends his argument by pointing out that throughout his Seventies' heyday, Springsteen regularly played three-hour shows that attracted a wide racial mix. Yet the standing joke during the 1984 tour was that there were more black people on stage than in the audience and 'the Boss' title, bestowed upon him by music critics, only succeeded in further alienating his black fan-base.

Werner's analysis of rap, perhaps the most severely criticised of modern music forms, is especially readable. In 1992, Oakland-based rap artist Paris released 'Bush Kill', a vicious attack on the US presidency. The song was condemned and the artist was forced to leave his record label. Similarly, the lionisation of all-white icons, Elvis Presley in particular, has provided rap groups with indignatory anger.

The chapters on rap are particularly well researched, even given the slew of releases over the last 20 years. Werner cites Living Colour as the best example of modern-day black militancy. The group, a three-piece rap/rock outfit, denounced Presley in 1988's 'Cult of Personality', a record that contradicted the popular view of the white boy from Tupelo as a subversive force. The same year, Public Enemy rapper Chuck D pronounced: 'Elvis was a hero to most/ But he never meant shit to me/ Straight up racist that sucker was/ Motherfuck him and John Wayne.'

Almost 20 years ago, James Baldwin wrote: 'Our history is each other. That is our only guide. One thing is absolutely certain: one can repudiate, or despise, no one's history without repudiating and despising one's own. Perhaps that is what the gospel singer is singing.' With his heartfelt consideration of black music, Werner has written a racial study every bit as profound as any civil rights declaration.

With his heartfelt consideration of black music, Werner has written a racial study every bit as profound as any civil rights declaration.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week: 13 Aug
fields.trailText: The latest issue of Index on Censorship turns its attention to the question of corruption in the world of sport.
fields.body:
This Sporting Lie
Index on Censorship £8.99, pp192
Buy it at BOL

The latest issue of Index on Censorship turns its attention to the question of corruption in the world of sport. There's a predictably interesting piece by Mike Marqusee. Predictably good because Marqusee is one of the very best sports writers in the country. Predictably less good because his tirade is directed against Murdoch et al. A fair target, but an obvious one, although Marqusee might argue that Murdoch, like Jeffrey Archer or Sir Tim Rice, is someone that you have to keep on knocking. And he's probably right.

There is also a good piece by Simon Kuper, who argues that football can be the most effective means of showing dissent against a dictatorship. As an example of such dissidence, he writes about Helmut Klopfleisch, a Hertha BSC fan, and suggests there might be millions of football dissidents. That may actually be stretching it a bit.

A good piece by Jim Firstle on drugs mentions the survey among Olympic athletes where an overwhelming majority said they would take a drug which guaranteed a gold medal even if it foreshortened their life. As Ben Johnson's coach, Charlie Francis, was forever saying: 'It ain't cheating if everybody else is doing it.' This is a classic variant on the 'Why me?' defence often advanced by the obviously guilty.

Finally, there's a load of flannel from Gary Whannel (professor of media cultures at the University of Luton). In the course of asking 'What exactly is David Beckham?' he argues: 'In a culture that is self-referential, parodic and marked by the globalised circulation of images, the role of the sporting hero is inevitably subject to public demonstration.' Yawn. It's only a game, Gary.
