fields.headline: Survey indicts 'ageist' NHS
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A major survey by hospital consultants has revealed that ageism is rife in the National Health Service. Younger patients are up to twice as likely as older ones to be given the best available treatment, their report reveals.
fields.body:
A major survey by hospital consultants has revealed that ageism is rife in the National Health Service. Younger patients are up to twice as likely as older ones to be given the best available treatment, their report reveals.

The consultants conclude that many older patients are dying unnecessarily. Charities for the elderly have been so alarmed by the findings they have demanded an urgent government inquiry.

The study, based on the records of 12,000 patients in 20 hospitals, will be published in September's edition of the journal Injury. It reveals that when older people go to accident and emergency wards they are less likely to get most types of care than younger people.

The report shows that a 70-year-old with the same injury as a 30-year-old is 26 per cent less likely to be admitted to intensive care, and 35 per cent less likely to be sent to the resuscitation room. A 70-year-old patient with a severe head injury is only half as likely to be sent to a specialist neurosurgery ward as a 30-year-old. On average, the chance of getting many treatments decreases by 1 per cent for each year of life.

Alice Hunt, of Age Concern, said: 'It is disgusting. This research shows that age discrimination cannot be dismissed as mere isolated incidents, and that it appears to be a common practice to pass over older patients for treatments and referrals.'

The report looked only at hospitals in Scotland, but the authors insist the situation is almost certainly the same - if not worse - south of the border.

The main author, Dr Patrick Grant, an A&E consultant at the Western Infirmary in Glasgow, admitted: 'It is difficult to argue against this. Society as a whole may have some subconsciously ageist philosophy.'

Even adjusting for the fact that the old are more likely to be weak and have other medical conditions, the authors found that far more died than expected.

'We consider the outcomes for the injured elderly could be improved by a more dynamic approach to their management,' the report concludes.

Grant suggested that the ageism was systematic in the way A&E departments operate, but insisted it was not due to ageist attitudes from staff.

'It's probably implicit rationing. When resources are really stretched, perhaps older people lose out. If you have one neuro surgery bed, and three patients, you say that maybe the 80-year-old won't do as well,' he said.

However, doctors also often deny treatment to elderly patients because they are pessimistic about the chances of them responding. 'This can become a self-fulfilling prophecy,' said Grant.

Medical staff also take too little account of how apparently small injuries can be life-threatening to older people. Ambulance staff and doctors are more likely to put people in the intensive 'resuscitation room' if the patient has really dramatic injuries - which are more common with the young. However, the lives of the elderly can be just as threatened by small injuries - such as from a fall - which are far less dramatic and easier to overlook. In the United States, elderly patients with moderate injuries must be treated as seriously as younger patients with major injuries - but there are no such official recommendations in the UK.

Jonathan Ellis, the 'Dignity on the Ward' campaigner for Help the Aged, also blamed the training of doctors: 'Two-thirds of patients are over 65, but the amount of training medical staff have with the elderly is very limited. Often staff don't know how to meet the needs of these patients.'

Charities welcomed the study because it made it more difficult for the Government to dismiss allegations of ageism in the NHS as anecdotal. Ellis said: 'Ageism in the NHS needs to be tackled urgently, but the Department of Health just comes up with bland statements. The Government is naive suggesting that things are ticking along nicely.'

A Department of Health spokesperson said: 'Discrimination of any kind - whether it is on the basis of age, race or gender - is completely unacceptable in the NHS.

'We are developing a blueprint for services for older people which will set national standards of care. This will address issues of concern to older people, including access to services on the basis of clinical need.'

anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

'My mother was left to die because she was old'

Robert Smith became convinced that many medical staff were ageist when his mother died last year. Mary Smith, 74, had started coughing up blood. At 2am she was driven to the local hospital, where she had worked as a nurse for 28 years.

Mrs Smith waited in pain in casualty for more than two hours. 'It was a very quiet night; they had extra staff on, but no one came near her. They were too busy laughing and joking with each other,' said her son. When she was finally examined, she couldn't remember what medication she was on. 'The doctor became very rude and even told her to shut up and stop babbling on,' Mr Smith said.

Mrs Smith was only given a pain-killing injection. She died five hours later. 'The fact she wasn't treated and the attitude of the staff definitely contributed to her death. If she'd been even 10 years younger, I'm certain she would have got better treatment,' he said.

'Old people are seen as a drain on NHS resources. But these are the people who paid their contributions all their life. What did they pay for?'
fields.bodyText: A major survey by hospital consultants has revealed that ageism is rife in the National Health Service. Younger patients are up to twice as likely as older ones to be given the best available treatment, their report reveals. The consultants conclude that many older patients are dying unnecessarily. Charities for the elderly have been so alarmed by the findings they have demanded an urgent government inquiry. The study, based on the records of 12,000 patients in 20 hospitals, will be published in September's edition of the journal Injury. It reveals that when older people go to accident and emergency wards they are less likely to get most types of care than younger people. The report shows that a 70-year-old with the same injury as a 30-year-old is 26 per cent less likely to be admitted to intensive care, and 35 per cent less likely to be sent to the resuscitation room. A 70-year-old patient with a severe head injury is only half as likely to be sent to a specialist neurosurgery ward as a 30-year-old. On average, the chance of getting many treatments decreases by 1 per cent for each year of life. Alice Hunt, of Age Concern, said: 'It is disgusting. This research shows that age discrimination cannot be dismissed as mere isolated incidents, and that it appears to be a common practice to pass over older patients for treatments and referrals.' The report looked only at hospitals in Scotland, but the authors insist the situation is almost certainly the same - if not worse - south of the border. The main author, Dr Patrick Grant, an A&E consultant at the Western Infirmary in Glasgow, admitted: 'It is difficult to argue against this. Society as a whole may have some subconsciously ageist philosophy.' Even adjusting for the fact that the old are more likely to be weak and have other medical conditions, the authors found that far more died than expected. 'We consider the outcomes for the injured elderly could be improved by a more dynamic approach to their management,' the report concludes. Grant suggested that the ageism was systematic in the way A&E departments operate, but insisted it was not due to ageist attitudes from staff. 'It's probably implicit rationing. When resources are really stretched, perhaps older people lose out. If you have one neuro surgery bed, and three patients, you say that maybe the 80-year-old won't do as well,' he said. However, doctors also often deny treatment to elderly patients because they are pessimistic about the chances of them responding. 'This can become a self-fulfilling prophecy,' said Grant. Medical staff also take too little account of how apparently small injuries can be life-threatening to older people. Ambulance staff and doctors are more likely to put people in the intensive 'resuscitation room' if the patient has really dramatic injuries - which are more common with the young. However, the lives of the elderly can be just as threatened by small injuries - such as from a fall - which are far less dramatic and easier to overlook. In the United States, elderly patients with moderate injuries must be treated as seriously as younger patients with major injuries - but there are no such official recommendations in the UK. Jonathan Ellis, the 'Dignity on the Ward' campaigner for Help the Aged, also blamed the training of doctors: 'Two-thirds of patients are over 65, but the amount of training medical staff have with the elderly is very limited. Often staff don't know how to meet the needs of these patients.' Charities welcomed the study because it made it more difficult for the Government to dismiss allegations of ageism in the NHS as anecdotal. Ellis said: 'Ageism in the NHS needs to be tackled urgently, but the Department of Health just comes up with bland statements. The Government is naive suggesting that things are ticking along nicely.' A Department of Health spokesperson said: 'Discrimination of any kind - whether it is on the basis of age, race or gender - is completely unacceptable in the NHS. 'We are developing a blueprint for services for older people which will set national standards of care. This will address issues of concern to older people, including access to services on the basis of clinical need.' anthony.browne@observer.co.uk 'My mother was left to die because she was old' Robert Smith became convinced that many medical staff were ageist when his mother died last year. Mary Smith, 74, had started coughing up blood. At 2am she was driven to the local hospital, where she had worked as a nurse for 28 years. Mrs Smith waited in pain in casualty for more than two hours. 'It was a very quiet night; they had extra staff on, but no one came near her. They were too busy laughing and joking with each other,' said her son. When she was finally examined, she couldn't remember what medication she was on. 'The doctor became very rude and even told her to shut up and stop babbling on,' Mr Smith said. Mrs Smith was only given a pain-killing injection. She died five hours later. 'The fact she wasn't treated and the attitude of the staff definitely contributed to her death. If she'd been even 10 years younger, I'm certain she would have got better treatment,' he said. 'Old people are seen as a drain on NHS resources. But these are the people who paid their contributions all their life. What did they pay for?'

webTitle: Business: photon technology that will expand the internet

fields.headline: Shining a light on the highway
fields.standfirst: Bookham is leading the way with photon technology that will expand the internet
fields.trailText: Bookham is leading the way with photon technology that will expand the internet
fields.body:
Dotcoms have never quite recovered from the cold chill that descended upon the sector in April. But even as hi-tech markets faltered, one internet-related company forged ahead with flotation, accompanied by little fanfare, other than the memorable assertion that it 'was no flaky dotcom'.

The markets believed that, and after just two months Bookham Technologies entered the elite group of Britain's largest 100 companies. Today it's worth some £4.3 billion despite sales of £2.5 million in the last quarter.

Using the hi-tech vernacular, investors 'climbed the value chain', shifting from uncertain consumer businesses concocted at north London dinner parties to the foundations of internet technology developed in university physics labs for over a decade - a shift to the people building the information superhighway rather than the 'freight' companies using it to transport data.

They saw the light - and then they invested in it. Optical networking, and photonics, or using light to transmit vast quantities of data, are the hot areas of the moment. And just as anything with the magical '.com' suffix yielded magnificent premiums a year ago, it is now the 'opt-' and 'photo-' prefixes that capture the attention of investors in the know.

Naturally the sudden rise of photonics is entwined with the use of the internet, and its key role is as an enabler in the convergence of media such as film, television, music and video games. The quality of such applications at the moment is laughable because of limits on bandwidth capability - the quantity and speed at which data is transmitted down wires and cables. Photonics and optical networking changes this by expanding the capability of existing optical fibres that serve as the trunk roads in telecoms networks.

'Last century was the century of the electron; this century will be the era of the photon,' declares Dr Andrew Rickman, Bookham's chief executive. Photons, particles of light, are somewhat niftier than the flow of electrons which represent a conventional electronic current. 'The potential for the photonic chip will be immense and we are only really scratching the surface now.'

But the technologies are not an overnight sensation, says Professor David Payne of the Optoelectronics Research Centre of the University of Southampton. Payne is a founder of Southampton Photonics, one of a pack of smaller companies riding in the slipstream of Bookham's success.

'Science councils have funded photonics over 30 years. It's produced a major strength in UK universities and we have a great opportunity here,' he says.

Charles Kao was the first person to transmit data down an optical cable at the Standard Telecommunications Labs in Harlow in 1966. By 1970 the British Post Office Research Laboratories at Martlesham Heath demonstrated a practical system.

Bookham's success is the result of 11 years of hard work, after Rickman spotted an opening for technologies that enable huge amounts of data to be carried at high speed. Rickman embarked on a measured, long-term strategy. He studied for a doctorate in integrated optics and an MBA at the same time.

Photonics certainly lacks the 'I could have thought of that' factor of a last-minute.com. There will be no former Swedish models fronting companies, unless they happen to have a sideline in dense wave division multiplexing (DWDM), integrated circuits and synchronous waveguides.

The detail may be baffling, but the basics are easy to grasp. From the Eighties fibre-optic cables, shown on Tomorrow's World as being able to transmit light around curves and even knots, were laid as the main trunk data carriers between large cities.

Now demand for data transfer is increasing and if visions of watching football matches over the internet are to be realised, the capacity of the existing trunk needs to rise. DWDM technology enables this by splitting the signal into different wave lengths or colours, in a similar way to how a prism splits white light into a rainbow of constituent colours. Each wavelength can carry the same amount of data as the original fibre, but potentially at different speeds and destinations; anything from 16 to 160 wavelengths is possible.

Bookham and Southampton Photonics come into this by providing the components for systems to allow such 'multiplexing'. Each wavelength needs to be filtered, divided, amplified, reconstituted, and monitored.

Another area is the expansion of fibre-optic networks, closer to the office and to the home. AT&T is doing this in the US, and this trend will drive demand for components. But it will also require expensive optical switches.

In the past, two trunks of optical fibre were joined together by conventional switches. This is like building eight-lane motorways, but having dirt-tracks as junctions. Small companies such as Ilotron, which started at the University of Essex, have designed solely optical routers.

Demand is very strong, in fact there is a supply shortage in the components business. This explains Bookham's value, venture capitalists circling smaller companies, and larger systems providers, such as Cisco, aggressively hunting for small technology companies. Companies are racing to build factories, and so far Bookham's record has impressed. The company, named after a Surrey town, takes an innovative approach, producing a synthesis of photonics technology with the tried and tested mass-manufacturability of silicon.

The innovation is in the manufacturing process as much as it is in the design of the components. 'Our philosophy is to maximise our profitability by owning both the intellectual property and having the manufacturing know-how,' says Rickman.

But amid this photonic euphoria, warning bells are sounding from the restructuring of the US market. JDS Uniphase gobbled up E-Tek in July and the following week announced a £41bn merger with SDL. It acquired the Torquay-based Sifam in November 1999 and a fortnight ago announced the opening of a new factory in Plymouth.

Lucent Technologies will open a microelectronics unit at the beginning of next year, combining the silicon manufacturing and optoelectronics units. The head of the new company is British, and it will incorporate part of the acclaimed Bell Labs research centre.

It sounds like an ominous development for the likes of Bookham. But both of these giants are in some way Bookham's customers, and co-operation seems to be one of the strategies to stave off any competitive threat.

Bookham's value embodies the pent-up investor demand for the optoelectronics sector. Whether it will increase and hold a market share commensurate with a valuation of £4.3bn depends on the technology and demand.

However, Bookham's share price leaves something to be desired, though its major customers, Nortel, Alcatel, and Marconi, are reassuring. Cisco and Intel hold minority stakes. Some longer-term investors are looking to sell part of their stakes in October. Rickman may be one, as he owns 24 per cent. Its share price has dropped 15 per cent since this news.

Investors may have seen the light, but will they be blinded by it? And in the meantime expect a rash of misplaced investment in optometrists.

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: Napster, the subversive MP3-swapping website, has been deluged with hits from around the world since the US recording industry tried to shut it down.
fields.body:
Napsta's gig

Napster, the subversive MP3-swapping website, has been deluged with hits from around the world since the US recording industry tried to shut it down.

In the two weeks since the now overturned shutdown, traffic soared 92 per cent, to 849,000 unique users, according to Nielsen Media Research. It appears Napster is successfully aping that well known rap music technique of getting yourself on the wrong side of the law to establish the all important 'bad boy' brand.

@large awaits contrived efforts to reinvent the e-aristocracy in flagging dotcoms as gangsta rappers and breakdancers fresh from the hood.

Loony toons

Last week, @large revealed the emergence of 'e-motional commerce', the softer caring side of the dotcom economy. Frankly, the office has been swamped with publicity from sickly sites such as wetnose.com - 'the one-stop site for the animals in your life' - and the infamous Greenpeace Polar Bear web game.

Our faith in entrepreneurialism was reaffirmed by ICL, however, which unveiled a secret weapon for websites seeking to flog yet more financial services: an animated parrot asking about your financial status. Cassandras who doubt the security of internet financial services will be won over by Peedy, the overweight cockatoo.

Other cartoon animals are available. The parrot will specialise in asking 'Do you want an Isa?' over and over again; there's a shark specialising in loan provision; and a leading internet bank is securing rights to the chicken, just to show that it came before the Egg. Apparently.

Crossed lines

If phone.com and software.com can merge in a multibillion dollar deal to produce mobile internet products, what would be the value of a kangaroo.com and sheep.com joint venture selling woolly jumpers?

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Named, shamed
fields.body:
Named, shamed

It has come to the attention of media diary that Michael Jackson, chief executive of Channel 4, is in possession of not just one, but two series of the iconic and excellent American drama West Wing .

Thus far he has been happy to stifle the excellent drama while at Sky One it happily gathered an ardent following among a small but select band - ourselves and former lobbyist Derek Draper, notably.

Now we learn that Jackson alone has the second series in his back pocket, and we will not be able to see how the thrilling denouement plays itself out until he releases this to the British public.

If he continues to hide his West Wing , a campaign will be organised to surround his headquarters until he agrees to give in.

Net losses

Existentialist angst has hit a most unlikely quarter of Fleet Street: the grinning form of the internet correspondent.

A press corps that luxuriated over the falls from grace of Martha and boo, now hungrily sniffs around ready to pounce on the first sign of underfunding, layoffs or dodgy websites.

After marinating in schadenfreude at the now pear-shaped prospects of the e-elite, internet hacks find the tables beginning to turn.

The uber-geeks who managed to reinvent themselves as square-glassed Prada-suited gurus of the e-economy - already sick as the proverbial parrot at seeing a couple of their number jump over the fence and earn a quick million or ten - are discovering that other hacks have cottoned on to the internet.

Travel correspondents, for example, have realised that multitudinous press releases from lastminute.com fall on their patch.

As one leading internet correspondent said: 'If Mary Meeker is saying there will be no such thing as internet analysts, where does that leave me? Why am I here? What am I for?'

Answers on an email please to business@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Business: Gene genius gives a lift to Amersham's image

fields.headline: Gene genius gives a lift to Amersham's image
fields.trailText: The mapping of the human genome has confirmed Darwin's theory of evolution, according to Bill Castell, chief executive of Nycomed Amersham.
fields.body:
The mapping of the human genome has confirmed Darwin's theory of evolution, according to Bill Castell, chief executive of Nycomed Amersham. He is hoping that the Nasdaq flotation of Amersham Pharmacia Biotech (APB) will finally persuade investors that his group has evolved into one of the stars of the healthcare industry.

Nycomed Amersham has undoubtedly made great strides since 1990 when, to quote Castell, its idea of innovation was to put radioactive material in a different-shaped phial. Now, it is a global business with a market-leading position in imaging, its instruments were used to sequence three of the first four chromosomes to be mapped, and it is a market leader in the fast-growing area of genetic sequencing.

The City has not ignored the transformation. A share price which is about 29 times the expected earnings for the full year is a decent premium to the market, but is more than 10 per cent below pharmaceuticals companies such as GlaxoWellcome or its betrothed, SmithKline Beecham. And they do not have a hi-tech gene mapping subsidiary to float.

Nycomed Amersham is clearly convinced that floating 10 per cent of APB, planned for the autumn, will unlock hidden value in the group. The genetic blueprint may now be complete, but the big bucks will be made in exploiting that information. There are plenty of rivals muscling in on its territory, but none covers the waterfront in quite the way Nycomed Amersham does.

Analysts estimate that the business will attract a valuation between $4 billion and $6bn (£2.6bn to £4bn). That would value its share at around £1.9bn, leaving the remainder of Amersham's businesses valued at just over £2bn, or less than 20 times earnings. True, some parts of the business - such as its seeds for cancer therapy and some of its unpatented products - are achieving pedestrian sales growth. But the core imaging business managed a 17 per cent sales increase, driven by products such as Myoview, its heart diagnostic product.

Critics point out that half of APB is in research products, where sales last year rose by just 3 per cent, and wonder whether the float will achieve the valuations predicted. And they question whether the rest of Amersham deserves a premium rating. But Castell and his team have done an excellent job evolving Amersham from a public-sector monolith to a highly focused, innovative business. That will eventually be recognised in the price. Buy the shares.

Reed sounds a stronger note

Crispin Davis's appointment as chief executive of Reed Elsevier may not have been greeted with universal acclaim but, a year on, the City is finally warming to his approach. Interim profit before tax may have fallen 4 per cent, after adjusting for things like currency and exceptional items, but that was because of increased investment on internet initiatives. The underlying picture was of a business which not only knows where it wants to go - something the old management was good at - but also has a plan to get there.

There are new executives in key management positions (apart from finance director) and Davis appears to have tight control. The £750 million three-year internet investment programme announced in February is already bearing fruit. So far, £110m has been spent, rising to £260m by the year-end.

Internet-generated sales reached £160m in the first six months of 2000, and are expected to be £400m for the whole year. The science division was the biggest beneficiary. But there are also signs that it has managed to stop the rot in the legal business, where it has launched a service for small firms and is establishing a good presence in universities.

On cost control, it is likely to exceed the promised £130m savings this year, suggesting there was a lot more fat in the group than analysts realised.

The only thing that really spooked the City was Davis's interest in US publisher Harcourt Brace, which is up for sale. But analysts take the view that Davis was expressing more a healthy interest in the affairs of its rivals than a serious intention to acquire.

After a faltering start, Reed's shares have recovered strongly in the past two months. They may now pause for breath, but those prepared to wait for their rewards should buy now.

Bolt from Colt is over the top

The collapse in Colt Telecom's share price after Paul Chisholm, its president and chief executive, announced that he planned to spend more time with his family in the US, perfectly illustrates how illogical the City's attitude to technology stocks is.

Colt Telecom is one of the more successful of the new generation of phone operators. It has done all it promised in establishing its European network, attracting large corporate customers and increasing its revenue.

The number of buildings connected to its network in the second quarter of the year jumped by 68 per cent over last year, while the number of minutes switched rose by 138 per cent. Profits are, of course, still a rather distant prospect but at least it has funds - £2bn to be precise - which should be enough to get it into that position.

Chisolm's departure is significant. He was the driving force behind the company's growth and will be missed. But he is hardly making a dash for the door with binbags full of trade secrets. Indeed, he is doing all he can to ensure an orderly succession: he will not finally depart for Boston until next year, and will stay on the board after a successor is appointed.

But such high-flying companies are valued less on common sense than on sentiment. Any unexpected news is likely to move the price sharply. That does not make it logical, however. Compared with some of the internet upstarts, Colt is well established with a long pedigree. A new chief executive, backed by the existing management team, should be well equipped to carry the business forward. Investors have some cause to be worried about how Colt's business model will adapt in the face of rapidly changing telephone technology.

The slump following Chisolm's departure looks overdone.

True, some parts of the business - such as its seeds for cancer therapy and some of its unpatented products - are achieving pedestrian sales growth. But the core imaging business managed a 17 per cent sales increase, driven by products such as Myoview, its heart diagnostic product. Critics point out that half of APB is in research products, where sales last year rose by just 3 per cent, and wonder whether the float will achieve the valuations predicted. And they question whether the rest of Amersham deserves a premium rating. But Castell and his team have done an excellent job evolving Amersham from a public-sector monolith to a highly focused, innovative business. That will eventually be recognised in the price. Buy the shares. Reed sounds a stronger note Crispin Davis's appointment as chief executive of Reed Elsevier may not have been greeted with universal acclaim but, a year on, the City is finally warming to his approach. Interim profit before tax may have fallen 4 per cent, after adjusting for things like currency and exceptional items, but that was because of increased investment on internet initiatives. The underlying picture was of a business which not only knows where it wants to go - something the old management was good at - but also has a plan to get there. There are new executives in key management positions (apart from finance director) and Davis appears to have tight control. The £750 million three-year internet investment programme announced in February is already bearing fruit. So far, £110m has been spent, rising to £260m by the year-end. Internet-generated sales reached £160m in the first six months of 2000, and are expected to be £400m for the whole year. The science division was the biggest beneficiary. But there are also signs that it has managed to stop the rot in the legal business, where it has launched a service for small firms and is establishing a good presence in universities. On cost control, it is likely to exceed the promised £130m savings this year, suggesting there was a lot more fat in the group than analysts realised. The only thing that really spooked the City was Davis's interest in US publisher Harcourt Brace, which is up for sale. But analysts take the view that Davis was expressing more a healthy interest in the affairs of its rivals than a serious intention to acquire. After a faltering start, Reed's shares have recovered strongly in the past two months. They may now pause for breath, but those prepared to wait for their rewards should buy now. Bolt from Colt is over the top The collapse in Colt Telecom's share price after Paul Chisholm, its president and chief executive, announced that he planned to spend more time with his family in the US, perfectly illustrates how illogical the City's attitude to technology stocks is. Colt Telecom is one of the more successful of the new generation of phone operators. It has done all it promised in establishing its European network, attracting large corporate customers and increasing its revenue. The number of buildings connected to its network in the second quarter of the year jumped by 68 per cent over last year, while the number of minutes switched rose by 138 per cent. Profits are, of course, still a rather distant prospect but at least it has funds - £2bn to be precise - which should be enough to get it into that position. Chisolm's departure is significant. He was the driving force behind the company's growth and will be missed. But he is hardly making a dash for the door with binbags full of trade secrets. Indeed, he is doing all he can to ensure an orderly succession: he will not finally depart for Boston until next year, and will stay on the board after a successor is appointed. But such high-flying companies are valued less on common sense than on sentiment. Any unexpected news is likely to move the price sharply. That does not make it logical, however. Compared with some of the internet upstarts, Colt is well established with a long pedigree. A new chief executive, backed by the existing management team, should be well equipped to carry the business forward. Investors have some cause to be worried about how Colt's business model will adapt in the face of rapidly changing telephone technology. The slump following Chisolm's departure looks overdone.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Hot off the press
fields.body:
Hot off the press

At United News & Media, Lord Hollick may have lost out in the battle to be king of ITV. But after the sale of its TV franchises to Granada for £1.75 billion, United's shares look distinctly undervalued.

At 845p, the shares are now trading on a price-earnings multiple of just 11 times - and that excludes the 260p per share due for the TV deal, the 35 per cent stake in Channel 5, LineOne and nest cash of some £300 million.

Ownership of the Express and Star newspapers may well be a drag on the shares, and on Hollick's attempts to reposition the group as a business-to-business (B2B) information provider. The Labour peer, however, intends to take United further into high-growth B2B publishing with ambitious internet spin-offs, and he now has the strong balance sheet to do it.

At broker WestLB Panmure leading media analyst Lorna Tilbian thinks there's now a rare buying opportunity following the slump in the shares after the collapse of United's merger with Carlton. Tilbian has a target price of 1,163p, which means United's now a buy.

Not plane sailing

Shares in Ryanair, the Irish discount airline, have had a barnstorming run this year, almost doubling so far in the new millennium. The June quarter results underlined the market's confidence, showing strong growth in line with expectations.

Even Ryanair's management, however, does not believe the current level of growth is sustainable for the rest of the year. At 547p, the airline is also now trading on a prospective price earnings ratio of 40 times, which is toppy for an airline indeed.

Broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney was bullish in June, when the stock stood at £5.90. Six weeks later, the shares have already reached their 12-month target price, so SSSB has downgraded from buy to hold. In other words, time to take profits for now.

Capita growth

Capita Group continues to reap benefits from increasing public sector contracting-out of services. And under New Labour there's no reason to believe the trend will go anywhere else but up.

True, on normal yardsticks, Capita's rating - over 90 times prospective earnings this year - is discounting one hell of a lot. But the market may grow twentyfold during the next decade and, barring scandals or hiccups, Capita looks set for 10 years of 20 per cent-plus earnings growth, according to City analysts.

In the first half, big new contracts worth £460m have already been won - a record level - and there is £750m of potential new business now in the pipeline. After recent weakness, the shares now stand at £16.37, and could well reach £20 in the near term, say Capita's fans.

Time up for ICI

Time to cut our losses, we think, at ICI. At 476p, the shares are near rock bottom, but this is no time for sentimentality. In November, with the shares at 642p, we said buy on any weakness, a call that was frankly wrong.

The reason: weak cashflow means the high debt burden continues and the dividend payout remains in doubt. True, ICI's restructured core businesses are growing, and there are possibly £1bn of disposals still to come.

Net debt, however, was £2.9bn - up £600m - at the halfway stage. That's high for the size of ICI's balance sheet, and the interest burden is still taking its toll.

The market had hoped that the dividend question would have been sorted out by this time, but ICI has now postponed the decision until the year-end. The continuing uncertainty is bound to weigh on the shares in the near term. Broker Old Mutual, for one, has lost patience and says the shares are a sell.

fields.headline: Success 'kills Emap dream'
fields.standfirst: The sudden sacking of a popular editor highlights claims of new management style at the media group, writes John Arlidge
fields.trailText: The Kir Royales were flowing at a celebration lunch at the Ivy restaurant in London when Andy Pemberton, editor of music magazine Q, got a message on his pager. 'Return to office immediately,' it beeped. Pemberton congratulated his production team on 'a good year of business together' and hurried out into the Covent Garden sunshine leaving his crème brlée untouched and his espresso to go cold.
fields.body:
The Kir Royales were flowing at a celebration lunch at the Ivy restaurant in London when Andy Pemberton, editor of music magazine Q, got a message on his pager. 'Return to office immediately,' it beeped. Pemberton congratulated his production team on 'a good year of business together' and hurried out into the Covent Garden sunshine leaving his crème brlée untouched and his espresso to go cold.

Back at the magazine's Oxford Street headquarters' Pemberton was summoned to a meeting with his boss, Dee Ford. Pemberton won't say what Ford told him and Ford is not talking either, but minutes later a white-faced Pemberton returned to his office, put a few personal belongings into a carrier bag and left the building. He has not been back since.

Pemberton's sacking has left staff at the music title reeling, and focused attention on a rising tide of discontent among staff at Emap, Q's owner. After months of internal turmoil, they say, the departure of the popular and talented editor marks the end of an era at Britain's leading magazine group, which publishes 150 titles including best-selling men's magazine FHM and entertainment weekly Heat .

Ever since Sir Richard Winfrey bought the Spalding Guardian in 1887 and Emap was born as East Midlands Allied Press, the company, has been 'different', staff say. Unlike other giant magazine companies - IPC or NatMags - the company was run by journalists for journalists. Managers wrote record reviews, signed articles and even did a little moonlighting on the sub-editors' desk. There was none of the 'them' and 'us' culture that characterises other publishers.

'The wages were never that great but that did not matter,' one former editor says. 'People worked there because they liked it. It was a good vibe. Most magazines that focus on music, glamour, showbiz, celebrity and style are not that glamorous to work for. In fact, they can be bloody awful. Emap magazines like Q and Empire never used to be like that. We saw them as pretty utopian - until now. Andy's sacking was like a terrorist murdering a hostage in front of a group of captives to demonstrate that they mean business.'

Pemberton's dismissal from Emap's flagship music title has left staff bitter. They claim he was the victim of a heavy-handed new management structure which is ignoring the company's key titles in favour of new media ventures. The company is now scarcely recognisable as the one they joined.

The change began, staff say, when Emap bought and and relaunched FHM , its rival to IPC's beer-and-babes mag, Loaded . It was a huge success, with sales of almost a million. From being a publisher of high-quality mags in niche markets - from music and cinema to motorcycle news and angling - Emap had broken into the big time.

'The company was blown away by the success of FHM and realised it could make its way into the mainstream and the money,' the former editor went on. 'Management thought it could boost profits by targeting new advertisers and readers who preferred pictures to text. The balance of the company suddenly changed. Nothing has been the same since.'

Insiders say that following the success of FHM, new management teams were installed and stopped nurturing the successful Q and Empire to concentrate on new media. 'Their successful titles were totally taken for granted,' says one. Key members of the magazines' original staff were sidelined, and new business methods introduced. Editors who were not presiding over rapidly rising circulations were sacked.

Pemberton fell foul of the new management style - and staff are wondering who will be next. 'We present this glossy glamorous image to the outside world, but the tactics of a tabloid newspaper have come in and are poisoning the atmosphere. Everyone is worried,' one staffer said.

Journalists say that with so many new managers, working out the company's strategy is almost impossible.

'There are so many new faces running the company now that it is hard to know who is doing what, and what the company's vision is,' says one. 'In the past everyone shared a love of the job and pretty much worked together.

'Now the company seems to be investing all its efforts into developing titles on the internet. From being choc full of people who loved magazines, it is full of marketing people and ad men who seem to want to turn everything into a lifestyle product because that will sell more ads for Caterpillar boots.

'People are massively disillusioned. They think they joined a magazine company, but the only thing everyone seems to be talking about is TV, radio and the internet. The core of the business is being forgotten.'

Andrew Collins, former editor of Q, who left to become a TV script writer, says: 'When I run into the people I used to work with it is incredible. They just moan all the time. They write about pop stars and movie stars but they have all become miserable bastards. I do not want to sound like some old fart bemoaning the passing of the good old days, but you have to remember that the sort of dramatic changes that have taken place have happened in just three years. In some ways, I suppose, it is a victim of its own success, but it is sad to see it going that way.'

Not surprisingly, executives at Emap, which has just launched a £250m, three-year investment programme, see things differently.

'In the past three years the company has grown significantly,' a spokesman said. 'It has expanded in the US has grown rapidly in France to become the number two consumer magazines publisher there. We have created Emap Digital to take our publications online. FHM is being launched in Germany and up to nine more countries, taking the overall total to 20. This is not the sign of a company looking back. We're moving forward.'

Recently reported figures show a 14 per cent rise in pretax profits to £184.3m, while total sales, benefiting from a first full-year contribution from Peterson, Emap's newly acquired US division, grew by 25 per cent to £1.1 billion.

The spokesman denied Emap was ignoring its key titles: 'Like any publisher we prize our content. If you go for something online, it has to have the right content. To suggest that we could go on line without getting the content right is daft. We value everyone who works for us and reads our magazines, listens to our radio stations or watches our TV channels.'

Taking titles into new areas of the media reflected Emap's desire to improve the performance of its magazines and establish them as increasingly powerful brands.

'We are creating brands that are focused on particular markets. To progress in the market you need mags, radio and websites so that you can go to an advertiser and tell them we can deliver a music market audience in the better than anyone else. Magazines like Q and Empire are still run for enthusiasts, but you have to grow the brand.'

webTitle: Bus profiteers abandon their grass routes

fields.headline: Bus profiteers abandon their grass routes
fields.standfirst:
Private operators are cashing in on city routes while leaving villages stranded, reports Joanna Walters

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Buses are disappearing from country lanes and suburbs as big operators focus on their most profitable routes, transport campaigners claimed this weekend.
fields.body:
Buses are disappearing from country lanes and suburbs as big operators focus on their most profitable routes, transport campaigners claimed this weekend.

In cities, private sector giants are investing heavily in state-of-the-art networks, while the Government is pumping in extra funding and relying on the humble bus to deliver many of the congestion- and pollution-busting benefits of its transport policy.

But passengers are alarmed that in some areas buses are becoming an endangered species. There are problems in areas as far apart as Glasgow and Gloucestershire, Cornwall and Cheshire and the taxpayer is having to pick up the cost of restoring services when private operators pull out in order to boost profits elsewhere.

The three biggest private companies, First Group, Stagecoach and Arriva, account for more than half the UK local bus market. David Redgewell, Somerset area campaigner for lobby group Transport 2000, says that over the next two months First Group is planning to eliminate 57 routes in Cornwall, Devon, Dorset and Somerset - such as Shepton Mallet to Wells, and Liskeard to Plymouth - and to close four depots and at least two ticket and information centres, in Bridport and Dorchester.

Redgewell acknowledges that bus services in such areas 'would never be profitable enough' to satisfy their private operators but argues that more should be done by operators to offer a comprehensive service. He called for an official passenger watchdog for buses to complement similar bodies in rail.

The Transport Bill is likely to be passed this autumn, giving powers for local authorities to hold bus operators to contracts offered across whole areas - obliging them to keep up service levels on secondary routes as well as the big urban centres. But after ferocious lobbying by the private sector, the 'Quality Contract' option is only to be used as a last resort, where looser arrangements based on partnerships have failed. Since deregulation in 1986, local authorities have no powers to tell bus companies when and where to operate, unless they are subsidising the services for social reasons.

Jonathan Bray of Transport 2000 says: 'The bus groups are doing whizzy things on main routes, making express networks and putting in new vehicles, but they are pulling out of the more marginal services, often in rural areas. If local authorities want to keep those services for the passengers, they then have to pay for them.'

Campaigners say Stagecoach has cut services in the Lake District and South Wales and reduced some frequencies around Greater Manchester and Middlesbrough. Arriva has cut a service running into Leicester city centre as well as routes in Bedfordshire. In a separate dispute over drivers' pay, it currently has no services in most of County Durham and parts of North Yorkshire on Fridays.

First Group, which has 23 per cent of the national market, comes in for the most criticism. The company is being hauled before the western regional traffic commissioner next month, accused of failing passengers in Bristol, Bath, Taunton, Weston-super-Mare, Yeovil and Bridgewater.

First Group is also under fire in Scotland for cutting services on the outskirts of Edinburgh and Glasgow in favour of extra investment in city centre, high-frequency networks. Jim Dunsmuir of Midlothian Council said his area had lost at least three services, while First Group poured cash into the four main transport corridors into Edinburgh city centre.

The company has also invested heavily in a comprehensive network serving Glasgow city centre, while withdrawing buses from some housing estates on the outskirts and further afield in North Lanarkshire.

Tom Harris, spokesman for the Strathclyde Passenger Transport Authority, said: 'We are sceptical about partnerships between bus companies and local authorities being effective without binding contracts behind them.'

Industry observers have found that when operators pull off commercial routes there are often no private-sector contenders to replace them. This is explained partly by the generally low cost of operation achieved by the big operators since privatisation and the consolidation within the industry that means the market leaders are dominant.

First Group defended its record and said only 1.5 per cent of its services were being altered in the South-West; all the routes it was leaving were loss-making, it added.

The House of Commons Transport Select Committee reported last year that bus operators were commonly pulling off commercial routes and then asking for subsidies to restore them, or putting up the prices of already subsidised services supplied to local authorities.

The Government has forecast a doubling of expenditure on local bus services over the next decade to around £4 billion, and predicts that the private sector will invest a matching amount. It forecasts a 10 per cent increase in passenger numbers from the current 4.3 billion.

The 1998 Budget allocated an extra £150 million for improvements to rural public transport, particularly bus services, which has boosted more than 1,500 services across the country. The Government is now in the process of changing the rules for rural subsidy so that market towns are able to get more support for struggling bus services.

But the committee reported that commercial groups were increasingly less willing to cross-subsidise between lucrative routes and more marginal services across their networks, leading to 'cherry-picking' of the most profitable journeys. On the other hand, bus operators have faced soaring costs in the past two years and defenders of the companies say this has made hundreds of routes which were barely profitable now unviable.

Wage costs have risen as badly paid drivers have been able to demand improved pay in a tightening labour market and rebates on fuel duty have not kept up with rising prices.

Chris Cheek, of independent consultancy TAS, said: 'The industry has got to concentrate on what it can do best, deliver good services in urban areas. It is always going to be difficult to improve rural services without support from the Government and local authorities.'

The company has also invested heavily in a comprehensive network serving Glasgow city centre, while withdrawing buses from some housing estates on the outskirts and further afield in North Lanarkshire. Tom Harris, spokesman for the Strathclyde Passenger Transport Authority, said: 'We are sceptical about partnerships between bus companies and local authorities being effective without binding contracts behind them.' Industry observers have found that when operators pull off commercial routes there are often no private-sector contenders to replace them. This is explained partly by the generally low cost of operation achieved by the big operators since privatisation and the consolidation within the industry that means the market leaders are dominant. First Group defended its record and said only 1.5 per cent of its services were being altered in the South-West; all the routes it was leaving were loss-making, it added. The House of Commons Transport Select Committee reported last year that bus operators were commonly pulling off commercial routes and then asking for subsidies to restore them, or putting up the prices of already subsidised services supplied to local authorities. The Government has forecast a doubling of expenditure on local bus services over the next decade to around £4 billion, and predicts that the private sector will invest a matching amount. It forecasts a 10 per cent increase in passenger numbers from the current 4.3 billion. The 1998 Budget allocated an extra £150 million for improvements to rural public transport, particularly bus services, which has boosted more than 1,500 services across the country. The Government is now in the process of changing the rules for rural subsidy so that market towns are able to get more support for struggling bus services. But the committee reported that commercial groups were increasingly less willing to cross-subsidise between lucrative routes and more marginal services across their networks, leading to 'cherry-picking' of the most profitable journeys. On the other hand, bus operators have faced soaring costs in the past two years and defenders of the companies say this has made hundreds of routes which were barely profitable now unviable. Wage costs have risen as badly paid drivers have been able to demand improved pay in a tightening labour market and rebates on fuel duty have not kept up with rising prices. Chris Cheek, of independent consultancy TAS, said: 'The industry has got to concentrate on what it can do best, deliver good services in urban areas. It is always going to be difficult to improve rural services without support from the Government and local authorities.'

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Ronson in £200m property sell-off

Property tycoon Gerald Ronson, who in 1990 served a six-month sentence for his part in the Guinness insider-dealing scandal, has sold central London office properties worth £200m.

Ronson, whose company Heron International is backed by some of the world's richest individuals, including Bill Gates of Microsoft and Rupert Murdoch, is taking advantage of a rising West End office market. Rents have now reached record levels, which makes his buildings more valuable to buyers.

The 60-year-old Heron chief executive has in the past fortnight sold offices in the Strand, Tottenham Court Road and in the City of London.

Small firms ignore new pensions

More than half of small employers could be at risk of breaking the law in failing to offer their staff the new low-cost stakeholder pension

In a survey of 400 small and medium-sized businesses, carried out for Britannic Assurance by NOP, only 46 per cent of companies said they planned to offer the pensions, mainly aimed at those earning between £9,500 and £21,600. It is compulsory for all but the smallest to do so by October next year unless they already have other employee pension schemes in place.

Citizens' (financial) advice

People on low incomes may soon have access to free independent investment advice through Citizens' advice bureaux .

Discussions about setting up a service are under way between the National Association of Citizens' Advice Bureaux (Nacab), the Society of Financial Advisers, which represents 9000 independent advisers, and the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds .

Many people who need, for example, pension advice cannot afford to see a financial adviser: many of them charge more than £150 an hour, and some as much as £250 for financial planning consultations. The alternative is a salesman who may earn large amounts of commission.

Wrap up your investment trust

Investment trust companies are considering plans to boost sales by allowing independent advisers to offer any investment trust under a generic 'wrapper,' using a fixed fee and commission structure .

The industry's umbrella body, the Association of Investment Trust Companies (AITC), believes this would help investment trusts take a greater share of investment money through products such as individual savings accounts. Currently 70 per cent of the funds invested in these vehicles goes into unit trusts.

The AITC will make a decision in October and, if the plan is approved, the product could be available by the end of the year.

Sell-off for Frankfurt Airport

Frankfurt Airport is set to be partially privatised in a move that could trigger sell-offs of other major European airports in the next 12 months.

The German airport is weighing up potential advisers in London and on the Continent. The federal and regional governments that hold stakes in Frankfurt Airport are likely to issue new shares on the German stock market next year.

Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport is also planning a part sell-off, as is Zurich.

Observers believe that the successful part-privatisation of Air France could eventually persuade the French state to sell off Paris's Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports.

fields.headline: Maggie Hyde's company futures
fields.trailText: Saturn entered Gemini last Thursday, and over the next two years opposition from Jupiter and Saturn to Pluto, in Gemini and Sagittarius, promise a sea-change in publishing and media.
fields.body:
Saturn entered Gemini last Thursday, and over the next two years opposition from Jupiter and Saturn to Pluto, in Gemini and Sagittarius, promise a sea-change in publishing and media. Riding this wave is IPC, with its spread of glossies from Marie Claire to Golf Monthly. Since the management buyout in 1998, the company has carried a half billion debt and was recently outbid for Gruner and Jahr's UK titles. How does this show in the stars?

IPC dates back to Newne's, publisher of Titbits and Sherlock Holmes , reflecting a Scorpio Moon. It is a royal Leo (5/8/1897), resplendent in its South Bank palace, Kings Reach Towers. Communicative Gemini rises, with powerful Pluto, planet of transformation, on the Ascendant. Pluto's half-cycle, from January 2001, shows major reconstruction. Its name change from IPC Magazines to IPC Media is the first step in a new strategy, focusing away from magazines and on to media brands with different platforms (print, web, wap).

The horoscope shows dizzying activity in the coming year. Steering the ship is CEO Sly Bailey, a cool, rational Aquarian with a dose of practical earth. Next spring, radical Uranus triggers her Mercury, indicating ingenuity and e-commerce. Even before then, IPC could excite the City and go for a float. Catalyst periods occur in May 2001 and May 2002. Success looks assured, provided that IPC does not lose sight of what it does best. Beyond the multi-platform rebranding hype, the mag in the bag still comes first.

fields.headline: Watch out for...
fields.standfirst: ...WPP
fields.trailText: Expect to be deafened tomorrow by the sound of champagne corks popping when WPP, the world's biggest advertising group after its acquisition of US agency Young & Rubicam, posts its first-half results.
fields.body:
Expect to be deafened tomorrow by the sound of champagne corks popping when WPP, the world's biggest advertising group after its acquisition of US agency Young & Rubicam, posts its first-half results.

These are heady days for our dear, creative friends in adland. Against a backdrop of a sustained economic boom, dotcom businesses with more money than sense are filling the agencies' coffers. Add the upcoming Olympics and the US presidential election and we are talking euphoria.

Expect to see WPP's pre-tax profits leap from £112 million to around £135m. Revenues should be up £180m to £1.2 billion, while earnings per share should increase to 11.7p from 9.8p.

Analysts will expect signs that WPP, whose clients include Ford, is on track to meet its target of an operating profit of 14 per cent. They will also want a progress report on its takeover of £3.2bn Y & R, which is in the hands of regulatory authorities.

This deal should be completed in the next month, with WPP controlling two-thirds of the merged outfit.

It would be interesting to know whether WPP chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell sees an end to the good times.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Pile them in and flog them stuff

fields.headline: Pile them in and flog them stuff
fields.trailText: It was heartwarming to hear Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, talk about sitting around the table with his customers while they sign up for one of his mortgages.
fields.body:
It was heartwarming to hear Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, talk about sitting around the table with his customers while they sign up for one of his mortgages.

Financial services deals used to be all about getting more customers and dreaming up more sophisticated products to flog them through mailshots. And if that failed, as inevitably it did, swingeing cost cuts were usually enough to make it look like a successful deal. Think Abbey National and National & Provincial, or Lloyds and TSB.

These days, financial services companies are a little more sophisticated. They are realising that, as competition intensifies, the cost of winning new customers is soaring. And there is no point in attracting new customers when the ones you have paid so much to acquire aren't buying anything from you.

The attention has therefore switched from cost cutting and customer generation to product sales and revenue enhancement.

So Barclays is paying £5.4 billion for Woolwich not because the former building society has succeeded in attracting 290,000 customers to its Open Plan account (which combines savings and borrowings) in a matter of months, but because all these customers are buying an average of three products each. Surely, Barrett reckons, if these customers can be persuaded to take out that many Woolwich products, they must be a surefire bet for a Barclaycard and a couple of income protection plans as well. And he can use Woolwich's salesmanship to persuade some of his more well-heeled customers to take out a mortgage or savings account with them.

Cynics might interpret Woolwich chief executive John Stewart's eagerness to agree a deal with Barclays when his shares were close to their all-time low as a sign of the strength of his faith in Open Plan to transform the fortunes of the Woolwich.

And they may not share Barrett's faith that those Woolwich customers would buy more products if the bank could just get them round the table. They may even see the lack of interest among consumers as a sign that, actually, the customers did not want them, did not need them, already had them and were heartily sick of chucking away mailshots aimed at flogging even more of them.

It is certainly true that the winners in financial services, as in any other business, will be the ones who manage to sell more products to more people. The key to that is producing products people want to buy, at an attractive price - and offering good service.

Open Plan looks like a good attempt at providing that but, given that it was little more than a glimmer in Stewart's eye even six months ago, it is impossible to gauge how successful it will be.

Barrett's first deal at Barclays may prove to be one of the bank's best. He certainly needs a success. Just as likely, however, is that Stewart will be the only one to emerge laughing. Not only did he manage to persuade Barclays to pay an attractive premium in a falling market, he has also put himself in pole position to succeed Barrett should he fail.

The bank of Japan may have done its utmost to warn of an impending rise in interest rates, but that did not lessen the shock when it finally happened, particularly given the Ministry of Finance's request to keep them on hold.

The best that could be said about the decision is that it may persuade Japanese consumers that the recovery is on track.

What is more likely, however, is that it will jeopardise that recovery, which is already fragile. Rates of 0.25 per cent may still seem low but, for small and medium-sized service and property companies struggling under the burden of massive debts, it could tip the balance.

The collapse of the Sogo retail group was welcomed, partly because it had a negligible impact on employment. The effect of bankruptcies elsewhere in the economy would be far less benign.

The Bank of Japan could yet regret its precipitate move.

webTitle: Skanska set to bid for UK building firm

fields.headline: Skanska set to bid for UK building firm
fields.trailText: Skanska, the Swedish construction giant, is preparing to bid for a major UK building firm in a move that confirms the growing pressure for construction firms to consolidate.
fields.body:
Skanska, the Swedish construction giant, is preparing to bid for a major UK building firm in a move that confirms the growing pressure for construction firms to consolidate.

Skanska, which in the past two weeks has bought building groups in the US and the Czech Republic, told The Observer that it has a £1 billion war chest and is hoping to strike a deal soon.

'We've always regarded the UK as an attractive market,' said Peter Wallin, Skanska's head of investor relations. 'Over the past two years, we have approached a couple of companies, but it's been hard to reach deals even though the price of the sector has slumped. The UK still is interesting to us, though, and we would like to agree something soon.'

It is understood that Skanska's preferred targets are Balfour Beatty, Carillion and, possibly, Amec.

Industry analysts believe Skanska, which last year turned over £8 billion and employs 60,000 people worldwide, is more likely to bid for Carillion. 'I see a bid of between 180p and 190p appealing to management,' one said. Such a bid would value Carillion at £400 million.

Skanska has positioned itself to become one of the world's biggest construction firms. It has sold most of its non-core assets, including a chunk of UK property, and has virtually no debt.

Shares in Britain's major building groups companies rose over the past month following Chancellor Gordon Brown's Comprehensive Spending Review.

Since 18 July Amec has risen 40 per cent, Laing is up 25 per cent, while Balfour Beatty has risen 20 per cent.

Brown's £43bn windfall means that growth in the construction sector is set to double to 3 per cent.

The global construction industry is in the midst of consolidation. The takeover frenzy has been sparked by customers rapidly slashing their list of contractors and giving performance incentives to those that remain, in a bid to match the efficiency gained by the rationalisation in most sectors.

Already this year Amec has bought Canadian project management firm Agra for £220m. Last month, Vinci, the construction arm of Vivendi, agreed a deal for Groupe GTM, making it the biggest European construction company. And Bouygues, the sector leader until Vinci's announcement, has bought up all the remaining shares in Colas, its road-building arm.

Blue Circle, Britain's biggest cement producer, last May narrowly fought off a hostile takeover bid by French group Lafarge.
