fields.headline: Racism, throat cancer and genocide... thankfully, nothing is sacred
fields.trailText: Scott Capurro | Omid Djalili | A Lump in My Throat | A Man of Substance in a World of Filth | Jeff Innocent
fields.body:
Scott Capurro (Pleasance)

Omid Djalili (Pleasance)

A Lump in My Throat (Assembly)

A Man of Substance in a World of Filth (Gilded Balloon)

Jeff Innocent (Pleasance)

Is nothing sacred? Er, no. There are still people who believe racism, child abuse and throat cancer are unsuitable subjects for comedy, yet in the space of a week I've laughed at lines about all of them. I didn't feel terrible afterwards, either. Scott Capurro has provoked mass walk-outs from his show with a gag which climaxes in the phrase 'Holocaust schmolocaust', but the people who thought this line beyond the pale were still outnumbered by those who sat there laughing. I would argue strongly that it's not intrinsically inappropriate or offensive to make people laugh at the darkest aspects of life and society. It's just really, really difficult.

There are various ways of attacking this problem, from Capurro's head-on provocation to the subtle, soft-soap charms of Omid Djalili, whose claim to fame used to be that he was 'the only Iranian comedian in the world'. Now there are two others, so his new unique selling point is that he's the only Iranian comedian in the world with a burgeoning Hollywood career (he sold Russell Crowe to Oliver Reed in Gladiator ), a plummy English accent (he was educated at Queen's, Belfast), and the ability to mimic middle-class women with two kids and a Range Rover fighting their way through a Waitrose car park.

'Out of my way, out of my way!' he shrieks with a face like a nun in a brothel, and 60 audience members howl with laughter. The sixty-first member of the audience sits pale-faced and tense, gripping the keys to her Range Rover. But not to worry, for a minute later she is grinning again. Djalili has no wish to offend anyone: he is, as he tells us from the outset in the thick Middle Eastern accent of a Bond villain, a 'crowd-pleaser', whose often pointed observations are always softened by his trademark 'winning smile'.

As with the young Lenny Henry, every serious racial point in his show is immediately undercut. Yet the point remains made. 'If you laugh at an ethnic comedian,' he says, 'you warm to his culture. So by the end of the night you'll be feeling very warm towards Islamic fundamentalism.' Djalili's strategy is to blow you away with a blizzard of gags, identities, accents and funny faces, as if to settle on one form of comedy for more than a minute would be to invite his worst enemy - boredom. The downside of this is obviously an inability to develop something slower and more thoughtful, but when you're a short, pudgy Iranian playing clubs full of drunken bigots, this is not the kind of activity you get much chance to practise. His reponse to hecklers who call him an 'Arab twat' is, he reveals, to reply: 'Thank you for reaffirming my identity.'

A Lump In My Throat has at its core another likeable man (journalist and author John Diamond) and a similar determination to prove that comedy is, like an inverted Yellow Pages, not just there for the happy things in life. This is a shorter, rawer version of the show that played in London earlier this year to rave reviews.

Most people in the first-night audience were Diamond fans, but it's not compulsory. Even if you don't like the columns, condensed into an hour they gain a new intensity. Performed by the charmingly downbeat Robert Katz, the evening starts off light and darkens deeply as the evening (and the cancer) progresses, but even at the end there are still cathartic laughs.

One of the most notable trends this year has been the increasingly blurred line between comic theatre and stand-up, and the most interesting shows often exist somewhere in that blur. A Man of Substance in a World of Filth is a one-man character monologue which keeps bursting into improvised interactions with the audience. Written and performed by the gawky, dynamic Andrew Clover, it is fairly unhinged, but never dull.

Clover plays a scholar of eighteenth-century literature who believes himself to be the reincarnation of Jonathan Swift, and who has a peculiarly intense relationship with his mother. Barking and braying, he takes us through his eccen tric life, family and self-made porn collection. Then he strips butt naked, prances around while making a deranged final speech, and runs off to a standing ovation.

Of course, not every comedy show at Edinburgh can be intelligent, lively and thought-provoking. There are plenty of chancers and idiots here to spoil the fun, and some of them are getting five-star reviews in other papers. One such is Jeff Innocent, a man whose musclebound suit and shaven, steel-lined head give you a fair indication of his life and material. He grew up in east London, got involved in crime, went to prison, and has come out the other end of the system a successful stand-up comedian.

In many ways this is an inspiring story, and you certainly couldn't accuse Innocent of glamorising violent psychopaths (unlike, say, most of the British media). There's nothing 'offensive' about him at all, in fact. Yet his rise is still deeply depressing. Because he is clearly not a natural stand-up: his style is an achingly competent, join-the-dots variety, every bog-standard gag and painfully timed facial gesture seemingly learnt at an evening course taught by Jim Davidson. Taboo schmaboo - in comedy, nothing is more offensive than a mediocre performer telling banal jokes.

One such is Jeff Innocent, a man whose musclebound suit and shaven, steel-lined head give you a fair indication of his life and material. He grew up in east London, got involved in crime, went to prison, and has come out the other end of the system a successful stand-up comedian. In many ways this is an inspiring story, and you certainly couldn't accuse Innocent of glamorising violent psychopaths (unlike, say, most of the British media). There's nothing 'offensive' about him at all, in fact. Yet his rise is still deeply depressing. Because he is clearly not a natural stand-up: his style is an achingly competent, join-the-dots variety, every bog-standard gag and painfully timed facial gesture seemingly learnt at an evening course taught by Jim Davidson. Taboo schmaboo - in comedy, nothing is more offensive than a mediocre performer telling banal jokes.

fields.headline: Behind the scenes...
fields.standfirst: It took the Whitbread Prize-winning novelist  Kate Atkinson four years to turn herself into a playwright.This is her diary
fields.trailText: It took the Whitbread Prize-winning novelist  Kate Atkinson four years to turn herself into a playwright.This is her diary.
fields.body:
June 1996
I'm encouraged by director John Tiffany to write a very short play called Nice for the Traverse Theatre. As a result of this I'm given a commission to write a longer, grown-up play - and yes, from 1996 to 2000 does seem rather a long time to have had a commission and not produced a play but it is 'one big lateness in this house', as a character in the play remarks irritably.

All I know about the play in its embryonic stage is that it's set in one room and there's a ghost. But, most importantly for me (because I cannot write without one), it has a title - Abandonment. So all you have to do now is write it, J.T. says. Yes indeed, that's all.

November
Write the first draft of Abandonment. Complain to J.T. that it's all dialogue and dialogue isn't something I really do . Well it is now,he responds, a mite testily. I think fondly of Slava's Snowshow in which there is no dialogue at all, but, sadly, I am not not writing a play with a part for a Russian existentialist clown.

1997-1998
Spend a year trying - and failing - to write the next novel. Give up and write second draft of Abandonment . Begin to get the hang of dialogue. No longer yearn for pages of descriptive writing but am still finding it very hard to eradicate speech indicators ('remarks irritably', 'responds a mite testily' and so on.) Adverbs are a particular loss. How on earth will the actors know how this naked speech is to be played? Trust them, J.T. advises (with quite a few adverbs). And how will we ever get by without helpful little signposts for the audience indicating 'this is funny' (and conversely, and perhaps more importantly, 'this is not funny')?

Write a third draft, still hanging on to all those lengthy stage directions that make directors despair - 'She looks up with interested expression on her face' or 'Exits to kitchen carry ing plates, cutlery, glasses, etc'. The play is going through its 'postmodern' stage, deconstructing all over the place, actors aware they're actors in a play and so on. Gently coaxed out of this (thank goodness).

1998
Abandon Abandonment and return to writing Emotionally Weird which, under the influence of the play, is suddenly full of dialogue.

1999
Finally finish Emotionally Weird. Write fourth draft of Abandonment.

February 2000
Workshop the play. Can't get over the novelty of actors speaking words that have been two-dimensional for so long.

April
Fifth draft. Finally eliminate all those stage directions.

May
Start casting. Leave some of the casting rather late and make one actress read the script and give us an answer the day before she gets married. Are we sympathetic? No. Casting makes you strangely ruthless. Finally we have our complete cast, every one a diamond - James Cunningham, Michelle Gomez, Kathryn Howden, Patricia Kerrigan, Neil McKinven, Sheila Redi, Elaine C. Smith.

June
See the model of the set for the first time. Designer Georgia Sion has made an exquisitely detailed claustrophobic doll's-house room - a round Victorian sitting room that must serve as both the past and the present, a panoramic curve that moves from order into disintegration, from reality to facsimile.

Start rehearsals, sitting round a table for the week going through the script with the actors, the result of which is the sixth draft which we rehearse for the next three weeks.

A word in praise of actors - apart from being intelligent and resourceful and brave and all that stuff - they never show that they're bored. Perhaps they aren't but I would be if I had to keep saying the same thing again and again (especially when I might not actually like what I was saying) each time finding a different nuance, a different place to go.

July
Technical rehearsal. Two long days' tech, 14 hours back to back, and the first time we've seen the completed set. Feel as if I've shrunk inside the model. The window, big on the model, enormous in reality, looks out on a cloudy backcloth of galactic nebulae, the kind of view you see from the bridge of the Starship Enterprise. 'You've not got much of a view, have you,' the mother in the play says. A half-empty kind of person, clearly.

This is the first time that the actresses who wear crinolines get to try them on, and suddenly walking and talking becomes amazingly difficult. You could hide a flock of goats and a small garden centre beneath Elaine C. Smith's dress. And where did all that eating and drinking come from? It's non-stop - 'Exits to kitchen carrying plates, cutlery, glasses, etc' may have disappeared as a stage direction but it exists now as a nerve-racking reality. If I ever write another play there will be no eating and drinking and everyone will wear chitons.

11 July
Previews begin. First preview night the audience seem as nervous as the actors. They laugh uproariously at a scene we had always thought of as tragic. I want back those little signposts saying 'this is not funny'. By the end of six previews we have grown to accept that the audience will always laugh at this particular scene.

17 July
A week's holiday so that it seems as if the play has finished after an incredibly short but reasonably successful run.

25 July
Back into rehearsals with a final draft. I am stuck with publicity. Sneak off and buy something gorgeous for the gala performance we're going to have on the last night. Am feeling very pleased with this glamorous acquisition but when I return home I have to face the Sewage Crisis - a monsoon downpour that caused the main sewer to back up. The main sewer, needless to say, runs under my house and garden, and I spend the next 24 hours cleaning other people's excrement off my patio. The puritan in me feels this must be good for me but I'm not sure how or why.

3 August
Press night. All this time and suddenly we're there. The Traverse is so full of flowers for the actors it looks like a funeral home. ('Or the botanical gardens,' as a more cheerful half-full sort of person says.) No one forgets their lines and (more importantly in my book) no one falls over. Audiences love the play, critics somewhat less so (it was ever thus).

7 August
Reviews. The good, the bad and the ugly. (And let's not forget the misogynistic and vitriolic). There are many reasons why I've never expected good reviews. For one, I have crossed genres and no one likes that ('Novelist writes play - must be bad'). Then there's that curiously British form of intellectual snobbery which proposes that if you're popular you can't be good, if you sell you must have sold out. This is insulting to readers and audiences alike. Just yesterday in the Scotsman a 'leading Scottish writer' was telling his fellow writers that if they wanted to sell books they would have to 'lower their standards'.

Plus, it's a very busy play, a lot of plot and action ('an overstuffed trunk', 'over-egged pudding'. Thank you.) But that's the kind of writer I am and, just as I don't like spare, thin novels, I don't like spare, thin plays (and neither do audiences). And of course, if you write a play with a lot of women in it, then it's a 'woman's play'. Write a play with men in it and it's just a play. Go figure.

Nevertheless, in case I sound like a totally empty-glass person, we do have some very lovely reviews and I am particularly taken by Michael Billington's encouraging comment that I 'have arrived at theatrical customs with a huge amount to declare' (even if it's with that somewhat overstuffed trunk).

We have done what we set out to do, which was to write a complex, opulent and entertaining play about identity and loss. And it's been a wonderful experience, the bitchiness and jealousy far outweighed by the love and creativity and companionship of a wonderful company. And working in the theatre has felt like coming home for me. At last.

Read Susannah Clapp's review of Adandonment here

fields.trailText: Our critics' choice  for this week
fields.body:
Music by Fiona Maddocks

Mozart piano concertos Christian Zacharias begins his complete cycle of Mozart Piano Concertos, as soloist and director, with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra. Usher Hall

Music of the millennium One of the best series in this year's festival opens tomorrow with eleventh-century Bruno of Toul sung by Gothic Voices , who move on to Hildegard of Bingen on Wednesday. Sequentia perform Music of the French Court on Friday. Various venues

Clevelsnd Orchestra In their only UK appearance this year, the Cleveland Orchestra gives the opening concert this evening of Berlioz's The Damnation of Faust Usher Hall

Steven Osborne This formidable pianist plays Messiaen's Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant Jesus. Highly recommended. Queen's Hall

Alcina The Stuttgart State Opera brings Handel to the festival, conducted by Alan Hacker, directed by Jossi Wieler and Sergio Morabito. In Italian with supertitles. Festival Theatre

Theatre by Susannah Clapp

Thunderstruck The Canadian group One Yellow Rabbit show what happens when lightning kills the parents of three backwoods brothers and their 'somnambulant but magically glowing' sister. Traverse

Barbaric Comedies Ramón del Valle-Inclán wrote it; McGuinness translated it; Calixto Bieito directs; the Abbey Theatre perform. King's Theatre

Picasso's women Four one-woman plays by Brian McAvera star Toyah Willcox, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Amanda Harris and Susannah York. Assembly Rooms

Don Juan Molière's play is directed - with dancing - by the acclaimed Swedish director Mats Ek. Royal Lyceum

Decky Does a Bronco Grid Iron swing in the park. Scotland Yard Playground, George V Park

Comedy by Sam Taylor

Otis Lee Crenshaw Rich Hall's ex-con country singer reaches a new peak of comic and musical brilliance. A sublime live experience. Pleasance

Dave Gorman In which our hero travels the world to find 25 other Dave Gormans and shake hands with them for a photograph. Insanely inspired. Pleasance

Paul Zerdin Yes, ventriloquists can be funny too. Zerdin may seem bland, but his puppets are sharp-tongued, malicious little bastards. Avoid the front row, especially if you're ugly. Gilded Balloon

Noble & Silver The next generation of comedy: desiccated, abstract, dominated by multimedia and inspired by Chris Morris. Lots of people will say it's just not funny . They'll be wrong. Gilded Balloon

Film by Burhan Wazir

Max Ophuls Comprehensive retrospective of the influential Ophuls, who settled in Hollywood in 1941 after fleeing Germany. Incorporates two career highlights - Caught , starring James Mason, and his last masterpiece, Lola Montes . Filmhouse

Dancer in the Dark Lars von Trier's Palme d'Or winner kicks off the festival. Björk's portrayal of a young émigré lost in America has already won rave reviews. ABC1

Keeping the Faith The directorial debut of Edward Norton is a New York comedy reminiscent of Woody Allen at his most accomplished. Ben Stiller, Anne Bancroft and Milos Forman star. ABC1

O Brother, Where Art Thou? A glorious ensemble cast - George Clooney, John Turturro, John Goodman - provide the laughs in the Coen duo's take on the Deep South. Filmhouse 1

Dark Days Inspired documentary following director Marc Singer's attempts to chronicle the lives of New York's underground homeless communities. Extraordinarily compassionate, Singer's debut arrives with all the hallmarks of another recent great American documentary, Hoop Dreams. Cameo

Websites

The International Festival
The Fringe
The Film Festival
Gilded Balloon

International Festival box office: 0131 473 2000
Fringe box office: 0131 226 5138

webTitle: The first time... I was bullied

fields.headline: ... I was bullied
fields.standfirst: She made my life hell. And after 35 years, I still dream of her. Nicci Gerrard introduces a new summer series of firsts for Observer writers.
fields.trailText: ... I was bullied. Nicci Gerrard introduces a new summer series of firsts for Observer writers.
fields.body:
I was six. Her name was Jane. She probably has no shred of memory of me, but I do of her. On some nights, she still rears out at me in my dreams. I remember her as huge, though she was only nine or 10, with loose, oily curls, a blunt nose, rosy cheeks, a big white merry smile, a hearty laugh. She towers over me still, 35 years later.

There I am, small and shrinking; wanting the ground to open so I can disappear, taking my shame with me. For the fear of all people who have been bullied is that the bully has seen something in them, sniffed out the invisible stain like a dog. She didn't pick on anyone else. She didn't pick on the girl with thick glasses, or the fat boy, or the class cry-baby or the one who still wet her knickers in moments of emotion. She picked on me.

Jane was a prefect in the junior school. Teachers liked her. She had a group of friends whom she walked around with at break, arm in arm, skirts hoiked up above the knee, strong, gleaming legs in short white socks. She was sent to sit with our class while we did our 'silent reading' several times a week. Here, she became my tormentor. She would tell everyone they could talk, except me. I had to sit silent amid the chatter. Then she'd tell them all to be silent, except me. I was now allowed to talk; I had to talk although no one was allowed to say anything back, or even look at me.

When my unanswered words dried up, she would put me in the corner and get my best friend (Rosemary Leeming, with long blonde plaits) to stand behind me with a ruler. If I turned round, Rosemary had to whack me. Can this be true, I wonder to myself now, or is this some gothic memory I've produced out of a calm and sunny childhood? Jane made us all write our names on the blackboard. When I spelled out N-I-C-C-I, she would jeer that I didn't know how to spell my name, what a baby! She made me spell it the more ordinary way: N-I-C-K-Y. She took away my own name. I had always been rather a confident child, a show-off and a flirt. Yet with what ease she saw beneath the surface.

Of course, I didn't tell on Jane. I lay awake in bed at night with my secret, which blossomed in the darkness. I don't know how long it went on - perhaps not many weeks, after all. I had always loved school, but I started wanting to stay at home. How did it end? I can't remember. Perhaps I eventually broke down and 'confessed' to my parents. Perhaps my friends mentioned it to theirs. At any rate, the secret came out. I know that because one afternoon at home, the telephone rang and it was Jane, calling to apologise. Her voice was strained. She sounded as if she had been crying but I didn't believe that. Wolves don't cry. I pretended I couldn't hear what she was saying. She shouted sorry, louder and louder, sorry sorry sorry, and in the end she put the phone down. And strangely, I never recall even seeing her again, let alone being persecuted by her. She must have still been at school, striding round the playground with her friends, but I don't remember it. For me, her power had been taken away and she simply disappeared.

I've been bullied since then, in milder forms. Picked on, excluded, like we all have - that little whispering knot of girls who snicker and fall silent when you approach. And I've watched other people being bullied, and some times I've tried to intervene, and other times I've let it happen, knowing my own timidity. Now I have four children of my own, and sometimes they have been bullied and, of course, that is the worst of all - thinking of them with their Janes, imagining them being eager and obedient with them.

I saw a boy at my son's school being knocked around the other day - a group of children set upon him, laughing and intent. In the few moments before I intervened, I saw the way the boy lifted his arm up in a gesture of appeal, and how his face twisted with fear and shame, trying so hard not to cry. It made me feel sick at heart for him, that expression, that was almost like a smile. Children love to belong and will do almost anything not to be excluded. They learn to conform. They mock the ones who stick out. Children will do almost anything not to be bullied; they'll let it happen to others, just so it is not them. They will become the bully themselves, just so they are not the bully's victim. Difference is dangerous. Cowardice makes us cruel. A Jane in all of us.

They mock the ones who stick out. Children will do almost anything not to be bullied; they'll let it happen to others, just so it is not them. fields.headline: Spencer's oxyacetylene angels
fields.standfirst: In the 1940s Stanley Spencer visited Port Glasgow as an official war artist to depict life in the shipyards where he portrayed the workers not as men of steel, but homely gents in Fair Isle sweaters
fields.trailText: In the 1940s Stanley Spencer visited Port Glasgow as an official war artist to depict life in the shipyards where he portrayed the workers not as men of steel, but homely gents in Fair Isle sweaters.
fields.body:
Men of the Clyde: Stanley Spencer's Vision at Port Glasgow Scottish National Portrait Gallery, to 1 October

Dalí's Optical Illusions Dean Gallery, to 1 October

Jon Schueler Ingleby Gallery, to 10 September

Stanley is back. We last saw him on stage at the National Theatre as the Man Who Carried His Paints in a Pram, played by Antony Sher in schoolboy fringe and Fair Isle sweater. Now Stanley Spencer can be seen for real in a rare film on show at the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.

It is 1943. He is an official war artist, sent to document the shipyards of Port Glasgow on the Clyde. His fringe is harried by the east-coast wind. His jersey looks quite inadequate. There he stands, struggling to keep his drawings secure, a tiny Alan Bennett surrounded by mighty shipbuilders.

Not that Spencer painted them that way: his workers are hardly heroic. There are eight friezes in the Port Glasgow cycle, each crammed with figures absorbed in the task of hammering, hauling, soldering and riveting the disparate parts of a gigantic ship. Many hundreds of workers, yet not a single man of steel among them - not one Achilles or Ajax to dismay the enemy, as the War Artists' Committee advised. Diego Rivera would have cast them as patriotic champions, blue-denimed fighters for freedom. Stanley Spencer painted the builders as homely gents in mufflers, cloth caps, herringbone breeks and, of course, Fair Isle sweaters.

This doesn't make the paintings anti-propagandist - there isn't a smutch of grease or sweat on these faces. Nor is there any sense of the fraught industrial relations at Port Glasgow, or the future of these ships as floating graveyards for the war-dead. What fascinates Spencer is the very thing that absorbs his subjects - a nice bit of craftsmanship. That's as likely to be the cobbling in a boot or the knitting in a waistcoat as the joinery of the worker who wears them. Devotion outweighs purpose. Spencer thought the shipbuilders were like the angels in Paradise Lost - it wasn't their usual job, but sometimes they were forced to bombard Satan's army with rocks.

What Spencer made of these figures is itself a religious revelation, oxyacetylene angels on the upper tier, scenes from the Bible below. It is by far the most complicated drama he ever painted and the Portrait Gallery has displayed it to perfection. For the first time, the friezes are hung as Spencer intended - the long, narrow panels, sometimes six metres in length, configured around a central altarpiece like the cycles in a medieval chapel.

So you see that some of the carpenters are building an ark, its giant, fish shape doubling as Jonah's whale. Or that the men pulling on guy ropes recall the Raising of the Cross, while the women, with their shroud-like sails, are enacting the Deposition. There is no Christ, just as there is no final image of the ship. But in the altarpiece a team of apostles draws a white-hot bolt from the furnace, shielding their eyes against the supernatural light. This Jerusalem-on-Clyde is both ancient and modern, quoting from Giotto and Mantegna while marrying man and machine with near-futurist dynamics. Men with blowtorches are hoisted high like spacemen, rotating in the shipyard darkness. Welders peer down through their visors as if seeing the earth below, their bodies transfigured with otherworldly brightness.

The Man with the Pram paints himself into this industrial panorama, a worried figure watching the Passion unfold. But Spencer also saw what happened next in a midnight vision as he walked through the civic graveyard.

The shipbuilding friezes are always shown alone. But the Portrait Gallery has chosen to hang them alongside Spencer's unofficial sequence, in which the Last Trump has been called and the Resurrection is being directed from Port Glasgow cemetery. It is hard to think of anything more gleeful painted in wartime: children reunited with parents, couples snogging against headstones, love exuberantly satisfied in a thronging, all-together-now finale of unfurling knitwear and discarded shrouds. To see these paintings together is to get the true extent of Spencer's Clydeside vision: the hard labour of war, of life, rewarded by the full-on pleasures of peace.

Dalí's Optical Illusions is a better collection of the old ham's offcuts than generally seen in Britain. This is partly because most of it comes from America, a country rich enough to afford paintings from the 1930s, before Dalí sank into bottomless kitsch. There are some unsettling dreamscapes, games with shadows and hallucinatory double-takes. You see how he analysed and parodied his own style by incorporating snapshots into photo-finish pictures; how he jumbled different idioms to confuse the eye; how perfectly the hologram suited his showmanship.

But with a few exceptions, such as the well-known face/ fruit-bowl pun, Dalí isn't much good at cunning illusions. His rabbit-duck tricks never quite swither between the two images as they should. I doubt if anyone could spot the face of Voltaire doubling as a crowd of courtiers if the curators hadn't supplied a handy visual aid. Otherwise, there are melting watches, nail-free Crucifixions and self-portraits as Velázquez: souvenirs of the longest ego-trip in art history.

The Ingleby Gallery is showing paintings by Jon Schueler, the Abstract Expressionist who got away. Schueler left the New York of Rothko, Newman and the rest in the Fifties for a Scottish fishing village with a view of Skye. He lived there, on and off, until his death in the Nineties, painting land and sky as divided by the tide.

Schueler refines the old adage that all landscapes are essentially abstract. His basic proposition is a horizontal line, sometimes two or three, sometimes blossoming into a glowing stripe.

With simple veils of colour, he abstracts the sea-bound reality - the vapours of Sleat, the pink dawn rising above a ribbon of bright water, the moist air hovering above the Sound. Rothko in Mallaig, sometimes, but Rothko to a purpose. This is a stunning show - Northern Romanticism via the School of New York.

fields.headline: True confessions
fields.standfirst: Sleeping with the enemy meant sleeping with my husband
fields.trailText: Sleeping with the enemy meant sleeping with my husband
fields.body:
They say you never know the true meaning of betrayal until it happens to you. It's true. I was betrayed by my husband of 12 years when I found out he was having an affair. And then weeks later, after hours spent crying into a whisky glass and clinging to my best friend for support, I found out that she was the other party involved.

This messy, humiliating situation tore my whole life apart and I sank to a place so low I thought I'd never be able to trust, or like, another human being again. It took me almost a year to come to terms with what happened. And then I sought revenge. As our divorce was proceeding, I started sleeping with my soon-to-be ex-husband again. Not because I still loved him or even because I wanted to - it was all part of a plan. He had moved in with my old friend, the pair of them living happily ever after, or so she thought.

What she didn't know was that every day of every week of every month since my husband and I had split up, he'd call me and occasionally we'd meet up. He'd call me from their house and switch to calling me 'Bob' when she walked into the room. He even called me daily from their holiday in Turkey. And every time he called, he'd repeat the same old thing: 'I'm sorry. I wish this had never happened. I want us to get back together again.'

And so I put the revenge plan in action. For three months, I became 'the other woman', with lunchtime meetings and afternoon sex with my ex-husband. 'I'm going to leave her,' he'd keep telling me. 'Yeah, whatever,' I'd reply. But he did. He threw her out, for me. There were tears and hours of talking before he told her to go and never return. He didn't tell her why. He didn't tell her there was someone else: me.

He didn't have the guts to tell the truth to anyone, and that's when I became certain I was doing the right thing. A couple of months went by with news of the ex-friend filtering through to me: that she was looking pretty rough, wasn't coping well at work and that my ex-husband's actions were a complete mystery to her.

In short, I'd caused her heartache. Not as much as she had caused me, but enough. Besides, I was starting to feel charitable. My life was back on track. Part one of the plan was complete. My ex-husband started making plans for me to move in with him and I went along with them, all the while knowing I wasn't going anywhere. I might once have been the naive one but I'd toughened up: no one would hurt me that much again. I told my ex-husband I wasn't going to move in with him.

For the first time, I told him what I'd gone through when our marriage was bombed to pieces. I told him that 'sorry' would never be enough. I told him the importance of trust and of honesty. The sad part is that I think he really did still love me. He listened, he understood, he cried. And then I walked out. I've seen him since, but only as friends.

There's no emotion there any more, just a dull, nagging reminder of the humiliation and pain the two of them put me through. I remember it now in the same way I remember falling off a swing and breaking my arm as a kid. Not the end of the world; it just felt like it at the time. And then it heals.

fields.headline: Fun for all the family?
fields.standfirst: Going on holiday can be relaxing, inspiring or enlightening... unless you've got kids
fields.trailText: Going on holiday can be relaxing, inspiring or enlightening... unless you've got kids.
fields.body:
I can't prove it, but taking the children on holiday must surely be right up there among the top five triggers for mental torment along with divorce, moving house, running out of toilet paper, and not being left any money following the sudden death of a well off relative. Of course, everyone puts a brave face on it for the sake of the holiday snaps, and we do make a point of bringing back hand-tooled plaster reproductions of Mount Snowdon for people with less fortunate taste than ourselves, and sending postcards to our mums joking about the typhoon that hilariously turned our caravan upside down while we were out trying to find a McDonald's in Brittany. That's all part of the fun. I'm not saying it can't be fun. The problem is... well, it's not exactly relaxing, is it?

Gone are the days when you might have spent the afternoon vegetating on a sun lounger with a chilled margarita and the Daily Mirror , or wandering around the Uffizi catching up on neoclassicism, or perhaps tramping the dappled byways of the Dordogne, sojourning at a homely auberge for a spot of boeuf, burgundy, bed, brioche and non-reproductive sexual intercourse. But that was then.

Now we are parents. It turns out that children don't much like sitting around reading yesterday's papers or being enlightened on the system of arts patronage under the Medicis or being taken on long walks with nothing to look at but haystacks. They're forever wanting you to make sandcastles or get wet in a variety of ways or watch them skim pebbles. And while it's true that there's about five minutes in your life when your first baby can still pass as hand luggage and it is theoretically possible to eat in a restaurant without stopping to breastfeed or wipe the sick off your shoulder, your days are numbered. This year the Amalfi coast, next year Bournemouth.

My wife's friend's sister Carol, a newly single parent who has just got back from 10 days in Norfolk with Bella, her two-year-old daughter, says: 'What I miss are those warm, balmy evenings strolling around some small mediterranean town, deciding where to eat, dropping into a bar for an aperitif... just being able to chill out. I used to be quite snooty about English seaside holidays,' she adds, 'but it's surprising how quickly you can get used to windbreaks and deckchairs and sand in your food - and it is less hassle than going abroad for me at the moment.'

Carol shared a cottage with her single-parent friend Janine and Janine's toddler Dennis. 'I had this mad idea that it would be a bit of a girls' holiday together - Janine's parents came for the first weekend and I thought they might babysit, but they went out to the pub instead! And Bella and Dennis didn't get on very well. Bella kept hitting Dennis with her tennis racket and stealing his toys, which made me tense, but then he'd be forever standing on the table or getting yoghurt on the sofa. I did think Janine could have been a fraction more hands-on, but what could I say?You know how it gets if you're even minutely critical of someone else's parenting techniques. Dennis would be allowed to stay up till midnight, whereas I'd normally put Bella to bed at eight, which was impossible with Dennis still running around. And Bella was still getting me out of bed at 6.30 every morning, so I was getting the worst of both worlds. I came back needing another holiday.

'But it was fun too,' she adds. 'We did sometimes manage to get the two of them to play together while we sunbathed or had a coffee. And with the grandparents there for a couple of days, it was nice to be part of a strange hybrid family. I did feel Bella was at least getting some experience of a typical ghastly English holiday.'

But going away with another family can numb the pain, especially if you have more children than they do. This year we took our four to Devon for a week with our old neighbours and chums John and Fiona, who have just the one cool, together, undemanding 12-year-old daughter, Harriet. Of course they are used to a less frenzied pace of life than us, but they soon got used to being woken up at dawn by our three-year-old, and didn't seem to mind the ambient whining soundtrack and new bulk cooking rota. Being in a spacious, well-resourced environment helped, especially one with its own corkscrew. Because we did manage to salvage the later part of our evenings to sit around drinking and making fun of John's range of surfwear. Fiona, who is a primary school teacher and accustomed to blocking out peripheral noise, read her usual eight books during our stay. Even I got to page 28 of Philip Roth's American Pastoral, which is a quite dense novel, chiefly about gloves.

The days, however, were full of not sitting down. It was all right for John, who enjoys nothing more than splashing about in a frogman's outfit and discovering his inner child. I have no inner child. Just outer ones. 'You shouldn't expect to relax,' says my wife. 'The holiday is for the children. Think of them.'

She's right, of course. I ought to be getting the hang of it by now. The thing is, it doesn't matter how many hours you spend watching them hold their breath underwater or how much money you give them to waste on machines, they'll always discover something they haven't moaned about yet. Do holidays have to be so fraught with anxiety? Are they like Christmas in that respect?

Dorothy Rowe, the psychologist, writer, and something of an expert on things that get you down, says: 'Holidays can be very challenging. You can get bored, the kids are difficult, perhaps someone gets ill. You're in an unfamiliar environment. Holidays are supposed to be wonderful, but a lot of kids would rather be at home where they know what's what. It's up to adults to make it work, but then it's down to adults when things go wrong. That's what parents are for - for the children to blame.'

'It's all a bit depressing,' I say.

'Depression is something else,' she says. 'But it can be very dispiriting.'

And, as Louise and Nick (not their real names) have discovered in the last couple of years, there's nothing like having a surly teenager in the family to make things worse. 'If you don't get it right, it can be an absolute nightmare,' says Louise, who has two boys, eight and 10, and Gemma, 15. 'The boys are easy to please and Nick is very good at getting any nearby children together for football or rounders. But we can't expect Gemma to play rounders now. She'd just hang around scowling and being difficult for two weeks and wanting to go home - or, worse, to a fairground.' The answer, says Louise, is to a) go abroad so Gemma can at least hold her head up at school - France is ideally situated, being right next door to Britain; b) book into a large, raucous Eurocamp or similar with a nightly disco and boys with earrings and tattoos; c) open a bottle of Chablis.

This year the family went to a site near Bordeaux - the same place they went last year. 'Both times Gemma has made friends with other teenagers. After the first day we hardly saw her, because she was out enjoying herself and being independent. She loved it. This year we let her invite a friend from school along, which was better for her, though slightly worse for us, in terms of privacy and space. But I suppose we're beginning to realise that every holiday she has with us now could be her last.'

My wife says we should enjoy the children while we can. Of course, she agrees that holidays can drive you scatty but she says they provide a family with a history of shared memories. They are like magical milestones on the highway of routine. Okay, she didn't actually say that last bit. But it's true that we do still talk about the trout that our eldest caught in France, and the bats that lived behind the shutters, and Bridget the camel in Tunisia and how the youngest lost his shoe in the souk and how our little trio of cuties won the fancy dress as mice in the Isle of Wight.

And the funny thing is... I can't seem to remember any of the bad bits.

The thing is, it doesn't matter how many hours you spend watching them hold their breath underwater or how much money you give them to waste on machines, they'll always discover something they haven't moaned about yet. Do holidays have to be so fraught with anxiety? Are they like Christmas in that respect? Dorothy Rowe, the psychologist, writer, and something of an expert on things that get you down, says: 'Holidays can be very challenging. You can get bored, the kids are difficult, perhaps someone gets ill. You're in an unfamiliar environment. Holidays are supposed to be wonderful, but a lot of kids would rather be at home where they know what's what. It's up to adults to make it work, but then it's down to adults when things go wrong. That's what parents are for - for the children to blame.' 'It's all a bit depressing,' I say. 'Depression is something else,' she says. 'But it can be very dispiriting.' And, as Louise and Nick (not their real names) have discovered in the last couple of years, there's nothing like having a surly teenager in the family to make things worse. 'If you don't get it right, it can be an absolute nightmare,' says Louise, who has two boys, eight and 10, and Gemma, 15. 'The boys are easy to please and Nick is very good at getting any nearby children together for football or rounders. But we can't expect Gemma to play rounders now. She'd just hang around scowling and being difficult for two weeks and wanting to go home - or, worse, to a fairground.' The answer, says Louise, is to a) go abroad so Gemma can at least hold her head up at school - France is ideally situated, being right next door to Britain; b) book into a large, raucous Eurocamp or similar with a nightly disco and boys with earrings and tattoos; c) open a bottle of Chablis. This year the family went to a site near Bordeaux - the same place they went last year. 'Both times Gemma has made friends with other teenagers. After the first day we hardly saw her, because she was out enjoying herself and being independent. She loved it. This year we let her invite a friend from school along, which was better for her, though slightly worse for us, in terms of privacy and space. But I suppose we're beginning to realise that every holiday she has with us now could be her last.' My wife says we should enjoy the children while we can. Of course, she agrees that holidays can drive you scatty but she says they provide a family with a history of shared memories. They are like magical milestones on the highway of routine. Okay, she didn't actually say that last bit. But it's true that we do still talk about the trout that our eldest caught in France, and the bats that lived behind the shutters, and Bridget the camel in Tunisia and how the youngest lost his shoe in the souk and how our little trio of cuties won the fancy dress as mice in the Isle of Wight. And the funny thing is... I can't seem to remember any of the bad bits.

fields.headline: A green man in a grey world
fields.standfirst: Jonathon Porritt - Eton, Oxford, Friends of the Earth - has just been appointed as a key adviser to Tony Blair. But being close to power won't stop him hugging trees
fields.trailText: Jonathon Porritt - Eton, Oxford, Friends of the Earth - has just been appointed as a key adviser to Tony Blair. But being close to power won't stop him hugging trees.
fields.body:
He calls himself 'the happy environmentalist', making it sound like the title of a fairy story. Sitting in the living-room of his beautiful house in Cheltenham - light floating in through the tall, clean windows; on the shelves books, children's videos, board games; on the cream walls two square, bright paintings of blue skies and blue seas; all around the room photographs of his two daughters smiling, his wife smiling, himself smiling from under his locks of dark hair - this seems a world of well-tempered tranquillity, prosperous contentment and a particularly English ease.

Yet the worlds Jonathon Porritt deals with are, as he says himself, ones of 'deep gloom and darkest dismay', where the news is very rarely good and often apocalyptic: poisoned beaches, toxic air, leaking gases, endangered species, a torn sky, a dangerous sun. So, he says, 'happiness can seem such an illegitimate emotion; optimism strange amid such deep, dark gloom. Happiness is quite psychologically complicated for someone like me. A lot of my friends are worn down by the literal despair that they feel at living with this pattern of destruction. In the face of dire news, people may easily become paralysed and feel powerless.' He smiles with great charm. 'Not me. I have never felt despair. I remain an optimist. You see, I think I can change things - still, even now, I think I can change what is happening.'

Jonathon Porritt has just been appointed by Tony Blair as the Government's key adviser on sustainable development; he will chair the 15-strong Sustainable Development Committee. He's rather modest, and mildly rueful, about his new position, which he calls 'a monstrous challenge'. He doesn't think that he was their first choice. 'In fact, I wasn't even a candidate at all,' he says. 'I've never had any internal dealings with the Labour Party. I've always been critical of them. I have not sought to defend this party's record, and I won't begin doing that now. I'm not going to be suddenly going, "oooh, I got it all wrong, all along". I've always been dark green and radical. Now here I am on the inside, or sort of. I have to report on the Government's performance on sustainable development, and you can't be on the inside doing that. You can't be too close, or there would be no usefulness in it for them; no credibility for others. I nailed that down with Michael Meacher, whom I have always admired. It will be a critical dialogue.'

When he was invited to do the job, he was 'very surprised indeed. I said, "I'm still a member of the Green Party, you know". They said, "no problem". I said, "what if I campaign for the radical greenies at the next election?" They said, "well, it might sit a mite uneasily; this is an independent body". I said, "what if I make critical speeches about the Government?" They said, "Jonathon, that's part of your job".' He thinks that he can be outside and inside, all at once.

In fact, that's pretty much what he's been all of his working life: inside and outside, establishment and radical, friend to the powerless and to the Prince of Wales. He was born to be a Sir - his father, who died eight years ago, was Baron Porritt of Wanganui and Hampstead. He was educated at Eton, where he was 'very happy; I had a wonderful time, I'm afraid - my whole childhood was very happy and untroubled... no torments there'.

He went to Oxford, where he obtained a first-class degree in modern languages. His sister works in finance; his brother is a property developer. Nothing prepared him for being an environmental activist and a thorn in the side of the establishment to which he belongs by birth and manner, except for his childhood love of wildlife. After Oxford, he started training as a barrister, but it bored him, so he spent the next 10 years teaching at a London comprehensive, during which time he became active in the Green Party, becoming its co-chair in 1980.

He left teaching and the chair of the Green Party (which by then was a wrangling and rivalrous organisation headed towards its Sara Parkin farrago) to become director of Friends of the Earth, which he built up into the face of 'respectable radicalism', firmly grounded in science and fact and setting its face against wacky and mystical environmentalism. He has written books on environmental issues, presented television series on them; he has chaired the United Nations environmental and development committee for the UK. In 1996, he became a founder and director of Forum for the Future, a charity campaigning for solutions to today's environmental problems. The Forum tends to highlight good news rather than pointing out the bad, and its members include Richard Rogers, Jonathan Dimbleby and Will Hutton. A lot of its work is done with large companies - if Friends of the Earth was a bottom-up organisation, Forum for the Future is a top-down one.

The great and the good, I say, and he smiles at the buried question mark.

'This conflict has been true all my life. I don't see it as a tension, but as a set of opportunities. I have always felt that. The fact that I know how the establishment world works, because I was born into it and educated into it, has not been a disadvantage to me or the organisations I've worked with. The opposite is true: it has helped me to do much more useful work. At Friends of the Earth, being at ease with the people who were on the inside track, in the corridors of power, it was plain useful for us. I could take this radical message to people who simply wouldn't have listened to others, but who would listen to me.

'I'm upfront about this. I've used my privilege to get greater leverage for green ideas. I've done it calculatingly. I have turned it to good effect. It's not complicated for me. I feel no guilt.' He adds, after a pause, that it is, however, 'much too easy to forget what it is like to be powerless and to have no voice. I am familiar with worlds where people don't just forget - they have never known. They are blind to injustice, inequality, poverty. Things are genuinely invisible to them'.

But he insists that 'that is absolutely not true for me. I will not allow myself to forget what my work is about and be seduced by power. I just won't. I still feel the same way about it as I did when I started. I can remember the first impulse as clearly as yesterday. I am,' he continues, 'an environmentalist not because I care about Nature, which I very much do, but because I care more about the human species. I care about things like social justice, fairness, equality, human potential - and survival. Part of the quality of life is our relationship with the natural world. Diminish that and we diminish ourselves. There are other activists who start from the other way round - that what matters is the natural world. Well, I think I have a huge sense of its spiritual significance. My attitude is not just utilitarian. But I see nature through a human lens.' He laughs: 'Anyway, you should try talking about spiritual things at Friends of the Earth; they'd shout you down in a blaze of materialistic fury. They are a rationalist, instrumentalist organisation. That's why they are so effective; they don't get cluttered up with, you know, stuff.'

He respects science, but only so far. Poetry creeps into his analyses. He is scornful of scientists such as Richard Dawkins, and his anti-religious, absolutist fervour. He hates the great divide between scientists and the rest of us - C.P. Snow's famous two cultures, and the yawning gap between them; the hole into which the world will fall. His latest book, Playing Safe: Science and the Environment (Thames and Hudson) contains a wealth of scientific information about the parlous state of the natural word, but also several swipes at arrogant scientists and their assumption that science is authoritative, objective, value-free and the last word.

He was one of the people who turned Friends of the Earth into a respectable, science-led place, but he bemoans its dry-eyed materialism. He loves James Lovelock and the Gaia principle; he calls for holistic solutions; he approves of the Prince of Wales's dogged championing of 'the sacred'; he can't stand media cynics; he talks about cosmic harmony and psychic disconnection, and about synthetic chemicals and sewerage systems. The world for him is not just a great rock but a 'whispering pond'.

'I do believe in a world that is a created world and not just an accident. God is probably the best word to describe that force. Well, I know it doesn't correlate much with what most people mean by God. And since I don't believe you can have a pick'n'mix Christianity, then I'd probably subscribe to the Christian faith. But as a Christian, I'd better tell you I fail on every count. I don't, for a start, believe in life after death. I do believe in reincarnation, by which I mean a literal, physical reincarnation, so that when we die we are promptly recycled into a million different organisms.'

In other words, he believes in decay. 'Yes. I love the thought. It thrills me. It turns me on. I revel in the idea that I'll be incorporated back into the world like that. I love the idea of being buried in a grove, a tree growing out of my heart. I'm not at all scared of death. Even less after seeing my father die. He was 92, after all, but none the less, he was very gentle, very accepting. We talked a lot about his death, and he thought there was nothing you needed to make a fuss about. I don't worry about dying at all.'

So where are the things that trip him up? 'Hmmm. Well, getting a balance. Some things have fallen by the way in my life. In my early adulthood, I had a really strong network of friends. I felt passionately about friendship. That's gone, if I'm honest. I've sacrificed that to family and work - I work tremendously hard in the week, and I spend every weekend with my family and I protect my space with them; that always takes priority. But I worry about friendships; it troubles me.'

Other things, he says, do not trouble him. He is lucky, cheerful, optimistic. Environmental work creates 'fear, guilt, anger. It touches on the darkest places of your psyche. And I've worked there all my life, but I do not feel despair. And now, with the Forum and its emphasis on best practice, I work with other things - like joy, fulfilment, success. It taps into other parts of human energy. And I think, I really do, that in some ways things are getting better. The pattern of destruction, well, the news remains uniformly bad, and often getting worse. But in terms of awareness, things are better. It's an area that is not so measurable, but I believe there's a growing commitment to changed behaviour, and a readiness for change. It's very different from the Eighties, let alone the Seventies.'

There's such joy, he says, in the business of protecting the earth. 'It's not a crabby, grim business at all. The essence of it is joy.' If he ever does get a bit depressed at the enormity of the task, 'I just get out there, into nature. I reconnect.' He chuckles. 'I hug those trees. I'm very flaky, you know. God knows what the Government's done. Appointed a complete flake.

'Maybe what I'll do after this is to start chaining myself to railings again. I'd like that sense of life being a cycle. I could loop round, back to where I started. Into the corridors of power and out the other side, chained to the railings and shouting for change.'

fields.headline: Two bingo addicts...
fields.standfirst: Kathryn Flett on why gamblers gamble, why men don't commit, why rowers row, and why Nick isn't Satan
fields.trailText: Kathryn Flett on why gamblers gamble, why men don't commit, why rowers row, and why Nick isn't Satan.
fields.body:
Big Brother C4
Blokes BBC2
Gold Fever BBC1
Jackpot BBC2
Secret History C4
Female Fantasies C5

My deadline precludes me from making up-to-the-minute observations about the progress of Big Brother , but none the less I'm still not itching to join in the 'Is Nick Bateman Really Satan?' debate - even if Nick is easily the most interesting thing on the show, merely because he is cleverer and more Machiavellian than his ghastly co-habitees. While undeniably watchable, Big Brother fails to engage emotions because the pressure for contestants to compete, to be 'on' effectively 24 hours a day, means that any sort of a relationship they appear to construct with each other is fundamentally dishonest and therefore as exhaustingly unedifying as watching a series of audition tapes for an MTV presenting job.

We can play at virtual voyeurism with this lot but we shouldn't fool ourselves: they're semi-pro media bunnies bouncing on cue inside their televised hutch - if they were prepared to sabotage their performances to reveal a real them, they'd be at it like rabbits, too. No, if this week you wanted televisual voyeurism featuring some truly awkward fledgling relationships then you needed to see the delightfully candid, funny, touching and entertainingly naive documentary, Blokes .

The young director/narrator, Cassie Allward, claimed she had set out to make a film about contemporary blokedom, with particular emphasis on male friendship. To this end she was introduced to Jack and Chris, a pair of sweetly feckless twentysomethings who agreed to be filmed for her project. However, Cassie rather waved goodbye to her objectivity when, on the night they first met, she snogged Jack and then went to bed with Chris. (Well, it was New Year's Eve).

This made for a better film, though: Cassie carried on having a desultory sort of relationship with Chris, while recognising that she much preferred the 'more appropriate' Jack; and Jack - though patently keen on Cassie - stuck doggedly to the unwritten code of honour: Thou dost not shag one's best mate's bird - at least not until he's dumped her. By necessity, Cassie sought sanctuary behind her lens, instigating needy conversations with Chris which, she acknowledged, indicated that 'all he wanted to do was have sex and play on his [record] decks'.

'I don't want you to, like, get too into me,' said Chris, who had some intimacy issues.

'Do you know exactly what you want?' pondered Cassie.

'In which domain?' wondered Chris.

'In the domain of sex and love...'

'No, blatantly [sic] not. But there's still that kind of natural desire to find a soulmate...'

These boys, a pair of hopelessly ricocheting emotional pinballs, were brimful of casual misogyny and wildly unrealisable romantic dreams, while Cassie herself was a tangled web-weaver of considerable skill (she should meet Big Brother 's Nick). In the end, though, it all went pear-shaped: Jack gave up and moved to Brighton in pursuit of another girl, while Chris just gave up.

Male friendships - and competitiveness - came under equally intense scrutiny in Gold Fever, the first of a four-part series looking at the three-year preparation by Britain's coxless four rowing team. Persuaded to have a stab at a potentially record-breaking fifth Olympic gold medal, Steve Redgrave again teamed up with Matthew Pinsent and enlisted newcomers James Cracknell and Tim Foster in a bid to, as Pinsent put it, 'pull a very sizable rabbit out of a very small hat' in Sydney next month. Much misleading glamour was implied by the opening title sequence - a doppel ganger for the current Seat Leon ad - which concentrated on the extremely attractively-proportioned foursome sweating in artfully lit pop-vid monochrome to the accompaniment of a testosterone-bonkers guitar solo. Though there were, admittedly, numerous distracting shots throughout the film of abdominal-crunching and bicep-pumping, there was also some insight into the process of pursuing whatever it is that lies somewhere beyond excellence.

Less than an hour in the company of the borderline-dour Redgrave and one could see that the life of a top-flight pro sportsman in the twilight of his career is no laughing matter. Freshly diagnosed with diabetes, Redgrave effectively shrugged and got on with it.

Later, hovering over his newborn son, he inquired 'am I going to row?', which sounded like a pretty rhetorical sort of question to both me and Mrs Redgrave - 'If you want to,' she said quietly, babe in arms, two small daughters causing havoc nearby. This was either heroic dedication or borderline insanity.

'It's difficult for all of them to get the balance right between rowing and relationships,' conceded the voiceover - including, apparently, the relationship between each member of the crew.

There was the collective sigh of disappointment (followed by an immediate breakdown in communications) between the four men when Tim (of the irritating half-smile and slightly wild streak - cigar-smoking, for example), accidentally stuck his arm through a window and severed some tendons. Matt Pinsent was 'pissed off because that sort of thing is controllable', and even Tim admitted: 'I'd be pretty annoyed with me if I were them.'

The rest of us can't really claim to be of the same species as these burnished, physically superhuman, emotionally constipated sportsmen - but, by God, you ended up wanting them to win. They do it so we don't have to. 'This is why I do it!' Pinsent had crowed as the team rowed to victory in the world championships in France in 1997. A sentiment echoed heartily by Dave 'Devilfish' (no, we didn't find out why) Ulliot, professional poker player, greyhound owners Pat and Nicky Chambers, committed gambler Sir Clement Freud, and Glaswegian bingo and slot machine addict Betty - the first four subjects of BBC2's entertaining series, Jackpot.

My one major criticism about Jackpot is that there was simply far too much winning going on: despite some substantial losses en route, Dave was several grand ahead by the end of the programme and, after a heartwarming parental scene in which he played blackjack (for cash) with his (very young) sons, was preparing to head for Vegas.

Meanwhile, after a disastrous season, Pat and Nicky (and Droopy's Rivero) won their first greyhound 'classic', the Romford Puppy Cup; Sir Clement lost on the ponies at a point-to-point in Pytchley, but watched his own horse make up for it by winning at Chepstow; and even Betty, who pitches up to play the slots at the Mecca Bingo first thing every Monday morning ('it's a bit quiet') and could easily be identified as the one with A Problem, finished late on Monday night £40 up on her £100 stake, despite losing at the bingo. Statistically the odds were surely against quite this much winning going on, though admittedly the series is called Jackpot , not Bankruptcy.

'You're Mussolini/ You're Mrs Sweeny/ You're Camembert...' sang Cole Porter - though, so far, only Camembert has survived with its reputation intact, as the Duchess of Argyll, the former Mrs Sweeny, ended up famously disgraced and, by the end of her life, clearly as bankrupt financially as she had been deemed to be morally. This Secret History also revealed (courtesy of a deliciously lugubrious Geoffrey Palmer voiceover) not only the identity of the famous 'Headless Man' - shamed, though not named, by the Duke in his divorce petition - but also the fact that, just like Posh Spice, the young Margaret Argyll was never photographed smiling. But, as Posh can doubtless testify, it is no laughing matter being a semi-professional multi-millionairess housewife superstar.

Anyway, the Duchess's voracious sexual appetite was said to have resulted from an accidental fall down a lift-shaft, which is as good an excuse as any. 'She went down in flames,' observed a friend of her subsequent, moral fall - though the famous Polaroid of the Duchess allegedly attending to the needs of Douglas Fairbanks Jr revealed that, in fact, she went down in some lovely pearls and a very large ring.

If that was your sort of sexual reality, where on earth would you go with your fantasies? On Thursday, Female Fantasies shocked me to the very core of my being when an interviewee talked candidly about her cellulite-free fantasy world. Only she pronounced it cellu leet. Which is seriously perverse, no?
fields.bodyText: Big Brother C4 Blokes BBC2 Gold Fever BBC1 Jackpot BBC2 Secret History C4 Female Fantasies C5 My deadline precludes me from making up-to-the-minute observations about the progress of Big Brother , but none the less I'm still not itching to join in the 'Is Nick Bateman Really Satan?' debate - even if Nick is easily the most interesting thing on the show, merely because he is cleverer and more Machiavellian than his ghastly co-habitees. While undeniably watchable, Big Brother fails to engage emotions because the pressure for contestants to compete, to be 'on' effectively 24 hours a day, means that any sort of a relationship they appear to construct with each other is fundamentally dishonest and therefore as exhaustingly unedifying as watching a series of audition tapes for an MTV presenting job. We can play at virtual voyeurism with this lot but we shouldn't fool ourselves: they're semi-pro media bunnies bouncing on cue inside their televised hutch - if they were prepared to sabotage their performances to reveal a real them, they'd be at it like rabbits, too. No, if this week you wanted televisual voyeurism featuring some truly awkward fledgling relationships then you needed to see the delightfully candid, funny, touching and entertainingly naive documentary, Blokes . The young director/narrator, Cassie Allward, claimed she had set out to make a film about contemporary blokedom, with particular emphasis on male friendship. To this end she was introduced to Jack and Chris, a pair of sweetly feckless twentysomethings who agreed to be filmed for her project. However, Cassie rather waved goodbye to her objectivity when, on the night they first met, she snogged Jack and then went to bed with Chris. (Well, it was New Year's Eve). This made for a better film, though: Cassie carried on having a desultory sort of relationship with Chris, while recognising that she much preferred the 'more appropriate' Jack; and Jack - though patently keen on Cassie - stuck doggedly to the unwritten code of honour: Thou dost not shag one's best mate's bird - at least not until he's dumped her. By necessity, Cassie sought sanctuary behind her lens, instigating needy conversations with Chris which, she acknowledged, indicated that 'all he wanted to do was have sex and play on his [record] decks'. 'I don't want you to, like, get too into me,' said Chris, who had some intimacy issues. 'Do you know exactly what you want?' pondered Cassie. 'In which domain?' wondered Chris. 'In the domain of sex and love...' 'No, blatantly [sic] not. But there's still that kind of natural desire to find a soulmate...' These boys, a pair of hopelessly ricocheting emotional pinballs, were brimful of casual misogyny and wildly unrealisable romantic dreams, while Cassie herself was a tangled web-weaver of considerable skill (she should meet Big Brother 's Nick). In the end, though, it all went pear-shaped: Jack gave up and moved to Brighton in pursuit of another girl, while Chris just gave up. Male friendships - and competitiveness - came under equally intense scrutiny in Gold Fever, the first of a four-part series looking at the three-year preparation by Britain's coxless four rowing team. Persuaded to have a stab at a potentially record-breaking fifth Olympic gold medal, Steve Redgrave again teamed up with Matthew Pinsent and enlisted newcomers James Cracknell and Tim Foster in a bid to, as Pinsent put it, 'pull a very sizable rabbit out of a very small hat' in Sydney next month. Much misleading glamour was implied by the opening title sequence - a doppel ganger for the current Seat Leon ad - which concentrated on the extremely attractively-proportioned foursome sweating in artfully lit pop-vid monochrome to the accompaniment of a testosterone-bonkers guitar solo. Though there were, admittedly, numerous distracting shots throughout the film of abdominal-crunching and bicep-pumping, there was also some insight into the process of pursuing whatever it is that lies somewhere beyond excellence. Less than an hour in the company of the borderline-dour Redgrave and one could see that the life of a top-flight pro sportsman in the twilight of his career is no laughing matter. Freshly diagnosed with diabetes, Redgrave effectively shrugged and got on with it. Later, hovering over his newborn son, he inquired 'am I going to row?', which sounded like a pretty rhetorical sort of question to both me and Mrs Redgrave - 'If you want to,' she said quietly, babe in arms, two small daughters causing havoc nearby. This was either heroic dedication or borderline insanity. 'It's difficult for all of them to get the balance right between rowing and relationships,' conceded the voiceover - including, apparently, the relationship between each member of the crew. There was the collective sigh of disappointment (followed by an immediate breakdown in communications) between the four men when Tim (of the irritating half-smile and slightly wild streak - cigar-smoking, for example), accidentally stuck his arm through a window and severed some tendons. Matt Pinsent was 'pissed off because that sort of thing is controllable', and even Tim admitted: 'I'd be pretty annoyed with me if I were them.' The rest of us can't really claim to be of the same species as these burnished, physically superhuman, emotionally constipated sportsmen - but, by God, you ended up wanting them to win. They do it so we don't have to. 'This is why I do it!' Pinsent had crowed as the team rowed to victory in the world championships in France in 1997. A sentiment echoed heartily by Dave 'Devilfish' (no, we didn't find out why) Ulliot, professional poker player, greyhound owners Pat and Nicky Chambers, committed gambler Sir Clement Freud, and Glaswegian bingo and slot machine addict Betty - the first four subjects of BBC2's entertaining series, Jackpot. My one major criticism about Jackpot is that there was simply far too much winning going on: despite some substantial losses en route, Dave was several grand ahead by the end of the programme and, after a heartwarming parental scene in which he played blackjack (for cash) with his (very young) sons, was preparing to head for Vegas. Meanwhile, after a disastrous season, Pat and Nicky (and Droopy's Rivero) won their first greyhound 'classic', the Romford Puppy Cup; Sir Clement lost on the ponies at a point-to-point in Pytchley, but watched his own horse make up for it by winning at Chepstow; and even Betty, who pitches up to play the slots at the Mecca Bingo first thing every Monday morning ('it's a bit quiet') and could easily be identified as the one with A Problem, finished late on Monday night £40 up on her £100 stake, despite losing at the bingo. fields.headline: Moral muse
fields.standfirst: My son is gay, so why do I feel bereaved?
fields.trailText: My son is gay, so why do I feel bereaved?
fields.body:
Our 22-year-old son has just told us he is gay. This came as a total surprise and we are stunned. I've always thought of myself as tolerant, open-minded, understanding. I have nothing against homosexuals, so why I am so upset? I sound like the worst kind of hypocrite but my son's homosexuality feels like some kind of bereavement. My husband shares my feelings. How do we come to terms with the situation so that we can give our son the support he needs? Do you know of any organisation for parents like us where we could contact people in a similar situation?
L.G.

The most significant word in your letter is 'bereavement', which is wholly appropriate. You may not be fully aware of the extent of your grief over the probable gap in the next generation, since your son is unlikely to provide you with grandchildren. The love which humans bear their children is multi-layered, and whether or not we like to admit it, at least one of the deeper layers is due to the investment made in those children as vehicles for the propagation of our own genes. This is not hypocritical or inconsistent, nor is your horrified reaction to your son's revelation; humans are made in this complex and apparently contradictory way.

You do not tell us if you have other children who may provide you with continuity in future generations. If you do not, it may be of some consolation to remember that a brother or a sister's children are close kin to you and share some of your inheritance; as do cousins and other family. With regard to your son, you have already progressed a long way towards adjusting to the situation, firstly by recognising your own unpredictability in this crisis - with fundamental responses at cross purposes with intellectualised ones - and secondly by very positive moves to understand and support him.

This will not happen overnight. He's a different person to the one you thought you knew, and though you'll respect his courage and honesty in breaking the news, he still has to be extensively re-thought.

Remember that this will be a taxing time for him too, wondering if he has permanently alienated your affection. You also want him to be happy and successful, but perceive that being a member of a minority group is not going to favour those aims.

Be thankful, though, that the public is more tolerant in its attitude to homosexuality now. Gay organisations are better organised and more open, so that even the shyest individuals do not need to suffer isolation.

In your telephone directory you will find a 'Gay Switchboard' which will be able to put you in touch with parents who have been through a similar discovery and upheaval, and are willing to share their acquired wisdom.

A reader's reply

At first, I don't think my parents found having a gay son easy at all. My mum only once hinted about the fact I wouldn't have children, and I think this upset her for a while. Perhaps you both had expectations about grand children and now you feel this option has been taken away. However, as two gay men have recently shown, it is perfectly possible for gay men to raise a family if they wish to do so.

My mum also had difficulties with probing questions from friends about what I was doing now I'd left home. I know she found this difficult, not because she was ashamed but because she was asked these questions by other people while she still had many of her own that were unanswered.

You say it feels like a bereavement, but what you're probably experiencing is a fear of the unknown. Two organisations may be able to help you: National Friend (0121 684 1261) and Parents' Friend (0113 267 4627).
M.H. of London

Next week's dilemma

I've been with my partner for several weeks, and since the beginning of the relationship, references to his ex-girlfriend have been slipping into our conversations on a daily basis. They take the form of reminiscences and anecdotes, but sometimes he'll mention her in circumstances where her presence is only incidental. Their break-up a few years ago was very painful for him, and she is evidently still on his mind.

He is open about still finding her attractive but believes this is irrelevant. We are happy together, but when he makes these references, I feel vaguely resentful and find myself wondering if he would like go back to her. Do you think it would be a good idea to discuss things with him or is my insecurity doing him a disservice?
R.C. of Swansea

 Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal
