fields.headline: This is Al, get me rewrite
fields.standfirst: The many makeovers and transformations of Al Gore are now complete and the first genetically modified presidential candidate is ready to run
fields.trailText: The many makeovers and transformations of Al Gore are now complete and the first genetically modified presidential candidate is ready to run.
fields.body:
Although he presents himself as an environmentalist guru, Al Gore has always been enthusiastic about genetically modified 'Frankenfoods' - and for many good reasons. One might be that he himself is a GM product. No man in the history of American politics can have been so carefully and deliberately groomed, moulded, deconstructed and reconstructed for the Presidential race for which Al 'GM' Gore presents himself at the Democrat convention, opening in Los Angeles tomorrow.

When Gore arrived for his first day as a journalist on the Nashville Tennessean newspaper in the autumn of 1971, most staff knew he was no regular cub reporter. Gore was being packaged to them as the young man who had just returned from his stint in Vietnam - wearing his country's uniform although he bitterly criticised its war - now making his way in the world free from the overbearing family tradition of politics. In contrast to the cynical realpolitik practiced by his father, Senator Albert Gore I, Al Gore II had studied esoteric spiritualism. He was a decent enough reporter too - he pursued a local corruption case all the way to a court hearing (although the target was acquitted).

But the package was a deceptive one. Had he really wanted to go into journalism, the Harvard-educated Gore could have walked into other, more prestigious newsrooms than that which happened to have been in his father's political back-pocket in Nashville. The editor of the Nashville Tennessean was John Siegenthaler, who employed celebrity interns who would enhance his own contacts in Washington.

In Vietnam, Gore's father had been able to pull a few strings (although without such sordid efficiency as George Bush's) and secured Gore a job as an army reporter. Accordingly, he had been mollycoddled around, a safe distance from the action which he reported in vivid detail from second-hand accounts. 'Gore was not the journalist type,' recalls his former colleague on the desk, Phil Sullivan. 'It didn't seem like that was what he was setting out to do. Siegenthaler saw him as someone who was going into politics.'

But although his colleagues knew exactly what he was up to, Gore himself could have had no idea that the more relaxed and apparently self-confident summer intern sitting at the next desk would, in two decades time, be the man to whom he would turn for yet another in the long series of makeovers that would define his career: Carter Eskew, 'message guru' of the current campaign, laboratory technician of the present-day GM Gore and Svengali of the LA convention.

It is hard to know which aspects of Al Gore's life are fact and which are fanciful, or indeed whether there is any difference between the two. Gore himself plays along with the entwinement, turning even the rawest and most intimate moments of his life - such as his own son's scrape with death in a car accident - into theatrics, part of the electoral strategy.

The packaging of Al Gore as President of the United States began when he was still in utero. On the day Gore was born, the Nashville Tennessean hailed the birth on page one: 'Well, Mr Gore, Here He Is', with the Knoxville News Sentinel adding only a year or two later: 'There may be another Gore on his way to the political pinnacle.'

Gore grew up not in Tennessee but in what is now the Ritz Carlton Hotel on Embassy Row in Washington DC, attending an élite prep school and spending summers on the tobacco farm in his father's home state. He played with a toy submarine in the Senate swimming-pool and bounced on President Nixon's lap. Albert Snr was a rags-to-riches, Scots-Irish politician, a New Dealer unafraid of unpopular positing and ultimately defeated after an 18-year career only when Nixon unleashed a slush of illegal finance against him, as revealed by the Watergate papers. Like his son, he enjoyed taking the ethical high ground and like his son he betrayed it. But it was Gore's mother, Pauline, who claimed the initial packaging of her son - 'I trained them both,' she said of Alberts I and II, 'and I did a better job on my son than I did on my husband.'

The most striking thing about packaging Al Gore is the regularity with which it happens and the extent of the metamorphoses. The most dramatic was the apparent conversion from new-age eco-catastrophist to Vice-President in 1992 and, more recently, from a woodentop with as much political razzmatazz as a traffic jam to something from Sopranos central casting.

The task in 1992 was particularly daunting and almost effective. Gore pre sented a curious figure at the time, as expressed in his book, Earth in the Balance . It was published at a time when politicians were full of foreboding about the various apocalypses of global warming, over-population and ozone-depletion and making routine pilgrimages to the Amazon rainforest.

Gore had been understandably affected by his son's narrow scrape with death after a car hit the child as the family was leaving a Baltimore Orioles baseball game. He had immersed himself in alternative psychotherapy, new-age thought and the fad philosophy of Gaia, popular among right-wing eco-catastrophists, suggesting that the human race is merely part of a single, natural organism.

'It cannot be accidental,' wrote Gore in one of his more wayward passages, 'that the percentage of salt in our bloodstreams is the same as the percentage in the oceans of the world.' Gore laments mankind's alienation from this natural order, putting the blame squarely on René Descartes. Quite apart from its intellectual absurdity, Gore's position had two curiosities: the fact that it did not put off the embryonic Clinton administration and its brazen disingenuousness.

On his 1998 tax return, Al Gore lists a $20,000 royalty payment from the Union Zinc Company for the right to mine zinc on his farm in Tennessee. The income, which has netted Gore $450,000 over the years, is the legacy of Gore Snr's lucrative relationship and joint ventures with fraudulent tycoon and Soviet agent, Armand Hammer, also chief executive of the environmentally controversial Occidental Petroleum Company. Among other ironies, Hammer was caught making illegal contributions to Nixon, used to topple Gore Snr. Hammer and Gore Snr enjoyed a two-way deal: Hammer boasted that he had Gore in his 'back-pocket'; he found protection from anti-communist investigations and open doors in Washington; Gore Snr secured campaign funds, a six-figure directorship upon retirement and donations for his son's Congressional campaigns.

After hosting Gore and Tipper at innumerable parties, and being Al's guest at Ronald Reagan's inauguration in 1987, Hammer died in 1990. But the $20,000 a year was a handsome supplement to what Gore complained were 'slave wages' on the Tennessean , and still listed in 1992 as his most important source of income after his salary, now eclipsed by the $1.1 million in royalties from Earth in the Balance .

The relationship between Gore and Occidental has remained a mutually advantageous one. Occidental loaned $100,000 to the Clinton-Gore inaugural committee in 1992, and has donated some $500,000 in 'soft money' to the Democratic Party since Gore made it on to the ticket.

This was the administration-in-waiting that decided it needed Al Gore on the ticket. When he took the initial call from scout Warren Christopher, Gore was attending the Rio Earth Summit in 1991, waving his copy of Earth in the Balance . Baby-boomer Clinton liked the generational chemistry with Gore, and the Vietnam 'record' which, on paper, contrasted with his own. Gore appealed to the 'new Democrat' right wing for a number of reasons. He had been recruited by the party as an attack dog to see off Jesse Jackson's candidacy in 1988 and had done a good enough job. Even then, Clinton also needed someone with a stable marriage to offset his embarrassment over Gennifer Flowers.

Gore was duly put through the mill, drilled into shape even by people who disliked him at the political core of Clinton's campaign: Hillary, James Carville and George Stephanopoulos. He was worked over by speech coaches and a ballet choreographer, who counselled him on his awkward movements. The wrathful impatience with conventional politics sketched in Earth in the Balance was silenced as the book became the first ever bestseller that a publisher refrained from pushing. Clinton liked the volume, but Carville, Harold Ickes and the realists on the party's Left, trying to win an election, found it insane at best, scary at worst. Gore the Rainbow Warrior duly became Gore the Vice-President.

But what kind of packaging was it? The nadir of Gore's life-as-theatre came at the party convention in New York that year, Gore's 'coming-out' event. He told the delegates and viewing millions how he had watched Albert Gore III 'fly 30 feet through the air and scrape along the pavement... I ran to his side and held him and called his name... his eyes were open with the nothingness state of death'. Gore was reading every word off the autocue.

The history of Vice-Presidents assuming the top office is a patchy one, as Pauline Gore must have realised when she expressed coded disapproval of her son's supporting role to the 'provincial' Bill Clinton. It was a concept in promotion pioneered by the shock of Truman's takeover from Franklin Roosevelt and L.B.J.'s even more dramatic succession of J.F. Kennedy, but these were without preparation. It worked differently in the more ambitious cases of Nixon, first of the 'modern' Vice-Presidents, and George Bush.

A year ago, a lifetime of grooming 'Veep' Al Gore for the presidency seemed doomed to failure. A bumper sticker appeared: 'Stuck in Traffic? Blame Al Gore'. Gore had creased the nation's sides by telling CNN's Wolf Blitzer he had 'taken the initiative in creating the internet'. Hillary Clinton's candidacy in New York created a Medusan triangle inside the White House with resentments in all directions. Most importantly, Gore was making instantly and utterly forgettable speeches: 'Gore' was spelled with a 'B'.

A Wagnerian family psychodrama was playing out between Clinton and Gore - 'father' and 'son' - which was, with hindsight, crucial to Gore's selection of running mate last week. Throughout the Lewinsky scandal, Gore had walked a high wire between loyalty and disgust. Apart from Hillary, he was the most senior victim of the President's deceit but also had the highest honour under Clinton's patronage to betray if he abandoned him.

Gore's political father (Clinton) finally blessed Gore's ambition to become President in 1998, the year that his actual father died, thereby turning Clinton's political paternity into something more complex. Gore always knew that his success lay in the passing of power by both to him, as George Bush Snr has done to his son. But there was a problem - the motives of both Gore's father figures were entirely narcissistic. One wanted a President Gore who would bear the family name in the White House, the other a President Gore to rescue his legacy from the stains on Monica's dress.

In his hour of need, Gore was shunned by the surrogate father in a way he never was by Albert Snr. Out of the blue, Clinton made an unsolicited call to the New York Times, making clear his displeasure at the way Gore was conducting his campaign. On the morning his remarks were published, the atmosphere in Gore's White House office was one of 'stunned disbelief'. Meanwhile, down the corridor, Gore had been shut out of the huddle that gathered around the President to discuss the advisability and fallout of the Times interview. Gore's retort came sharp enough. He told Diane Sawyer he thought Clinton's behaviour during the Lewinsky scandal had been 'inexcusable... especially as a father'.

Gore assembled a team with specific instructions - to repackage him again, almost from scratch. One source told The Observer that Gore himself even admitted privately that 'I would not vote for the Al Gore I read about'. A war council was convened by the new campaign director, Tony Coelho, a former Congressman dogged by allegations of embezzlement and scandal, to do just that. With Coelho was Bob Shrum, former wordsmith for Teddy Kennedy who will have written Gore's sink-or-swim Los Angeles speech; Gore's daughter, Karenna Gore Schriff, and wife, Tipper; Eskew and stringent political director Donna Brazile, who acted as pastor and conscience to the otherwise devious bunch.

According to one present at the meeting, the message was to 'free Gore from his office and from the White House' - to declare UDI from Bill and Hillary. Gore moved his campaign headquarters from Washington to his supposed 'roots' in Tennessee. The move was also a good way to cull a troubled, squabbling staff, to sort out the wheat prepared to sacrifice everything to follow him from the chaff who preferred to stay around their DC dinner tables. Brazile added a trial by salary, cutting everybody's by two-thirds. Gore and his senior staff remained in the comfort of Washington.

Diane Sawyer conducted the first TV interview in Tennessee with Gore and Tipper on his late father's tobacco farm. Gore wore jeans and cowboy boots. Sawyer threw the first pitch, a fastball. Her grandmother, she said, who was in tobacco farming, wanted to ask: how many strains of tobacco are there in the US? Gore stared back blankly, a look of wounded hatred in his eyes. The second question was about the maintenance of fencing between two properties; Gore was equally clueless.

Addressing the crowds at his launch rally in Tennessee, Gore pledged to 'take my own values of faith and family to the Presidency' and promised: 'If you entrust me with the Presidency, I will marshal its authority, its resources and its moral leadership to fight for America's family.' It was a brazen slap in Clinton's face. Gore's campaign hit the road with speeches luxuriating in the strong economy, but barely mentioning Clinton. He needed to share in the President's public successes (and stubborn popularity among Americans) while denouncing his private failings.

Winter came, and the packaging team devised a new, folksy Al Gore who stopped talking about 'livability' and held town meetings and his audience to raise their hands until he had identified who had the most grandchildren. As the jester of American politician-watching, Professor Todd Gitlin at New York University, puts it: 'The difference between Bush and Gore now is that Bush is fake trying to be real, while Gore is real trying to be fake.'

But even the 'fake' package had trouble selling himself. Gore was tainted by the Russian money-laundering scandal. A photo opportunity in a canoe backfired when it emerged that 170 million gallons of water had been released to stage it, during a drought. Bill Bradley was making headway he simply didn't deserve. Coelho's tyrannical style was driving the team to distraction to no effect; he was hardly the Carville figure the campaign so obviously needed. There was bitter internal strife between one-time partners Eskew and the (now late) Bob Squier, policy adviser. The two men had once run a consultancy together but their combined presence on the Gore campaign was, said old White House hand Dick Morris 'like asking the Albanians and Serbs to work together'. Then came a final split from Bill, a bit of the sex appeal and the final makeover.

The Gores had decided that marital bliss was the key to the post-Monica era, but now they added a bit of libido to their version. On stage, Tipper would summon him with a wave of her hand, saying: 'He's so sexy', and he would respond: 'I love it when she beckons me with her finger like that.' fields.bodyText: Although he presents himself as an environmentalist guru, Al Gore has always been enthusiastic about genetically modified 'Frankenfoods' - and for many good reasons. One might be that he himself is a GM product. No man in the history of American politics can have been so carefully and deliberately groomed, moulded, deconstructed and reconstructed for the Presidential race for which Al 'GM' Gore presents himself at the Democrat convention, opening in Los Angeles tomorrow. When Gore arrived for his first day as a journalist on the Nashville Tennessean newspaper in the autumn of 1971, most staff knew he was no regular cub reporter. Gore was being packaged to them as the young man who had just returned from his stint in Vietnam - wearing his country's uniform although he bitterly criticised its war - now making his way in the world free from the overbearing family tradition of politics. In contrast to the cynical realpolitik practiced by his father, Senator Albert Gore I, Al Gore II had studied esoteric spiritualism. He was a decent enough reporter too - he pursued a local corruption case all the way to a court hearing (although the target was acquitted). But the package was a deceptive one. Had he really wanted to go into journalism, the Harvard-educated Gore could have walked into other, more prestigious newsrooms than that which happened to have been in his father's political back-pocket in Nashville. The editor of the Nashville Tennessean was John Siegenthaler, who employed celebrity interns who would enhance his own contacts in Washington. In Vietnam, Gore's father had been able to pull a few strings (although without such sordid efficiency as George Bush's) and secured Gore a job as an army reporter. Accordingly, he had been mollycoddled around, a safe distance from the action which he reported in vivid detail from second-hand accounts. 'Gore was not the journalist type,' recalls his former colleague on the desk, Phil Sullivan. 'It didn't seem like that was what he was setting out to do. Siegenthaler saw him as someone who was going into politics.' But although his colleagues knew exactly what he was up to, Gore himself could have had no idea that the more relaxed and apparently self-confident summer intern sitting at the next desk would, in two decades time, be the man to whom he would turn for yet another in the long series of makeovers that would define his career: Carter Eskew, 'message guru' of the current campaign, laboratory technician of the present-day GM Gore and Svengali of the LA convention. It is hard to know which aspects of Al Gore's life are fact and which are fanciful, or indeed whether there is any difference between the two. Gore himself plays along with the entwinement, turning even the rawest and most intimate moments of his life - such as his own son's scrape with death in a car accident - into theatrics, part of the electoral strategy. The packaging of Al Gore as President of the United States began when he was still in utero. On the day Gore was born, the Nashville Tennessean hailed the birth on page one: 'Well, Mr Gore, Here He Is', with the Knoxville News Sentinel adding only a year or two later: 'There may be another Gore on his way to the political pinnacle.' Gore grew up not in Tennessee but in what is now the Ritz Carlton Hotel on Embassy Row in Washington DC, attending an élite prep school and spending summers on the tobacco farm in his father's home state. He played with a toy submarine in the Senate swimming-pool and bounced on President Nixon's lap. Albert Snr was a rags-to-riches, Scots-Irish politician, a New Dealer unafraid of unpopular positing and ultimately defeated after an 18-year career only when Nixon unleashed a slush of illegal finance against him, as revealed by the Watergate papers. Like his son, he enjoyed taking the ethical high ground and like his son he betrayed it. But it was Gore's mother, Pauline, who claimed the initial packaging of her son - 'I trained them both,' she said of Alberts I and II, 'and I did a better job on my son than I did on my husband.' The most striking thing about packaging Al Gore is the regularity with which it happens and the extent of the metamorphoses. The most dramatic was the apparent conversion from new-age eco-catastrophist to Vice-President in 1992 and, more recently, from a woodentop with as much political razzmatazz as a traffic jam to something from Sopranos central casting. The task in 1992 was particularly daunting and almost effective. Gore pre sented a curious figure at the time, as expressed in his book, Earth in the Balance . It was published at a time when politicians were full of foreboding about the various apocalypses of global warming, over-population and ozone-depletion and making routine pilgrimages to the Amazon rainforest. Gore had been understandably affected by his son's narrow scrape with death after a car hit the child as the family was leaving a Baltimore Orioles baseball game. He had immersed himself in alternative psychotherapy, new-age thought and the fad philosophy of Gaia, popular among right-wing eco-catastrophists, suggesting that the human race is merely part of a single, natural organism. 'It cannot be accidental,' wrote Gore in one of his more wayward passages, 'that the percentage of salt in our bloodstreams is the same as the percentage in the oceans of the world.' Gore laments mankind's alienation from this natural order, putting the blame squarely on René Descartes. Quite apart from its intellectual absurdity, Gore's position had two curiosities: the fact that it did not put off the embryonic Clinton administration and its brazen disingenuousness. On his 1998 tax return, Al Gore lists a $20,000 royalty payment from the Union Zinc Company for the right to mine zinc on his farm in Tennessee. The income, which has netted Gore $450,000 over the years, is the legacy of Gore Snr's lucrative relationship and joint ventures with fraudulent tycoon and Soviet agent, Armand Hammer, also chief executive of the environmentally controversial Occidental Petroleum Company. Among other ironies, Hammer was caught making illegal contributions to Nixon, used to topple Gore Snr. Hammer and Gore Snr enjoyed a two-way deal: Hammer boasted that he had Gore in his 'back-pocket'; he found protection from anti-communist investigations and open doors in Washington; Gore Snr secured campaign funds, a six-figure directorship upon retirement and donations for his son's Congressional campaigns. After hosting Gore and Tipper at innumerable parties, and being Al's guest at Ronald Reagan's inauguration in 1987, Hammer died in 1990. But the $20,000 a year was a handsome supplement to what Gore complained were 'slave wages' on the Tennessean , and still listed in 1992 as his most important source of income after his salary, now eclipsed by the $1.1 million in royalties from Earth in the Balance . The relationship between Gore and Occidental has remained a mutually advantageous one. Occidental loaned $100,000 to the Clinton-Gore inaugural committee in 1992, and has donated some $500,000 in 'soft money' to the Democratic Party since Gore made it on to the ticket. Baby-boomer Clinton liked the generational chemistry with Gore, and the Vietnam 'record' which, on paper, contrasted with his own. Gore the Rainbow Warrior duly became Gore the Vice-President. But what kind of packaging was it? The nadir of Gore's life-as-theatre came at the party convention in New York that year, Gore's 'coming-out' event. He told the delegates and viewing millions how he had watched Albert Gore III 'fly 30 feet through the air and scrape along the pavement... The history of Vice-Presidents assuming the top office is a patchy one, as Pauline Gore must have realised when she expressed coded disapproval of her son's supporting role to the 'provincial' Bill Clinton. It was a concept in promotion pioneered by the shock of Truman's takeover from Franklin Roosevelt and L.B.J.'s even more dramatic succession of J.F. Kennedy, but these were without preparation. Gore had creased the nation's sides by telling CNN's Wolf Blitzer he had 'taken the initiative in creating the internet'. Hillary Clinton's candidacy in New York created a Medusan triangle inside the White House with resentments in all directions. Most importantly, Gore was making instantly and utterly forgettable speeches: 'Gore' was spelled with a 'B'. A Wagnerian family psychodrama was playing out between Clinton and Gore - 'father' and 'son' - which was, with hindsight, crucial to Gore's selection of running mate last week. Throughout the Lewinsky scandal, Gore had walked a high wire between loyalty and disgust. Apart from Hillary, he was the most senior victim of the President's deceit but also had the highest honour under Clinton's patronage to betray if he abandoned him. Gore's political father (Clinton) finally blessed Gore's ambition to become President in 1998, the year that his actual father died, thereby turning Clinton's political paternity into something more complex. Gore always knew that his success lay in the passing of power by both to him, as George Bush Snr has done to his son. But there was a problem - the motives of both Gore's father figures were entirely narcissistic. One wanted a President Gore who would bear the family name in the White House, the other a President Gore to rescue his legacy from the stains on Monica's dress. In his hour of need, Gore was shunned by the surrogate father in a way he never was by Albert Snr. Out of the blue, Clinton made an unsolicited call to the New York Times, making clear his displeasure at the way Gore was conducting his campaign. On the morning his remarks were published, the atmosphere in Gore's White House office was one of 'stunned disbelief'. Meanwhile, down the corridor, Gore had been shut out of the huddle that gathered around the President to discuss the advisability and fallout of the Times interview. Gore's retort came sharp enough. He told Diane Sawyer he thought Clinton's behaviour during the Lewinsky scandal had been 'inexcusable... especially as a father'. Gore assembled a team with specific instructions - to repackage him again, almost from scratch. A war council was convened by the new campaign director, Tony Coelho, a former Congressman dogged by allegations of embezzlement and scandal, to do just that. According to one present at the meeting, the message was to 'free Gore from his office and from the White House' - to declare UDI from Bill and Hillary. Gore moved his campaign headquarters from Washington to his supposed 'roots' in Tennessee. The move was also a good way to cull a troubled, squabbling staff, to sort out the wheat prepared to sacrifice everything to follow him from the chaff who preferred to stay around their DC dinner tables. Brazile added a trial by salary, cutting everybody's by two-thirds. Gore and his senior staff remained in the comfort of Washington. Diane Sawyer conducted the first TV interview in Tennessee with Gore and Tipper on his late father's tobacco farm. Gore wore jeans and cowboy boots. Sawyer threw the first pitch, a fastball. fields.headline: Smith's problems start
fields.standfirst: Palace fail to break their losing streak but fallen giants Forest and Blackburn both start the season well
fields.trailText: Palace fail to break their losing streak but fallen giants Forest and Blackburn both start the season well.
fields.body:
Graeme Souness and Blackburn Rovers will have slept happier last night. With the first three points of a make-or-break season safely in the kitty, the 'fat cat' legacy their manager has been so keen to shrug off has receded, leaving their supporters purring in quiet satisfaction.

Goals from Nathan Blake and Matt Jansen just before half-time were enough to cleanse a summer of frustration watching others take their place among the elite. There was even a hint of a smile below the Scotsman's trademark moustache.

'The first half we were very good, almost excellent,' said the Blackburn manager. 'But then I got it wrong and made the mistake of telling them that at half-time. We looked tired and nervous after the break. But you have to remember the bad start we made last year. We were all wary of the criticism and expectation, but I'd rather be favourites to go up than be relegated any day.'

Last season's gross under-achievement still haunts Ewood Park, where the images of Charlton and Manchester City enjoying their promotion parties on the Ewood Park pitch are still fresh in the memory.

But, with Souness at the helm, such failure will not be tolerated again. 'The future starts today, right here and now,' he proclaimed in his programme notes. 'The players, coaches, management and backroom staff have sweated, stretched and strained every sinew to enable us to hit the ground winning.'

His battle cry almost reaped instant rewards, although for 'ground' read 'woodwork'. With 10 minutes gone, the lively Irish winger Damien Duff dispossessed Hayden Mullins, advanced into the area and saw his shot deflected on to a post with Stuart Taylor well beaten.

Matt Jansen, a former Palace player who had earned the nickname 'Magic Man' at Selhurst Park, almost conjured an opener five minutes later but his shot whistled wide of the upright.

Jansen's former employers are looking to a brighter future themselves. Since Simon Jordan bought the club last month there have been seven new signings and, most significantly, a change in management with Alan Smith replacing last season's saviour, Steve Coppell.

Smith's task is to establish Palace as the fourth biggest club in the capital. Given that many of their fans were stuck en route in a traffic jam on the M6 at kick-off, the vociferous support which had successfully arrived in Lancashire made such a suggestion less laughable than it may at first appear.

But, a scuffed Clinton Morrison effort aside, Palace were rarely in contention during a one-sided first half which had almost drawn to a close before Rovers found their reward. Dean Austin dallied with the ball on the edge of his area and was robbed by David Dunn. With the defender desperately trying to atone for his error, Dunn squared the ball across the six-yard box for Nathan Blake to score via the underside of the bar. It was the transfer-listed Welshman's first goal since February.

As Palace floundered, Rovers doubled their advantage with the interval approaching. Dunn emerged from midfield and slipped a delightful ball inside the Palace rearguard for the on-rushing Jansen. The 22-year-old calmly took it round Taylor and passed the ball into the empty net.

'It was five minutes of madness,' said Smith. 'I'd started to work out what to say to the lads at half-time, but after conceding those two I was back to square one.'

The last time he brought a Palace side to Ewood Park, Rovers won a tense encounter 2-1 thanks to a goal from Kevin Gallacher. Blackburn went on to win the Premiership that year; Palace were relegated. Times have changed at both clubs but, while the Eagles' financial problems are over, the turmoil of last season appears to have transposed itself on to the pitch this term.

'I suppose when you've lost 5-1 at Crawley and 6-0 at Millwall, losing 2-0 here borders on a miracle,' said Smith with a wry smile. 'Blackburn have been to Germany and played games against Everton and Leeds here. Some of my lads went to China on a pre-season tour. What kind of preparation is that?

'I've got such a young side. There were eight players under 22 out there and this is a big place for them to come. They've got to be tucked up by nine o'clock tonight.' Some of the youngsters may have wet the bed after this Ewood experience. Duff volleyed into the side-netting just after the break and Jansen had what appeared to be a legitimate goal disallowed seconds later.

But, with Blackburn visibly sitting back on their lead, the visitors were handed a route back into the contest - Mikael Forssell, on a season's loan from Chelsea, burst through the centre but saw his prodded effort drift wide of Alan Kelly's post. With it went Palace's chances.

'We were slightly worried that they might overrun us,' conceded Smith. 'But, with some better finishing, you don't know what might have happened.'

His players will report for training this morning with their manager vowing not to give them a day off until matters improve on the pitch. 'We will get better,' he insisted.

As for Blackburn, life already is. 'It's nice to win games and entertain,' added a contented Souness. 'It's a start.'

fields.headline: Watford's luck turns
fields.trailText: It was never like this in the Premiership for Watford, who discovered that defensive failings will not be punished by First Division teams as they were on the way to relegation last season.
fields.byline: John Wardle at The McAlpine Stadium
fields.body:
It was never like this in the Premiership for Watford, who discovered that defensive failings will not be punished by First Division teams as they were on the way to relegation last season.

Graham Taylor's side were in disarray after gifting the opening goal to Huddersfield and offering the Yorkshire club enough opportunities to start with a confidence-enhancing victory.

Huddersfield squandered every one and Watford made them suffer by scoring twice either side of half-time. But at least Taylor recognised that much of this season's allocation of good fortune had already been used up.

'I would have been happy to get one point after our first-half performance,' he said. 'To finish with all of them is a footballing miracle.'

To add to the miserable mood of Town's supporters, the chief miracle worker was Michel Ngonge, a player many of them hoped would now be a Huddersfield player.

They wanted manager Steve Bruce to sign Ngonge after a successful stay on loan last season and applauded the midfielder generously when he went on as a substitute at the start of the second half.

It was a nice gesture, regretted within a minute when Ngonge's first touch was a perceptive through-ball that Tommy Smith swept home to earn Watford a victory that looked improbable for all but the final minute of that one-sided first half.

Espen Baardsen, the keeper Watford signed from Spurs, was given plenty of early warnings that uncertainty lurks within the defenders in front of him.

This was confirmed after 15 minutes. Martin Smith's left-wing cross was fractionally too high for Clyde Wijnhard, but his presence was enough to distract Steve Palmer, whose header found the top corner as he stooped to clear.

Town should have wrapped it up in the next 10 minutes. Steve Jenkins picked out Wijnhard with a 23rd-minute cross, but the Dutchman's firm header was kept out by Baardsen's legs.

Then Kevin Gallen exposed an alarming gap in front of the keeper, who was beaten by a shot that struck the inside of the post, swerved across the goal and past the outside of the other post.

Watford, reprieved and relieved, went on to an improbable success after an equaliser in the dying seconds of the half. It undoubtedly changed the interval atmosphere in the two dress ing rooms and Huddersfield keeper Nico Vaesen must take the bulk of the blame.

Vaesen, expecting a cross when Neil Cox took a free-kick from the left flank, succeeded only in pushing the ball in after Cox drilled it towards the near post.

Ngonge's arrival and Smith's goal made a mockery of Huddersfield's earlier superiority and, growing increasingly anxious, they were unable to rediscover it in the second half.

webTitle: Dons off to a weary start

fields.headline: Dons off to a weary start
fields.trailText: If Wimbledon fans greeted the fixture computer's choice of opening-day opponents with a smack of the lips at the prospect of an easy victory, Tranmere swiftly disillusioned them. Despite long periods of pressure and obvious superiority in almost every position, they failed to secure the victory they should have done. A familiar story.
fields.body:
If Wimbledon fans greeted the fixture computer's choice of opening-day opponents with a smack of the lips at the prospect of an easy victory, Tranmere swiftly disillusioned them. Despite long periods of pressure and obvious superiority in almost every position, they failed to secure the victory they should have done. A familiar story.

Tranmere celebrated their first clean sheet in 16 league games as a frail defence, who started uneasily, gradually hardened although Wimbledon plainly lacked a cutting edge. 'I'm reasonably happy with the performance, if not the result,' said Terry Burton after his first game since being appointed Wimbledon's full-time manager at the end of last season. 'The only thing missing is the goals. In this league you do need a goalscorer.'

He will be hoping that the return of John Hartson, still suspended after being sent off at Bradford last season, solves that problem. But Burton was particularly pleased with the form of a less well-known forward, the 19-year-old Patrick Agyemang, making his full debut. The first team may not be flourishing but Wimbledon's youth scheme continues to bear fruit.

Agyemang showed a nice touch, has plenty of pace and was happy to run at defenders, even if he was over-enthusiastic. 'The kid's got ability,' said Burton. 'He's quick, pleasing to the eye and fans like that kind of player. He does a lot of fine work outside the box, but he's not a natural goalscorer.'

That much was proved by the fact that, despite the high number of crosses that Wimbledon aimed towards him, Agyemang got on the end of only one, screwing his header wide of goal. 'When he was in the youth team I bet him £20 that he'd never score with his head,' added Burton. 'I've still got the money.'

Agyemang's most telling contribution came after just 10 minutes when his pace scared John Achterberg in the Tranmere goal into taking his eye off the ball.

Wimbledon's young forward stole it, but his shot hit the back of a defender and rolled across the box where Neil Ardley, who wasted almost all of Wimbledon's best chances, completely missed his kick when 10 yards away from an unguarded net.

In contrast to Burton, the Tranmere manager, John Aldridge, was happy with the result but not the performance. 'We made it hard for ourselves,' he said. 'We gave the ball away too much but for sheer guts and determination you've got to say we deserved the draw.'

Even with Dave Challinor's prodigious long throws, the visitors created few chances and came closest to scoring through a long-range effort from Steve Yates that Kelvin Davis, replacing Neil Sullivan in Wimbledon's goal, did well to turn wide.

They were not helped by a first-half injury to Nick Henry, who needed stitches to his neck after a collision with Mark Williams, and the second-half sending-off of Sean Flynn after two unnecessary bookings although neither event, to be fair, made much difference to the course of the game.

But Wimbledon must get used to starting games as favourites, to opponents happy to come away from Selhurst Park with a draw, and, inevitably, to disappointing attendances. In short, to life in the Nationwide League and all that comes with it. Even after this disappointing draw, they look good enough to cope.

webTitle: Paterson heads home to give Smith a welcome break

fields.headline: Paterson heads home to give Smith a welcome break
fields.trailText: New Dundee United boss Alex Smith had a lucky escape after his side were out-classed for most of game but still came away with a point.
fields.body:
New Dundee United boss Alex Smith had a lucky escape after his side were out-classed for most of game but still came away with a point.

A late Jim Paterson equaliser saved Smith's side from total humiliation after Motherwell outplayed and outfought them for 90 minutes. John Spencer had fired the visitors into an early first-half lead, which they seemed highly unlikely to surrender. But, with seconds remaining, Paterson latched on to a Neil Heaney cross to send a header past a helpless Andy Goram and into the Motherwell net.

While Smith looked relieved as his side left the pitch, in truth, there had been little for the small crowd to get excited about. United have looked out of sorts since the start of the season and even the arrival of a new manager, after Paul Sturrock's resignation, failed to galvanise the team into action.

Motherwell clearly started more energetically with Spencer, returning after a two-match ban, showing some nice touches. Subsequently it was no great surprise when the visitors took the lead. Spencer raced on to a Ged Brannan pass and when United keeper Alan Combe hesitated, the little striker poked the ball into an empty net.

Five minutes later Combe again was slow off his line and this time it was Lee McCulloch who won the race for the ball. Much to his relief the United keeper watched the ball slip harmlessly past his far post.

Even this early on, United looked ragged and were finding it difficult to find team-mates with their passing.

Although Motherwell remained dominant, the home side could have equalised minutes from the break when Steven Thompson set up Alex Mathie on the six-yard box - only for the United striker's overhead kick to clear the bar comfortably.

Smith must have had plenty to say to his players at half-time, but it appeared his message had fallen on deaf ears. Within a minute Combe had to react smartly to pull off a good save from Paul Harvey, whose shot from 10 yards looked netbound.

Eventually the home side applied some pressure to the visitors' goal. After 54 minutes Thompson came close but watched in agony as his angled shot from 10 yards skimmed the bar with Goram beaten.

Then just as United seemed to be heading for defeat, they grabbed an equaliser. Substi tute Neil Heaney raced down the right and swung over his cross to the back post. Paterson appeared to be struggling to reach it but he stretched his neck muscles and sent his header over Goram and into the net.

fields.headline: Kiddy enjoy perfect debut
fields.trailText: Jan Molby's Harriers express, against a background of appreciative toots from trains on the adjacent Severn Valley Railway, began to make up for lost time at a packed Aggborough Stadium.
fields.body:
Jan Molby's Harriers express, against a background of appreciative toots from trains on the adjacent Severn Valley Railway, began to make up for lost time at a packed Aggborough Stadium.

Shamefully denied access to the Football League by the suits in 1994, Molby's team began their overdue journey in fine style - their football proving too much for a more physical Torquay side.

That aspect of the Third Division had worried Molby before kick off and he was delighted with his team's display. 'We showed we can play a bit against a very good team who were unlucky not to reach the play-offs last season,' he said.

'Obviously I don't want to get carried away because we're judged in May and not the middle of August. But we're entitled to enjoy today.'

Molby will also have enjoyed the performance of two of his new recruits, Andy Ducros and Barry Horne, who scored a spectacular second goal to complete the victory.

Ducros, the club's record signing at £100,000, was a constant menace to the visiting defence who were unable to get to grips with his role of withdrawn striker and it was his cross that set up Harriers' first chance.

It fell to Paul Webb, who at 32 has given up a well-paid job as a warehouse manager to join Molby's adventure. He headed over, but Harriers' first League goal was not long in coming.

It came from Stewart Hadley in the 15th minute, following spadework by Ian Clarkson and Scott Stamps. Hadley fired home from 10 yards and this part of Worcestershire erupted. So too did the Torquay defence, who felt the goal should have been disallowed for offside.

At the heart of the protests was central defender Jimmy Aggrey, who became increasingly irate as he and his fellow defenders were given the run around and was predictably booked near the end.

Torquay, though, were presented with some good fortune of their own in the 31st minute when the otherwise impressive Adie Smith slipped and gave the ball to Kevin Parker, who advanced on Harriers keeper Tim Clark. Initially Clark looked disinterested but he eventually reacted to thwart Parker with a diving save.

It was to prove a costly miss for the visitors when Horne scored with a spectacular 25-yard volley to complete the victory.

webTitle: Five-star Hibs post warning to rivals

fields.headline: Five-star Hibs post warning to rivals
fields.standfirst: Hibernian leapfrog Rangers and Celtic to go top of the Premier League after a five-goal rout of hapless Dundee
fields.trailText: Hibernian leapfrog Rangers and Celtic to go top of the Premier League after a five-goal rout of hapless Dundee.
fields.body:
Hibs reached the top of the Premier League on the back of a performance that will cause the other 11 members to take them very seriously indeed.

A game that could have been a classic between two talented and adventurous teams eventually became a lopsided mismatch after the Dundee striker Fabian Caballero was sent off shortly before the interval. It was Dundee's misfortune to have another player, Patrizio Billio, issued with a red card - the result of a second yellow - as stoppage time approached.

Easter Road's regular customers can rarely have witnessed football as exhilarating as these two produced before the ordering-off that rather interfered with the over-all fluency.

The dismissal was an unfortunate souring, the Argentinian swinging his forearm at the face of Mathias Jack after the German had completed a harmless tackle near the touchline. It appeared that Caballero expected to be hurt by the momentum of Jack's lunge, but in fact the latter took the ball and the Dundee man appeared to retaliate in anticipation, rather than as the result of being assaulted.

The sadness of that dismissal was deepened by the memory of the goal with which Caballero had given a sweet-moving Dundee side their early lead. As Juan Sara, with his back to goal, played the ball out to Georgi Nemsadze just beyond the penalty area, Caballero bolted into the right side of the box. The pass was impeccable, allowing him to hit a ferocious drive into the far corner of Nick Colgan's net.

That seemed a hard goal to match, but Agathe actually topped it with the first strike that levelled the score. Receiving the ball from Russell Latapy on the half-way line, the French striker shrugged off three challenges - each seeming likely to ground him - on his 50-yard run, ending with a cool side-foot finish low to the left of Robert Douglas.

Agathe completed his double when Latapy's powerful run out of defence gave him the space to send another precise pass to the Frenchman in the inside-left position. This time he finished with a right-foot drive high to the left of Douglas.

Sandwiched between these goals was an unconverted penalty from the home team, Latapy uncharacteristically giving Douglas a comparatively easy save with a weak shot to the goalkeeper's left, after Marcello Marrocco had lost control of the ball and stretched out a foot to trip Tom Smith.

The difficulties of overcoming 10-man opposition quickly presented themselves as Hibs' previously incisive forward movement was rather blunted by visitors who were forced into a policy of containment - clearly one that was not suited to their cavalier instincts.

But the third did arrive when substitute Dirk Lehmann, on for Paatelainen, headed the ball down and over the line from John O'Neil's right-sided centre. The German striker almost immediately completed his double by sliding a cut-back from Ulrik Laursen over the line from six yards.

By the time another sub, Stuart Lovell, knocked in the fifth from close range, Dundee were discouraged, dismayed and in disarray.

fields.headline: Saha makes his mark
fields.trailText: A variation of this score line could read Voila 2 Gotcha 0. For this was the definitive new Millennium clash between the longest serving managerial head in the English game and one of these new-fangled French tutors.
fields.body:
A variation of this score line could read Voila 2 Gotcha 0. For this was the definitive new Millennium clash between the longest serving managerial head in the English game and one of these new-fangled French tutors.

And it was a case of ta-ta Saha 12 minutes from the end but not before French striker Louis, a recent £2 million import from Metz, had finally beaten heroic Crewe goalkeeper Jason Kearton with an exquisite chip from Fulham skipper Chris Coleman's old-fashioned long ball.

The first thing Fulham fans had to thank new boss Jean Tigana for was the Riviera weather he brought with him. Ironically, the man who looked most at home in it was Crewe's Greenwich-born defender Efe Sodje who sported a red and white pirate's bandana to match his shirt.

Saha was even more daring in his choice of coiffeur. He sported braids and beads. And he nearly made a right pig's ear of that 'Barnet' as early as the third minute with a close-in header from Bjarne Goldbaek's cross.

Unfortunately he failed to make a mess of the Fulham net when goalkeeper Jason Kearton produced the first of his many breathtaking first half saves.

Prompted by his fellow £2m Scottish debutant John Collins, who earned frequent applause for his aplomb on the ball, Saha went on to stage a one-man assault on Kearton, who was making his 105th consecutive appearance for his club.

But the Crewe keeper, who had understudied Neville Southall at Everton for seven years, appeared to have broken this French import's spirit by half time when he forced Saha to shoot tamely over the crossbar from an open goal.

Tigana has, of course, inherited a Harrods bumper from Mohamed Al Fayed, but there was nothing much of the muck and nettles style defending from sophisticated Crewe. Their manager, Dario Gradi, is the longest-serving one-club English manager with an incredible 17 years at Crewe under his belt. And he has long been famed for the conveyor-belt of bright young English talent that he churns out.

His counterpart Tigana has gone on record as saying that it is his vision to train a young English player to play for England one day. But Gradi has beaten him to it at least half a dozen times already. Crewe's skipper, Steve Macaulay, earned the first booking of the match after half an hour, but it owed much to Saha's French importation of the well known roly-poly reaction to tacklers.

Old hand Barry Hales put Fulham ahead seven minutes after replacing Louis Boa Morte in the 66th minute. He scored from close in after the umpteenth Goldbaek cross which was cut back into his grateful path by Lee Clark. Because of the almost tropical sunshine, we saw the rarity of a full house of all six substitutions.

fields.headline: Bolton pegged back
fields.trailText: Honours even in the first of the many Lancashire derbies the First Division has to offer this season, but despite an intriguing and heated encounter, it was one that offered little insight into the long-term fortunes awaiting the two rivals.
fields.byline: Ian Whittell at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
Honours even in the first of the many Lancashire derbies the First Division has to offer this season, but despite an intriguing and heated encounter, it was one that offered little insight into the long-term fortunes awaiting the two rivals.

For Bolton, whose makeshift team dominated the first half, surely better awaits once manager Sam Allardyce is able to work with a settled squad. For Stan Ternent's Burnley, as commanding after the interval as their hosts were before it, survival appears achievable on this display, should they avoid injuries to a worryingly thin squad.

Given those limitations, it was ironic that it was a Burnley substitute, winger Glen Little, who dramatically altered the course of a game that seemed to be comfortably heading towards a home victory.

Pre-season injury robbed Little, the object of summer interest from Aston Villa and Bradford, of a starting place, yet his introduction could scarcely have had a bigger impact on the game.

fields.headline: Aimless Forest scrape a win
fields.trailText: Amazing what a bit of sun can do to fan the feel-good factor. A crowd 4,000 above Nottingham Forest's average of last season thronged to the City Ground optimistically, only to be subjected to the shortcomings of last season for most of the game. Then, finally, it happened, courtesy of a man fortunate to be on the field.
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at The City Ground
fields.body:
Amazing what a bit of sun can do to fan the feel-good factor. A crowd 4,000 above Nottingham Forest's average of last season thronged to the City Ground optimistically, only to be subjected to the shortcomings of last season for most of the game. Then, finally, it happened, courtesy of a man fortunate to be on the field.

Chance after chance went begging, Forest looking in need of a term at a finishing school, until Jon Olav Hjelde headed home a corner to break the stalemate. He might well have been up in the stand, suited up, however, having escaped a red card and the concession of a penalty after appearing to haul down West Bromwich Albion's new £2million striker Jason Roberts in the first-half.

'Yeah, without a shadow of a doubt,' said the Albion manager Gary Megson when asked about the 'penalty'. He was, in fact, so convinced that he was not constrained by the month's touchline ban he is already serving for remarks about referees. 'Even if their lad's ended up getting the ball, it's a tackle from behind and he had to have brought our player down first.'

'I thought it might have been outside the area but, yes, we got away with it,' admitted the Forest manager, David Platt. His side may ultimately have deserved their victory, but this one decision - with referee Paul Taylor and his linesman both looking as if they were abdicating responsibility - had huge impact on the outcome.

You could see why Platt had thought about picking himself on the first-half's evidence. To be fair, he was missing the injured striker Stern John - Dwight Yorke's partner for Trinidad and Tobago. That said, anyone with a resemblance of calm would have tucked away some of the Forest opportunities.

First, Gary Jones, acquired on a 'Bosman' from Tranmere and pressed into striking service, headed Alan Rogers's cross across goal from a few yards out. Then Andy Johnson lazily nodded over the impressive 18-year-old David Prutton's curling cross from even closer.

Punishment seemed imminent a minute before the interval when Derek McInnes's long ball found Roberts, signed from Bristol Rovers, in the clear and he seemed certain to score until Hjelde intervened. Goalless and still with 11 men, Platt was able to re-organise for the second half.

A hamstring tweak to the lumbering Johnson was a blessing in disguise, with Riccardo Scimeca moving into midfield and using possession more effectively. Even he caught Forest's mal a la tete, however, heading Matthiu Louis-Jean's cross over.

In addition, he twice sidefooted shots - one set up cleverly by Prutton - too close to the Albion goalkeeper Brian Jensen, though the goal did come from the second. From Rogers's corner, Hjelde thrust himself to the near post to divert home a firm downward header and embarrass his forward players, one of whom, Jack Lester, went on to see a lob that beat Jensen bounce over the bar.

Albion's late flurry never looked likely to bear fruit but it was more than a bit presumptuous and premature of the home DJ to play We Are The Champions at the final whistle. Forest had luck to go with the optimism, both necessary ingredients, but, more importantly, if they are to mount a promotion challenge, they will need a few quality re-inforcements.

fields.headline: Essex romp it
fields.standfirst:
Worcestershire 302 & 282
Essex 462 & 125-0
Essex won by 10 wickets
fields.trailText:
Worcestershire 302 & 282
Essex 462 & 125-0
Essex won by 10 wickets
fields.body:
Never mind that other distraction a mile across town at Aggborough Stadium, the place to be yesterday, in the pre-prandial hours at least, was the Chester Road ground where Worcestershire sought to keep pace with those other promotion contenders, Essex.

Not that they entertained realistic hopes of overturning the visitors, who required only 117 at the start with all second-innings wickets intact to move within five points of Northamptonshire, the Second Division leaders. The match was duly done and dusted in glorious weather 10 minutes before lunch, after the two Pauls, Prichard and Grayson had extended their overnight opening stand to 125 with undefeated half-centuries.

Nasser Hussain, the England captain, sat in ruminative repose on the pavilion balcony, not even required - a mixed blessing if ever there was one. He was on a hiding to nothing, of course, with only 144 runs in a dozen completed first-class innings this season, and has much on his mind in the coming weeks.

A terrible trough of form five days before the critical fourth Test at Headingley is worrisome all round, and he was understandably in no mood to expound afterwards. 'I've done nothing today and I need a couple of days away,' he said.

Worcestershire are feeling the pinch after Glenn McGrath's temporary defection to Australia's one-day series against South Africa, and Alamgir Sheriyar, who went for 22 in two overs, all to Prichard, is short of bowling. The pitch is a road of a track with good pace and even bounce, and is made for batting. Dennis Jones, the groundsman, is sadly unwell, but has nurtured the turf like a loving father for 25 years, infusing true devotion with a top-dressing of Banbury loam.

The result is impressive, but Worcestershire have lost their last four championship matches here and yearn for McGrath's return to sustain the challenge. To that end, they are seeking to fly him by helicopter from Heathrow to the crunch game at New Road against Warwickshire on 22 August. Desperation indeed.

fields.headline: Lights out for unlucky Neil
fields.trailText: Neil Fairbrother is surely the first batsman to be given out by reflected light. And in the process the Lancashire batsman could have been the unwitting catalyst in the development of another hi-tech aid for the third umpire.
fields.body:
Neil Fairbrother is surely the first batsman to be given out by reflected light. And in the process the Lancashire batsman could have been the unwitting catalyst in the development of another hi-tech aid for the third umpire.

When Fairbrother appeared to be run out in Wednesday's day-night match at Headingley a replay was called for. The usual side-on shot didn't seem to be available. Instead, there was one from roughly behind the bowler, with someone obscuring the critical action, and that left the view from the stump camera. This showed the Fairbrother bat coming towards the crease, and also three thin, vertical strands of light - which suddenly wobbled when the bat was still short. 'That's the stumps going,' said a commentator. 'And that's out.'

Were Sky pioneering a scientific method of showing the precise moment the bails come off - something they will feature, perhaps, as the Stump Shake? 'No,' says a spokesman, 'it was just the light on the lens reflecting back off the stumps. But thanks for the idea.'

*****

Even motor racing, or the space industry, would be pushed to meet the challenge recently flung at cricket equipment suppliers. They were given five weeks, of which two remain, to produce an advanced helmet for juniors. The requirements are a new material, lighter but just as strong; a ventilation solution for dehydration problems; and adjustability for different sized heads.

The rush is on due to the England Cricket Board's much-debated decision early this year to make helmet-wearing compulsory for all young players. Unsurprisingly, there has been a big shortage of small helmets. Now, the ECB hope to have 20,000 ready for next season, if an order can be placed by the end of the month.

To companies like Alfred Reader, suppliers of the Albion C&D helmet, 'it's a very difficult timescale - they don't seem to understand the logistics of getting the product into the marketplace'. Readers say they do have 'something in the pipeline', which they will try to accelerate. But they are shaken by the added objective for the new helmet - a selling price of nearer £30 than the current £70. 'I find it amazing,' says a Readers spokesman, 'that we're trying to persuade parents to buy a helmet for £30, when they'll spend over £100 on a bat - and happily pay £60 for their child's riding helmet.'

Frank Kemp, the ECB officer in charge of the project, acknowledges that 'there will inevitably be a trade-off between price and technological improvements'. He also accepts that 'it may take a year or more for improvements to be seen'. Not such an impossible timescale after all, then.

*****

Not a single run came from the bat when Cuddalore were dismissed for six - all wides - by Chennai B in an inter-district women's match in India. But the oddest thing about this story of 10 consecutive ducks, told on the cricinfo.com website, is that one of the batswomen did get the ball away in the direction of the boundary, only to be seized by cramp as she started to run. A runner was called for, but when she arrived there was, alas, nothing more to run for.

fields.headline: Smith's mad moment
fields.standfirst: Knight and Singh make the most of Hampshire's generosity
fields.trailText: Norman Harris sees Knight and Singh make the most of Hampshire's generosity.
fields.body:
Quite reasonably, the man of the match was Nick Knight for his faultless hundred. But the central figure in this not-always-straightforward NatWest semi-final was undoubtedly the man Hampshire call Judge: Robin Smith. It was he who made the fateful decision to bowl first, on a pitch that turned out to be a featherbed. And he who took it upon himself, with the bat, to try to rectify the consequences of that decision.

He didn't succeed. On 61, the captain of Hampshire was beaten and bowled by his namesake, Neil, the captain of Warwickshire. Great was the fielding side's rejoicing. Greatly expressive, too, was the weary pause before the batsman started his homeward trudge.

Much earlier in the day the two Smiths had met for the toss, and there was considerable surprise at the decision to let Warwickshire bat first. That was evidently made on the basis of a touch of moisture in the pitch, perhaps promising a little movement in the morning.

But it still looked like a desperate gamble by the poorest-performing side of the season, and quite soon it hardly looked like a contest at all as the ball went through slowly and without deviation - except from the bat.

At other levels of cricket you will get sides turning up in August who are so weak - with players on holiday and a couple of fill-ins who may turn up late - that they opt to put the other team in to bat if they win the toss, to make the game last a bit longer. In truth it looked a bit like that, as Hampshire's decision to bowl at first looked increasingly nonsensical, and a huge Warwickshire total inevitable.

Once Knight had got the pace of the pitch, he was soon finding an easy route to the backward-point boundary. Soon, too, he was going down the pitch to seam bowlers - forcing the keeper to come up to the stumps to try and deter him.

Anurag Singh took a little longer to get moving. And, on 10, he survived when bowler and wicketkeeper believed the ball had flicked Singh's outside edge as he played forward. Channel 4's snickometer gave some credence to that, but umpire Jeremy Lloyds wasn't convinced.

In the absence of Shane Warne, Hampshire's only bowling ace was Alan Mullally, who has been in great championship form. But when he came on first change he was immediately expensive - Singh striking a wonderful extra-cover boundary 'on the up' - and was withdrawn after two overs. It wasn't that he was bowling badly, more that the pitch offered no pace or movement.

So easy was it that it is hard to say whether Knight's performance will force his Test claims. It must also have been hard for Warwickshire to determine how well they were doing. Ironically, the sublime progress of Knight and Singh left little time for the real enforcers. No blame to the openers, though. The pair's 185 was a first-wicket record for Warwickshire in any one-day competition, beating the 180 of those 1970s favourites Dennis Amiss and John Jameson.

Given a platform of 133 without loss from 30 overs, 262 was perhaps a touch light. Perhaps Hampshire had done rather well after all? That nagging thought deepened as the captain came in first, and gave the innings a flying start. His highest score in any cricket this season is just 71, but now we saw the Smith of old: the bristling body language, the defiant forward defensive alternating with the rifle-shot square cut.

But spin was always his weak point, and he was 'done' by both the flight and turn of the ball which went through his half-formed drive. It was 101 for two when he fell. Hampshire were always going down after that - though as Warne might have said, as he watched Down Under, they proved they were not the mugs many people took them for.

fields.headline: Pollock hopes to restore pride
fields.trailText: Captain Shaun Pollock and his South African squad arrived in Australia yesterday for a three-match limited overs series anxious to put the Hansie Cronje match-fixing scandal behind them.
fields.body:
Captain Shaun Pollock and his South African squad arrived in Australia yesterday for a three-match limited overs series anxious to put the Hansie Cronje match-fixing scandal behind them.

Pollock said victory in the one-day internationals against Australia in Melbourne would help restore the South African public's confidence in the game. The first match is on Wednesday.

'If we can win this it will go a long way to help people who have been miserable about what has happened,' he said.

'I think it's only a matter of time before they can rally behind us 100 per cent again. Maybe once the report is out it can be totally forgotten about.'

Judge Edwin King handed the South African government his interim report into the scandal on Friday, stressing it made no recommendations.

Pollock said none of the players on the current visiting team had been involved in the scandal and team morale had not been affected.

Herschelle Gibbs, Henry Williams and Pieter Strydom have all been suspended after admitting during open hearings in June to having accepted bribes of $15,000 from Cronje to under-perform.

However, all three have also said under oath they did not receive the money because they had not fulfilled their part of the agreement.

Pollock said he was confident opening batsman Gibbs would return to the team after he accepted whatever the disciplinary panel dealt out.

'After their findings he can obviously concentrate back on his cricket and we'd love to have him back whenever he's ready,' Pollock said.

fields.headline: Mullally the man in form
fields.trailText: Two problems only for the England selectors prior to the Headingley Test, one of which they can't do much about; the other will prompt plenty of agonising up until 10.30 on Thursday morning.
fields.body:
Two problems only for the England selectors prior to the Headingley Test, one of which they can't do much about; the other will prompt plenty of agonising up until 10.30 on Thursday morning.

The selectors, who name their squad for the fourth Test this morning, are powerless when it comes to making Nasser Hussain score some runs. We are not in Mike Denness territory yet - remember how he dropped himself on the 1974/5 tour of Australia. Hussain has to play and so he should, but some runs would ease anxieties all round.

However they might consider shuffling the order. There is a case for sending the adhesive Michael Vaughan in at number three, which was where he batted at Lord's and dispatching the out-of-form captain to number six, where he might see a little more of Franklyn Rose and Reon King than Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose. But I doubt whether Hussain would like the idea. He might see it as an admission of his frailty. But if it's better for the team....

More taxing will be deciding the balance of the side that takes to the field. The first six batsmen will stay the same and the four pace bowlers employed at Old Trafford will also remain unchanged. Which leaves the position occupied by Robert Croft at Manchester to be debated. So much will depend on the state of the skies on Thursday, the long term weather forecast and what the capricious Headingley strip looks like.

The ball does not always seam mischievously there. Given blue skies and some extra attention from the groundstaff the pitch can be slow, bland and justifying the inclusion of a spinner. But once the grey clouds glower over the Western Terrace a spinner is as much use as a contracted player when in pursuit of the County Championship.

There are three options open to the England camp. If sunny they could retain Croft or try an alternative spinner like Ashley Giles, who is modestly reliable with the ball and a handy batsman. I doubt whether they will do this, though. They may reason that the ball turned at Old Trafford and yet the spinner took only one wicket so what's the point of playing one on a surface that is not expected to turn?

Or they could play seven batsmen, which would mean that Graeme Hick would be recalled, which might cheer him up. But he might have to bat at number seven, which might make him grumpy again. This ploy could only be justified if the selectors were convinced that the Headingley pitch was going to be at its most nefarious with innings lasting no more than about 70 overs. Otherwise England might run out of bowlers.

Perhaps the likeliest option will be to replace Croft with another paceman and let Vaughan do whatever spinning is necessary. In which case Matthew Hoggard would expect to be recalled on his home ground. He may be deserving but it must also be tempting for the selectors to whisk Alan Mullally back into the team. Being left-handed he offers variety. More importantly he is in the best form of his life. As the selectors managed with Marcus Trescothick there is the chance to play someone when he's in the middle of a rich vein, so why not take it, even if this may seem unfair to Hoggard?

There are not so many options open to the West Indies. What's more they hate changing their team under any circumstances. With Shivnarine Chanderpaul still out of commission, the batting line-up, which redeemed itself in the second innings at Old Trafford, will presumably stay the same.

Their major concern must be their support bowling so they must decide whether Nixon McLean could do a better job than either of the current incumbents, King and Rose.

Rose, for all his high spirits, must be infuriating to captain, which was neatly highlighted by his first over at Old Trafford. When he was introduced for the eleventh over of the innings, Trescothick was still sweating on his first Test run; he had been expertly tormented by Ambrose and Walsh; it seemed impossible for him to score. On comes Rose; his first ball was a leg-stump half volley, gratefully received and despatched by Trescothick.

Pressure relieved; captain exasperated. It must be tempting to replace him.

fields.headline: Kings for a day depleted
fields.trailText: Logic dictates a Lancastrian victory at Bristol today in the second semi-final of the NatWest trophy, but since when has logic had much to do with the outcome of a cricket match?
fields.body:
Logic dictates a Lancastrian victory at Bristol today in the second semi-final of the NatWest trophy, but since when has logic had much to do with the outcome of a cricket match?

All the knowing old lags are coming back into the Lancastrian team as they are prone to do when a Lord's final is on the horizon. Peter Martin has recovered from injury; so has Ian Austin. Mike Atherton is even available - he was the only contracted player not to appear last week, which put the Lancashire chairman, Jack Simmons, in a spin. Add to these the relative newcomers in the Lancastrian one-day juggernaut, Saurav Ganguly and a new streamlined Andrew Flintoff, and there is a side oozing experience and match winners everywhere.

However, Lancashire are not so consistent in one-day cricket as they once were. Take last week. On Wednesday, they were humiliated by nine wickets at Headingley; on Friday, they played today's opponents, Gloucestershire, and won by 10 wickets at Old Trafford. Surprisingly, they are threatened by relegation in the one-day National League with just three victories in 11 games.

They are familiar with Gloucestershire - they lost to them at Bristol in the semi-final of the B&H Cup earlier this summer - and won't underestimate them, which is easy to do. They appear to be a ragbag of motley cricketers from the veteran Kim Barnett, the quirky Jack Russell, the imperturbable Mark Alleyne and the little old swinger, Mike Smith. Yet these are the men, alongside a band of bits and pieces cricketers, who have not only contested the last three Lord's finals, they have won them as well. If they win today they can definitely claim to have superseded Lancashire as the one-day kings.

I'll be surprised if they do. They have one crucial absentee. Ian Harvey, the Australian, has been summoned back to Melbourne alongside Glenn McGrath and Shane Warne to play in a brief one-day series against the South Africans under a roof. Harvey's contributions, especially with the ball at the end of the innings, have been vital to Gloucestershire's success. They will miss him.

If they win today they can definitely claim to have superseded Lancashire as the one-day kings. I'll be surprised if they do. They have one crucial absentee. Ian Harvey, the Australian, has been summoned back to Melbourne alongside Glenn McGrath and Shane Warne to play in a brief one-day series against the South Africans under a roof. Harvey's contributions, especially with the ball at the end of the innings, have been vital to Gloucestershire's success. They will miss him.

fields.headline: Durham fail to fight
fields.standfirst:
Kent 170 & 354-4 dec
Durham 223 & 157-3
Match drawn
fields.trailText:
Kent 170 & 354-4 dec
Durham 223 & 157-3
Match drawn
fields.body:
With relegation looming, Durham were paralysed by the fear factor yesterday, and Kent left the Riverside with few worries about being overhauled in fourth bottom place.

The only inroad Durham made into the 15-point gap between the sides was to earn the game's only batting point, and their feeble efforts yesterday ensured that the rare prospect of an intriguing final day degenerated into a stalemate.

Kent's batsmen savoured the worst and the best of a pitch that eased as the weather improved, but it was still flat enough on the final day to leave their depleted attack no chance of dismissing a side who put safety first.

With Ed Smith reminding the selectors of his existence with a highly impressive 175, Kent were able to declare on 354 for seven, setting Durham a target of 302 in 69 overs.

At 106 for one at tea, they needed 196 off 36 overs, which many sides would fancy against a team shorn of four frontline bowlers. But once the Western Australian Simon Katich edged Matthew Fleming's first ball after the break to Paul Nixon, Durham could not even be enticed by Rahul Dravid's off breaks.

They allowed the asking rate to rise to seven an over before Paul Collingwood tried to lash the second ball of a new Martin Saggers spell into the stratosphere and was caught at deep mid-off.

For Saggers, playing against his former county, it was his ninth wicket of a match in which the other Kent bowlers took three between them as Durham sauntered to 157 for three before a halt was called with 11 overs still available.

There was occasional low bounce yesterday and if Durham were to have any chance they needed a substantial innings from Katich, who opened up with three fours and contributed 33 to a stand of 62 in 18 overs with Jon Lewis, who finished on 59 not out.

Kent added 94 in 24.2 overs in the morning for the loss of three wickets, Smith being the last to fall, edging a drive to slip when two short of the highest championship score made on this ground, which belongs to Yorkshire and England batsman Michael Vaughan.

fields.headline: Brown downs sorry Sussex
fields.trailText: Northamptonshire top of the County Championship's Second Division after needing just 20 balls to finish off Sussex at Wantage Road.
fields.body:
Northamptonshire top of the County Championship's Second Division after needing just 20 balls to finish off Sussex at Wantage Road.

Off-spinner Jason Brown bowled Tony Cottey for 112 in the day's fourth over, leaving the visitors 211 all out and Northamptonshire victorious by an innings and 17 runs - their fourth win in five matches.

Brown claimed a career-best seven for 78, taking 11 for 131 in the game, and Cottey was the 25-year-old's fiftieth first-class victim of the summer.

Brown, who has made only 23 appearances for Northamptonshire's first team since his debut in 1996, seven of them this year, said afterwards: 'I don't think I'm doing a lot different this season, although perhaps I've learned to become a bit more patient.

'It's gone well for us in the Championship over the last few weeks.

'The lads have clocked up a lot of runs and that's given Graeme (Swann) and me a chance to give the ball a big spin.

'If I haven't done it then he has, and the other way round.'

Cottey's defiant 145-ball knock featured two sixes and 12 fours, but the result was never in serious doubt once Brown and Swann had ripped through the Sussex batting again on Friday night.

Northamptonshire take 19 points from the game, with Sussex getting three. The teams will face each other again at Eastbourne on Wednesday in a game that should go a long way in deciding who goes up.
