fields.headline: Clean living on the Nile
fields.standfirst: Game for a laugh and would like to make a difference in Egypt? For  Dorota Nosowicz  it also meant a cheap holiday
fields.trailText: Game for a laugh and would like to make a difference in Egypt? For Dorota Nosowicz it also meant a cheap holiday
fields.body:
Hands safely encased in huge, bright yellow suede gloves, I held several used tampons in one hand and something dried up and much worse in the other. At least there were no flies. It was 8am and the sun was beating down on my sweating head. I wondered what kind of week I had let myself in for.

Our group of 24 strangers had arrived in Egypt three days earlier with Explore Worldwide and was travelling down the Nile in feluccas , traditional Egyptian sailing boats. Our aim was to take part in a subsidised operation to clear rubbish left on the riverbanks by other tourists. The lure was a holiday for just £250 and feeling good about undoing the environmental damage caused by others.

From the 17-year-old student to the retired maths teacher, we were a diverse group. On the first day our guide, Suzy, led us on a vigorous early-morning donkey trek from Luxor, across the honey-coloured cliffs to the Valley of the Kings. An equally lively descent brought us to the Mortuary Temple of Queen Hatshepsut, the third queen to rule ancient Egypt and the first to reign as a 'pharaoh'. It was here in November 1997 that six armed Muslim fundamentalists had killed 58 holidaymakers, including six Britons. The only destruction we saw was that wreaked by Hatshepsut's successor, Tuthmosis III, whose hatred of the woman drove him to obliterate her image and replace it with his own.

Next we boarded a train to the southern city of Aswan, in Nubia. A hot evening Sahara wind and a team of taxis took us past the Aswan dam to a vivid, blue-painted Nubian village at the side of the Nile, where our host for the night welcomed us into his home. We listened entranced to his description of his family's frugal life. There was a distant ringing, louder by the second. Slowly, he reached into the pocket of his gallabiyah and pulled out his mobile phone.

Having slept on the sand outside the house, under a star-littered sky, I was woken at dawn by the gentle sounds of the Nile tickling its banks and the less gentle sound of some of my snoring companions.

Forty minutes later we were on rock-hard saddles, trekking across the desert on camels to St Simeon's monastery, a sixth-century Christian stronghold. It was several hours before I lost my John Wayne walk. Comfort for the saddle-sore came with retail therapy at Aswan bazaar, bursting with colour and noise, where traders tested their Del Boy hard-sell with cries of 'luvly jubbly' and 'have a gander'.

So, to our outdoor home for the next four days: three beautiful, cotton-sailed feluccas on our clean-up route from Aswan to Edfu. Early each morning we cleaned in three teams for several hours - and again at the end of each day on another stretch of the river where we would moor for the night. We bagged our rubbish for recycling or built bonfires. Sweating over piles of rubbish, we bonded quickly, our squeamishness forgotten in the haste to avoid the heat.

The days were spent drifting downriver past rushes, banana palms and trees of bursting ripe mangoes on one side and sun-cracked earth on the other. We passed Nubian farmers loading their day's work on to faded blue and green rowing boats. We lay on deck, talked, snoozed, swam, watched the river and felt its current. The captain had mastered the art of delegation, leaving the sweaty work to his young lieutenant, while he spent his days lazily eyeing up the women, offering his services - 'youwannamassage?' - and Arabic lessons. For reasons that soon became apparent he was called Gin.

Our slumber was occasionally broken. On our third day on the river, suddenly there stood the well preserved temple of Kom Ombo, on the Nile's east bank, a garden of sunflowers and heady jasmine at its base. It is dedicated to Horus, the sky god, and Sobek, the crocodile god.

At sunset, a party would take its turn to dig our lava tory for the night, and hammer in its surrounding canopy at a discreet distance from our boats. We ate simple meals and retired to the beach, beer in hand, to dance, talk or play raucous Jameson-fuelled games by the fire to the hypnotic sounds of our crew's drums and their vibrant song. It became hard to imagine another life. We slept on deck, waking with first light for a communal wash in the Nile.

On our final felucca day, we reached Edfu, where accumulated rubbish which had been stored on a separate boat was transferred to the incinerator for disposal. Dusty, we mingled with much cleaner tourists at the temple of Horus, built in honour of the falcon-headed god.

Climbing into taxis, we sped back to Luxor, where our senses were assaulted by the dry heat, car horns so loud I felt my head about to burst, traffic, men yelling ' baksheesh ', and wild Egyptian music coming from every roadside village.

It was almost over. A horse-drawn caleshe took us to the Temple of Amun at Karnac. Easy to understand its ancient name of IpetIsut, 'the most perfect of places'. We spent our last night sampling the exotic Luxor nightlife. I stood on the rooftop of our hotel with its panorama of the river we had just left behind, and wished I could stay.

Was it worth it? Well, I lost count of the number of bonfires we lit on beaches, burning the paper we had collected. We cleared 12 beaches, collected 213 sacks of tin, plastic and glass and felt we had made a difference. We absorbed ourselves in a culture wildly different from our own, formed friendships and laughed like drains.

Fact file

Future clean-up trips to Egypt, and possibly other countries, will be announced in Explore Worldwide's newsletter. Call 01252 760100 to be put on the mailing list.

The Nile trip was subsidised by Explore, with participants paying £250. This included flights, accommodation, some meals, a camel trek and visits to historic sites.

fields.headline: Taxi ride to a  past life
fields.standfirst: Sarah Adams joins the party to end all parties on the tiny island of Skinoússa as the Greek diaspora arrives from all over the world to celebrate  Panagyri, the Assumption of the Virgin Mary
fields.trailText: Sarah Adams joins the party to end all parties on the tiny island of Skinoússa as the Greek diaspora arrives from all over the world to celebrate Panagyri, the Assumption of the Virgin Mary.
fields.body:
Kyrios Angelos laid off the booze and fags at 70. At 92, he's looking sharp. He sings to me, his fingers tracing the litany across an Orthodox Bible etched by a lifetime's use. It is dusk on 14 August and preparations for the eve of the Assumption are under way.

Festivals on Skinoússa - one of the tiniest inhabited islands in the Greek archipelago - don't come much bigger than the summer Panagyri . Its full name is the Apokímisis tis Panagyias , or Final Repose of the Blessed Mary. As prodigal offspring jet in from the far reaches of the Greek diaspora to celebrate the Virgin's assumption into heaven, the island embraces its extended family. These xeniteméni (self-imposed exiles) are the legacy of sustained economic migrancy, and the sight of barnacled old men greeting their smooth-skinned brothers from abroad is peculiarly touching. For two weeks, this rock in the Aegean is transformed into a cosmopolitan microculture where 10-year-olds insist they like Skinoússa because the crime rate is much lower than in Johannesburg.

The name derives from the violent thorns ( skína ) specific to its rough terrain, all four square miles of it. Part of a cluster of Minor Cyclades also known as the 'Islands of Solitude', it buffers the waves between Náxos to the west and Orthodox Amorgós to the east. Here, the feudal and the modern nuzzle together. Windmills and satellite dishes and pylons score the horizon.

What unites the crowds gathered for the Panagyri celebrations is a tenacious nostalgia for the nest they have flown. 'Don't you dig the lifestyle? Like these guys really know how to enjoy themselves,' says Christina, from Astoria, New York. 'Back in the States we just work and then some!'

If the myth of Persephone is alive and kicking, the price of paradise has gone up in modern times. Instead of six months away from the 'underworld', you get two weeks of annual freedom and stockpile the rest for retirement. Perhaps those who stayed put view it all differently. Like Mítsos, the ancient fisherman deafened in an encounter with a windmill blade; and Bárba Ioánnis, near-blind with cataracts, his Assos cigarette invariably missing the three ashtrays on his table. The tragedy of lost communication can be excruciating to behold when the deaf man forgets to remember to watch the lips of the blind man.

Paradise or not, Skinoússa is a strikingly beautiful island. It is also surprisingly lush. And, like a floating Noah's Ark, it bursts at the seams with outsized livestock. Away from the toil of subsistence farming, the island boasts 17 unspoilt and chiefly hidden beaches. Desert island life is both pleasurable and disarming : it was curious to return from an isolated beach to find my outgoing footprints still immaculate in the dirt-track. Perhaps the flip-side to this Crusoe-esque stuff is the islanders' fascination for the verb taxidevo - travel. Used for transport of all sorts, it refers more specifically to figurative modes of escape. Drink, music, love and nature are all 'taxis' ferrying passengers to otherworldly destinations.

Which is, of course, the spirit of the Panagyri . Miraculously, Skinoússans reinvent life on their tiny slab of existence, resorting to their exhilarating talent for music and dance and letting rip. Forget plate-smashing and think a different breed of bacchanalian abandon: whole crates of Amstel beer and ersatz champagne hurled to the ground with the sort of gusto that offers enough of a fleeting escape to be a holiday in itself. I wonder if this exuberant 'journeying' reflects the knowledge that the Virgin Mary is not the only one bound for the skies, for the Panagyri also marks summer's close.

Shutters are snapped into place and the acrid camphor of mothballs mingles incongruously with the scent of wild thyme. Down at the port of Mersíni, there are painful leave-takings as the Skopelítis - the provisions boat from Náxos - manoeuvres its way out of the natural harbour into the world beyond. The night is young, however, and I am getting ahead of myself. Kyrios Angelos would not approve.

The old man looks up from his Bible and focuses on the spectacle of sated tourists at his niece's kafenío . Worked off her feet, Kyria Pothití shrills and spins in the kitchen like a whirling dervish. Out on the terrace, her university-educated son enjoys the attention he's getting as a temporary waiter. Expertly, he knits his eyebrows together and flurries into irresistibly accented English. Named after his great uncle, he briefs natives and oxéni (outsiders) about the Bar Piraktikó where his brothers are preparing the way for us to party long beyond dawn. Getting there involves a trek across recently ploughed fields, but there are lifts to be caught and the views of Almirós beach just below and Kéros over on the horizon will make it worth our while. Everyone is welcome at the festivities.

Apart from two Parisian fashion designers, there are Italians and a sprinkling of Scandinavians, but no Germans and few English. An international currency of words and smoke wafts over from the crowd next door, at Meltémi's fresh grill.

Along the main thoroughfare, the ambience is hotting up on the balcony of Bar Margaríta and stomachs are swelling at Panoráma, a summer joint run by the primary school teacher and ex-president of the island.

The church's blue dome is set in the heart of the island. Its circular stained glass windows are shot through with lingering shafts of sunlight and the courtyard is a riot of abstract Cycladic lines. Inside, there are rich frescoes and an unusual icon depicting the Virgin standing rather than seated. Tapers are lit and incense fills the air. The chanting of those freed from tourist duties provides a contrast to the light, skipping rhythms of Cycladic island music.

The priest has made a special trip over from the (literally) cliff-hanging monastery on Amorgós. He is part of Skinoússa's history, in as far as today's inhabitants - all six clans of them - are descendants of the last wave of settlers sent over by the monastery in 1840.

I meet a sound-recordist from an award-winning film documentary about Skinoússa. He is back on the island for the first time in around 20 years and trying to absorb the changes in a place candied in his mind. He assures me that his experience was the real thing.

He spins me tales of paraffin lamps and water drawn from the well down at Mersíni, of grown men dancing with handkerchiefs and children learning to write with their fingers in the dust. He enthuses about musicians playing at dawn to wake the sleeping fishermen cradled in their boats and about a people who had never been to Athens or experienced the razor-blade of tourism.

His chin grows long with regret and we head to the Piraktikó to lift our spirits. It is a good move. Everyone is down on their knees, clapping and yelping encouragement to the solo-dancer in their midst. He is Manólis, Angelos's younger brother, and he kicks his legs and shrieks and spins before brushing the ground skilfully and rebounding. He combines lightning dexterity with hovering poise and he punctuates his rhythms with such intricate counterpoint that even the sound-recordist approves.

The onlookers keep offering him toasts or propósis , and Manólis downs a throatful from each glass before flinging it away and continuing the dance.

Adónis, cousin of Angelos and Manólis, is supposedly keeping the tab at the bar, but the drink is flowing so freely and so generously that I cannot see the point. We have danced all night to the starlight and now the sun is rising, red and mystical, behind Kéros.

We are expected for church at 10. We plunge into the early morning waters of Almíros, before heading up to the village and the day's festivities. We pass the farmers on their way to milk the goats and we hear the sound of firecrackers resonating from every corner of the island.

Pothití's terrace fills for the game of bílies , a version of skittles that uses nine wooden bricks. The aim is to topple the centre brick, worth 10 points, or else score a point for each brick hit. There are two teams and it takes until evening for one of them to reach a winning score.

Then the sound-recordist entreats us, xeniteméni , oxéni and Skinoussans alike, to a viewing of his film. I am torn between watching it and glancing at the faces of the islanders watching themselves 20 years ago. Unfortunately, the priest's video player goes up in a puff of smoke halfway through our session. But I've seen enough to know that Kyrios Angelos looks as sharp now as he did then. Are these the benefits of his abstemious regime? He smiles and asks me whether there are windmills in London.

Fact file

Flights

Allsun and Faraway Holidays offer connecting Olympic Airways flights Heathrow-Athens-Náxos from £243.80 return, inc taxes. Tel: 020 7409 2477.

Ferries

Check www.ferries.gr for ferry details from Piraeus. The Highspeed Minoan Flying Dolphins (3hrs) to Náxos leaves daily at 7.45am. The first ferry (6hrs) leaves at 8am. Call 020 7734 5997 for a timetable.

From Náxos the Skopelítis departs daily from the small pier at 3pm. Tickets from ZAS Travel on the harbour front.

Tel: 00 30 (0)285 23330/ Fax: 23419.

Accommodation

Evdokía Nomikós at Hotel Sunset/ Anna's Rooms offers rooms from £30 a night in August. Tel: 00 30 (0)285 71948/ Fax : 74064.

Giorgos Gríspos offers the same price at the Tsigoúri Beach Villas on 00 30 (0)285 71930 / Fax: 71176.

Alternatively, ask for rooms at Meltémi, Prováloma, Panoráma or Níko the Baker's when you reach the port.

Used for transport of all sorts, it refers more specifically to figurative modes of escape. Drink, music, love and nature are all 'taxis' ferrying passengers to otherworldly destinations. Which is, of course, the spirit of the Panagyri . Miraculously, Skinoússans reinvent life on their tiny slab of existence, resorting to their exhilarating talent for music and dance and letting rip. Forget plate-smashing and think a different breed of bacchanalian abandon: whole crates of Amstel beer and ersatz champagne hurled to the ground with the sort of gusto that offers enough of a fleeting escape to be a holiday in itself. I wonder if this exuberant 'journeying' reflects the knowledge that the Virgin Mary is not the only one bound for the skies, for the Panagyri also marks summer's close. Shutters are snapped into place and the acrid camphor of mothballs mingles incongruously with the scent of wild thyme. Down at the port of Mersíni, there are painful leave-takings as the Skopelítis - the provisions boat from Náxos - manoeuvres its way out of the natural harbour into the world beyond. The night is young, however, and I am getting ahead of myself. Kyrios Angelos would not approve. The old man looks up from his Bible and focuses on the spectacle of sated tourists at his niece's kafenío . Worked off her feet, Kyria Pothití shrills and spins in the kitchen like a whirling dervish. Out on the terrace, her university-educated son enjoys the attention he's getting as a temporary waiter. Expertly, he knits his eyebrows together and flurries into irresistibly accented English. Named after his great uncle, he briefs natives and oxéni (outsiders) about the Bar Piraktikó where his brothers are preparing the way for us to party long beyond dawn. Getting there involves a trek across recently ploughed fields, but there are lifts to be caught and the views of Almirós beach just below and Kéros over on the horizon will make it worth our while. Everyone is welcome at the festivities. Apart from two Parisian fashion designers, there are Italians and a sprinkling of Scandinavians, but no Germans and few English. An international currency of words and smoke wafts over from the crowd next door, at Meltémi's fresh grill. Along the main thoroughfare, the ambience is hotting up on the balcony of Bar Margaríta and stomachs are swelling at Panoráma, a summer joint run by the primary school teacher and ex-president of the island. The church's blue dome is set in the heart of the island. Its circular stained glass windows are shot through with lingering shafts of sunlight and the courtyard is a riot of abstract Cycladic lines. Inside, there are rich frescoes and an unusual icon depicting the Virgin standing rather than seated. Tapers are lit and incense fills the air. The chanting of those freed from tourist duties provides a contrast to the light, skipping rhythms of Cycladic island music. The priest has made a special trip over from the (literally) cliff-hanging monastery on Amorgós. He is part of Skinoússa's history, in as far as today's inhabitants - all six clans of them - are descendants of the last wave of settlers sent over by the monastery in 1840. I meet a sound-recordist from an award-winning film documentary about Skinoússa. He is back on the island for the first time in around 20 years and trying to absorb the changes in a place candied in his mind. He assures me that his experience was the real thing. He spins me tales of paraffin lamps and water drawn from the well down at Mersíni, of grown men dancing with handkerchiefs and children learning to write with their fingers in the dust. He enthuses about musicians playing at dawn to wake the sleeping fishermen cradled in their boats and about a people who had never been to Athens or experienced the razor-blade of tourism. His chin grows long with regret and we head to the Piraktikó to lift our spirits. It is a good move. Everyone is down on their knees, clapping and yelping encouragement to the solo-dancer in their midst. He is Manólis, Angelos's younger brother, and he kicks his legs and shrieks and spins before brushing the ground skilfully and rebounding. He combines lightning dexterity with hovering poise and he punctuates his rhythms with such intricate counterpoint that even the sound-recordist approves. The onlookers keep offering him toasts or propósis , and Manólis downs a throatful from each glass before flinging it away and continuing the dance. Adónis, cousin of Angelos and Manólis, is supposedly keeping the tab at the bar, but the drink is flowing so freely and so generously that I cannot see the point. We have danced all night to the starlight and now the sun is rising, red and mystical, behind Kéros. We are expected for church at 10. We plunge into the early morning waters of Almíros, before heading up to the village and the day's festivities. We pass the farmers on their way to milk the goats and we hear the sound of firecrackers resonating from every corner of the island. Pothití's terrace fills for the game of bílies , a version of skittles that uses nine wooden bricks. The aim is to topple the centre brick, worth 10 points, or else score a point for each brick hit. There are two teams and it takes until evening for one of them to reach a winning score. Then the sound-recordist entreats us, xeniteméni , oxéni and Skinoussans alike, to a viewing of his film. I am torn between watching it and glancing at the faces of the islanders watching themselves 20 years ago. Unfortunately, the priest's video player goes up in a puff of smoke halfway through our session. But I've seen enough to know that Kyrios Angelos looks as sharp now as he did then. Are these the benefits of his abstemious regime? He smiles and asks me whether there are windmills in London. fields.headline: I remember...
fields.standfirst: Holiday memories by  Shola Ama
fields.trailText: Holiday memories by Shola Ama
fields.body:
As a child we never had much money for holidays. However, when I was very young I visited family in St Lucia and Dominica. My only memories of these visits are of it being very colourful and running around with my cousins barefoot.

At the end of 1997 I had just finished promoting my first album and was totally shattered. I needed to get away from everyone and everything so I went to St Lucia on my own and booked myself into the Wyndham Morgan Bay. I had never been anywhere on my own before so I wanted to go somewhere familiar.

I kept reminding myself that I wasn't working and became a real tourist. I went to the bat caves and the Petans and had a go at jet skiing and parasailing, which I loved. I had never done these before but I love thrill rides so I thought I would just go for it, as no one I knew was watching! The instructor was a typical tourist rep, full of himself and oozing confidence. I got used to him as I realised they think this is part of the job description!

There were loads of families where I was staying and I spent much of my time mucking about with the kids. They would knock on my door and we would go down to the beach or the pool and play. I spent so much time with them, their parents kept thanking me for taking them off their hands. I felt like a kids' club representative, but I like having kids around.

One night I was introduced to a couple who were about to get married out there. When they asked me to sing at the wedding, I was really touched. Well, what's another personal appearance? They had a lovely wedding and everyone knew all the words.

Even though I was on my own, I met loads of great people and had a really relaxing time. I was surprised that eating and going on excursions alone was actually quite nice! I had never considered it a possibility back in Britain and without anyone to entertain I felt totally relaxed. This holiday is also memorable as it's the only three weeks I can remember when I didn't so much as think about shopping!

 Shola Ama is an R&B singer. Her new single, garage mixes of 'Imagine', is out on 13 September.

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: Follow the leader | Gear up for cycling festival | Learn a language on your holidays
fields.body:
Follow the leader

Dust down your hiking boots: the Festival of Summer Walks begins on 19 August and runs until 28 August. The Ramblers' Association has organised the event and is leading 750 walks taking place all over the country. Walks are divided into five themes. Of particular interest may be the family walks, which are suitable for young children, and the local discovery walks which celebrate local wildlife and heritage.

Next weekend, for example, explore the orchards and lanes of Tunbridge Wells, Kent, with a treasure hunt, or visit Kirtlington Quarry in Oxfordshire, where dinosaurs once roamed, via the Oxford Canal.

The walks are free and open to everyone. However, if you would like to become a member con tact the Ramblers' Association at 2nd floor, Camelford House, 87- 90 Albert Embankment, London, SE1 7 TW, visit www.ramblers.org.uk or telephone 020 7339 8500. All new members participating in the festival are entitled to a 20 per cent discount. Membership usually costs £20 for individuals and £14 or £26 for families.

A Festival of Summer Walks brochure is also available from the Ramblers, most branches of Millets and many tourist information centres.

Gear up for cycling festival

Mountain biking is one of the better ideas to have emerged from the Seventies.

The sport is booming and the UK's first outdoor bike festival, Bike Live, takes place next weekend in Newnham Park, Plymouth.

Catch some of the best riders, such as World No.2 Steve Peat and World No.1 Katrina Miller, competing in Swatch Biker X event (on the 1999 World Cup course), downhill races, half-pipe competitions and motocross trials. If you need a breather, check out the retail village, try sumo wrestling or test drive a 4X4.

Saturday night is party night, and if you're staying for the weekend you'll need to bring a tent, although bikes themselves are optional.

We have a Giant mountain bike and a pair of Bike Live tickets to give away and a runner-up prize of a family pass to Bike Live.

Just send a postcard with your name and address to Bike Live Competition, Observer Kids' Escape, 119 Farringdon Road, London, EC1R 3ER. The closing date is 17 August and first out of the bag wins.

Tickets for Bike Live, from £5 to £32, are still available. Call 01458 271 148.

Learn a language on your holidays

A great way to pass the time on long holiday journeys is to brush up on a foreign language with your children, especially since kids can absorb languages at a young age. Help Your Child to Learn a Foreign Language (£6.95, Berlitz) is full of tips, ideas and activities to develop a child's fluency.

The book is also included within the Berlitz Kids Language Pack (£15.95), which is available in French, German, Italian or Spanish.

Call 020 7518 8300 for more information or visit their site at www.berlitz.com.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Martine Jasmin, guest relations at The Shandrani, Mauritius
fields.trailText: Martine Jasmin, guest relations at The Shandrani, Mauritius.
fields.body:
Any celebrity guests?

We've had quite a few sportsmen, such as the football players Jordi Cruyff and Ole Gunnar Solksjaer, and the racing driver Mika Hakkinen. We are in a very private resort, with no towns or villages nearby, so it is very quiet.

So what is there to do on Mauritius?

If someone wants to go out there are two main choices on the island. The North tour includes a visit to the capital, Port Louis, and the shopping around it; the Pamplemousse Garden (one of the oldest ornamental gardens in the world) and the north coast, which is a bit like the Cte d'Azur. The South tour is more of a nature walk, with mountains, waterfalls and the multi-coloured earth at Chamarel.

There are some very nice places near the hotel which are not well-known, like a natural bridge of volcanic rock that you can cycle to.

What about nights out?

Most guests stay in the hotel at night. We have an evening show and a band that plays until midnight. There are three beaches at the hotel, all with thatched umbrellas and lighting and in the evenings you often see couples relaxing on the beach with a bottle of something, enjoying the Milky Way above them. Some even stay up to watch the sunrise.

Sounds romantic...

Mauritius attracts a large number of honeymooners from the months of May to November. Every Friday evening we organise an Indian Blessing and get the couples dressed up in saris and kurtas. We once had a wedding between a senior pilot and an air hostess so I managed to get a helicopter for the couple and the registrar to travel to the ceremony in.

Is there anything for families?

We have a colourful mini-club where we take care of children aged from around three to 12. There are loads of activities and sports for them to enjoy, such as tennis, mountain-biking and volleyball. There is also a games room.

The Shandrani: 01483 533 008

Prices start at £1,613 per person for 14 nights during September. This includes return flights from Heathrow and transfers.

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Get your pulse racing | Family fun | Home is best
fields.body:
Get your pulse racing

Sports fans can look for excitement abroad and make a holiday out of it. A fly-drive holiday from Lakes and Mountains Holidays will bring you to Baveno at Lake Maggiore for seven nights just in time for the Italian Grand Prix in nearby Monza. The circuit is an hour's drive away, making it close enough to make use of the hired car that comes with the trip, but at a good distance for partners who want to avoid the roar of the Formula 1 altogether. Those who stay behind will find pleasure boats calling at Baveno's small harbour and can take several trips.The holiday costs £456 per person based on four sharing a two bedroom apartment and includes flights to Milan and car rental. Phone 01329 844 405.

Family fun

Parents may not want to admit it, but there are times when they feel in need of a holiday from their children. Tropical Places is one of the operators offering an all-inclusive holiday with very generous childcare options at the three-star Club St. Lucia. Three kids' clubs and a nursery mean that someone else can entertain the children as adults take advantage of watersports, tennis and a fitness club. Departures are from the end of this month until 1 October from Gatwick or Manchester and the holiday price starts at £699 per person for seven nights, which is a discount of £300. Children's prices are £399 each for under-twelves sharing with two adults. Phone 0800 083 6662.

Home is best

Resisting the temptation to join the exodus from this rain-soaked island can pay dividends. Crystal Premier Britain and Crystal Days and Nights are offering discounts on hotel accommodation around the country. More value can be gained from a trip to London by taking advantage of an all-inclusive package for £52, or a free ticket to the London Eye for stays of two or more nights in any London hotel in the new Days and Nights brochure. Phone 0870 848 7002 for Crystal Premier Britain or 0870 888 0030 for Crystal Days and Nights.

Winter sun and sights

The choice between a sun holiday and one that is rich in cultural interest can be a difficult one, but it is possible to combine the two. The resort of Eilat on the shores of the Red Sea in Israel is such a place, with warm temperatures all year round in a location just a short distance from Jordan and the city of Petra. A day trip to Jerusalem can add to the historical interest and a float in the Dead Sea will help tired tourists to unwind after all the sightseeing. Superstar Holidays offer winter sun breaks to Eilat from £361. Phone 020 7957 4300.

fields.headline: Killer whales in a fight for their life
fields.standfirst: Hunting, tourism and even golf courses are threatening the orca.    Joanna Walters  looks behind the nature holiday 'paradise'
fields.trailText: Hunting, tourism and even golf courses are threatening the orca. Joanna Walters looks behind the nature holiday 'paradise'.
fields.body:
Seeing a killer whale close up in its natural surroundings is a heart-stopping moment. Of awe, not fear. It doesn't have to do anything spectacular such as leap in the air or hunt in a pack, with David Attenborough narrating.

Simply watching this gargantuan and graceful beast glide slowly through a piercing-blue stretch of ocean is utterly thrilling. Around 100 killer whales spend all their springs and summers pursuing the wild king salmon and chilling out between meals just yards off the San Juan archipelago of tiny, lush islands not far from Seattle, at the northern end of the US Pacific coast.

The Free Willy movies were filmed around here and the area is a real draw for nature lovers and sailors, especially those who want to watch whales. Tourists take to boats and canoes to observe the resident orca - to give killer whales their polite Latin name - or just sit on the shore with a picnic, as the whales often swim close by.

When a group of eight of us in an open-backed cruiser chanced on a group of three killer whales it was an emotional moment. Our skipper had been about to give up and turn back to the harbour because a bone-chilling and seemingly impenetrable late-spring mist was gathering.

But as suddenly as it had descended, the fog evaporated, just as a giant male orca bobbed its head up out of the water some distance away, looking around in what whale watchers call a 'spy hop'. Moments later two towering dorsal fins cut through the water next to the boat and a calf followed behind, breaking the surface with its body and flashing its characteristic white patches.

The orca family was in no hurry, content to swish and dive in the millpond sea. The snow-capped Olympic Mountains formed the backdrop to the glassy ocean on one side, a hazy view of Vancouver Island, just across the Canadian border, on the other.

It is not hard to see why the San Juan islands have become the holiday playground for burnt-out Boeing bosses and millionaire Microsoft net-heads who work for Seattle's two biggest employers. These and other urban stressballs consume the tranquillity and natural feast from their timber lodges, discreet guesthouses and yachts. There are no traffic lights, nightclubs or high-rise blocks. But there is fresh seafood, ancient woodland, crystal waters and the chance to commune with the sealions, whales, bald eagles and cormorants.

Even getting to San Juan Island, the largest in the archipelago, is special. Trippers take off in seven-seater De Havilland Beaver seaplanes from the middle of Lake Union amid the skyscrapers of downtown Seattle. After an hour's low-level flying over Puget Sound with spectacular views of the snowy Mount Rainier volcano, the plane skims into San Juan Island's diminutive Friday Harbour. There are also ferries from the mainland. Either way it feels like arriving in paradise.

But wonderful as it looks, there is trouble in paradise.The killer whales are under threat. An adult orca needs almost 50 kilos of salmon a day. But Bill Wright, who owns San Juan Safaris, which runs boat and canoe trips to see the whales, estimates that the region's salmon population has declined by 90 per cent in the past 100 years, with its annihilation greatly accelerated during the 'greed is good' Eighties.

He partly blames aggressive logging in nearby Washington and Oregon states and the transformation of near-desert landscape inland into lush ranches with golf courses using thousands of gallons of water for irrigation and artificial fertilisers. These actions decimated the topsoil and filled the rivers pouring into the whales' Pacific feeding waters with silt and pesticides he said.

In addition hydro-electric programmes have dammed many of the rivers, providing inadequate salmon 'ladders' alongside and therefore making it virtually impossible for the fish to swim upriver to their breeding grounds. Combine all that with straightforward over-fishing and it won't be long before the islanders start to lose their orcas.

Wright is very conscious that what looks like perfection is already an illusion and that the fragile ecosystem will break down without greater protection. He said: 'Some of the worst damage was inflicted at the height of Republican economic aggression, and there was only thought for money in these parts, no thought for tomorrow and no thought for our environment.'

The local island newspaper is full of stories of the whale population shrinking and familiar individual orcas failing to return from their winter feeding grounds. The scarcer minke and grey whales are also reportedly being spotted less frequently.

Whale watching itself has come in for criticism. Wright is an example of a local businessman who is also an environmentalist. He makes a living taking tourists out on his cruisers and believes the orca don't mind the dozens of tourist boats from different companies that criss-cross their habitat during the summer. Boats are not allowed to drive within 100 metres of a whale and must switch their engines off in the vicinity.

Wright said: 'I was there yesterday and some dolphins surrounded the boat for 15 minutes, leaping and diving around the hull. They were curious and obviously loving it.'

He said that, since the hunting parties that used to come out from the Seattle area to shoot whales were banned in the Seventies, the whales were in better shape than they had been for 30 years. As well as being a leading figure in the San Juan whale watching industry, Wright is also involved in environmental and conservation movements seeking better ways to protect the orca.

But some locals disagree that commercial whale-watching is beneficial. One boat captain said it was not uncommon to see 100 boats out in the single stretch of ocean just off San Juan Island watching the whales at the height of the season - in August.

He said: 'When things get really busy out there I think the whales do get upset. I see mothers with calves slapping the water with their fins repeatedly. I always interpret it as the equivalent of them shaking their fist, saying "get out of here" to the humans,' he said.

Others spoke of the rules governing whale watching as being too lax and poorly enforced in the area. 'There are boats coming from Vancouver Island, mainland Canada and the San Juan Islands, so there isn't one system. People try to be considerate, but it gets pretty chaotic out there at the height of the season,' said one.

A greener alternative to the cruiser boats are the paddling trips in kayaks. As well as the chance to see whales close up in absolute silence, there is the exhilaration of paddling past the wooded island peninsulas and rocky outcrops with their resident eagles and seals. And giant starfish and anemones are visible on the seabed in the shallows. Kayaking, however, will never be the money-spinner that whale-watching boat trips are.

The other local debate is the one about the whales and the area's Native American communities, or what this all-white enclave mostly refers to as 'Indian tribes'. Native Americans hunted and fished these waters as long as 10,000 years ago, but have long since been driven out and corralled on mainland 'reservations'.

Lee Brooks, who runs a small Native American art and sculpture gallery at Friday Harbour, said he has listened to torrents of poisonous ranting from both islanders and visitors about the very existence of the people who produce the crafts on display.

Some islanders blame the Native American populations in Washington State for over-exploiting their ancient fishing rights. One group has caused a storm by winning the right to kill five minke whales a year, which has prompted a local environmental protest ship to blockade their boats during the hunting season.

Brooks said: 'The environmentalists did not want to discuss or negotiate with the Native American fishermen - there was no dialogue, just leafleting and placards.'

He is dubious about the merits of the tourism industry that makes a fortune off the orca's graceful backs and on which the island now depends. He believes the whale-watching industry has been allowed to grow too far.

He looked out of the gallery window disconsolately as another seaplane arrived from Seattle and a Canadian ferry docked, disgorging more pleasure seekers eager to indulge in nature's bounty.

'The orcas are dying and time's running out to save them,' he said bitterly.

Flights

Joanna Walters travelled to Seattle with British Airways (0845 77 333 77) from Heathrow. Return fares in the whale-watch season range from £329 Apex/ £737 fully flexible economy in May, to £570 Apex/£2,180 fully flexible economy from July-Sept. Airport taxes in London and Seattle total £52. Seattle-San Juan Island with Kenmore Air £95 return.

Accommodation

Inn at Friday Harbour, prices per room per night range from £31 to £190 for a suite.

Boat trips

A three-hour whale-watch boat trip or a three-hour kayak trip costs £28 per person.
fields.bodyText: Seeing a killer whale close up in its natural surroundings is a heart-stopping moment. Of awe, not fear. It doesn't have to do anything spectacular such as leap in the air or hunt in a pack, with David Attenborough narrating. Simply watching this gargantuan and graceful beast glide slowly through a piercing-blue stretch of ocean is utterly thrilling. Around 100 killer whales spend all their springs and summers pursuing the wild king salmon and chilling out between meals just yards off the San Juan archipelago of tiny, lush islands not far from Seattle, at the northern end of the US Pacific coast. The Free Willy movies were filmed around here and the area is a real draw for nature lovers and sailors, especially those who want to watch whales. Tourists take to boats and canoes to observe the resident orca - to give killer whales their polite Latin name - or just sit on the shore with a picnic, as the whales often swim close by. When a group of eight of us in an open-backed cruiser chanced on a group of three killer whales it was an emotional moment. Our skipper had been about to give up and turn back to the harbour because a bone-chilling and seemingly impenetrable late-spring mist was gathering. But as suddenly as it had descended, the fog evaporated, just as a giant male orca bobbed its head up out of the water some distance away, looking around in what whale watchers call a 'spy hop'. Moments later two towering dorsal fins cut through the water next to the boat and a calf followed behind, breaking the surface with its body and flashing its characteristic white patches. The orca family was in no hurry, content to swish and dive in the millpond sea. The snow-capped Olympic Mountains formed the backdrop to the glassy ocean on one side, a hazy view of Vancouver Island, just across the Canadian border, on the other. It is not hard to see why the San Juan islands have become the holiday playground for burnt-out Boeing bosses and millionaire Microsoft net-heads who work for Seattle's two biggest employers. These and other urban stressballs consume the tranquillity and natural feast from their timber lodges, discreet guesthouses and yachts. There are no traffic lights, nightclubs or high-rise blocks. But there is fresh seafood, ancient woodland, crystal waters and the chance to commune with the sealions, whales, bald eagles and cormorants. Even getting to San Juan Island, the largest in the archipelago, is special. Trippers take off in seven-seater De Havilland Beaver seaplanes from the middle of Lake Union amid the skyscrapers of downtown Seattle. After an hour's low-level flying over Puget Sound with spectacular views of the snowy Mount Rainier volcano, the plane skims into San Juan Island's diminutive Friday Harbour. There are also ferries from the mainland. Either way it feels like arriving in paradise. But wonderful as it looks, there is trouble in paradise.The killer whales are under threat. An adult orca needs almost 50 kilos of salmon a day. But Bill Wright, who owns San Juan Safaris, which runs boat and canoe trips to see the whales, estimates that the region's salmon population has declined by 90 per cent in the past 100 years, with its annihilation greatly accelerated during the 'greed is good' Eighties. He partly blames aggressive logging in nearby Washington and Oregon states and the transformation of near-desert landscape inland into lush ranches with golf courses using thousands of gallons of water for irrigation and artificial fertilisers. These actions decimated the topsoil and filled the rivers pouring into the whales' Pacific feeding waters with silt and pesticides he said. In addition hydro-electric programmes have dammed many of the rivers, providing inadequate salmon 'ladders' alongside and therefore making it virtually impossible for the fish to swim upriver to their breeding grounds. Combine all that with straightforward over-fishing and it won't be long before the islanders start to lose their orcas. Wright is very conscious that what looks like perfection is already an illusion and that the fragile ecosystem will break down without greater protection. He said: 'Some of the worst damage was inflicted at the height of Republican economic aggression, and there was only thought for money in these parts, no thought for tomorrow and no thought for our environment.' The local island newspaper is full of stories of the whale population shrinking and familiar individual orcas failing to return from their winter feeding grounds. The scarcer minke and grey whales are also reportedly being spotted less frequently. Whale watching itself has come in for criticism. Wright is an example of a local businessman who is also an environmentalist. He makes a living taking tourists out on his cruisers and believes the orca don't mind the dozens of tourist boats from different companies that criss-cross their habitat during the summer. Boats are not allowed to drive within 100 metres of a whale and must switch their engines off in the vicinity. Wright said: 'I was there yesterday and some dolphins surrounded the boat for 15 minutes, leaping and diving around the hull. They were curious and obviously loving it.' He said that, since the hunting parties that used to come out from the Seattle area to shoot whales were banned in the Seventies, the whales were in better shape than they had been for 30 years. But some locals disagree that commercial whale-watching is beneficial. One boat captain said it was not uncommon to see 100 boats out in the single stretch of ocean just off San Juan Island watching the whales at the height of the season - in August. He said: 'When things get really busy out there I think the whales do get upset. I see mothers with calves slapping the water with their fins repeatedly. I always interpret it as the equivalent of them shaking their fist, saying "get out of here" to the humans,' he said. Others spoke of the rules governing whale watching as being too lax and poorly enforced in the area. 'There are boats coming from Vancouver Island, mainland Canada and the San Juan Islands, so there isn't one system. People try to be considerate, but it gets pretty chaotic out there at the height of the season,' said one. A greener alternative to the cruiser boats are the paddling trips in kayaks. fields.headline: The round Britain quiz
fields.standfirst: Our country houses, castles and ruins have come up with activity sheets and questions to test your observation.  Claudia Pritchard goes on a whistle-stop tour of the country
fields.trailText: Our country houses, castles and ruins have come up with activity sheets and questions to test your observation. Claudia Pritchard goes on a whistle-stop tour of the country.
fields.body:
Anglesey Abbey and Garden
Lode, Cambridge
(National Trust)

Things to do: Count the clocks from room to room, record your final tally and look out for curios on your route through this idiosyncratic house dating from 1135. Find a terracotta goat, a wheelbarrow for lugging some of the 9,000 books in the library, and Napoleon's circular table. An unlovely house, but jammed full of oddities.

Wednesday-Sunday and bank holidays 1pm-5pm; garden daily 10.30am-5.30pm and until 8pm on Thursdays in August. Times change 23 October.

From £3.50 (children); £6.10 (adults). Family concessions

Tel: 01223 811200

Bateman's
 Burwash, East Sussex
(National Trust)

Things to do: At Rudyard Kipling's much-loved home the visitors' book records 'FIP' by the names of distinguished guests who Fell In Pond. Look for the house mouse with the aid of the children's guide book. Carved models of Jungle Book characters are at child's eye height.

Saturday to Wednesday 11am-5pm. Times change 2 November.

Family ticket £12.50

01435 882302

Biddulph Grange Garden
Biddulph, Stoke-on-Trent
(National Trust)

Things to do: Refreshingly humorous trail for children has batty multiple choice questions. How you wish that the garden's Victorian creator really had also been a collector of bus tickets, or that there was a statue of a hamster. The children's activity sheet never lets facts get in the way of a good gag. Why do hummingbirds hum? Because they don't know the words.

Wednesday to Friday noon-6pm; Sunday and bank holidays 11am-6pm. Times change 20 October. Family ticket £10.70

01782 517999

Brontë Parsonage Museum
Haworth, near Keighley, West Yorkshire

Things to do: Children may think that Charlotte Brontë did a bad swap when she turfed out the pet geese Victoria and Adelaide and turned their quarters into a study for her husband. A guide book highlights the pleasures of the Brontës' home life - learning to bake bread; and the hazards - an overcrowded churchyard contaminated the water and the village lost half of its under-sixes.

Special events: Magical Islands - map-making workshop 17, 18 August; Parsonage Patchwork, 24, 25 August

01535 644333

Daily 10am-5.30pm. Times change from October

Family ticket £10

01535 642323

Carisbrooke Castle
Newport, Isle of Wight
(English Heritage)

Things to do: At King Charles I's island exile the great attraction are the donkeys which turn a sixteenth-century treadmill in the well house with equanimity. With the help of the free activity sheet look for the window through which Charles I attempted his third escape attempt.

Daily 10am-6pm daily. Times change November

Family ticket £11.30

01983 522107

Castell Coch
Cardiff
(Cadw: Welsh Historic Monuments)

Things to do: A fold-out quiz sheet has spaces for souvenir postcards or drawings. William Burges, who designed this medieval fantasy for the Marquess of Bute, was known as 'ugly Burges' to distinguish him from a contemporary artist known as 'pretty Burges'. Unravel anagrams to find three types of tree in the grounds.

Daily 9.30am-6pm. Times change 2 October

Family ticket £7

029 20 810101

Castle Howard
North Yorkshire

Things to do: Count the birds and animals; the Polar Bears are a trick - they are a type of rhododendron. Inside match key artefacts to their rooms - a baby's rattle, glass pigs, and, intriguingly, a head on a plate.

National ballooning championships 21-26 August; children's weekend 26-28 August.

Daily until 5 November: house 11am-4.30pm; grounds 10am-6.30pm

£4.50 (children); £7.50 (adults), and family tickets depending on numbers

01653 648333

Chartwell
Westerham, Kent
(National Trust)

Things to do: No adults allowed in the summerhouse built by Sir Winston Churchill for his daughter Mary. Would you fancy swimming in that pool? Visit the garden studio, the lakes that Churchill dug and admire his skills as a bricklayer. Guide book for children and quiz.

Tuesday to Sunday and Bank Holiday Monday 11am-5pm. Days change 1 September

Family ticket £13.75

Story-telling and animal trail, 2pm Tuesday 22 August

01732 866368

Chatsworth House and Garden
Bakewell, Derbyshire

Things to do: The History Trail and Water Trail are packed with archive pictures and thought-provoking questions. The lighter Look at Chatsworth eight-page children's guide highlights curios - a table hung with stalactites, a trompe l'oeil violin, a Landseer poodle depicted as a judge and firescreens to stop the ladies' wax-based make-up melting.

House 11am-5.30pm daily; gardens 10.30am-6pm. Times change September

Family ticket £16.75

01246 582204

Hardwick Hall
Doe Lea, Chesterfield
(National Trust)

Things to do: Meet Bess of Hardwick, one of four daughters and a son, who became the richest woman in England next to Elizabeth I on the strength of a legacy of £26 and a succession of lucrative marriages. Look for four Sea Dogs who never left dry land.

House: Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday, Sunday and bank holidays 12.30pm-5pm; garden daily noon-5.30pm. Family ticket £15

01246 850430

Housesteads Roman Fort
(Vercovicium)
Hadrian's Wall

Things to do: Top of the bill here are the lavatories, with communal seating, continual sluicing, and - kids really love this - sponges on sticks for bottom-wiping. Worksheet at 99p also covers Corbridge Roman Side (Corstopitum) and Chesters Fort and Museum (Cilurnum).

Daily 10am-6pm. Times change October

£1.40 ( children); £2.80 (adults)

01434 344363

Petworth House and Park BR> Petworth, West Sussex
(National Trust)

Things to do: Why is the Duke of York wearing a dress? How is the unusual square dining room made symmetrical? Why is the Beauty Room so called? The Percy family manor, dating from 1150, was visited by Turner who painted and drew here. Capability Brown designed the landscape.

Treasure trails, noon-4pm, Thursday 18 August; Swords and shields 1pm-4pm, Thursday 25 August

Friday to Wednesday, house 1pm-5.30pm; grounds noon-6pm; park daily 8am-sunset

01798 342207

Rievaulx Abbey
Helmsley, North Yorkshire
(English Heritage)

Things to do: Contemplative and compassionate, but also consummate businessmen, the Cistercian monks at this elegantly ruined abbey ran a shrewd operation. Knickers were allowed only on days out. A free activity sheet for children unlocks the divine and the trivial.

Daily 9.30am-7pm. Times change September

£1.20 (children); £3.40 (adults)

01439 798228

Shakespeare's Birthplace
Stratford-upon-Avon

Things to do: The playwright's childhood and a typical Elizabethan upbringing are recreated here. Imagine the young William peering at his glovemaker father's materials and tools, family evenings and playtime in the gardens.

Monday to Saturday 9am-5pm; Sunday 9.30am-5pm. Times change 20 October

Family ticket £14; £20 for three town centre Shakespeare houses; £29 for five houses including Anne Hathaway's Cottage and Mary Arden's House (including farm and forge)

01789 204016

Skara Brae and Skaill House
Orkney

Things to do: This 5,000 year-old village was discovered by William Graham Watt in 1850. Piece together the lifestyle in a prehistoric home and compare it with the comfortable routine in Watt's mansion house.

Daily 9.30am-6.30pm. Times change October

£1.20 (children); £4 (adults) Joint ticket for all Historic Scotland monuments on Orkney available

01856 841815

Stirling Castle
Stirling
(Historic Scotland)

Things to do: The Scottish emblem was changed from a dragon to a lion by William the Lionheart in 1200. How many lions appear in the square of the King's Old Building? Who was baptised in the Chapel Royal in 1594? Find out with the children's guide, complete with questions.

Daily 9.30am-6pm. Times change October

Special events daily during school holidays: theatre, birds of prey, music

£1.50 (children); £6.50 (adults)

01786 450000

fields.headline: Observer best TV experience
fields.trailText: A round up of the most entertaining TV related day trips.
fields.body:
The Emmerdale Tour, Leeds

It may not be up there with Buffy or Hollyoaks, but Emmerdale provides an opportunity to go on a tour of a working studio.

Entertainers take visitors behind the scenes of what is apparently the 'world's largest single floor television studio' at the Emmerdale Production Centre in Leeds. There is little scope for participation, but it is one of the few programmes to offer a glimpse of life with the cameras turned off.

Times and availability vary according to demand. £6. Call 01274 562107.

Play TV, @Bristol

Play TV, part of Explore-at-Bristol, offers children a hands-on television experience with its purpose-built studio that could make programmes for Lilliput. Children can try presenting, filming and editing television. Adult intervention is kept to a minimum. A blue screen area allows scope for technical wizardry, providing the background for special effects.

Open Monday to Wednesday from 10am to 6pm and Thursday to Sunday from 10am to 8pm in August. Adults £6.50, children £4.50. Phone 0117 909 2000.

The BBC Experience, London

Point out the cold front coming in from the west to your friends or try your own rapid-fire sports commentary at the BBC Experience near Oxford Circus in London.

Striking a balance between exhibition and interaction, the first part of the tour is spent watching films and history shows while the end concentrates on allowing visitors to get hands on with the equipment. Everyone has the chance to bring away a tape of their own radio drama, produced either from a BBC script or one of their own.

Adults £7.50, child £4.95. First tour at 10am (11am on Monday), last tour at 4.30pm. Call 0870 603 0304.

fields.headline: Flames of life
fields.standfirst: Radio 1 DJ  Rajesh Mirchandani cautions against despair as America's giant sequoias burn
fields.trailText: Radio 1 DJ Rajesh Mirchandani cautions against despair as America's giant sequoias burn
fields.body:
We are all watching in awe as America's West Coast forests burn. Eleven states on fire. One million acres. If you've ever visited the giants of northern California, the sequoias and redwoods, you will understand the true scale of this devastation - and the huge irony of it.

It was last September when I went to the Giant Sequoia Grove on the outskirts of Yosemite National Park. The leaves were turning russet and gold against the backdrop of summer's green. I was expecting to be amazed by them, and had got used to the idea of size by the presence of foot-long sugar-pine cones littering the forest floor. But nothing prepares you for the trees themselves.

Giant Sequoias grow up to 300ft tall, the first one we saw was 87ft in circumference and its weight estimated at 6,100 tonnes. Giant sequoias are the largest single living organisms on the planet and can live for up to 3,000 years. How do you even start putting that figure into any kind of appreciable context? It precedes the Battle of Hastings by 2,000 years, it's 1,000 years older than Christianity. What does all the fuss over the millennium mean to a sequoia that has lived through three of them?

The Giant Sequoia Grove was very quiet and cool. I pressed my body against the soft, reddish bark and stretched my arms out as far as I could. I was completely flat. It was like pressing up against a spongy wall, the top of which was invisible above me.

One sequoia yields the same amount of timber as one acre of pine. About 100 years ago early timber manufacturers realised they could make a fortune from a single tree and set about cutting down as many as possible. Now they are protected and their natural habitats are national parks.

And as biologists and botanists understand more about these ancient and majestic giants, they have also started to believe that the thing that is threatening to destroy so much of America's forests may also be one of the things that ensures the sequoia's survival. For now some experts think that fire is part of the trees' regenerative cycle; that, far from damaging forest growth, it is a necessary part of it.

Every year giant sequoias drop up to 1,500 pine cones on to the forest floor. Each cone contains as many as 200 seeds. When the forest floor burns it heats the cones which releases the seeds. The fire also burns all the debris from the forest floor, known as duff, exposing mineral-rich soil for the seeds to take root in. In addition smaller, weaker trees are destroyed by the fire, leaving more space for the stronger trees to succeed.

Over time, lightning has struck in the Giant Sequoia Grove and started fires which have cleared away the duff. In the grove we visited there are just a handful of trees as their growth is also restricted by elevation and warmth. The fact that so few sequoias succeed shows what a hit-and-miss system of survival this is. Yet survive they have done.

As we sat in the grove, it felt like all the wisdom in the world was contained within these trees, that here was the very soul of the planet; that this is what it's all about: trees that live and grow and spread and creak and then finally die and fall, crushing huge swaths of forest beneath them, decaying for centuries but nourishing generations of life.

We may think we run this planet, but I very much hope the giant sequoias will be here long after we're gone.

fields.headline: Tales of the high seas
fields.trailText: Get reading | Ahoy me hearties! | City life
fields.body:
Get reading

Famous names from the world of children's books will be appearing at the Edinburgh International Children's and Young Persons' Book Fair until 28 August. As well as readings by a range of authors including Terry Jones and Dick Bruna, creator of Miffy, the world's largest selection of children's books will be available to buy. Call 0131 624 5050 or check out www.edbookfest.co.uk for the full programme of events and prices.

Ahoy me hearties!

Have a swashbuckling time at Whitby Abbey today when the Inner State Theatre Company presents 'More Skulduggery'. Let Captain Nathan Darke and his friends wow you with tales and jokes from the high seas and find out all about the legendary pirate Blackbeard. Shows at 12.30pm, 2pm and 3.30pm. Adults £1.70, children 90p, concessions £1.30. Under-5s free. Call 01947 603568.

City life

Unlikely as it may seem, London is the home of many species of wildlife. Discover the nature lurking on your doorstep by attending some of the events in the Going Wild In London season run by the London Wildlife Trust. To find out about events in your area phone 020 7261 0447 visit www.wildlifetrust.org.uk/london/regular.html. Even more events in the south-west of the city can be found at www.wildlife2000.org.uk.

High flying

Eastbourne is the venue for Airbourne 2000, a festival of all things aeronautical from 17-20 August. See the Red Arrows in action, test your nerves in a simulator, or join in with the kids' activities. The event runs from 10am-6pm and is rounded off by a firework display at 10pm on the Sunday night. Entry is free. Call 01323 736373 or visit www.eastbourne.org for details and the display programme.

Juggling high jinks

Show how much balls you have got by taking part in the Juggling and Circus Festival at The Hawth in Crawley today. Professional jugglers will be giving demonstrations and workshops for all abilities while talent from the world of the big top will amaze you with gravity-defying displays. Adults £5, children aged six-12 £3. Call 01293 553636 or visit www.hawth.co.uk.

What a carve up!

Become a sculptor for the day as The Glass Park in Kirk Sandall, South Yorkshire, turns into the studio for local artist Dan Jones. Between 10am and 4pm Jones will show children and parents how to design and make their own willow sculptures in this community-owned park. The site is approximately four miles north-east of Doncaster and well signposted. Entrance is free but don't forget to bring your own lunch. Call 01302 881898.

Born to skate

The Osiris team is hoping to skate to victory on the huge ramps and obstacles constructed for the UBI Open Skateboarding Championships. The London Arena is the venue for today's final of the tournament, where some of the world's best skaters can be seen from 10am. Adults £9, children £6. Call 020 7538 1212 or visit www.urbanbeach.co.uk.

Potty about pets

Wellington Country Park in Risely, near Reading, is performing some animal magic today from 10am-5:30pm. Measure one of Britain's smallest horses, Wonky Tonks, against a special guest, the Dulux dog, and enter your pet in the Exemption Dog Show. You can also see a huge variety of animals including wolves and llamas. Adults £4, children £2 (under-5s free). Call 0118 932 6444.

Flaming tasty

Spice up your Sunday with a visit to the Chilli Fiesta in West Dean Gardens, Chichester. More than 100 varieties of chilli peppers will be there to try (if you dare!) along with cookery demonstrations, competitions and tips on how to cultivate your own fiery crop. Open 13 August from 10.30am-5pm. Call 01243 818209 or visit www.westdean.org.uk.

Good clean fun

Eco Fest 2000 takes place in Singleton Park, Swansea, this weekend and is a fun way of raising awareness of all things green. Theatre, dance, music, workshops and demonstrations are taking place based on environmental and sustainable themes. The fun starts at 10am and comes to a close at 6pm. Admission free. Call 01792 635748.

fields.headline: Making waves
fields.standfirst: From her startling debut in  Breaking The Waves, Emily Watson has swiftly established herself as a gifted star, with two Oscar nominations to her name. But she's just been 'lucky' she tells an incredulous  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: From her startling debut in Breaking The Waves, Emily Watson has swiftly established herself as a gifted star, with two Oscar nominations to her name. But she's just been 'lucky' she tells an incredulous Mark Morris.
fields.body:
Emily Watson is distracted. She's staring at the cover of the book on the table. The book is Vladimir Nabokov's The Luzhin Defence, now - it almost certainly says - a major film starring John Turturro and Emily Watson.

Watson is on the cover, although you couldn't really tell: she's got her head turned away from the camera, towards Turturro. Both are soaked. 'Why did they choose this picture?' she's asking. 'That scene isn't even in the film. We got halfway through shooting it when the rain pump broke down, so it was all a disaster. We managed to realign the story so we didn't need it.'

Meeting Watson is strange. Beforehand, everyone says she's very nice, and so she is. In most ways she seems like a very average 33-year-old Londoner, if one on the more grown-up end of the spectrum. In person, she's more elegant than you expect: tall and wearing a dark green top and pale green trousers that accentuate her height.

But Watson isn't an average Camden Town resident, still less your average actress. She received best actress Oscar nominations for her first film, Breaking The Waves and also for Hilary And Jackie. And even that doesn't do her justice: Breaking The Waves was hardly Academy-fodder, being foreign, strange, brutal and sexual. The force of Watson's performance meant that the Academy was forced to pay attention.

Her impact has been so powerful so fast that it is a surprise when you realise how few films she's done. She counts them on her fingers, suggests six before deciding on seven. In fact, it's eight. In her third film, she starred opposite Daniel Day-Lewis in Jim Sheridan's The Boxer. The fourth was the controversial Hilary And Jackie. And her fifth was Tim Robbins's Cradle Will Rock, followed by Angela's Ashes. All in four years.

It's an unlikely tale. After an impeccably middle-class upbringing (father an architect, mother a teacher) in London, Watson went to Bristol University to do English. She wanted to act, but had trouble convincing people she could. Drama schools turned her down. Eventually The Drama Studio in west London took her and she graduated to the Royal Shakespeare Company. By the time she started acting professionally, she was already 25.

One of the words she uses most is 'lucky' and you can see why. She was still unknown at 29 when Lars von Trier chose her to play the disturbed girl from the tiny Calvinist Scottish island who marries a foreign oil rig worker. Then again, at the time only film buffs knew who von Trier was. Breaking The Waves would change both their lives. 'It was just a very personal thing for me,' she says in her soft voice. 'I'd never made a film before. I didn't know it was an important film. But I think I was aware that it represented a very intense time of personal change for him [von Trier]. Because if you look at the change between Europa and Breaking The Waves, he's thrown the rule book out of the window, and his relationship with actors completely changed, from bodies that you put somewhere to really being in touch with his emotional state. And he was discovering that in Breaking The Waves, so it was special.' Most actresses aren't able to analyse the different stages of directors' careers. Watson is different.

There is a chance that Breaking The Waves will turn out to be one of the key films in cinema history. Already its influence has been enormous. And the reactions to it have been repeated with von Trier's Dancer In The Dark. Watson is a fan, although she expresses it in a slightly disturbing way. 'For me, watching it was like having someone walk over my grave. I could tell what was going to happen. Little things. I loved it, I found it very raw.'

In a way, it is easy to see why the drama schools passed on Watson. The reason she is so effective on screen is that she acts with her face. Sure, she is no slouch at accents, but the expression comes from the corners of her mouth, her vast eyes. She is mildly taken aback when I suggest that this might be why her film career blossomed in a way her stage career did not. But she considers the point. 'It's funny, you don't know that about your face until someone points a camera at it. The first time I saw Breaking The Waves was in Cannes, and each nostril was as big as a house. It was a real shocker: I wasn't wearing any make-up - and no clothes at times - and everything was very exposed. It's a weird thing.'

'Exposed' is something she's willing to do: in Hilary And Jackie she took Jacqueline Du Pre, something of a secular saint, and showed her to be a complex, confused and sexual character. Having also played Angela McCourt, she is aware of the peril of playing real people. 'It is a huge responsibility. Unless you make something incredibly bland, you're going to upset somebody. It's tricky, and I felt a bit stung by the whole thing with Hilary And Jackie . I was quite taken aback by the reaction to that. The way the press were talking about it, as if it was salacious tittle-tattle. It just so wasn't.'

The Luzhin (pronounced as in illusion, according to Nabokov himself ) Defence isn't a showpiece for her on the scale of Breaking The Waves or Hilary And Jackie. Not that she's not good in it: she is. But it's not that kind of part. The film is a well-appointed costume drama but is turned into something more interesting by Turturro's performance as a damaged chess genius. Watson found someone else playing a traumatised character an interesting expe rience. 'I did have more of an appreciation of how, when you're in the thick of it - you think that everybody understands what you are going through. They don't. You have to stay in that world, it is so easy to destroy it. During Breaking The Waves, I was on my own in a hotel room. I think I would have been impossible to live with. When you go home, you have to pretend to be the person you are at home.'

There is no obvious biographical reason why Watson should be so adept at trauma. She seems happy in her life in Camden with her husband, actor/writer Jack Waters, with whom she is working on a screenplay. And the only strange thing about her childhood seems to be the way her parents took a certain kind of educated, middle-class approach to life to its extreme. 'I grew up without a television. It meant that I read lots of books and entertained myself. I missed things: There's a huge gap in my knowledge of popular culture basically, because of it. I occasionally still get embarrassed when someone says "you know such-and-such..." and you just think' - her voice goes very meek - "nooo...".

Yet to be released here is Trixie, a comedy by eccentric American director Alan Rudolph. Watson, taking a turn far off her expected course, plays a malapropism-spouting private eye. On her co-star Nick Nolte, she says: 'He's... just completely nuts, in the nicest possible way. He doesn't care, he really, really doesn't care. He's done everything. He's completely unshockable.'

At one point, we talk about the Pitt-Aniston wedding, how mad all that is. In one way, Emily Watson belongs to that world now. But unlike Brad or Jennifer she can pass through at will: after she has finished her last interview of the day, she can just fade into the crowds of people ambling through Soho, leaving the star behaviour for when she's on screen.

The changing faces of Emily Watson

Angela's Ashes
(Alan Parker, 2000)
Uneven and gloomy adaptation of Frank McCourt's massively successful memoir, but Watson does a fine job as Frank's long-suffering but not exactly saintly mother.

Hilary and Jackie
 (Anand Tucker, 1999)
Still controversial biopic of Jacqueline Du Pre, with Watson deftly showing all sides to Du Pre's complex character, including her fascinatingly bizarre affected accent, as well as her descent into illness.

Breaking the waves
(Lars Von Trier, 1996)
Watson's astonishing debut as Bess, the troubled girl from a remote Scottish island who slides into madness. The film is either a work of genius or unwatchable, but Watson's performance is terrifyingly convincing.

 The Luzhin Defence is showing at Edinburgh Film Festival (0131 623 8030) on 22 August and opens nationwide next month.

fields.headline: Tales from the couch
fields.trailText: Three patients share their experiences of psychotherapy
fields.body:
Mark, mid-forties

'I went into therapy telling myself it was because I had decided to train to become a psychoanalyst, and therapy is part of the training, but I knew that I had stuff of my own to deal with. At the bottom of my problem was the fact that I was adopted when I was a baby, and it had left me with a barely conscious sense of deep abandonment. My adoptive family was fine, but I grew up like a cuckoo in their nest. I liked different things: I was quite academic and they were a very non-academic family. To this day, I'm the only member of the family from any generation to go to university.

'Growing up, I felt a low level of unhappiness all the time. To a large extent I cauterised my feelings, but I was always angry, and socially incompetent. If I'd met myself, I wouldn't have liked myself. I chose psychoanalysis, which is one of the most demanding - and expensive - therapies. I went for an hour a day, four days a week, for just over a year. I wasn't a good patient. I intellectualised the process.

'It was only gradually that I relinquished control, and that's when the therapy began to really affect me. For the first time, I let myself not be strong and in control. It was a very big thing for me, very liberating. Sometimes I'd become incredibly emotional. I'd drive home from sessions weeping in the car.

'My adoptive family were blue-collar workers, and my birth mother, whom I'd met a few years before, was an academic. I began to idealise her family. During analysis I met my mother again, and my analyst helped me to understand my real feelings about her as the person who had abandoned me, and to get a more adult distance from the family. It's easy to underestimate the damage done to children by their parents.

'I've always been good at my job, but I've also always had a unique ability to piss people off at work. I could never work out exactly why, but I seemed to rub people up the wrong way. As a consequence, my career has usually been most successful when I've been self-employed. During analysis, a really good job came up and I applied for it. I got it, and not only that, I became a pivotal person at the office, the consiglieri . That had never happened to me before, and I don't think it would have done without therapy.

'I'm certainly calmer, less angry and more open. But the biggest effect went beyond individual examples. The best way I can describe it is to say that it gave me a completely new language - the language of emotions. It taught me to understand my own feelings and motivations, but also how to understand other people's. I gave it up because the emotional and financial commitment became too demanding, but what I learned from it, emotionally and intellectually, has stayed with me. 'I went into therapy a few years ago, because I was suddenly stuck in my life and needed to get unstuck. Sarah, mid-thirties

Sometimes I'd be angry with my boyfriend or one of my children, and he'd make me see it was left over anger from other relationships and betrayals. A big part of therapy is just becoming conscious about your own emotional issues.'
