webTitle: UN set to tackle Britain on racism

fields.headline: UN set to tackle Britain on racism
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The United Nations is set to launch an attack on the Government's record on race relations, after condemnation from more than 30 British human rights and ethnic minority groups.
fields.byline: by Martin Bright, home affairs correspondent
fields.body:
The United Nations is set to launch an attack on the Government's record on race relations, after condemnation from more than 30 British human rights and ethnic minority groups.

The criticism is contained in a report submitted by the groups to the UN committee responsible for monitoring racism. It contains claims that the Government's policy on asylum-seekers 'gives comfort to racists' and has led to increased racial tension.

It also criticises Ministers for failing to grapple with police hostility to the findings of the Macpherson inquiry into the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

The UN Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination meets every three years and last reported on Britain as Labour came to power. Campaigners believe its findings will, therefore, provide a clear picture of race relations in Tony Blair's Britain.

Officials from the Home Office and the Foreign Office will fly tomorrow to Geneva in an attempt to head off the criticism. They will claim that they have met most of the committee's recommendations from 1997. The civil rights and anti-racist groups will make presentations on asylum-seekers, deaths in custody and education.

The report has been compiled by the civil rights group Liberty and the anti-racist 1990 Trust from submissions by groups that include the Refugee Council.

Maxie Hayles, of the Birmingham Racial Attacks Monitoring Unit, said he had failed to notice any significant change in police attitudes since the Macpherson report was published in February 1999. 'Although there have been some improvements in police policy, this is not getting down to the bully boys on the ground.' he said.

The report contains a list of six major areas of concern:

 The number of racist attacks have increased.

 People from ethnic minorities are more likely to be stopped and searched.

 Immigration and asylum policy has become a threat to good race relations.

 New race relation legislation includes exemptions for immigration policy.

 Certain ethnic minorities are more likely to be unemployed.

 Little improvement in the representation of ethnic minorities in public life.

It is hoped that the committee will demand public inquiries into the deaths in custody of Alton Manning and Roger Sylvester and the killing of Zahid Mubarak while he was at Feltham young offenders' institution.

However, Brenda Weinberg, chair of the United Families and Friends Campaign, which works for the relatives of people who have died in custody, said she was sceptical that anything would come of government plans to set up a fully independent police complaints procedure.

The Home Office told The Observer that it had presented its own submission to the discrimination committee (CERD) last May, but said officials would be providing the UN with an update when they arrive tomorrow. 'We are are confident we have fulfilled our reporting obligations to the UN,' a spokesman said.

However, the organisations involved said that they had been given less than a week to respond to the Government's submission to CERD. Those which failed to do so were told that it would be assumed they were not interested.

fields.headline: Sir Alec Guinness
fields.standfirst: An appreciation by Philip French
fields.trailText: An appreciation by Philip French
fields.body:
What has the 1934 Evelyn Laye comedy Evensong, in which an Irish opera singer gives up her career for love in Vienna, got in common with the 1995 thriller Mute Witness, in which a woman sees a murder committed in Moscow? They were the first and last movies of Alec Guinness. In the first, he appeared uncredited in a crowd scene; in the second, he spoke briefly from the shady interior of a car as a Russian mafia boss and was billed as 'Distinguished Mystery Guest'.

Thus a great career began and ended in anonymity. His modest Who's Who entry (mentioning eight plays, seven films, two TV series) ran to a mere 18 lines as compared to a whole column each for Richardson, Olivier and Gielgud. Between 1946 and 1995, I saw all of his 40-odd movies, and between 1951 and 1990 I saw him about 15 times in the theatre. Weirdly, his stage failures, especially Hamlet and Macbeth, come more immediately to mind than his triumphs (eg Ross, Habeas Corpus).

Conversely, I've largely forgotten his many weak movies, yet can replay in my head his four great Ealing comedies - Kind Hearts and Coronets, The Lavender Hill Mob, The Man in the White Suit, The Ladykillers - Tunes of Glory (his finest performance) and a half-dozen others.

Guinness's childhood was Dickensian and before the war he adapted Great Expectations for the stage. After the war, he became a star in screen versions of Great Expectations and Oliver Twist. His last major screen role was in Little Dorrit and his last movie performance of consequence was as the recluse in the jungle who compels the hero of A Handful of Dust to read Dickens to him forever.

Guinness shared Dickens's great gift for mimicry, of which Peter Ackroyd has written: 'It is often said of mimics that they can only successfully imitate characters whom they admire or in some way care for; and it is true of Dickens, too, that he literally became the characters and friends whom he mimicked. That is why, even in his greatest villains, there is more than a trace of fellow feeling and sympathy.'

The same might be said of Sir Alec Guinness.

webTitle: Clearing 2000: A student writes about gap years

fields.headline: Finding just the right gap
fields.standfirst:
A year in Australia was full of fun, but also a foray into adulthood

Useful link: Gapyear.com
fields.trailText: A year in Australia was full of fun, but also a foray into adulthood
fields.body:
The start of my travelling gap year can be summed up in one word - fear. There was no excitement, anticipation or thoughts of adventure. My best friend Laura and I got on the plane, looked at each other and thought, 'What on earth are we doing?'

We both cried practically all the way to LA and kept saying to each other, 'If we hate it we can come back' - and we honestly thought we would. In LA we were miserable: my parents had booked us a hotel which had fallen through - not what we needed on our first night away. The Holiday Inn was horrible to us and didn't make us feel any better about the fact that we'd just left home for eight months. We then got our connecting flight to Fiji.

Once we arrived, we had one drink - and it all changed! Suddenly it was the most exciting thing in the world: we were exploring islands, catching local buses to remote villages, getting lost and having to hitch-hike back - the fear was gone and we were having the times of our lives. We were to spend a large proportion of our gap year in Australia - a mixture of work and travel. On arriving we stayed with friends with whom we fell out. Then we moved to a flat where we slept on a sofabed together surrounded by mess and often drunken Aussies - and absolutely loved it.

We got jobs in a local restaurant and then explored the Harbour City. Our advantage was that we were looking round Sydney as locals - we were working and living with Australians so we just developed an entirely new lifestyle. We had got working visas before we left, which were valid for a year and cost less than £100. You could work anywhere you liked, but for no longer than three months at a time.

After about four months we travelled to Melbourne, through the middle of Australia and then down the East Coast. This is when we became tourists, staying in hostels, scuba diving, bungee jumping and drinking excessive amounts of beer with fellow Brits, Swedes and Danes. Some of the trips we took were very long. It was a 36-hour bus journey from Ayers Rock, now known as Uluru, to the East Coast, and this was hot and uncomfortable - but seeing the Rock and King's Canyon in central Australia were definitely worth it. I would recommend anyone to take that journey.

In fact, all the trips were worth the money, although if I did it again I'd get my diving certificate when I was on the Great Barrier Reef. It was travelling that Laura and I had our only low points. Moving around all the time, never unpacking and not having time on your own can get you down after a while. If you want to just slump, there are people in your room. The communal areas are always heaving and, after a while, we both found this quite hard.

Once back in Sydney, we couldn't leave. We had intended to go to New Zealand and San Francisco, but we extended our time in Oz instead. We got our old jobs back and went skiing with friends - we'd fallen in love with the place - and some rather cute surfers too. Laura and I left for these travels in February after leaving school, and had both been working in the interim. We had about £4,000 saved each, after having paid for our flights. Some of this money was in an Australian bank account; my father was in charge of the rest, both to pay off my credit card bills and to top up my Australian account when needed.

We both kept budget books, which we updated weekly by keeping all our receipts and payslips. As soon as we arrived, we started work - even though we had enough money stacked up. If you can work in a restaurant or bar, the money is fantastic. It is paid like a temping job would be in England, and if you work weekends and late at night, the money increases even more. You earn enough to live very comfortably, and get the added advantage of meeting the locals. However, the money we saved while working in England and in Sydney went quickly up the East Coast. The hostels are expensive - although dorms are cheaper - and buying your coach ticket is a hefty sum. We bought a ticket that let you jump on and off a specified route, which was brilliant as there were no restrictions. Obviously we found sneaky ways to save money. We'd catch coaches overnight - getting a good night's sleep without the cost of a hostel. But you don't realise how much you can spend when travelling. During the day you are constantly getting drinks, food or paying for galleries or entertainment. When we were there we both vowed that we would never worry about money and not do something because of cash restrictions as we may regret it later. We decided that we'd prefer to come back to England with vast overdrafts and then pay them off. Australia is not cheap, but there are opportunities to work all around the country. It could be done more cheaply if you bought a car and camped, but being two girls on our own, away for the first time, we decided not to do it like that. Looking back on it we'd have been absolutely fine.

So what did I think of my year off? I still regret not doing something a bit more 'worthy' and actually helping someone. On the other hand, on organised gap years, people tend to get 'mothered' and it's really just like a long school trip to somewhere far away. A lot of people explored more countries than we did, adding South East Asia to their itinerary. This would have been fantastic, but we needed to work to keep our money topped up, and we now have the advantage of knowing a city inside out, having lived there as residents. There's plenty of time to go elsewhere and we preferred to explore places properly.

We gained experience that was invaluable at that time in our lives. We learnt to be independent. We sorted out everything from our jobs and taxes to remembering to buy groceries and wash our knickers. We'd both been at day school so this was the first occasion we'd left home for any length of time. We also learnt to budget. When I got to university it was obvious who had been away for a year - we had loads to talk about and we no longer acted like kids just out of the classroom. For instance, those who had come straight from school were throwing up everywhere at the Freshers' Ball.

What are the cons then? When I came back home I was an absolute nightmare. I was so miserable to be back - I'd met someone in Australia and fallen in love and I wanted to stay in Sydney with him. I announced that I did not want to go to university: I wanted to travel more, return to Australia, and defer a year. My parents had a few words to say about that. My mother thought that I was being such a lunatic that she hid my passport, thinking that I would run away in the night, and I was so mad I probably would have. Laura was also so miserable when she got back that she hopped on a plane and went back for another six months. This was a major negative point of travelling. The feeling of complete despondency and disorientation on return was horrible.

The other problems included my mother sorting out my university accommodation, which meant that I was in a university hall full of the most awful people. I also put on two stone while I was away, thanks to vast quantities of beer and the 9p-a-packet noodles eaten in gargantuan quantities. But, all in all, my gap year was one of the best times of my life. As for the Australian love of my life, he fell by the wayside after about the second week of university. He came to visit for Christmas - but you'll have to ask my parents about that, as he ended up staying with them for three months.

 Katie graduated in physiology from Bristol University last year. She now works in advertising.

You earn enough to live very comfortably, and get the added advantage of meeting the locals. However, the money we saved while working in England and in Sydney went quickly up the East Coast. The hostels are expensive - although dorms are cheaper - and buying your coach ticket is a hefty sum. We bought a ticket that let you jump on and off a specified route, which was brilliant as there were no restrictions. Obviously we found sneaky ways to save money. We'd catch coaches overnight - getting a good night's sleep without the cost of a hostel. But you don't realise how much you can spend when travelling. During the day you are constantly getting drinks, food or paying for galleries or entertainment. When we were there we both vowed that we would never worry about money and not do something because of cash restrictions as we may regret it later. We decided that we'd prefer to come back to England with vast overdrafts and then pay them off. Australia is not cheap, but there are opportunities to work all around the country. It could be done more cheaply if you bought a car and camped, but being two girls on our own, away for the first time, we decided not to do it like that. Looking back on it we'd have been absolutely fine. So what did I think of my year off? I still regret not doing something a bit more 'worthy' and actually helping someone. On the other hand, on organised gap years, people tend to get 'mothered' and it's really just like a long school trip to somewhere far away. A lot of people explored more countries than we did, adding South East Asia to their itinerary. This would have been fantastic, but we needed to work to keep our money topped up, and we now have the advantage of knowing a city inside out, having lived there as residents. There's plenty of time to go elsewhere and we preferred to explore places properly. We gained experience that was invaluable at that time in our lives. We learnt to be independent. We sorted out everything from our jobs and taxes to remembering to buy groceries and wash our knickers. We'd both been at day school so this was the first occasion we'd left home for any length of time. We also learnt to budget. When I got to university it was obvious who had been away for a year - we had loads to talk about and we no longer acted like kids just out of the classroom. For instance, those who had come straight from school were throwing up everywhere at the Freshers' Ball. What are the cons then? When I came back home I was an absolute nightmare. I was so miserable to be back - I'd met someone in Australia and fallen in love and I wanted to stay in Sydney with him. I announced that I did not want to go to university: I wanted to travel more, return to Australia, and defer a year. My parents had a few words to say about that. My mother thought that I was being such a lunatic that she hid my passport, thinking that I would run away in the night, and I was so mad I probably would have. Laura was also so miserable when she got back that she hopped on a plane and went back for another six months. This was a major negative point of travelling. The feeling of complete despondency and disorientation on return was horrible. The other problems included my mother sorting out my university accommodation, which meant that I was in a university hall full of the most awful people. I also put on two stone while I was away, thanks to vast quantities of beer and the 9p-a-packet noodles eaten in gargantuan quantities. But, all in all, my gap year was one of the best times of my life. As for the Australian love of my life, he fell by the wayside after about the second week of university. He came to visit for Christmas - but you'll have to ask my parents about that, as he ended up staying with them for three months.  Katie graduated in physiology from Bristol University last year. She now works in advertising.

fields.headline: Girl, 15, makes human rights history
fields.trailText: A schoolgirl of 15 is set to make English legal history by using the Human Rights Act to take action against her school.
fields.body:
A schoolgirl of 15 is set to make English legal history by using the Human Rights Act to take action against her school.

The parents of the girl, who cannot be identified, have said that her expulsion from her secondary school a year before her GCSE exams could do irreparable damage to her education.

The girl, from the South East, was expelled on the last day of the summer term. As a result, she will appear at a magistrates' hearing this week on a minor criminal charge.

Her case, which will be taken after the criminal investigation is completed, will test Article 6 of the Convention, the right to a fair trial.

It is claimed that new procedures for appealing against exclusions do not give enough rights to the school child or parents.

It will be the first of a series of cases involving education and gay rights which will test the limits of the Act, which comes into force in October.

The girl's solicitor, David Ruebain, said that because of changes to the right of appeal against exclusions, it was difficult to see how children who were expelled could get a fair hearing.

Last month David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, announced that schools had the right to override the appeals process if they thought the child was a threat to other children.

'There is a view that the new guidance is a breach of Article 6,' Ruebain said. 'What is the point of an appeals process if that appeals process can be overridden?'

Because the girl was expelled on the last day of term, she will not be able to appeal against exclusion until the first day of the new term. By then the exclusion policy will be in place and by the time her case comes to court the human rights act will also be in force.

Stonewall, the gay rights group, is considering a number of cases where it can be proved that employers are not giving the same rights to gay partners of employees as to married couples.

webTitle: Edinburgh theatre: Decky Does a Bronco

fields.headline: Child's play for adults
fields.standfirst: When the emotions of a gang of boys are portrayed by adults, the results are disturbing
fields.trailText: When the emotions of a gang of boys are portrayed by adults, the results are disturbing.
fields.body:
Decky Does a Bronco Scotland Yard Playground

Medea Assembly Rooms

The Bogus Woman Traverse

Abandonment Traverse

Further than the Furthest Thing Traverse

The Donkey Show Club Pleasance@Potterow

Three shows soar above the rest in the first week of the Fringe. They're so diverse that it's as if someone had set out to demonstrate the variety of contemporary theatre. One of them corrals the city itself into its tale of childish bullying and child abuse. The second re-imagines a Classical tragedy. The third is a ferocious piece of political pleading.

Decky Does a Bronco is staged - like so much stirring theatre - outside a theatre building. In the aptly named Scotland Yard Playground, Grid Iron Theatre Company have arranged a circle of child-size stools for their audience. Outside loom the grey Edinburgh turrets; in the centre are some children's swings. Swaying idly, these look sweet at the beginning of the evening, and sinister by the end.

Douglas Maxwell's play, dynamically directed by Ben Harrison, makes everyday things seem weird. Its gang of boys is played by adults: the spilling-over energy, total crossness and awkward affection of nine-year-olds become disturbing when written large on grown-up faces.

As do its obsessions. The 'Bronco' of the title is a swing thing - a trick which involves levering yourself up level with the bar and jumping off: 'What started up as vandalism ended up as a sport.' It's a sport displayed with acrobatic zeal, and discussed with a severity which takes you into the heart of childhood. Observing the exacting rules is as unnerving as taking the entrance exam for the Civil Service; falling short - as does the wee, bullied Decky - means exclusion.

The plot of Decky ends grimly. But since the event is open to the outside world, it will always have a slightly different conclusion.

Last week, as the hero reflected on the persistence of things after childhood tragedy, a real - proper-size - child burst out of the bushes surrounding the stage and gambolled towards it, carefree and callous - as if to prove his point. After the Festival, the show goes on tour through Scotland.

Theatre Babel's superb production of Medea takes as its text Liz Lochheed's Scots version of Euripides . Salty and sardonic, it casts the woman who was once considered a witch as the archetype of the wronged woman. The chorus, in dove-grey, with knotted hair, is a politicised crew of widows, mistresses, wives - all recently- turned worms. Jason is a male-chauvinist pig; Kreon an old-style master, buttoned-up like a church elder or an advocate.

There's nothing even-handed about this: it pushes an argument about the unfair lot dealt to women. Nor does it in the end give a really convincing reason - what could it be? - for Medea's murder of her children. But you can quarrel with nothing else in an absorbing, galvanic evening.

Maureen Beattie - alone in red, and isolated in her speech, as the incomer in a Scots-speaking Establishment - is magnificent. Her anger is the more effective for containing displays of deflationary humour with which she cajoles the audience before her blackest deeds; she purrs without cease. A national tour follows.

You don't often hear people crying in the theatre. But you do during The Bogus Woman. Kay Adshead's play, presented by The Red Room and Mamo Quillo, is a body-blow.

Delivered with top-velocity grace by Noma Dumezweni on a brutally bare stage - there's a slop bucket and some gnawed blocks of wood - the play tells the story of an African journalist whose father, husband and baby daughter have been butchered, who has been raped by soldiers, fled her country and who wants to stay in England. 'Why', inquires one of the sweetly sceptical admission officers of the asylum-seeker, 'did they rape you and not kill you?'

It's a fictional account in as much as it is the story of no particular woman's life; it's a documentary account in that it draws on the facts of many lives - part of Adshead's research involved talking to a refugee charged with causing riot and affray at the Campsfield Detention Centre in 1997. The result is, she has said, a history 'more shocking than some and less shocking than others'.

Its effect is increased by an almost Grecian restraint. The violence has already taken place; what the audience observe is a series of dogged humiliations: casual racial insults from the officers in the camp; the institutionalised contempt which delivers weeny food vouchers and insecure lodgings. Dumezweni makes you feel you are inhabiting a world behind the headlines.

Other Traverse shows seem wan in comparison: while nearly every play has something to recommend it, few come across as urgent. Kate Atkinson's likable Abandonment is a case in point. It's in many respects a good advertisement for her novels: full of good sentences and funny, with themes woven together as intricately as a bird's nest.

The device of parallel lives seems particularly congenial for examining the stories of women's lives. Atkinson's heroine is a twentieth-century historian, left by her mother as an infant, dumped by her lover, who finds a way of building a family of her own - and whose life is shadowed by that of a nineteenth-century governess.

The cast double up across the two time zones: at one point, the faithless lover cradles both Victorian and modern woman.

There are no loose ends here: the structure is the story; and it's a story warmly realised in design and warmth of acting. But despite its intimate touches, you are left admiring an apparatus rather than feeling compelled by the heroine. A bit more abandon would have come in handy.

Zinnie Harris's Further than the Furthest Thing, a joint production between the Tron and the National, is also freighted with good ideas, not carried lightly. Inspired by the experience of the inhabitants of Tristan da Cunha, evacuated to England in the Sixties when a volcano erupted, it evokes a displanted island culture, whose survival is threatened by realpolitik and metropolitan commercialism.

Niki Turner's design is striking: a paralysed wasteland in which stony slopes are supervised by a frozen gush of water. There's a beautifully judged performance by Paola Dionisotti - precise, proudly spoken, emotionally disarrayed. But its boldest stroke - the creation of an island patois - confines its characters to quaintness.

Meanwhile, The Donkey Show is playing to packed houses with its clubbing adaptation of A Midsummer Night's Dream . There's no dialogue, but a carnival of undulating, roller-skating, tattooed bodies. Titania, in thigh-high shiny boots and a ruff of peacock feathers, gives new resonance to her name, with butterflies perched on her nipples. As the lovers lose each other in a forest of people, Helena sings 'Don't leave me this way'. The magic potion is a bag of cocaine. It's very New York - and very Edinburgh.

webTitle: Why no one can afford to ignore Big Brother

fields.headline: Why no one can afford to ignore Big Brother
fields.trailText: There is nothing on television more compulsive than Big Brother. The Channel 4 10-week experiment sounds on paper like a sick joke that would hold the attention of only a tiny handful of sad individuals. But in reality it is the only programme outside the limited parameters of the soap genre to reinvigorate television as a social medium.
fields.body:
There is nothing on television more compulsive than Big Brother. The Channel 4 10-week experiment sounds on paper like a sick joke that would hold the attention of only a tiny handful of sad individuals. But in reality it is the only programme outside the limited parameters of the soap genre to reinvigorate television as a social medium.

The American phrase 'water cooler television', or our own more quaint 'village pump' television can be properly applied to Big Brother, which is the biggest talking point in popular culture since Princess Di met her untimely end. Big Brother merchandising is now leaching out, as fervent anti-Nick-ers or pro-Caroline-ers feel the need to wear their prejudices on their sleeves.

To some people it may be the kind of trivia that would give Lord Reith a coronary - were he not dead already - but it is essentially a perfect use of the medium and the first, and possibly last, example of a piece of interactive television really working. If Big Brother had been produced by Lars Von Trier and presented as art-house cinema, it would have swept the board and seafront at Cannes.

As it is, the intelligentsia, by which I mean David Aaronovitch at the Independent and Jonathan Freedland at the Guardian, have been slightly miffed as what to make of its undoubted success. (Though I thought Freedland's observation that the group never discussed politics was an excellent point to pursue - could we perhaps have the comment pages of the Guardian, or even the Observer, dropped from helicopters on to the Big Brother house?).

The popularity of Big Brother may be baffling to some, but it is entertainment with a capital E. The exposure of 10 fit, egotistical young people to the rigours of superstardom, character assasination and CCTV in the lavvies is a far more edifying use of media time and space than the disgraceful naming and shaming carried out by certain tabloid newspapers.

But the phenomenon of Big Brother highlights another trend within the broadcasting industry - the hit-driven schedule. Big Brother, despite being scheduled largely outside peak time, has delivered Channel 4 its biggest audience share for four years.

For a channel that is usually batting around the 10 per cent mark, the BB factor has, on certain nights, given it a 20 per cent share. Enough of these audience 'spikes' and you can pad the rest of your schedule with cheese-rolling contests and philosophical discussions about eugenics - or in C4's case cricket and World Federation Wrestling.

The hit-driven schedule is indicative of changing viewing habits. The days when people did not even know where the C4 or BBC2 button were are long gone. The realisation that channel brands, though important, are only as strong as their programmes has meant that broadcasters have to think differently about how they market themselves to the increasingly promiscuous viewer.

And the downside is that anything without 'hit' appeal will wither on the vine rather more quickly than it did in the days when no one changed channels between 6.30 and 11pm. For instance, a television executive was pointing out to me last week that on Sunday night, BBC1's new drama, the rather confused Border Cafe, was pulling in barely more than 2 million viewers - something that at one time would have been totally unheard of for a relatively expensive production in a prime slot.

But then Border Cafe, though whimsical, is - how can I put this - not that great. For the BBC it is better to commission something that's not quite a hit, or that's even an out-and-out flop, than to commission nothing at all. But what the Big Brother experiment also proves is that in the quest for hits, experimentation still pays.

Clinging to money-spinners such as Prime Suspect is only a strategy for the desperately conservative. Stripping 13 nights of a pub quiz across prime time (ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire?) is a winner, as is experimenting with soft pornography in the late- night schedules (Channel 5) and, now, prurient social experimentation.

'Original drama' will still be the mainstay of the schedule as long as it is good enough (Cold Feet) or sufficiently 'different' to build a following despite limitations of plot and script (Bad Girls). But Big Brother-style experiments should be celebrated and embraced, even by those who are not keen viewers themselves. After all, if you don't like it, you can always read a book.

webTitle: Ex-priest fights for right to be MP

fields.headline: Ex-priest fights for right to be MP
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: A former priest standing to be a Labour MP will not be able to take his seat in Parliament because of archaic laws lost in the mists of England's anti-Catholic past.
fields.body:
A former priest standing to be a Labour MP will not be able to take his seat in Parliament because of archaic laws lost in the mists of England's anti-Catholic past.

David Cairns, Labour candidate for the safe seat of Greenock and Inverclyde in the west of Scotland, will be barred from sitting in the House of Commons, even though he left the Catholic priesthood six years ago.

Cairns is seeking to get the law, thought to originate in the 1600s when anti-Catholic feeling in Britain ran high, overturned. It would be embarrassing for a proudly modernising Government if the issue turned into a constitutional row after the next election.

'The law must be changed,' Cairns said. 'I am allowed to get selected, to stand for Parliament, to win the election but not to take my seat.'

Only once before has the issue threatened to become a public battle. Bruce Kent, the former leader of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament and a onetime priest, stood for election in 1992. But he failed to win his seat and the law went unchallenged.

Labour MP Siobhain McDonagh is leading the amendment campaign. The intention is to have a clause inserted into an election Bill to be considered by the House of Lords which would allow ex-priests into Parliament.

McDonagh tried to have the law changed last year, but failed to win enough support from the Government.

'If people are properly selected by their party and win a valid mandate from the voters, it is simply undemocratic that our ancient law can prevent those elected members from taking their place in the House,' Mc Donagh told Parliament at the time.

The ban on former priests is based on nine Acts of Parliament from the 16th and 17th centuries. It does not apply to the Church of England clergy or other faiths such as Judaism or Islam.

In a memorandum to the Select Committee on Home Affairs, Robert Blackburn, a professor of constitutional law, said: 'The reasons for the discriminatory principles... have no justification today.'

Cairns, who works in McDonagh's office in Westminster, became a priest in 1991, at St Mary's Catholic Church in Clapham, south London. He said working with disadvantaged groups gave him a political appetite and he left the priesthood in 1994.

Bruce Kent, the former leader of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament and a onetime priest, stood for election in 1992. But he failed to win his seat and the law went unchallenged. Labour MP Siobhain McDonagh is leading the amendment campaign. The intention is to have a clause inserted into an election Bill to be considered by the House of Lords which would allow ex-priests into Parliament. McDonagh tried to have the law changed last year, but failed to win enough support from the Government. 'If people are properly selected by their party and win a valid mandate from the voters, it is simply undemocratic that our ancient law can prevent those elected members from taking their place in the House,' Mc Donagh told Parliament at the time. The ban on former priests is based on nine Acts of Parliament from the 16th and 17th centuries. It does not apply to the Church of England clergy or other faiths such as Judaism or Islam. In a memorandum to the Select Committee on Home Affairs, Robert Blackburn, a professor of constitutional law, said: 'The reasons for the discriminatory principles... have no justification today.' Cairns, who works in McDonagh's office in Westminster, became a priest in 1991, at St Mary's Catholic Church in Clapham, south London. He said working with disadvantaged groups gave him a political appetite and he left the priesthood in 1994.

fields.headline: Go for it!
fields.standfirst: Late bargains
fields.trailText: Late bargains in Thailand, Egypt, Tenerife and more.
fields.body:
Holidays

Thailand
Travelbag (0870 737 7820 and www.travelbag.co.uk is giving an extra seven free nights at the luxurious Imperial Samui Hotel on Koh Samui to those who book seven nights B&B for the period between 16 September and 31 October. The hotel, near Chaweng town, overlooks a beach. Fourteen nights, including all flights, costs from £780 per person.

Egypt
Save over £100 per person on an escorted trip with The Imaginative Traveller (020 8742 8612) departing 27 August. The Nile Rover tour begins from Cairo. You will stop off in Luxor before cruising along the Nile to Aswan. The new price is £588, which includes return flights from Heathrow, internal transport and nine nights' accommodation.

Tenerife
Fourteen nights on the largest Canary Island is just £325 per person with Eclipse (08705 010203), based on two sharing two-star accommodation. The flight departs from Manchester on 22 August.

Tunisia
Wigmore Holidays (020 7836 4999) is offering a seven-night stay at the four-star Aziza Hotel in Hammamet for £536 per person. The price includes return flights from Heathrow, departing 1 September, transfers and half-board accommodation.

Canada
Throughout August there are public wolf howls in Algonquin Park, north of Toronto. There are about 25 packs in the park and they respond, vocally, to human imitations. There is no charge for attending but you may require a vehicle permit (£4). Book a one-week fly-drive package to Toronto with Canadian Affair (0870 075 3000) for £479, including car hire, taxes and insurance.

Barbados
A three-week self-catering holiday is available on Barbados for £709? The flight departs from Manchester on 20 August. For more details call Lunn Poly on 0870 333 4400 or drop into one of their shops.

Flights

Japan
Return flights to Tokyo with Air Nippon are £389 from 14 August to 30 September. There is a maximum stay of one month. Call Thomas Cook on 0870 752 0066.

Sales
GB Airways (0845 773 3377) is holding a sale on scheduled services between London and Spain, Portugal and Malta until 28 August. Prices range from £129 to £169 and travel must be completed by 27 October.

Or catch the last day of Ryanair's seat sale which ends tomorrow. Log on to www.ryanair.com and you might pick up a flight to Turin for £19.

fields.headline: Drinking by numbers
fields.standfirst: Scoring wines is all the rage, but one person's 97 is another's 79, so take your time and think for yourself
fields.trailText: Scoring wines is all the rage, but one person's 97 is another's 79, so take your time and think for yourself.
fields.body:
The world of wine is being colonised by numbers. I'm not talking about things like alcohol by volume or even price tags here, though both are increasingly important these days. No, sir, the numbers I have in mind are scores out of 100. Visit an American wine shop and the shelves are covered in figures: 92s, 93s and the occasional 95 or higher. You might find something with an 85 attached to it, but unless it's cheap, it will almost certainly be covered in dust.

Scores are the work of American wine critics, ex cathedra pronouncements from the spittoons of the Fourth Estate. To say that they can make or break a winery is an understatement. Put bluntly, wines that score well sell well, irrespective of what they taste like. Wines that score badly (and in a culture which values success, that means anything below 90 points) are bin ends waiting to happen.

There's nothing wrong with using a score to classify a wine. When I'm writing my own notes, I use a mark out of 20, with a baroque and highly personal series of pluses, minuses, question marks and acronyms. The problem starts when consumers take numbers too seriously - and, far worse, when they cease to believe the evidence of their own tastebuds. One of my favourite American cartoons shows a bloke tasting in a wine shop. 'This is repulsive,' he tells the guy behind the counter. 'It scored a 94,' comes the reply. 'OK, I'll take two cases,' says the consumer.

Scores, like tasting notes, are highly subjective. They are not scientific; more to the point, they are not repeatable. Even experienced wine tasters are inconsistent in their scoring. Something that gets an 88 today could easily notch up a 93 tomorrow. Wines change over time, and so do tasters. Mood and atmosphere can have a huge impact on our appreciation of a given bottle. Try sampling a range of tannic reds when you've got a hangover or it's a humid, muggy day, and you'll see what I mean.

Could scores catch on over here? Most British wine hacks prefer words to numbers, but wine merchants are starting to use American scores with worrying frequency. It's easy to see why - giving something a numerical rating makes it easier to classify, which is why scores are so popular with wine collectors and bottle strokers. 'My cellar contains nothing with a score below 90,' one such individual told me recently. Perhaps he's a friend of the man I saw dining in a top French restaurant openly checking the wine list against scores he'd stored in his palmtop computer.

I think we're missing the point here. A huge part of the pleasure of wine is its diversity and slippery subjectivity. We all enjoy different styles of wine and have different ways of describing them. As a journalist, I do my best to share my enthusiasms with you, but no one's forcing you to agree with them. In America, the implication is that if you don't like a high-scoring wine, there's something wrong with your palate.

Scores are a short cut, developed in a country where time is at a premium, and an expensive one at that. They eschew minor roads, country lanes and cul-de-sacs in favour of the five-lane motorway, where speed is an end in itself. You may not agree, but scores remind me of a man I once overheard in the Louvre. 'Where's the Mona Lisa ?' he asked a guide, with a breathless, 'I'm double-parked.'

fields.headline: Sweet talking
fields.standfirst: Baste a roast with it, drizzle it into tea or spread it on toast... it's easy to get stuck on honey
fields.trailText: Baste a roast with it, drizzle it into tea or spread it on toast... it's easy to get stuck on honey.
fields.body:
Honey is what you get when bees collect nectar from flowers and break it down with their spit. Something to think about next time you watch the golden syrup slowly dissolve into your herbal tea.

But it is also the ultimate luxury for the sweet of tooth - a fat pot of liquid gold with which to dip, drizzle and spread. Unlike jam or golden syrup, honey gets a nod of approval from the health police. Yet ask them to explain exactly why its sucrose, fructose and maltose are superior to the stuff in the sugar bowl, and their reasons rapidly descend into folklore. 'Honey is a natural antiseptic,' they cry, before flying away on their broomsticks.

The true magic of honey is not what it did for aficionado Barbara Cartland - who was prolifically penning romantic novels into her late nineties - but how it is made, a procedure surely worth a few moments of anyone's daydreams on a sunny afternoon. Watching a portly bumblebee at work in the lavender has always had me reaching, Pooh-like, for the honey pot. A pot that belongs to a time when the summers were longer, the world smelled of honeysuckle and toast, and honey was part of a Sunday garden tea rather than a snatched weekday breakfast wolfed on the run.

However much our lives have speeded up, honey still moves at its own leisurely pace, falling slowly from the spoon on to thick slices of toast, into heavy Greek yogurt or, sacrilegiously, on to porridge. (It will get a move on if you can be bothered to heat the spoon first.) I regard honey dippers, those bee-shaped wooden stirrers you get in your Christmas stocking, in much the same way I do any kitchen gadget - as just another thing I can live without. They are pretty pointless for the crystalline, glucose-laden lavender honeys I prefer.

The floral and herbal notes of the purest honey depend on which flowers' nectar the bees have been gathering. How beekeepers keep track of this is a mystery. I have visions of lone apiarists furtively following their swarm, peeping from behind trees, little black book in hand, recording every flower visited. The answer has much to do with where the hives are located and what flowers happen to be in season.

Over the years, I have sampled the floral notes from raspberry flower (imperceptible) and orange blossom (charming) to acacia (revered but nevertheless boring) and the mysterious rhododendron (you could have fooled me). The one scented with herbs from the garrigue - the short, woody brush that covers so much of southwestern France - is memorable for its deep, almost cough-linctus back notes. Those from lavender fields remain a great favourite, and not just for the cute picture of hives among the rows of mauve bushes. They all have their fans, though I have yet to finish a whole jar of any of them. You could almost measure my life in pots of unfinished honey.

As with Dairylea, roast beef and Dandelion & Burdock, my lust for honey is an occasional one. But it is unmistakably lust. What appeals is gouging the fudge-like, flower-scented paste from its pot and spreading it on thick slices of pale toast. It does not matter how generously I spread it, even the thinnest scraping is sweet enough to subdue the craving for a while. I have been known to set out especially to buy a jar or even two, a honey-fix if you like, but find that good though it is, one spoonful is always enough.

It is this sweetness that demands much thought from the cook once the romance of a new jar has faded and it is 'off to the kitchen' with it. Some balance is needed. Sadly, the herbal and floral notes present in raw honey fade once it is heated. Gentle warmth will bring the flavours to the surface; fierce heat will send them scuttling away. But you can cook with them effectively enough if you temper their shock of sweetness with lemon, vinegar or ginger, and remember that generosity is not always a good thing.

Honey is used chiefly with duck, in which case its sugar-coating is harnessed with the aniseed of star anise and the salt-shock of soy sauce; with chicken, where lemon, orange and ginger are included, and most successfully with pork. It seems strange that the sweetest of meats should benefit from the stickiest of preserves, but it does. The clue is to add a carefully judged squirt of acidity in the form of lemon or lime juice or white-wine vinegar. It does little for the meat itself, but wonders for the pan juices, which take on a deep, sweet savour and a burnished gloss.

The texture of honey depends, like the flavour, on where the bees collected their nectar. The higher the glucose content of the nectar, the thicker the honey. I find those varieties such as clover, some of the older, more granulated heather honey and the lavender varieties a particularly unctuous spread for toast or soft farmhouse white bread. This is the best way to pick up the discreet floral notes. Once you start cooking with the stuff, rather than simply spooning it from the jar, you might as well use whatever you have in the cupboard.

Tonight there will be honey for tea, and thick white doorsteps of the freshest imaginable bread. A rather old-fashioned tea, I know, but who cares when you get to eat nectar, pollen, royal jelly and the sugar of herbs and flowers? Oh, and that bit of bee spit.

Baked pork chops with mushrooms, lemon and honey

Savoury chops, a few mushrooms and some sweet herbal juices for a summer lunch. You may like to have a few fancy salad leaves washed and ready on the side. Serves 4, or 2 if you are very hungry.

4 pork steaks or spare-rib chops
a little mild olive oil
2 largish mushrooms
dried oregano
1 lemon
2 tbsp liquid honey

Put a large oval dish or small roasting tin over a moderately high flame and pour in just enough oil to cover the bottom. As the oil starts to simmer, add the pork chops, not moving them till their undersides are golden - a matter of a minute or two. Meanwhile, slice the mushrooms (not too thinly). Turn the chops over and colour the other side, then push them to the side of the pan and add the sliced mushrooms, turning them briefly in the pan juices. Lay the chops on top and turn off the heat.

Season the meat with salt, ground black pepper and several good pinches of oregano. You can, of course, use fresh oregano leaves, but the dried herb works exceptionally well in this instance. Squeeze over the lemon then add the spent shells to the dish. Drizzle over the honey, but no more than a couple of tablespoons' worth.

Bake the chops for 20 to 25 minutes at 200 C/gas mark 6, basting them once or twice as they cook. You will need some salad leaves on your plate to mop up the sweet, herbal juices.

Fig, orange and honey cake

A truly moist cake, crunchy with fig seeds and scented with honey. Serves 12.

200g ready-to-eat dried figs
225g butter, cool but not hard, cut into small chunks
225g golden caster sugar
100g plain flour
75g ground almonds
4 large eggs, beaten
the grated zest of an organic orange
the juice of 2 oranges
4 tbsp honey
2 tsp orange-blossom water
strained Greek yogurt to serve

You will also need a 21cm cake tin, the base lined with baking parchment.

Set the oven at 180 C/gas mark 4. Snip the hard stalks from the figs, then chop them coarsely. They need to be no larger than raisins. You can blitz them in the food processor if you wish.

Put the butter and sugar in a the bowl of an electric mixer and beat till fluffy and white, scraping down the sides of the bowl as you go. Mix the flour and almonds together.

Slowly beat the eggs into the butter and sugar, one at a time. Add a third of the almonds and flour, turn the mixer off, add another third and beat slowly and briefly, then add the final third, again mixing briefly. Too fast a mixing will make the cake heavy.

Fold in the chopped figs, the orange zest and juice of one orange, taking great care not to over-mix. Transfer the mixture to the lined cake tin, gently smoothing the top. Bake for about 45 minutes, till the top is golden and the cake is firm to the touch.

Melt the honey with the juice of the second orange and the orange-blossom water. Put the cake, still in its tin, on a plate, then spoon over the warm honey and orange. Leave to cool. Ideally the cake should be served slightly warm. Loosen the edges with a palette knife and remove the tin. Serve with the yogurt.

fields.headline: Derby Day
fields.standfirst: A little competition is no bad thing, Jay Rayner  discovers, as he ventures into the foodie  wilderness of Derby to sample the lunchtime  offerings of Darley's
fields.trailText: A little competition is no bad thing, Jay Rayner discovers, as he ventures into the foodie wilderness of Derby to sample the lunchtime offerings of Darley's.
fields.body:
If it wasn't for the existence of Darley's, the fine city of Derby would have much in common with the wastes of Antarctica: there would be nowhere to eat. Study the maps, and you will quickly see its splendid isolation. There is nothing else worthy of note for many miles in any direction. This barren territory does, I suppose, give the lie to the oft-reported claim that we are in the grip of a restaurant boom. Other parts of the realm may think that paying reasonable money for well-prepared food is now a good idea, but clearly, in Derby there's very few folk who hold with that sort of thing.

So we should, I think, give thanks for Darley's. It occupies an attractive site overlooking a weir on the tree-lined River Derwent to the north of the city, and is part of a development of a hulking, old Victorian mill. There has, in fact, been a restaurant on this site for over a decade, but Darley's has only been up and running for the past 16 months, as the management attempts to 'go for the rosettes', as the waiter put it.

Having tried it for a solo weekday lunch, I fear that the lack of competition in Derby does it no favours. One of the reasons there are a lot of good restaurants in London is that there are a lot of good restaurants in London. Put another way, chefs raise their game if they know the punters could be going elsewhere. The fine town of Ludlow in Shropshire has no particular reason for being of note where eating out is concerned, for example, but because Shaun Hill's Merchant House and Ken Adam's Oaks Restaurant are both there, other chefs have now crowded in and it has become something of a foodie mecca.

Darley's, meanwhile, has to 'go for the rosettes' without anything to judge itself by. That, at least, can be my only explanation for my rather lacklustre lunch. This is not to say that Darley's is a bad place. The service is very friendly and efficient, the room light and airy, and there is a dinner menu both reasonably priced and ambitious which promised an interesting busyness on the plate: 'Twice-baked goat's cheese soufflé, salad of grilled red peppers, tapanade and pistachio-nut vinaigrette' to start, for example (£6.90); 'Caramelised breast of Gressingham duck, Oriental vegetable spring roll, black cherry compote with Thai chilli dressing' as a main course (£17.50).

Three courses at lunch is good value at £14.50. To start, I chose grilled sardines with what was described as a 'vine tomato fondue', because doing grilled sardines well in a restaurant of some ambition is very difficult. The fondue was just a thick tomato sauce, and not a particularly distinguished one at that. As to the fish, it was a bit of a mistake to gut one and not the other; there's nothing wrong with an ungutted sardine as long as it's cooked properly. But a little consistency on the plate goes a long way.

My main course, honey-basted belly pork with celeriac purée, compote of figs, beans and crackling also displayed a similar lack of attention to detail. The crackling was perfect, the meat fine, but the celeriac purée was grossly over salted and the compote was an overly crude and lumpy affair, plonked on the plate with little thought for presentation. For pudding, the best part of the lunch, I went local and ordered the Bakewell tart with a raspberry coulis. It was more of a cake than a tart, the customary slick of jam replaced with crush of fresh raspberries, and all the jollier for that. Unfortunately, it was then let down by a truly dismal cup of insipid coffee.

I have no doubt that Darley's has a dedicated band of loyal fans. I'm sure you'll get in touch and tell me so - you usually do. And I also have no doubt that, when everything works, the grand promise of that dinner menu can deliver something very interesting. But at my lunch, it didn't work out that way. Frankly, when there's nothing else in town touting for this kind of trade, it seems a great opportunity wasted. It's a pity, is all.
fields.bodyText: If it wasn't for the existence of Darley's, the fine city of Derby would have much in common with the wastes of Antarctica: there would be nowhere to eat. Study the maps, and you will quickly see its splendid isolation. There is nothing else worthy of note for many miles in any direction. This barren territory does, I suppose, give the lie to the oft-reported claim that we are in the grip of a restaurant boom. Other parts of the realm may think that paying reasonable money for well-prepared food is now a good idea, but clearly, in Derby there's very few folk who hold with that sort of thing. So we should, I think, give thanks for Darley's. It occupies an attractive site overlooking a weir on the tree-lined River Derwent to the north of the city, and is part of a development of a hulking, old Victorian mill. One of the reasons there are a lot of good restaurants in London is that there are a lot of good restaurants in London. webTitle: Observer review: Kitchen Confidential by Anthony Bourdain

fields.headline: Escoffier on speed
fields.standfirst:
Take one New York chef, add drugs, brandy and blood and you have a cooking classic. Jay Rayner on Anthony Bourdain's recipe for a good read, Kitchen Confidential
Read an extract
fields.trailText:
Take one New York chef, add drugs, brandy and blood and you have a cooking classic. Jay Rayner on Anthony Bourdain's recipe for a good read, Kitchen Confidential
Read an extract
fields.body:
Kitchen Confidential
Anthony Bourdain
Bloomsbury £16.99, pp307
Buy it at BOL

The best writing about food, the stuff that makes the juices run even as the eyes read, are dispatches from the front line of the battle for pleasure. Anthony Bourdain, 25 years a New York chef, has been a soldier in that battle all his blood-stained, sweat-sodden working life and this coruscating account of his years in combat stinks of it.

The military metaphors are his, not mine. They lurk not just in the language of 'crews' or 'brigades' that he forms about him in his kitchens, but in the total approach to the life that the working chef must lead. Hell, these boys are even armed, with serious lengths of thrice-sharpened steel.

In one sequence, Bourdain describes how he and his sous-chefs, strung out on a rich stew of dope, amphetamines and overwork, would re-enact the opening sequences of the movie Apocalypse Now as an overture to the evening service. As a finale, they would recreate the napalm blast by emptying half a pint of brandy over the range so that it would ignite, sending a sheet of flame powering through the kitchen. They were, he says, happy days. Eventually, the restaurant went bust.

Most of the restaurants where Bourdain served went bust. It is that litany of failure which distinguishes this book. Although he is now an established figure in New York, executive chef at Brasserie Les Halles, a faux French joint serving up brasserie staples, for most of his career he was just a jobbing guy with his knives and his moves and his tricks with demi-glace who tumbled from kitchen to kitchen, rubbing shoulders as often with the Mob as with the suburban dentists turned ill-fated restaurateurs, on a picaresque adventure to put Don Quixote to shame. He was never one of the generals with his daytime TV slot and his name stitched carefully across the breast of his whites. Mind you, the heroin addiction probably had something to do with that.

But what really makes Bourdain's writing sing is his complete understanding that food is not a subject for aesthetes. It's a belly thing, not a head thing. From his very first meeting with 'stinky runny cheeses that smelled like a dead man's feet' or his first oyster ('this glistening, vaguely sexual-looking object, still dripping and nearly alive') both while in France with his parents aged just nine, he grasped the true sensuousness of food and eating.

The result is an obsession with prime ingredients without any of the tiresome reverence that too often follows on behind. Sometimes, that lack of reverence tumbles into a curious kind of disdain and the book becomes less an education than a warning. It began life as an article in the New Yorker entitled 'Don't Eat Before Reading This', which explained why you should never order fish on Mondays (it's been hanging around since the previous Friday) and why mussels are a terrible dish to order in restaurants ('mussels are allowed to wallow in their own foul-smelling piss in the bottom of a reach-in').

Kitchen Confidential takes it all much further. There are extraordinary accounts of the cooking practices at an esteemed New York restaurant where the chateaubriand would be chucked in the deep-fat fryer to give it a good crust or steaks would be cooked off an hour ahead of time and then reintroduced to heat courtesy of a slick of sauce thrown over them just before service. It also seems you can never be sure which animal provided the juices on your plate; in another manic kitchen overseen by Bourdain, the crew decided that cuts incurred during service were such a badge of honour that they should spray as much of the resulting blood across each other as possible. Can you be sure none of that ended up on your plate? Can you really?

For my part, it has made me realise that any respect I had for this newspaper's war correspondents has been entirely misplaced. They are not the ones taking risks with their lives in pursuit of truth. It's me, the restaurant critic. I want danger money and I want it now. It also seems that we should give thanks for fashion; the explosion in the number of restaurants with their kitchens open to the dining-room, so that the punters may watch the dramas, may actually end up saving lives.

Kitchen Confidential does have its faults. There are long meditations on the state of the New York restaurant business which will make about as much sense to British readers as an Arabic menu. And there is some unnecessary material here on the stand-up guys he has known which, like toasted pine nuts added to a Caesar salad, don't improve the dish any.

But this is to quibble. There are also extraordinary passages here, written with a clarity and a clear-eyed wit to put the professional food writing fraternity to shame. His account of a day in the life of a chef is a tour de force. (The moral of the story: never trust a fat chef; they just aren't working hard enough.) In short, Bourdain has written a bouillabaisse of a book. Which is to say it's a classic, and a ripe one at that. There are very few books which all professional cooks should read but this is one. To Escoffier and Larousse may now be added the name Bourdain.

fields.headline: Play ground
fields.standfirst: Immaculate flowerbeds and lawns and rampaging children don't go hand in hand - but nothing brings a garden to life so much as noisy games and lots of laughter
fields.trailText: Immaculate flowerbeds and lawns and rampaging children don't go hand in hand - but nothing brings a garden to life so much as noisy games and lots of laughter.
fields.body:
The Bang has a spring in it. It builds to an echoing climax and then is thrown up into the air. Whoosh, Ka-bang, bo-ing. Then, as the sound lands, a resounding thump. For two teenage boys this is a good noise, a sound rich with all the corollaries of pleasure. For the two adults weeding over the wall it is almost torture, almost an invasion, almost bloody intolerable. But not quite. It shatters the peace that the garden so carefully laces around itself and is an assault of a kind - but one thing saves it. After each elastic, clattering crash is a whoop of laughter. That raucous, pubescent addition to the general row clears and legitimises everything else. Adam and Josh are having fun.

I got a nice letter today from a reader of this column asking me to drop by and see the letter-writer's garden, asking me to bring the children, too 'as it is a great place for playing hide and seek'. While it is a charming image (and invitation) it presupposes that my children are locked between the ages of about four and eight. The truth is that gardens are dangerous places for unsupervised toddlers and dead boring for any child over seven. Popular garden lore can accommodate toddlers and young children, and there are a number of books that explore all the delightful ways that small children can enjoy your garden. However, there is always a subtext to these books - children enjoying the garden without trashing it too badly. But trashing things is inevitable, if you are having the right kind of fun. Football and cricket ruin lawns, flowerbeds and greenhouses. (This summer Adam hit a cricket ball through the open door of the greenhouse; it bounced once on the path, miraculously went through an open window and out the other side - straight on to a pile of spare panes resting against the fence. Six sheets of glass, smashed.)

Treehouses are most fun with six-inch nails, scaffolding planks, rope and plenty of branches sawn off to fit them in and get a good view. Bicycles make good muddy ruts in paths and, anyway, seem to spend most of their lives thrown down on the ground blocking a doorway.

My children are all heavily into blading (or is it skates - the wrong terminology in front of their friends is met with eye-rolling contempt). Hence the half-pipe, which consists of three pieces of 8ft by 4ft marine ply coaxed into curves to make an enormous ramped semicircle so they can swoop down one side, up the other, jump and twist in mid-air and either whizz back down again or fall tumbling on to their backsides. It is brilliant and took the two boys a whole afternoon to make. A variety of tools were used, and the principal ingredient, other than the ply, assorted blocks of wood, concrete blocks, four milk crates, all my nails and a mysterious quantity of rope, is the courtyard garden. This is a minimalist area, refined to an exquisite harmony in stone and wood, the yard paved in York stone, the walls of ancient red sandstone and a square of river-washed pebbles in the centre. Around the perimeter are nine cubes of green oak, now weathering into a silvery-cracked maturity. It is the children's best bit of the garden at the moment, because it is brilliant for blading. Unfortunately, the half-pipe means blocking the only entrance to the walled garden, which is where we eat whenever we can in summer.

The walled garden was completely revamped last year for the children. They wanted a lawn near the house. Sarah and I wanted a hard surface near the house. There was a huge open space down the end of the garden, but children like to be near. They like popping in and out. They like the garden as an extension of their bedrooms, and after a day at home the two look pretty similar. So we cleared the four big borders, moving them to the perimeter, and made a lawn in the centre. The trampoline sits in the middle of that patch of grass.

Trampolines are just another piece of the affluent family's kit nowadays. Boasting about having a trampoline is dead uncool, and I'm the only one in our household who does it. But the children use it all the time. From the landing window, I can watch my lovely daughter Freya, 12, leaping and flying, headphones on, crazy auburn corkscrew hair shooting out, eyes closed as she dances to the rhythm of her CD Walkman. Actually it is mine and was a birthday present, but she has nabbed it. Nine-year-old Tom goes and jumps when he is angry, and it soothes him. Adam and his friends, Josh and George, all 14, fight and laugh and swear in that hoarse, shouty way 14-year-olds do, like boisterous, awkward cubs. The funny thing is that Sarah and I ignore the trampoline - which totally dominates the space - in the same way that they ignore the subtleties of the planting - all pastels and whites - around their leaping selves. We accommodate each other's needs by pretending that they are temporary.

And, of course, on every level, they are. The children grow as fast as the garden, and they change their demands from the garden almost daily. Certainly by the time you have established any kind of set-up for them, they have moved on to something else. What children beyond the hide-and-seek age want is a kind of loosely equipped playground with enough familiarity so that they can loaf comfortably, but with enough novelty to make the world up afresh as the spirit takes them.

Horticulture doesn't come into it. My daughter made a garden this year and did it carefully and well. But once made - which took her perhaps three sessions of an hour spread over a week - it was forgotten. Everything was in the doing of it. In fact, it has thrived and her sweet peas are every bit as good as ours, despite total neglect. Tom periodically makes camps and treehouses but his are all essentially hiding places. One was elaborately dug out and then camouflaged to look like a stack of brashings (sweet that he does not think I know every stick and leaf of this garden) and he has a series of flowerpots sunk in the ground, covered over with a tile and then hidden by soil. They each contain an emblematic piece of him, like a key or a sweet. He roams this garden like a member of the Resistance, seemingly compliant to its strict regulations and adult, horticultural tyranny, but really possessing it as fully as anyone.

And there is his shed. This is strictly private and entrance is by invitation only. There are a series of notices to that effect, the latest of which reads: 'BUGER OF, I LIVE HEAR' - he's not so hot on spelling, our Tom, but he has other skills. His shed is a serious workshop and much more highly sophisticated than anything I possess or am able to employ.

At the age of nine, he can make almost anything that he sets his mind to, copying things seen on television or in magazines, or making up inventions. He makes things all day. Nothing is more admirable. Yet his mess spreads like a dervish workshop ripple from his shed to the farthest reaches of the garden, with saws, power drills, hammers, endless bits of wood, plastic, metal and string put down and abandoned wherever the fancy has taken him. And he bangs an awful lot. Boys in the garden always equal noise. Tom seems to foray out from his shed with the tools of the moment and to work wherever the action is. This is not just limited to the garden but has now ventured quietly out into cyberspace. I got a bill the other day for a domain name registered as www.tomshed.com that he had set up entirely on his own. I think perhaps that tomshed.com is the most accurate metaphor for a growing child's garden - a mental space of limitless imagination founded on the comfort of an actual, utterly safe haven.

Inevitably, the real garden with a growing family of children will be untidy, messy even, noisy and often destructive. It drives arch control-freaks like myself mad. But I hate it when they are not there.

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

All change. All the broad beans and peas are up and on the compost heap, and purple kale, red cabbage, purple sprouts and purple-sprouting broccoli have replaced them. You may notice a theme. The idea is that the winter is fundamentally a brown and grey place here, and while green is good and to be encouraged, purple is better. It also seems to make the green greener while diminishing the brown. So the greener brassicas - calabrese, savoys, cavolo nero - have all been planted out up the top end of the garden where the garlic was.

Garlic is good for the soil and most things thrive that follow it on a piece of ground, so this is hardly relegation for the green greens. I did not dig the ground after the garlic was lifted, but simply raked it over and trowelled a hole for each plant, which had been grown in a 3in pot, so that it is a fair-sized plant before the slugs can get at it. I don't believe in no-dig gardening, except as a labour-saving scheme, but brassicas like firm soil so that their roots anchor strongly. It will be interesting to see if this laissez-faire method makes them able to withstand wind better than their purple counterparts in the more pampered vegetable garden.

The garlic is a fabulous crop this year. I sowed 'Cledar' in November and 'Printnor' a month later on heavy ground lightened only with mushroom compost. While I do not think of this soil or climate as being good for garlic, I know that it is perfect for parsley and have never failed to have masses of flat-leaf all year round. This year, for a reason I have not yet established, all three sowings of parsley are looking poorly, with orange, feeble leaves and weak root-growth. Although it has been rather dry, I think the cause of this might be a fungal infection.

Talking of dry, everything could do with a good soak. We do not water much because we do not have the time or irrigation system, but I always know what things are beginning to suffer when the Acanthus spinosus starts to flop dangerously. But the plant that suffers the most from dry weather is the Gunnera manicata that I planted last spring. I lined its (large) planting hole with an old butyl liner, and added masses of compost to hold moisture, but it only gets wet when the garden floods or when I leave the hose on it. However, it has amazing powers of recovery after a long bath.
