There are a series of notices to that effect, the latest of which reads: 'BUGER OF, I LIVE HEAR' - he's not so hot on spelling, our Tom, but he has other skills. His shed is a serious workshop and much more highly sophisticated than anything I possess or am able to employ. At the age of nine, he can make almost anything that he sets his mind to, copying things seen on television or in magazines, or making up inventions. He makes things all day. Nothing is more admirable. Yet his mess spreads like a dervish workshop ripple from his shed to the farthest reaches of the garden, with saws, power drills, hammers, endless bits of wood, plastic, metal and string put down and abandoned wherever the fancy has taken him. And he bangs an awful lot. Boys in the garden always equal noise. Tom seems to foray out from his shed with the tools of the moment and to work wherever the action is. This is not just limited to the garden but has now ventured quietly out into cyberspace. I got a bill the other day for a domain name registered as www.tomshed.com that he had set up entirely on his own. I think perhaps that tomshed.com is the most accurate metaphor for a growing child's garden - a mental space of limitless imagination founded on the comfort of an actual, utterly safe haven. Inevitably, the real garden with a growing family of children will be untidy, messy even, noisy and often destructive. It drives arch control-freaks like myself mad. But I hate it when they are not there. My roots: A week in Monty's garden All change. All the broad beans and peas are up and on the compost heap, and purple kale, red cabbage, purple sprouts and purple-sprouting broccoli have replaced them. You may notice a theme. The idea is that the winter is fundamentally a brown and grey place here, and while green is good and to be encouraged, purple is better. It also seems to make the green greener while diminishing the brown. So the greener brassicas - calabrese, savoys, cavolo nero - have all been planted out up the top end of the garden where the garlic was. Garlic is good for the soil and most things thrive that follow it on a piece of ground, so this is hardly relegation for the green greens. I did not dig the ground after the garlic was lifted, but simply raked it over and trowelled a hole for each plant, which had been grown in a 3in pot, so that it is a fair-sized plant before the slugs can get at it. I don't believe in no-dig gardening, except as a labour-saving scheme, but brassicas like firm soil so that their roots anchor strongly. It will be interesting to see if this laissez-faire method makes them able to withstand wind better than their purple counterparts in the more pampered vegetable garden. The garlic is a fabulous crop this year. I sowed 'Cledar' in November and 'Printnor' a month later on heavy ground lightened only with mushroom compost. While I do not think of this soil or climate as being good for garlic, I know that it is perfect for parsley and have never failed to have masses of flat-leaf all year round. This year, for a reason I have not yet established, all three sowings of parsley are looking poorly, with orange, feeble leaves and weak root-growth. Although it has been rather dry, I think the cause of this might be a fungal infection. Talking of dry, everything could do with a good soak. We do not water much because we do not have the time or irrigation system, but I always know what things are beginning to suffer when the Acanthus spinosus starts to flop dangerously. But the plant that suffers the most from dry weather is the Gunnera manicata that I planted last spring. I lined its (large) planting hole with an old butyl liner, and added masses of compost to hold moisture, but it only gets wet when the garden floods or when I leave the hose on it. However, it has amazing powers of recovery after a long bath.

webTitle: Clearing 2000: What you really, really want to do

fields.headline: What you really, really want to do
fields.standfirst: Media studies or pure maths? Find something you enjoy and don't get hung up on finding the right vocational course
fields.trailText: Media studies or pure maths? Find something you enjoy and don't get hung up on finding the right vocational course
fields.body:
'It isn't about filling a bucket; it's about lighting a fire!' So goes the advice given to undergraduate students choosing their subjects at Miami University, Ohio.

The advice given to students selecting a degree course on this side of the Atlantic may be less colourful, but it still carries the same message. Universities, careers advisers and employers agree that students should choose a subject they enjoy.

Students should ignore advice to go for a subject that promises a job in a sexy part of the economy, such as IT, or one thought to involve watching lots of daytime TV, such as media studies.

At the very least studying a subject you find boring is unlikely to lead to academic glory. At most it could mean subjecting yourself to three years of misery.

Keith Hicks, communications manager for the University of the West of England, says the university has found it vital for students to study a subject that matches their ambitions. He says that students who who do not are much more likely to drop out.

To address this problem the University set up a programme in collaboration with Ucas to produce a profile of individual courses to help students choose.

This 'course profile' gives students details about jobs former graduates of the course are doing and the skills the course will require of an individual student. It is meant to be a kind of course CV. Hicks says: 'Those studying more vocational courses such as education, computer studies or media studies tend to be more typecast in the kinds of jobs which they go on to after graduation.' They should therefore be very sure about their ultimate career ambitions. 'Non-vocational courses are better for people wanting to keep their options open.'

Carl Gilleard, chief executive of the Association of Graduate Recruiters, represents employers who recruit between 20 and 30 thousand graduates each year across all sectors of the economy. In his view it is necessary to look much further than the choice of subject when considering how best to secure a graduate job. He says: 'It's not enough just to go to university and end up with a degree'. Students, he says, 'need to take control of their career and take advantage of opportunities to develop new skills.'

Employers are looking for difficult-to-define skills such as the ability to work with colleagues, to express yourself clearly - and the self confidence to follow a job through to completion. Gilleard says that while at university, students should take part-time or voluntary work to build their self-confidence and demonstrate their abilities to future employers.

Anne Lindsey, from the Learning and Skills Group of employers' organisation The Confederation of British Industry (CBI), says: 'Students should go to university knowing what they want to get out of their time in terms of personal development and improving their employability.' She believes that employers look for, 'intellectual, communication, interpersonal and specialist knowledge'. All the other skills can be gained from academic study of any subject and, importantly, from experiences beyond the curriculum.

Lindsey says students must nowadays, 'think early about how to improve employability and take advantage of the careers services at their university early on in their course'. Already, according to a study by the Department for Education and Employment, 41 per cent of all students now do some form of work experience during their degree.

Work experience is often a part of the curriculum in vocational degrees, through 'sandwich courses', where students work for a time in industry during their studies.

However the view of the CBI is that all students need to be getting work experience. Even those students studying non-vocational subjects such as English should be looking to improve their mix of skills through extra-curricular activities during their time at university.

The requirements of employers are greater than ever, and a student can't meet them any longer simply by doing well in their degree. Many graduates, those who did media courses for example, have already found that there are a very limited number of jobs being chased by a large number of graduates.

Graduates from non-vocational courses are competing with them for the same jobs. In the media, as in many other areas, getting the perfect job on graduation depends on a lot more than getting on to the right course.

The growth in the number of vocational degrees and places available on these courses has continued throughout the Nineties, and shows no sign of ending.

There are now more places available to study business as an undergraduate (41,000) does than there are to study physical or biological science (37,000).

This growth is partly driven by the appetite of business for more and more graduates qualified in booming sectors such as IT and electrical engineering. It is also a response to the demand from students for new kinds of courses.

Among many students there is a misconception that vocational courses offer the best employment opportunities after graduation. However when applying for the majority of graduate jobs the degree subject is irrelevant. What is important to an employer is simply that the candidate has a degree, which demonstrates their sound intellect.

Unwelcome as it may sound to those who believe their place on a media studies, or other vocational course, will guarantee them a job, there are plenty of hurdles to clear before the first pay cheque.

Conversely, for those who fancied a media studies course and have ended up in clearing, expecting to study English or other traditional courses, the chance of getting that dream job may be better than you thought.

The writer of this article studied politics at university, qualified as a lawyer and decided to become a journalist only after working for several years. I dread to think of all the vocational knowledge, which poured into my brain never to be seen again. My advice is not to worry.

Remember everyone's fire gets lit eventually. Take your time and work out what it is you really want to do, and then get going.

webTitle: Clearing 2000: higher education and higher income

fields.headline: Weighing up the benefits by degrees
fields.standfirst: A higher education can ensure a higher income later in life
fields.trailText: A higher education can ensure a higher income later in life
fields.body:
This is a tense time for students who have just taken their A Levels (or equivalents) - and, indeed, for their parents. Those who have conditional offers for university or other higher education courses know what grades they have to make. Depending on those results, different career paths and lifetime opportunities would appear to open up - or, if the grades aren't good enough, be closed down.

But will going to university increase your future earning capacity? Given the considerable financial costs of going through three or more years of higher education, it is well worth looking beyond the immediate hurdle to see whether there are other ways to get what you want out of life and to glean some idea of what you might be earning four or five years out.

A survey conducted by the economics department at the University of Warwick looked at the earnings of nearly 45,000 students who graduated in 1993 from traditional universities (not former polytechnics) and went more or less straight into employment. After six months, average earnings for men were £464 a week, while the average for women graduates was considerably lower, at £347 a week. This was in line with most earlier research, which showed male graduates earning salaries 17 per cent higher than those of men who did not attend university or did not complete their degrees. The differential for women was even more pronounced, with a 37 per cent premium over non-graduates.

But that data goes back to 1993 - before the internet and the 'New Economy' took off. Nor does it include graduates from any of the 'modern' universities. Taking a longer viewpoint, the differential between graduates and non-graduates tends to increase with age. All the research confirms that university graduates do earn more in the long run. Richard Pearson, director of the Brighton-based Institute of Employment Studies (IES), uses a 'rate of return analysis' to show that, on average, graduates earn 60 per cent more over a working life.

'But that,' he notes, 'is historical data based on final salaries before retirement. It's looking back into the twentieth century, not forward to the twentyfirst.' What the Warwick research does underline is that it makes a big difference what kind of degree you get. A first-class degree holder will earn about 12 per cent more than a person who gets a third. It also found considerable differences between subjects studied. At the older universities, law and politics students found jobs paying roughly 20 per cent above average, while those studying the humanities or agriculture were paid well below the median salary.

But again, these results are achieved by analysing historical data and extrapolating forward. They are also based on the graduates' first jobs. Those taking time out are not represented, while those who took a temporary and fairly low-paid job before deciding on their career may depress the averages.

Yet another approach was applied in a recent study conducted by the Higher Education Career Services Unit (CSU), using data from the Labour Force Survey to see how graduate earnings compared with those of non-graduates. Based on a random sample of British households conducted in 1998, the research shows that, on average, graduates earn over 60 per cent more than non-graduates. The pay gap among the 20-24 age group was 31 per cent; by the late thirties it was 60 per cent; and graduates in their late forties were earning 76 per cent more. It also found that the earnings gap between female graduates and non-graduates was consistently higher than for males.

So most significant consideration for those thinking of taking a university degree is not the salary level of their first job after graduating, but what happens thereafter. For their earnings rise much more sharply as their career 'takes off' between the ages of 25 and 35. Above the age of 40 average earnings level out or even drop off - maybe because the older respondents were working fewer hours or taking on different roles. But the graduates tend to 'plateau' at a much higher level and retain their peak earnings later in life.

Another CSU report, entitled 'Moving On' tracked the early career paths of people who graduated in 1995, including those from the new universities. Again, the choice of subject was critical, with those qualifying in medicine, maths and computing, engineering and business studies earning more than £20,000, while those who had studied arts or humanities earned on average £17,000 or less. The demand for good graduates has been booming in recent years. The demand is most fierce at the 'high-flyer' end of the spectrum, with big recruiters such as multi-nationals, the City and financial services companies still unable to find what they need. At the IES, Richard Pearson notes: 'Despite their recurrent difficulties, the major recruiters have not markedly raised graduate starting salaries. While last year a few paid in excess of £25,000, many jobs are advertised at £10-12,000. Changes to the median starting salary (£17,500 in 1999) largely track the rise in national earnings'. For those who are certain to get into the university and course of their choice, the answer as to whether it's worth it is straightforward. On average graduates do earn more, and continue to do so throughout their working lives.

But that is on average. Different individuals have different skills and aptitudes. The decision is most difficult for those who haven't got on to the course they wanted, or who are unsure whether they'll graduate. The experience of going to university may be worthwhile in itself, but the financial bonuses normally kick in only if you get the qualification.

The UK has one of the lowest student drop-out rates in the world. In 1995-6 only 18 per cent did not complete their higher education course; this compares with 28 per cent in Germany, 37 per cent in the US and 66 per cent in Italy. And as for the likelihood of being in a job three years after graduation, 94 per cent of British students manage that, as against 86 per cent of French graduates and 68 per cent in Italy.

Work out what the total cost of your degree will be, factor in all the variables, such as dropping out or not finding a job, and then make an estimate of what your lifetime earnings might be. The result would be a basic risk/reward ratio. But the law of averages will always work out that it is worth taking that risk and making the personal investment of taking that university place.

fields.headline: Invest for three precious years
fields.standfirst: It's a wise parent who plans ahead
fields.trailText: It's a wise parent who plans ahead
fields.body:
Wealthy parents can send their prodigies to college with an allowance large enough to maintain the state of comfort, if not cleanliness, they enjoyed at home, and with a flash car that ensures they will always have friends. Most parents cannot. Instead they are consoled by believing that it is no bad thing for youngsters to struggle a bit financially.

Part of a university education is realising the cost of electricity, the effect of demand over supply in the student housing market, and calculating how many takeaways you can afford on one term's allowance. But nothing stops parents worrying when a child first leaves home and many parents scrape together as much as they can, knowing that students whose life is restricted to study and sleep also waste the experience of university.

Parents have already learned that, if your children go to university, it is going to cost you money - around £18,000 for a three-year course outside London, and £22,000 in London. You have to pay at least the means-tested parental contribution but can add however much you want for holidays, travel, sports and a student social life. Further education costs are cheapest if your child attends a university near home because it cuts out rent, food, and coach or train fares back. Most kids ignore the expense and take the opportunity to leave the family nest.

Immediately they are tempted to borrow money. The student loan has replaced maintenance grants, and banks readily lend to students. As a result, graduates now leave university more than £5,000, and sometimes £10,000, in debt, which can take years to repay. Add this to your calculations if you want your child to graduate debt-free.

Ian Millward, investment marketing manager at financial adviser Chase de Vere, explains the benefit of starting to save for this expense early: 'The first pound in is the most valuable, because it has longer to grow: so the sooner you start saving, the less it will cost.' Not all parents have the chance to start saving ahead of the event: many simply have no money to spare while the children are young. Parents worrying where they are going to find the money for this October have limited options.

You can pay out of current income, which is difficult even if you cancel all holidays. Grandparents may help. Or you can make the child work through college. You could sell investments - but please do not sell life insurance policies. If life insurance is your only source of money, try borrowing against the policy but remember that, if you die before repaying the loan, the debt is deducted from the payout to your dependants. You can borrow from other sources. Overdrafts are a bad idea because they are not intended for long-term debt. Personal loans are possible but expensive. Instead, negotiate with your mortgage provider, or find one that has remortgage scheme, allowing you to use the equity in your home. As a last resort, you could move to a cheaper property.

An increasingly popular idea is buying a house for the student to live in. Not only does this avoid paying rent, but the student earns money from taking in lodgers. The property market has gone off the boil recently, so you may not make a capital gain after three years - but you could continue renting to other students. You face capital gains tax if you do make a profit when you sell.

For parents who are planning ahead, saving for university fees is the same as saving for any event happening on a known date. You can earmark a lump sum if you have money to spare, or you can start a regular savings scheme. You choose the type that is most appropriate to the length of time left before you will need the money. And the less time there is, the less risk you should take. When there is less than five years to go, keep your savings safe, in a bank or building society deposit account, mini cash Isa or National Savings product. Look for the highest rate of interest.

If you have 10 years in hand, you should go for safe unit trusts or investment trusts. You can hold these in your own name, or designate the investment with your child's name so the money is taxed as the child's and not yours. Unless children have investments or earnings totalling more than the personal tax allowance (£4,385 this year), you can avoid tax.

But choose funds that concentrate on capital growth rather than income because, once the income on money you give your child exceeds £100 a year, the Inland Revenue taxes it as yours again. Zero-dividend preference shares, a type of investment trust, are a possibil ity according to Millward: 'Zeros produce a set amount on a set date, but finding zeros to match what you are looking to do is not always easy.' You can put the investment in an Isa in your own name to avoid tax.

Parents with plenty of time can put money into riskier unit trusts or investment trusts, although you should still keep some money in a comparatively safe investment. 'Time is on your side, so you can take more chances, which should give you better returns, which should mean you need to save less,' says Millward.

Friendly society savings plans are tax-free and take a maximum £25 a month. You are locked in for 10 years, but it is a relatively small premium. Be wary of wrap-up school-fee and university schemes. Millward warns: 'They tend to be just wrapped around a series of endowments that run at different maturity dates. They are normal lump-sum investments, as you might buy for a retirement or wedding, that someone has chosen to badge for university fees. With any endowment, you are locked in - and they are inflexible.'

Ian Millward, investment marketing manager at financial adviser Chase de Vere, explains the benefit of starting to save for this expense early: 'The first pound in is the most valuable, because it has longer to grow: so the sooner you start saving, the less it will cost.' Not all parents have the chance to start saving ahead of the event: many simply have no money to spare while the children are young. Parents worrying where they are going to find the money for this October have limited options. You can pay out of current income, which is difficult even if you cancel all holidays. Grandparents may help. Or you can make the child work through college. You could sell investments - but please do not sell life insurance policies. If life insurance is your only source of money, try borrowing against the policy but remember that, if you die before repaying the loan, the debt is deducted from the payout to your dependants. You can borrow from other sources. Overdrafts are a bad idea because they are not intended for long-term debt. Personal loans are possible but expensive. Instead, negotiate with your mortgage provider, or find one that has remortgage scheme, allowing you to use the equity in your home. As a last resort, you could move to a cheaper property. An increasingly popular idea is buying a house for the student to live in. Not only does this avoid paying rent, but the student earns money from taking in lodgers. The property market has gone off the boil recently, so you may not make a capital gain after three years - but you could continue renting to other students. You face capital gains tax if you do make a profit when you sell. For parents who are planning ahead, saving for university fees is the same as saving for any event happening on a known date. You can earmark a lump sum if you have money to spare, or you can start a regular savings scheme. You choose the type that is most appropriate to the length of time left before you will need the money. And the less time there is, the less risk you should take. When there is less than five years to go, keep your savings safe, in a bank or building society deposit account, mini cash Isa or National Savings product. Look for the highest rate of interest. If you have 10 years in hand, you should go for safe unit trusts or investment trusts. You can hold these in your own name, or designate the investment with your child's name so the money is taxed as the child's and not yours. Unless children have investments or earnings totalling more than the personal tax allowance (£4,385 this year), you can avoid tax. But choose funds that concentrate on capital growth rather than income because, once the income on money you give your child exceeds £100 a year, the Inland Revenue taxes it as yours again. Zero-dividend preference shares, a type of investment trust, are a possibil ity according to Millward: 'Zeros produce a set amount on a set date, but finding zeros to match what you are looking to do is not always easy.' You can put the investment in an Isa in your own name to avoid tax. Parents with plenty of time can put money into riskier unit trusts or investment trusts, although you should still keep some money in a comparatively safe investment. 'Time is on your side, so you can take more chances, which should give you better returns, which should mean you need to save less,' says Millward. Friendly society savings plans are tax-free and take a maximum £25 a month. You are locked in for 10 years, but it is a relatively small premium. Be wary of wrap-up school-fee and university schemes. Millward warns: 'They tend to be just wrapped around a series of endowments that run at different maturity dates. They are normal lump-sum investments, as you might buy for a retirement or wedding, that someone has chosen to badge for university fees. With any endowment, you are locked in - and they are inflexible.'

fields.headline: Into the vortex...
fields.standfirst: The clearing system is more than just a safety net for those who fail to get the grades they need. Plan carefully and you won't get tangled
fields.trailText: Behind the hype of the Government's campaign to widen access and achieve greater equality by breaking the stranglehold that Oxford, Cambridge and the independent schools have had on prestigious areas of university education, real change is happening.
fields.body:
Behind the hype of the Government's campaign to widen access and achieve greater equality by breaking the stranglehold that Oxford, Cambridge and the independent schools have had on prestigious areas of university education, real change is happening.

Clearing, the system run by Ucas (Universities and Colleges Admissions Service) to provide an opportunity for those who have failed to achieve their hoped-for A-level grades, should not be seen as 'scraping the barrel', as Richard Claas, director of studies at King's College, London University, recently put it.

Rather it is an increasingly vital stage of the admissions process at which universities, the National Union of Students (NUS) and schools all agree. It is an essential mechanism for would-be undergraduates to make well informed personal decisions. Careful choices during clearing mean fewer mistakes - and fewer traumatic drop-outs.

The top-of-the-tables universities all allow themselves some slack so as to be able during clearing to take candidates who have achieved better-than-expected grades. Universities, gaining their funding on per capita estimates of numbers, play a balancing act over admissions. Too many students can be as expensive as too few. But all like to keep the freedom to take the high-fliers who emerge on results day.

Each year there are prestigious academic courses that have vacancies. Each year the slack is in different subjects or different universities as institutions drop down the popularity scale for no apparent reason. Five years ago the slack might have been in computer sciences; this year it is the environmental sciences that are less popular.

This year there will be vacancies in subjects across the board and in universities that include those in the Russell Group (the top 20 degree-giving institutions) where students may well need three A grades - or certainly a mixture of As and Bs - to be considered for most courses. And it is worth noting that no university can hoist its haughty skirt out of clearing system.

The increasing importance of clearing is part of a change that will, many believe, mean that within a relatively short time, Britain will move to a post-A-level qualification system for university application, rather than the complex pre-qualification application and then post-qualification clearing system that exists currently.

It is also part of a trend that means university access is, however slowly and unevenly, being extended across the socio-economic board.

All universities have programmes to identify and recruit students from non-traditional areas and backgrounds. What is causing concern is that there are some signs that students from working-class backgrounds choose, for economic reasons, to go to local universities.

However, Ucas has also identified a trend among middle-class students towards living at home and taking degrees at their local universities, a trend being driven by the increased cost to families of a university educations; thanks to the student loan system and the introduction last year of academic fees.

Ucas does attempt to ensure that students getting better-than-expected grades accept offers that they were already holding. But most university admissions tutors accept that it is not possible to insist that a student who has achieved, say, three As to accept a place based on an estimate of, say, three Bs.

No one will officially encourage students to trade up, but most will acknowledge privately that, if students approach the university to which they have committed and seek to break the contract and go back into clearing in search of a preferable place, it can be done.

No university sees any real benefit in holding on to a student who will be dissatisfied and therefore may well be more likely to join the much worried about annual number of dropouts.

King's College, one of Britain's oldest universities, with main campus buildings on the Strand in London and at Waterloo, takes a mixture of students, a traditional cohort of middle-class applicants from around the country, an inner city group, and a significant number of foreign students. King's finds even middle-class students more likely to be home based.

Claas says: 'The key to clearing is for students to forget the myths that exist about universities and courses. What is popular in the eyes of applicants is not necessarily popular in the eyes of employers. They remain interested in the quality of students, and the best way to show quality is to do well at something that interests you.'

Mark Drayling of the NUS is concerned that the changes caused by student loans and fees will further widen the difference between middle- and working-class graduates. He believes that the increase in the number of university places is in danger of stratifying the difference, with traditional universities taking the majority of their students at between the ages of 18 and 25 and seeing them through to a degree at the end of three or four years.

Within that structure the degrees may have become modular, and some universities may have shifted to a two- semester rather than a three-term year, but the socio-economic profile of students taking degrees immediately after leaving secondary school remains predominantly middle-class.

'I used to think that students going away to university was a good thing,' he said. 'Now I am not sure. I am getting sick of university being a finishing school for the middle classes. The socio-economic profile of the universities has not changed.'

At John Moores University in Liverpool, where much of the Ucas and the HEFCE research into university applications and drop-out rates has been carried out, Professor Mantz Yorke, professor of higher education, believes that this autumn there will be a first opportunity to study accurately the effects of loans and fees.

Like the NUS, Yorke fears stratification between traditional and newer universities and also sees the drop-out rate as disproportionately affecting the newer universities, partly because many of their mature or working students may well opt - usually for family reasons - to take modular degrees in bits and pieces.

He says research is needed on trends in higher education. No research has yet looked at the effect of fees, which he thinks will be significant.

Past surveys have shown money to be a first cause of drop out, unhappiness with the course a close second and social life third. 'There is an interest to know what is happening with student fees and loans,' he said. Government policies to widen access would risk being flawed without an accurately researched understanding of what was happening already.

fields.headline: There is life after children
fields.standfirst: What to do and how to cope when kids fly the nest
fields.trailText: What to do and how to cope when kids fly the nest
fields.body:
Line dancing, lovers or late parenthood are just some of the options chosen by people still reeling from the trauma of seeing their children leave home for university. The Americans call it 'empty nest syndrome', but the range of feelings a parent feels when their loved one leaves home is no medical condition.

'It's quite natural to feel sad when your children leave home,' says Cheryl Walters, head of policy and research at Parentline Plus, the family support organisation. 'And it's OK for it to be difficult. If you didn't care about them, their leaving wouldn't matter. If someone becomes seriously depressed, of course, that is a medical condition, but I would suggest that person would be predisposed to depression.'

US parents Van and Shirley Hughes of Arizona felt the lack of their two sons so deeply that they decided to become foster parents and ended up adopting 10 brothers and sisters. 'Everybody thinks we are crazy, but the pros outweigh the cons,' Shirley says.

Although Walters would not necessarily advocate rushing off and having more children, she agrees that some women simply cannot face losing their role of mother. Forty five-year-old 'Sarah', who found herself in this position, says: 'My whole life has revolved around my kids and when they were ready to move out of the house I had a hard time dealing with it. It was like all of a sudden I felt so alone and didn't feel needed anymore. Well that didn't last long. I ended up getting pregnant again and had another baby at 40.

'At the time I thought I was mad for wanting to do it, but after five years now it's been one of the best things that ever happened to me. I cherish her more every day and feel like I have a purpose in life again.'

But it is obviously not possible to keep on having babies for ever. Walters says: 'While it is very difficult telling people what they should do, one thing I would say is that it is very important not to live your life entirely through your children. You need to have interests that can be expanded to fill the space left when they leave.'

Paradoxically, though, Walters does not believe that stay-at-home mothers necessarily have a harder time adjusting to their children leaving home. 'A mother who doesn't work may feel more aware of the loss faster, but it could also be argued that a working mother will have a job to hold down while at the same time having to deal with some difficult feelings. It is all about adjustment, and how easily you do this will depend more on the type of person you are than on whether you work. Not everyone will experience problems.'

Indeed, for some parents their children leaving home can be nothing short of liberating. 'Rachel', who had stayed at home while her children were growing up says: 'I served my role as chauffeur, nurse, teacher, referee, you name it. I have never regretted one day of it. But it was inevitable that one day my children would grow up, and if I did my job the way I was supposed to, they would become responsible adults and leave home.

'I have to admit that the anticipation I used to feel when I thought about them leaving home was far worse than the reality. I have kept myself busy with a fun job, with college courses and doing things I always wanted to do but didn't because I didn't want to feel guilty for taking time away from my kids.'

But empty nest syndrome is not just an issue for mothers; fathers suffer too. Playwright Jack Rosenthal became so depressed when his own children left home for university that he sought the help of a counsellor. What he describes as his 'agony of loss' inspired two television plays, Eskimo Days and Cold Enough for Snow. He found parting with each of his three children extremely traumatic. In Cold Enough for Snow, one of the two fathers in the play has a nervous breakdown but finds salvation when his wife (played by Rosenthal's real-life wife Maureen Lipman) persuades him to go back to the local college in Blackburn, where he does a night school course in sports science. But what of the children in all this. It is an exciting but often frightening time of transition for them.Watching their parents going through agonies at the prospect of them leaving is unlikely to be very helpful. 'You never really get rid of your children: a sign of a healthy relationship is where the child can go off without feeling guilty,' says Walters. 'It is very important that you don't put these negative feelings on to the child. A child needs to feel confident that they can go off and be OK and that you'll be OK and that if they have any problems they can come back to you.'

And come back they probably will. Students are likely to be at home for about 20 weeks of the year. And once you have started to adjust to the fact that they have left, you then have to readjust to them coming back. Lucy Selleck, a Relate counsellor and mother of undergraduates, says that can prove just as difficult, not just on the parent-child relationship but also the relationship between the parents. 'Maybe as a couple you start to come closer again. You adjust to your nice new life - going out, supper parties - then back the kids come in the holidays or at weekends. It can be difficult: everyone wants to be nice to each other but it may be hard.

'People often feel they are alone in dreading these returns home, but the adjustments don't end with the child going away and you recovering from the trauma. When your children come back they often regress. They come back to mummy and daddy very ambivalent. Half of them wants to be looked after, and the other half feels overmothered and overparented.'

But if you recognise this situation, do not despair. Selleck says that parents as well as children grow up during this period, and both start to recognise each other's space - no more rows over the use of the kitchen. 'It is good if you all recognise boundaries. Children can't treat their homes like a student house, and you must remember that the family house is also still their home. Also, as parents, it is most important to remember that you are a team - kids are very good at splitting you.'

This is one of the reasons why this time of adjustment can also put a strain on a marriage. Relate sees many couples for whom the empty nest has played a part in bringing problems to a head. 'If a relationship has not got good basic foundations, it can be sorely tested. Couples may look at each other and wonder what's still there,' says Selleck. But children leaving home, whether to go to university, to get married, or just to lead an independent life is also just a part of the natural order of things - one of those rites of passage where parents must learn to let go.

Selleck's advice to parents is reassuring:
1. Be aware that your child leaving home for college is a transition period. Year one can be difficult and it can take time for all of you to adjust. Don't panic.
2. Don't rush into things yourself. It is very tempting to fill up every minute of your day. You need time to think as an individual and as a couple. Don't do anything drastic.
3. Take the time to work on your relationship as a couple. Don't give up on it.

fields.headline: Material boy
fields.standfirst: Madonna's boyfriend, father of her second child, director of Lock, Stock, and a new film due out soon... it's going to be a very hot summer for this 'mockney' lad
fields.trailText: Madonna's boyfriend, father of her second child, director of Lock, Stock, and a new film due out soon... it's going to be a very hot summer for this 'mockney' lad
fields.body:
Madonna really doesn't go for the boy-next-door type. Anyone who remembers her encounter with Kevin Costner in the documentary In Bed with Madonna knows this.

Costner's first mistake that evening was wearing a blouson, a satin baseball jacket, for his audience in her dressing room, but he then compounded the error by choosing to describe Madonna's stage show as 'neat'. Such preppy language went down very badly indeed.

It is a fair guess then that Guy Ritchie did not become consort to one of the most famous women on the planet by adopting a friendly, New Man approach. Being cool is important to Madonna and Ritchie's carefully-maintained 'diamond hard' persona fits the brief.

This weekend Ritchie, 31, is celebrating the first of two important life events slated for late summer 2000. He has a new baby boy; a first child for him and born to Madonna on Friday night. The couple have decided to call the him Rocco, a name which has the requisite Italian associations but certainly also resonates with Ritchie's strong interest in organised crime. Considering there was speculation that the film director might plump for the names of Ronnie or Reggie, Rocco perhaps represents a compromise.

And in 10 days' time Ritchie faces the second big diary date of the year. His new feature film, Snatch, is premiered on 23 August amid much hype. Three years ago his first full length feature, Lock, Stock, and Two Smoking Barrels, was hailed as a modern British classic. A lively and flash tale set in London's gangland, it resulted in a copycat outbreak of criminal proportions.

The success of his first movie in America has put Ritchie in the same boat as Sam Mendes, the other one-film-wonder-boy of British cinema, although the career paths of the two could not be further apart. While Mendes went to Cambridge and then made his name in the theatre, Ritchie had no academic success and is known to dislike the 'stagey' style of theatre actors.

Snatch is another gangland story, but this time it is largely set in Hatton Garden and stars a very big name. Brad Pitt. The Hollywood star is rumoured to have cut his normal fee by 90 percent to take the part of a gypsy boxer who, incidentally, is almost entirely incoherent throughout.

The film, naturally, had a much bigger budget than Lock, Stock and so this time Ritchie did not come up against the same obstacles. Back then, as the film was starting to win critical praise, Ritchie was angry.

'We made our film without a distributor,' he said, 'and in Britain that is a big problem. The distributors here are the wrong people to be deciding what should get a theatrical release. We kept getting these fantastic results from audiences off the street, but when we showed the film to 10 British distributors, we didn't get a laugh or a snigger from any of them.'

He and his producer, the even younger Matthew Vaughn, were considering recasting the whole story, when a new set of investors stepped in and Polygram took up the cause. The success of the £1 million film saw the birth of 'geezer chic', with the footballer-turned-actor, Vinnie Jones, in the unlikely role of mid-wife. It made £50m at the world box office and £11m in Britain.

Nowadays, because of his relationship with the woman he calls Madge, Ritchie is encased in the glass box of ultra celebrity. But he still gets angry.

He is irritated, for a start, by the way the press have attacked him for having an affluent background and a cockney, or 'mockney', accent. Too many jokes about his 'manor' having a gravel drive and a swimming pool have made him cross. 'I never said I lived in the East End for 30 years,' he complains.

He is tall, with dark brown eyes set quite far apart, and has something of the reluctant gay icon about him - from the gold sovereign ring on his finger, to his tousled blond hair.

There is an old Stanley Knife scar down one cheek too, that is testament to a violent streak. A year ago he fought Madonna's ex-boyfriend, Andy Bird, in the exclusive Met Bar, and reputedly floored Nick Moran, the star of Lock, Stock, in another fight. This spring he was held briefly by the police after beating up one of the male fans who waits outside Madonna's London home.

In fact, their relationship appears to be predicated on his being a man's man. He makes her do the shopping and he won't let her drive in this country because she is used to driving on the other side of the road.

The family lived in Fulham, west London, where Ritchie's sister, Tabitha, now runs a dance centre. Their parents divorced when he was five.

During this time he admits he hung out with villains, but says he did not become one. 'If you haven't lived, you're nicking ideas from other people's films,' he explains.

After a moment of epiphany on his 25th birthday Ritchie went into film, first becoming a runner and then making music videos. His first short film, The Hard Case, was a rough draft of the Lock, Stock story and Ritchie's real break did not come until he showed the longer screenplay to Vaughn, the 27-year-old estranged son of the actor Robert Vaughn,

Then, of course, came the big meeting with the woman he was soon to dub a 'top bird'. Sting's wife, Trudie Styler, introduced him to Madonna at a party and the singer was enchanted by the cheeky hopeful who was 10 years her junior. She offered to bring out the soundtrack of Lock, Stock in the States.

In the current issue of the listings magazine Time Out , which Ritchie guest edits, he sets out a fresh role for himself as a champion of the outsider. He loves gypsies, he writes, because they are so 'visceral'.

webTitle: Gay kiss on TV shows hidden power of disgust threshold

fields.headline: Gay kiss on TV shows hidden power of disgust threshold
fields.trailText: The sight of two lovers kissing in the street has always warmed the heart. After all, love makes the world go round, doesn't it?
fields.body:
The sight of two lovers kissing in the street has always warmed the heart. After all, love makes the world go round, doesn't it?

But how acceptable is this romantic image when the two lovers are men?

Despite political correctness - and the fact that soap operas have included scenes of gay petting - the thought of gay contact is still deeply disturbing for many people.

A Channel 4 documentary series starting this week demonstrates how strongly some people react when suddenly confronted with a homosexual clinch.

The directors of An Anatomy of Disgust took two male actors to Camberwell, south London, and filmed the results to demonstrate their point about prejudice. 'The response was amazing,' said series director Gary Johnstone. 'We had such extreme reactions. And everyone who was upset seemed to use the word "disgust".'

The staged passionate embrace forms part of the second programme in a three-part series and is due to be shown next Tuesday. The experiment was designed to illustrate the way the apparently instinctive reaction of disgust can be harnessed and used to maintain social taboos.

'People who think of themselves as caring and gentle are very quickly able to talk with some aggression when they feel that something is genuinely disgusting,' said Johnstone. 'One middle-aged man admitted that he would like to break the legs of the male couple if he could.'

The programme-makers make the case that disgust is as powerful a human emotion as fear and has often been used to further political ends.

'The whole programme is saying that, while humans are generally quite moral beings who tend to hate discrimination and unfairness, we do find it much easier to put those concerns aside when the question of disgust comes up,' explains Jonah Weston, director of the second programme.

The first programme, to be screened on Tuesday, tackles the latest scientific research into the biological mechanics of disgust, while the final programme will look at the way shocking modern works of art - such as Tracy Emin's dirty, unmade bed, Sarah Lucas's kebabs, and Damien Hirst's cow organs - may provide an escape valve for this potentially lethal side of human nature.

The second programme draws a comparison between the way the Nazi regime in Germany played on anti-Semitic folklore and the way the image of the cockroach was employed to incite murderous racist attacks in Rwanda.

webTitle: Euro 'will be world currency for cars'

fields.headline: Euro 'will be world currency for cars'
fields.standfirst:
An expert warns that the pain from the high pound will not let up, so manufacturers should put up and shut up. Joanna Walters reports


Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: UK carmakers and components suppliers were warned this weekend by a leading industry expert that they must learn to live with the high pound.
fields.body:
UK carmakers and components suppliers were warned this weekend by a leading industry expert that they must learn to live with the high pound.

But the Government was given notice by the expert, academic Nick Matthews, that the euro will eventually become the global currency of the motor industry, and that manufacturers will continue to suffer real financial pain as long as Britain fails to commit itself to the single currency.

The warnings came after Toyota, which builds cars in Derbyshire and engines in north Wales, last week put further pressure on the Government to join the euro by demanding that suppliers of components sign all contracts for future new business in euros.

This was the latest call in a catalogue of protests this summer from virtually all the companies building cars in the UK: the high value of the pound against the euro is, they insist, threatening existing factories as well as future investment in Britain.

Toyota's announcement followed a meeting between Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn and Tony Blair at the end of last month at which the Prime Minister was warned that the Nissan plant in Sunderland did not have a future if currency imbalances meant it was not awarded the contract later this year to build the next Micra model.

The Government has so far steadfastly refused to bend to the manufacturers' appeals either to join the euro or to commit itself unequivocally to joining, in order to encourage the pound and the euro to move closer in value.

Matthews, senior fellow at Warwick University's international manufacturing group, said that rather than relying on the Government, carmakers and suppliers would have to 'get used' to the industry costing in euros and adapt to the environment in order to survive.

'The aerospace industry costs in US dollars the world over, whether trading parts or whole aircraft, because the planemakers work in dollars and because North America is the leading marketplace,' he said.

'What is happening with the motor industry is that Europe is the world's single biggest car market, and the euro is becoming the currency of the auto business.'

European motorists buy around 16 million cars a year, ahead of North America with 12 million and the Far East with 10 million.

Matthews said: 'It does not matter whether you currently operate with pounds, yen or dollars: the future for the industry is the euro. Everyone outside the eurozone, including the UK and places like Norway, Poland and the Czech Republic over time will be forced to cost components in euros as the norm.'

Smaller UK component suppliers have most to lose from the large manufacturers demanding to pay in euros, as they are least flexible and all their staff and materials costs are in sterling.

The motor industry is consolidating, with an increasing number of tie-ups between US, European and Asian manufacturers. International barriers are being broken down and companies are increasingly buying parts wherever in Europe they can get the best price, rather than remaining loyal to local suppliers.

The carmakers will benefit from buying in the eurozone, or paying UK suppliers in euros. But British car factories are still at a disadvantage in terms of selling their cars in the UK in competition with cheaper imports, as well as trying to make profits when exporting into the eurozone.

British car factories are less cost-effective than many of their continental counterparts because their tooling and equipment are outdated, often because of under-investment. Nissan's Sunderland plant - now more than 10 years old - is heading the same way. This means the plants cannot produce the huge variety of models that firms want to make from a single, expensive platform.

This problem contributed to Rover's near-collapse, and to Ford's decision to stop making cars at Dagenham.

This exacerbates the problem of Britain becoming a less attractive place for foreign-owned carmakers to invest.

Meanwhile, Mark Schennum, vice-president at Gemini Consulting, said the UK government seemed to be 'letting the market' bring the value of sterling nearer to the euro. 'If your suppliers bill in euros, it puts downward pressure on the pound anyway,' he said.

It would be 'political suicide' for the Government to join the euro now, because public opinion was firmly against it.

Schennum said UK carmakers were 'undoubtedly hurting', but the Government needed to consider seriously whether the manufacturers could adjust successfully to the currency situation.

He felt that their protests were part of a backlash against the Government's ruling that the price of new cars in Britain must be slashed.

He added: 'Britain is still getting more than its fair share of inward investment from around the world compared with the rest of Europe.'

webTitle: Loretta Young, virtuous queen of the screen, dies

fields.headline: Loretta Young, virtuous queen of the screen, dies
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The quintessential American beauty, Loretta Young, whose acting career extended from silent cinema to Hollywood's golden era of the Forties, died yesterday in Los Angeles. Young, 87, had battled against ovarian cancer for several months - and recently returned home after surgery.
fields.body:
The quintessential American beauty, Loretta Young, whose acting career extended from silent cinema to Hollywood's golden era of the Forties, died yesterday in Los Angeles. Young, 87, had battled against ovarian cancer for several months - and recently returned home after surgery.

During her Hollywood heyday, Young shared the silver screen with most of the era's leading men - Lon Chaney, Clark Gable, James Cagney, Spencer Tracy, Cary Grant, Tyrone Power, David Niven, Robert Mitchum and William Holden. With her blue-grey eyes and sculpted cheekbones, she rose from child star, to ingenue, to one of Hollywood's leading ladies.

Born Gretchen Michaela Young in 1913 in Salt Lake City, Young spent most of her childhood in a convent school. Her father was a railway auditor who left the family; mother and three children resettled in Los Angeles. Young had her first screen role at the age of four, in The Only Way as a weeping child on an operating table.

It was on her return from schooling, in 1928's The Magnificent Flirt, that Young first began to play righteous women of moral strength. Between 1929 and 1930, she appeared in 15 films - including Broken Dishes, with western star and hellraiser Grant Withers. They eloped and lived together for eight months before she filed for divorce in 1931. Young never mentioned it in her 1961 autobiography, The Things I Had To Learn.

When she signed to Fox Studios in the mid-Thirties, Young became one of the era's leading ladies. In 1947, she starred in The Farmer's Daughter - a tale of a farm girl who becomes a Congresswoman. The role was her career highlight, for which she was awarded a Best Actress Academy Award. That same year, she featured alongside David Niven and Cary Grant in The Bishop's Wife - a cornerstone of US Christmas television schedules.

Outwardly the face of American virtue, Young's personal life was less shiny. In a 1994 autobiography, Uncommon Knowledge, Judy, a daughter adopted in the mid-Thirties, claimed she was the result of an affair between Loretta Young and Clark Gable. This was denied. In 1995, the elderly actress told the New York Times it was a 'rumour of a bygone time'. Young married a third time in 1993, at 80 - to fashion designer Jean Louis. 'We've known each other for so long. And when something is right, it just slips into place,' she said.

Young made a triumphant switch to television in 1953, with Letters To Loretta - later The Loretta Young Show . The variety show was perfect for her wholesome, family-orientated style - with Young reading a poem or Bible passage at the end. It earned her three Emmy Awards in eight years.

Yesterday Norman Brokaw, her agent of 50 years, said: 'She was an incredible lady. I learnt from her that if you can handle yourself with class and dignity, you can work as long as you want in this business.'

 Loretta Young is survived by a sister, a daughter and two sons.

fields.headline: Go tell it to the Marines... right?
fields.standfirst: Rules of Engagement is a simplistic, far-fetched gung-ho American war movie. So nothing new there then
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...it's arguably right-wing and unarguably pretty bad...
fields.body:
Forty years ago Kenneth Tynan conducted a lengthy interview for The Observer with Jean-Paul Sartre, during which he asked if right-wing art was possible. Unfortunately, instead of saying la droite (the political Right), he said le droit (the law). Before he could correct himself, Sartre had taken off on an unstoppable spiel, beginning with the assertion that 'the law is theatre' and going on to show that 'the characters of Sophocles, of Euripides, even of Aeschylus - they are all lawyers' and that 'the stage is the courtroom'.

When Tynan returned to the matter in hand, asking Sartre if 'an author of extreme right-wing views could ever succeed in creating a work of art', he received a plain answer 'in my opinion, no'. According to Sartre, as the Right no longer understood how the world functions 'one can't imagine a modern play that could be at the same time right-wing and good'.

I thought of this exchange while watching William Friedkin's Rules of Engagement because as a courtroom drama it fulfils in the most literal way Sartre's definition of what constitutes theatre and also because it's arguably right-wing and unarguably pretty bad, though not without entertaining moments, mostly connected with the central performances.

There have always been two streams of Hollywood movies about the armed forces - those made with the assistance of the army, navy or air force, which have constituted the majority, and those which have not sought, or have been denied, official assistance.

The presidential candidate avoided serving in Vietnam and his vice-presidential running mate had 'more pressing business' than doing his national service. webTitle: Nick Cohen: Perils of going private

fields.headline: Perils of going private
fields.standfirst: Corruption and greed: welcome to the world of private healthcare
fields.trailText: The rich may do it, but go outside the NHS for healthcare and you enter a world of corruption and greed, argues Nick Cohen.
fields.body:
In an address given to an aptly awful audience of venture capitalists a few months ago, Tony Blair adopted the modish confessional style and told the world that his struggle to manage the public sector had left 'scars on my back'. The National Health Service was not a home for the many under-resourced and over-worked people who run the most efficient medical service in the developed world, but a swamp of vested interests. Nurses, doctors and cleaners were the élite forces of conservatism. The Prime Minister was their proletarian victim. Only the unreliable protection of an enormous Parliamentary majority and a Cabinet which will let him do anything he wants, prevented a martyrdom to rival Saint Di's.

After his performance, no one had the right to be surprised when he announced that henceforth the NHS would buy operations from private hospitals. A 'concordat' had been reached with corporate medicine. 'I have always made clear that it is not a question of ideology,' he said in July when asked if further treaties were likely.

Admittedly, this particular policy without ideology was the wheeze of New Labour's most influential think tank - the Conservative Party, which once was considered to be an ideologically motivated organisation. But all Third Wayers of good will and sound judgment could be relied upon to forget intellectual origins in this instance and agree that it is nothing more than plain common sense to cut waiting lists by snapping up private services. Who wouldn't prefer to be treated on demand by suddenly deferential consultants in a room of one's own, luxuriously appointed with pot plants the size of triffids, soft carpets and cable television? How many Observer readers have forgotten their loud defences of the NHS when worrying pains afflict them or their loved ones and gone private? What matters is what works. Only a weirdo and probable paedophile would sacrifice the health of a child on the alter of an exhausted ideology. The private sector delivers.

It can deliver your child at the Portland Hospital, where Sarah Ferguson, Patsy Kensit, and Posh Spice were relieved of various sprogs. Those with other requirements can be sent to the Harley Street, Princess Grace or Wellington hospitals in central London. All four were brought by a company called HCA on 19 May. The US health conglomerate, which used to be called Columbia/HCA, but was forced to dance the old Windscale-Sellafield name shuffle for reasons we'll get to in a moment, added the Devonshire, Lister and London Bridge hospitals to its portfolio in June. The company intends to nab 'new facilities in markets outside the London area' as soon as possible.

Commercial rivals at the London Heart Hospital are so worried by the Americans' predatory intent they are trying to excite a media campaign to persuade the Department of Trade and Industry to stop HCA creating a private monopoly in London. Sir Richard Needham, a former Conservative Health Minister who now runs the Heart, complained to me at length that HCA's associates, the PPP insurance company, had insisted their patients - sorry, customers - should be diverted from his beds to the rooms of HCA hospitals. Needham's colleagues say the loss of income may force him to sell to the Americans.

You may not care about Needham's problems - I won't pretend to have been sobbing myself - when HCA seems the better product. The company's PRs boast it is 'one of London's leading healthcare providers... committed to excellence and quality through the provision of specialised healthcare services. We have established an international reputation for offering the highest quality of service in private healthcare'.

They forgot to add that HCA's international reputation is somewhat tarnished. On 19 May it agreed to pay $745 million (£500m) to the US Justice Department for the greatest fraud in American medical history, without admitting liability, after two executives had been jailed. When other alleged scams are resolved the final fine will be about a billion dollars.

By purchasing private beds for public patients, New Labour is imitating American health care. The US government uses the Medicare and Medicaid national insurance schemes to pay 'independent' hospitals to treat working-class and elderly Americans. (The poor are left to suffer and die without health cover.) Charitable institutions with a rudimentary grasp of medical ethics are being taken over by medical conglomerates which seek to maximise profits. The US authorities cannot have officials on the spot to check that treatment is necessary and bills are accurate - if they did, they might as well go for the full Soviet terror of a 'socialistic' national health service administered by the state.

The result of a freeish market is pervasive fraud. June Gibbs Brown, Inspector General of the US Department of Health, estimated that private hospitals were overpaid by $23 billion (£15bn) a year. Fourteen cents in every dollar spent on health were stolen from the government by accident or design. Tales of scams fill the US press. There were the psychiatric hospitals which refused to release cash-earning patients even when they had recovered their wits; the psychologists who billed for 24 hours of therapy a day; and the health-company owners who claimed their son's first BMW was a medical expense.

The FBI investigation into HCA showed corruption went beyond the odd rotten apple. 'Columbia's fraudulent cost-reporting practices have infected the cost reports of virtually every health care facility,' the US government said in its affidavit.

As in Britain, HCA had engaged in the vigorous buying of beds and built a network of 340 hospitals. It was then able to add new euphemisms to the dictionary of fraud. Its executives tried 'upcoding': the exaggeration of the seriousness of an illness to receive higher fees; 'gaming': the double billing of the state; and 'physician partnerships': the practice of offering doctors shares, subsidised offices and directorships in return to steering patients to HCA hospitals.

Mark Gardner, who worked in three Columbia hospitals, testified: 'I committed felonies every day. Let me tell you this a ruthless greedy company. Employees are the largest operating expense. Cut that to the bone. Cut nursing to the bone.' The instructions were obeyed to the letter. One nurse told how she was left to watch 80 heart monitors by herself. John W. Schilling, another whistleblower, said the company was confident it could avoid detection. Advertising and marketing costs were passed off as medical necessities and when the danger of a government auditor getting too close to the truth grew, he was told to buy her off with a job offer.

Their testimony sounds strange to British ears. Yet Action for Proper Regulation of Private Hospitals (whose website at www.homeusers.prestel.co.uk I urge you to read before paying for treatment) suggests that many American vices are here in embryo.

Private hospitals are dangerous places. They don't have the emergency teams of the NHS and their lovely single rooms are not the safest places to be when you need to attract attention urgently. For all the pampering on offer at HCA's Portland Hospital, the death rate of pregnant women is five times above the national average, as we reported last week.

Their parasitic nature is well known - they rely on the NHS to train their staff and to take their patients when an operation goes wrong or an insurance company refuses to pay for complicated treatment - but their imitation of US practices deserves a wider audience. The British Medical Journal claimed in 1993 that at least one-third of all private 'hysterectomies... are unnecessary', while the growth in the number of 'therapeutically useless' removals of tonsils was an 'epidemic'.

The NHS, by contrast, has no interest in overcharging or performing pointless operations, quite the reverse. The largest employer in Europe is remarkably free of fiddles in all areas except one: consultants skipping NHS commitments to work in the private sector. There is a perverse incentive: unscrupulous consultants benefit if they persuade patients to pay to see them privately. Invariably, the consultants with the longest waiting lists are those with the largest private practices.

Instead of buying out consultants and giving them the generous salaries they deserve - for these are skilled men and women - to work exclusively for the NHS, the Government is making the perverse incentive more attractive still by pumping public funds to the likes of HCA. It claims that it will ensure that health authorities get value for money. If you were to point out that the US Government which has decades of experience of auditing private hospitals still cannot prevent fraud which would dazzle a mafioso, you would be dismissed as an ideological dinosaur. HCA has the advertising slogan 'You've Never Seen Health Care Like This Before'. Indeed you have not. But soon you may.

fields.headline: Will City be feeling blue?
fields.standfirst: Ian Whittell hears how Joe Royle intends to keep his side up
fields.trailText: Ian Whittell hears how Joe Royle intends to keep his side up.
fields.body:
The competition between Manchester football managers Sir Alex Ferguson and Joe Royle begins in earnest on Wednesday when the first derby match in half a decade sees the teams meet in front of 67,000 in a testimonial game for United's veteran full-back Denis Irwin.

A meaningless pre-season run out this is not. Not when the blue half of the city is still struggling to shrug off a collective inferiority complex borne out of nearly two decades of failure.

The fact that City supporters can even look forward to competing in the same division as their rivals is a testimony to Royle's achievements in lifting a moribund club to two successive promotions, a feat that arguably ranks with anything Ferguson has achieved across the city.

The rivalry between Ferguson and Royle, firm friends off the field, has even extended to their respective pension plans. The United manager has announced he will retire in 2002, two years ahead of the expiry date on the new contract Royle was handed this summer for ending City's four-year Premiership exile.

The question is, after working his miracle on Moss Side over the past two seasons, just how much further does Royle see himself taking the club before he retires?

'Europe,' says Royle succinctly as he somehow finds time for an interview in between training and completing the £3 million signing of Newcastle defender Steve Howey, who joins fellow interna tionals Alfie Haaland, George Weah and Paulo Wanchope as City's close season arrivals. 'We're going into the new Commonwealth Games stadium in three years and it is a long time since this club has been stable. My chairman David Bernstein and his board hardly need a pat on the back from me for their work on the financial side.

'But we are spending sensibly and we have acquired four proven Premiership players for £9m, some of that offset by outgoings.

'The club is going into the Premiership on a good basis and quite honestly, in four years I think this club has got to be pushing for major honours. We are too big to go up and struggle.'

Royle is hardly one of the breed of managers who actively seeks self-promotion, his record at City, after all, speaks far louder than any of his more vocal managerial rivals ever could. That is part of the reason he is anxious not to attract the sort of unofficial countdown-to-retirement that has become an increasing occupation at Old Trafford.

'The pensionable age for managers is 55 so for Alex to go at 60, you can only admire him and say he must thrive on it,' says Royle, 51.'However, I don't particularly relish the thought of another 10 years in management.

'But as the chairman says, with a smile, "In four years time when we're going into Europe, there's no way you'll leave." In the short time I've known him, I've come to realise the chairman usually gets his way.'

Such a decision would sit well with the City fans who will never forget what Royle, and Bernstein, have done for the club. It is a short journey from Macclesfield to Manchester United but, in football terms, an indescribable chasm separates the two clubs. To put Royle's achievements in perspective, 18 months ago it was Macclesfield, not United, who offered City their derby opposition.

'I think the Premiership has become quite elitist,' adds Royle who left Everton in March 1997. 'There are only four or five teams at present that can win the title.

'There are maybe four or five more who can win a cup and won't struggle. Then there are 10 all fighting to be 10th from top, or at least out of the bottom three. The Premiership has developed into three divisions.

'I'm not going to burden us with predictions but I don't see us as a struggling side. Realistically, we are targeting the second group rather than the third and that is what I have said to the players.

'We're not trying to kid or con anybody that we are going to go straight to the top of this division... but then again, it wouldn't surprise me!

'We've been in the surprise business for two years now and we have players still here that were part of the side that was branded the worst side in the club's history when we went down two years ago. That has been a great source of motivation to us.'

'There are maybe four or five more who can win a cup and won't struggle. Then there are 10 all fighting to be 10th from top, or at least out of the bottom three. The Premiership has developed into three divisions. 'I'm not going to burden us with predictions but I don't see us as a struggling side. Realistically, we are targeting the second group rather than the third and that is what I have said to the players. 'We're not trying to kid or con anybody that we are going to go straight to the top of this division... but then again, it wouldn't surprise me! 'We've been in the surprise business for two years now and we have players still here that were part of the side that was branded the worst side in the club's history when we went down two years ago. That has been a great source of motivation to us.'

webTitle: Lethargic Blues out of the blocks slowly

fields.headline: Lethargic Blues out of the blocks slowly
fields.trailText: Typical. Summer finally arrives on the first day of the football season, and the reward for forsaking the beach is the most boring of stalemates.
fields.body:
Typical. Summer finally arrives on the first day of the football season, and the reward for forsaking the beach is the most boring of stalemates.

In the circumstances, perhaps it is unfair to berate these two sides for a lacklustre opener, since it could not have been easy playing the first competitive match for a couple of months in such burning sun. Those of us broiling in the shadow of the stands were uncomfortable enough, but when the game stopped for an injury in the 38th minute and every player on the pitch raced to the touchline for drink, it became clear conditions were difficult for football.

That doesn't really excuse Peter Ndlovu's wastefulness in front of goal, Chris Kiwomya's scuffed chance on the half-hour or any other of the factors contributing to a goalless afternoon. But both sides were reasonably happy with a point and both know they will play better as the season progresses.

Birmingham had better hope so, anyway. Expectations are fairly low at Loftus Road these days after the rel egation scares of a couple of years ago, but Trevor Francis's side are supposed to be going places. On this evidence they are not in much of a hurry. Geoff Horsfield put himself about a bit and certainly let the referee know he was around, picking up a caution for a foul on Steve Morrow, but City's record £2.25million signing from Fulham needs time to settle.

There were a couple of suggestions of a potentially profitable relationship with Stan Lazaridis, but not much to indicate any kind of understanding with his strike partner, Ndlovu. The former Coventry player is still delightfully nimble and unpredictable, but he has lost some of his sharpness.

On two occasions in the first half his wastefulness bordered on the selfish. Horsfield, unmarked in the middle the second time, let Ndlovu know in no uncertain terms that a pass would have been a far better option.

The visitors always looked the more likely to score, but their best opportunities in the first half fell to midfielder Martin Grainger, who was twice foiled by good saves from Lee Harper.

With Rangers debutant Clarke Carlisle impressive in the home defence, the closest the game came to a goal was five minutes after the interval, when Ndlovu thought he had scored from Grainger's corner only for Gavin Peacock to head out from under his own bar.

Rangers almost found a goalscorer in the unlikely form of debutant Peter Crouch. Unlikely because the matchstick physique of Gerry Francis's summer capture from Spurs makes him look even taller than his stated 6ft 6in.

Unfortunately, although he won more aerial battles in the second half than the first, heading does not appear to be his strong suit. Crouch was on his own in front of goal when Peacock crossed from the right after an hour, but he could only head weakly over Ian Bennet's bar.

But Gerry Francis was pleased enough with his QPR side's performance. 'Considering we still have a few out, I was pleased with the performance against a team who are many people's favourites this season,' he said.

His squad are also to be strengthened by the arrival of Birmingham's Paul Furlong in a three-month loan deal which was confirmed yesterday.
